text: Bottle from Consumers Beverage. This ones reputation precedes it. Excellent throughout. Near black pour with tight, creamy beige head, leaves rings of lacing all the way down. Aroma is chocolate, roast malts, coffee. Taste is sweet, chocolate, burnt toast. Feel is creamy and slick. Sweet bitterness lingers. Perfect porter, benchmark for the style.
Dark brown appearance. Aroma is malty with chocolate. Taste is cola with chocolate. More of a bitter finish.

Was finally able to snag a bottle of this while on a recent trip up North, brought it home to SC and currently enjoying this outside on a beautiful cool spring afternoon. This exceptional rendition of a classic American porter pours a dark brown-black color with translucent highlights of ruby-brown, and has a bright off-white khaki head. Lots of foam and bubbles at the top but not as much lacing from this bottle. Regardless, this brew releases a fresh roasty chocolate malt aroma with notes of wood smoke and mocha. Flavor features a dark slightly smokey cocoa and coffee bean maltiness along with a mild but recognizable northwest hoppy bitterness, and finishes with a bittersweet dark chocolate taste. A hint of vanilla was also present. The hoppiness is clean and herbal, which distinguishes this from the more earthy hops of this brews London porter cousins. This beer has a surprisingly light-medium body given the complexity of the flavor, distinctly smooth and refreshing on the palate for a porter. A great example of balanced drinkability with complexity, light enough to drink casually but sophisticated enough to sip and savor. I would love to find this one again, would be a go-to porter for me if only there was the availability down south.

DATE: April 27, 2017... OCCASION: uncapping an Ohio classic--how havent I had this already?!--as I expect the Browns to finally find a classic of their own (Myles Garrett?)... GLASSWARE: Stoudts autographed pint...pours a nice, dark body that floats a thick brown head, fluffy and effervescent enough... brilliant, thick chocolate, coffee bean, roasted toffee, slight caramel, suppressed hoppiness--slight citrus, yes... boldly announces itself at just 5.8% ABV... instantaneous warmth, with a thick creaminess that acts as a dessert unto itself... peat and chocolate linger at the finish, while teeth buzz with hoppy presence.... medium-bodied, tremendously drinkable... avoids the cola cliche of lesser porters, with the sweet, peaty finish that evokes a scotch ale...caramel, coffee, oak, and soft vanilla--a lot packed into this one... versatile, powerful, rewarding--like Myles Garrett?--and another victory for one of the best things going for Cleveland... what a great everyday porter, as the style was no doubt intended to be...
Pours a very dark color. Dont care for the taste - Very bitter with an unpleasant aftertaste that lingers. Absolutely wont be drinking again.

The porter to compare all other American porters to, EF is superbly roast with deep coffee and blackstrap molassses tones. Super drinkable but hearty. Pours dark brown and leaves long legs of tan lacing. Robust yet pairable with any pub grub. True to Its English roots.

12oz Bottle. Black color with a tan head. Roasted malt chocolate aroma. Roasted malt dark chocolate vanilla flavour. Medium light body. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

most memorable factor being the sexy branding but also the chalky milk cocoa character. feels good on the taste buds lol. didnt seem quite as complex as people are telling it, but great none the less.
Bottle given to me by a friend into a snifter. Aroma of cocoa and coffee malts.

12floz bottle with a BBD of 07.24.2017. Paid $10 as a single in a mix-six, six-packs go for about the same in the Metro-East area of St. Louis. Ive had this before, and it still holds up as the champ of American porters available. Dark in appearance with little light able to shine through. Smells like brown sugar oatmeal, which transcends to perfect moderately roasted and semi-sweet palate. Im always satisfied when I drink this beer. Its well balanced, possesses simple complexity (oxymoron, yeah but its an apt description), and immensely flavorful and drinkable. I could go on to detail broad verbiage about how it tastes, but no need as it pins the style down with a blue ribbon from me.

This beer is everything you would want in a porter. Great Lakes has always produced quality product and this is no different. Full body with a clean finish. The main quality of this porter is it delivers a bold flavor while avoiding a bitter aftertaste. If youve never tried a porter before, this is a great one to try.

Served from bottle into glass at home. Pours black with strong sepia colored head. Somewhat underwhelming mild roasted malt aroma with hint of coffee. What was lacking in aroma is more than made up for in flavor. Classic porter taste, creamy roasty toasty malt and subdued chocolate and coffee notes. Low medium bitterness, like dark chocolate and no detectable hops. Smooth mouthfeel, low carbonation and superb drinkability.

Bottle. It poured black with a mocca head. The aroma was dark chocolate and coffee bean. The flavor includes roasted malt, chocolate and some light dark fruits. It has a thin oily mouth feel. I liked this the first time I had it in Cleveland years ago and I still think it is a very good Porter.
Tap at Darryls, Greensboro. Colour is clear dark brown with small white head. Aromas and flavors: Coffee, chocolate and roasted malts. Pretty nice.
12 oz bottle. Pours a dark opaque black with a thin layer of tan head. Aroma of coffee and roasted malts. Taste is great, with a well balanced coffee and roasted malt combo with hints of chocolate.
12 oz bottle Dark brown with beige head. Aroma is of cocoa, coffee, roasted malts. Taste follows aroma
Its a really good beer, and has a forward grapefruit hop presence. Not the best Porter Ive ever had though. Would probably take a pass for some other porters.
Backlog entry: I had this one at the brewery. Its a solid beer, nothing too unusual or stand-out. Im surprised this beer is Top 50, a solid representation.

Aroma: 6 ashes, bitter, sour cherry, some dark chocolate, a touch of coffee.
Appearance: 4 Dark brown, creamy off-white head
Taste: 6 Not bad. Same as aroma. Less coffee.
Palate: 4 Creamy, velvety. Could be fuller body. 
Overall: 14 Nice.
12 oz bottle. Deep brown with an average beige head. Aroma is of cocoa, coffee, roasted malts, earth and nutmeg. Taste is of cola, cocoa, hazelnuts, nutmeg, and licorice.
Bottle. The look is brownish to black in color, a beige head, and clearish. The smell is chalky, roasty, chocolate, malt, burnt sugar, and good. The taste is malty, burnt, chocolate, and good.

Bottle. Pours an opaque dark reddish brown with a mostly lasting light beige tight bubbly head. Aroma is of coffee, dark chocolate, biscuit, caramel, dark fruits. Taste is of coffee, dark chocolate dark fruits, nuts, biscuits, caramel, bitter roasted finish. Thin watery to oily mouthfeel, medium carbonation.

Fresh bottle from the brewery. Nearly-opaque with mahogany glow. Chocolate-espresso malt notes, some bright tobacco, earthy herbal notes of noble hops. Flavor is chocolately with a nice grainy maltiness, hints of smooth espresso and cacao, lingering with the alpha acids of spicy and citrus noble hops. A no-brainer porter. Those in favor of dark beers shouldnt hesitate to grab this one. Clean, balanced, proper. A solid go-to for those who love dark beers with modest abv.

I had it on tap. It pours a dark brown with a nice, tan head and lacing. The aroma is roasted coffee and chocolate. The taste is coffee, chocolate, and tobacco. The sweetness is subtle. The bitterness is strong. Theres a lot of flavor here.

Aroma of sweet chocolate, roasted malt, and light tobacco. Taste follows the nose pretty closely. Like most porters the mouthfeel is a bit too thin for my liking. That being said, this brings a lot of flavor for a 6% abv beer. This one is on par with Founders Porter except for the thin mouthfeel.

Pours black with small head very little aroma. Excellent crisp flavor and very good palate slightly light for easy drinking. Not very creamy texture which doesn't harm it. Love the name

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: AUG 21, 2016 12 oz bottle. A dark caramel to near black color gradient. Milky, khaki head that seems to replenish itself. Aromas of leather, tobacco, brown sugar, toffee, and oak. A very nice, earthy flavor. Dark caramel, dried fig, roasty coffee. Medium body. No discernable alcohol, but does have a warming quality.

Filter coffee, dark, toasted malts, cacao nibs. Clear, dark brown, small, creamy, beige head. Light bitter. Coffee, light, dark fruits, soft carbonation, medium bodied. Nice Porter, well-balanced, maybe a bit light. Keg at Sugar Maple, Milwaukee.

On tap at Progressive Field. Nice dark brown color and a fizzy tan head. Nice robust flavor with coffee and caramel. A lasting roasted malt aftertaste. Carbonation is just lively enough. Body is a little watery. Solid stuff here!

THEY CHANGED FITZY! I just got back from Cleveland with my 12 pack of Edmund Fitzgerald Porter. I noticed when I compared the bottle to 3 I had leftover from 3 years ago when I was there last that the ship on the label was different. Naturally, I had to do one of my double-blind taste tests with my wife to see if it was just the label or if they had changed the brew also.

Conclusion: The old EF was smooth and drinkable with a subtle licorice note; 5.8% abv. Very nice! The new EF is a robust, roasted brew with a slight coffee note 6% abv. Very nicer!

I have no idea if GLB made any announcement to the effect of their changing the formula, but they definitely have.

Great Lakes Edmund Fitzgerald Porter has a thick, beige head, a dark, ruby-brown (as the light hits it) appearance, with some lacing left behind (but, not heavy lacing). The smell is of rich, sweet coffee, cream, chocolate, brown bread crust, and strong malt. Taste is of all that, with balancing bitterness. Mouthfeel is high medium, and Edmund Fitzgerald Porter finishes on the powdery side. RJT
pours nearly black with a medium tan head. Rich aroma of roasted malt. creamy mouth feel with rich dark malt flavor. Black coffee notes creep in. Bittersweet linger. Very good!

Draught at Jet Rock Bar and Grill in Terminal B of PHL. The highlight of a flight of 8 beers during a layover. Fantastic chocolate aroma with slight roast. Brown with light brown head that is sustained. Lovely all around.
Dark brown black. Sweet. Very malty. Tootsie roll. Nutty. Dynamic on palate. Nice porter.

Bottle, have had this a couple times and really like it. Pours dark brown with thin tan head, coffee aroma follows through to taste with a little bit of chocolate and a slight bitter finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Deep garnet color with a persistent head. Chocolate malt aroma with slight caramel. A good bodied beer full of malt flavor. Very drinkable.

Shared from a brown bottle into sampler glasses, it poured a near-opaque dark brown colour with moderate off-white foam and lace. Malty, grainy, caramelly, toasty, roasty, nutty, strong dark stone fruit esters. Grassy and citrusy hops. Medium mouthfeel and carbonation, delicious balanced aftertastes. Extremely tasty and moreish, an excellent Americanized porter.
One of the best porters Ive tried. Rich dark malt aromas and flavors, hops in the background, and a finish that is quite long.

Nice color, decent head that sticks around. Inviting, roasty aroma, with a hint of hops. Surprisingly bitter taste, though. Dang, I was really hoping to like this one, but the bitterness was just too much for me.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2016 Bottle. Average carbonation. Prominent burnt coffee aroma and flavor, followed by solid chocolate and malt flavors. Slightly sweet, slightly bitter finish. Not as punchy in flavor as the best of the porters, but still quite flavorful and satisfying.  The bonus is 6% ABV, which is about as much of a good thing that you need.  Overall, more of a drinking beer than a tasting beer.  One of my faves!

Very dark brown, nearly black, beer with a light tan, sparse head.

Aromas of roasted coffee and chocolate. Hops provide a generalized bitterness.

Medium sweetness and moderate bitterness.

Medium to somewhat full body; oily/creamy texture; average carbonation; finish is long with coffee and chocolate.

Overall a pretty good Porter; I like the chocolate and coffee flavors though its not especially complex.

Pours dark with medium head. Aroma: a burst of chocolate and coffee, some raisins, vanilla, dark fruit and of course raosted malt. Taste: chocolate and coffee dominate, making this beer compley but at the same time drinkable. Great.
Pours a deep black with a brown head. Aroma of roast, dark chocolate with a hint of vanilla. Taste is bakers chocolate and roast. Full body, thick and chewy.

Many thanks to Erzengel for sharing!

Pours very dark brown colour with a mid-sized creamy good lasting beige head. Aroma of dark roasted malt and coffee. Taste of dark roasted malt, coffee, some bitter hops, tons of vanilla in the aftertaste, nice stuff!

Many thanks to my "Santa 2015" jsquire for this bottle!  The beer starts malty and dry. Very intense dry with a great dry caramel and chocolate aroma. Moderate bitterness, soft, round and fresh. Intense aftertaste with dry roasted caramelly malts and espresso with a great full and rich body. Fantastic.

5 oz sample at a tasting. Pours a nice dark brown with small bubbly head. Aroma was baking chocolate, coffee, roast malts, and some vanilla. Flavor follows the nose perfectly and is nicely balanced out. Medium body, slick texture, average carbonation, and a nice bold finish with bitterness from the hops. Solid porter.

Jet black pour, but holding onto light at the bottom of the glass is a deep, ruby red. Creamy, milk-white head with nice lacing. Aromas of burnt coffee, roasted malt, chocolate, caramel and brown sugar. The taste is not as sweet as the nose; coffee, bitter chocolate, and nutty pine, with bitter finish, but has a nice slight sweet after taste as it warms. Creamy, medium-bodied porter with a pleasant mouthfeel. Overall, this is a nice American Porter

Sampled from a bottle at The Tilted Kilt S Wabash Avenue. Dark brown/black with a beige head. Lots of chocolate and and coffee in the taste and flavours of vanilla and sarsaparilla. This is a rich and tasty porter. Highly drinkable.

Im not big on porters, but this is definitely one Id recommend to others. Its flavorful and its not overpowering. Its kind of scary looking at first, because it pours so dark, but the flavor doesnt smack you in the mouth. Its just not a beer to drink in big sips.

Medium aroma with dark chocolate and some roasted malts. Pitch black color with medium beige head. Medium smooth earthy taste with dark chocolate, some coffee and roasted malts. Some tangy notes like cellar. Medium balanced with medium taste spectrum and medium aftertaste. Medium body with medium carbonation. Overall, nice porter except earthy notes which are either good or bad.

Pours a nice dark black with a tan head. Pleasant aroma of cocoa, roasted malt, coffee. Medium body, taste is light coffee, bittersweet chocolate with a hop finish to keep it well balanced. One of the better porters Ive had.
Bottle Shop at Hunger and Thirst Lancaster Pa. Brewery deScription on point. Coffee, roast, bittersweet finish. Solid porter. Not good enough to buy a case but would definitely drink again.
Vanilla oak aroma with a burnt toffee body. Hints of raisin and plum with a slightly bitter finish.

This has a very nice flavor and can be found at stores all over the Great Lakes region. Pours dark. Goes down smooth. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

The body is shades of sasparilla with a nice tan-browned head. The nose is moderately roasty with nuances of chocolate and coffee. Similarly, the body has a good balance to it and an easygoing roastiness made up of equal parts coffee and chocolate character. A solid porter.

Sampled at GABF 2015. In the tasting glass brown with a tan head. Nose of roasted malts, chocolate and dark ripe fruit. Some citrus as well. Medium plus body. Flavor is dominate by chocolate and coffee, but the fruit and hops plus the bitter finish make for a solid and really great tasting porter. I liked this one a lot.
Nice roasted malts, coffee, and vanilla aromas with some dark fruits & dark chocolate too. Taste is roasted malts, chicory, vanilla, dark chocolate, and coffee.
A classic porter. Pours with a lot of head. Good aroma, nice nutty taste with a hint of coffee. Bottle.
Aroma of coffee with a hint of cocoa, pours a dark black color with a short last tan head. Taste of coffee and malt with a hint of chocolate. Viscous feel and bitter finish.

A tulip glass showing half a finger of latte colored foam and coffee brown center. 

The nose shows lightly roasted malts with a light vanilla in the background coming together to show an adzuki-like sweetness. 

The palate is light bodied and moderately carbonated but very foamy. Light flavors of roasted yet sweet adzuiki light malts. Light coffee on the finish and a good coffee flavor on the linger. Overall, simple yet tasty.

Low head. Faint coffee taste with very crisp finish. Light taste and easy to drink. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours clear dark brown with a beige head. Nose: a little ground cumin at first.. Odd.. Then more rosted notes follow, although its all very restrained. Wallnuts too.. Taste: like a light stout but at only 5.8% this packs an okay punch flavor-wise. Mouthfell is medium and the aftertaste has lightly roasted malts, licorice and coffee. Not bad at all.

Pour is opaque dark reddish brown, with a small slightly off white head. 
Aroma is nicely roasted, with some coffee and a lot of licorice present. Slight ash and bitter chocolate. Slight asphalt notes as well. (Ye. Ive been licking the pavement from time to time) 
Taste has very slight sweet notes up front, but is dominantly bitter. 
Medium bodied, with a somewhat fizzy carb.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2015 Bottle at home. Black pour. Creamy beige head. Aroma is sweet roasted malt, coffee, dark chocolate. Flavor follows suit with smoky vanilla notes, ash, woody, and a sweet chocolate maltiness underneath. Creamy palate. Ashy bitterness with stale, musty tasting hops on the finish.

Aroma: coffee, chocolate, roasty
Appearance: dark clear amber, tan head
Taste: medium sweetness, medium bitterness, chocolate, coffee
Palate:medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, long finish, 

Mmm - delicious porter

ポーター
苦味&

12 oz bottle. Simply put -easily one of the 3 best porters I have ever had, and porters are my favorite type of beer. They turned up the coffee on this one. This is one gorgeous looking beer. Now I have to find it on tap somewhere.
Gordon Lightfoot would roll over in his grave (is he dead?) if he knew that a beer named after one of his most famous songs was this bad. If you would like to try a Porter, skip this one. Thanks.

Probably the first porter I became really familiar with. Aroma is really nothing spectacular--kind of chocolate milk/mocha. Beautiful reddish-dark brown, but not opaque. Nice tightly knit head. Taste is coffee--chocolate, kind of sweet, but theres a suggestion of hops and slight suggestion of roasted barley==just enough. Still havent had a better porter.

Pours dark brown with a little more than average head. The aroma is anise, bakers chocolate, coffee. Thats all present in the flavor, too. The finish is a strong, roasted malt and a little hop tingle. This is an affordable porter, and its low price and high quality make it one worth seeking out.

Draft to taster
Vanilla, coffee bean, caramel, nutmeg, a liitle red wine. 
Deep translucent ted with a thin off white head. Chocolate, vanilla, toasted malt.
Dark brown, thin pour. Nose is vegetal, metallic, some roast. Taste is roasty, chocolate, fresh water, bitter finish. Thin mouthfeel.
roasty, slight chocolate aroma. black in color with little head. rich roasty flavor, slight chocolate and coffee, faint bitter finish

Pours a lovely dark body with a great malty taste and smooth finish. A nice
Porter. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at the airport in Philly, Jet Rock Bar and Grill. Dark brown with reddish hues, and a small light tan head. Nose is toasty and malty with mild hints of chocolate. Taste is cola like, semi sweet chocolate. Medium bodied, bitter finish.

Draught @ Ashleys, Ann Arbor, MI
Pours reddish brown with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, chocolate, caramel and coffee. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter with a long chocolate, caramel and coffee finish. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Bottle. Clear dark reddish brown with a foamy, beige head that lasts and laces. Aromas of roasted malt, dark chocolate, coffee, light pine and caramel. Flavor is the same with just a hint of citrus and nuts toward the end. Light plus bodied, smooth with a roasty, slightly dry end.
Ontap,poured into a pint glass.dark brown with a fluffy off white head..aroma of coffee,vanilla,roasted malts,milk..dry,malty,nutty..not bad.
The best beer I have had yet, I think. I am very impressed with Great Lakes, and want to have this one again.

Bottle to shaker glass. Pours black to the eye but deep red when held to light. Quick off white head some lacing with no real retention. Aroma of coffee and dark chocolate. Taste is perfectly balanced bittersweet. Medium bodied, average carbonation, creamy mouth feel. Finishes coffee like bitter. Tasting note of coffee, dark chocolate, slight smoke and vanilla. This is a very tasty porter hopped the way I like it!
bottled - a very good porter. Lightly sweet roasted malt flavor. Nice dark color. Nice chocolate flavor as well.

Draft pint from Slainte. Mahogany with ruby red tint, nice tan lacing, moderate carbonation. Coffee and malt in the aroma, malty hops taste and mildly bitter finish. A solid porter if a bit more hoppy than I prefer for the style. Very enjoyable.

Pours deep golden brown from 12 oz with generous tan head. Chocolate and toasted malt aroma. Malty chocolate, molasses, and roasted character with citrusy hop finish. Chewy on the palate with full body. Delicious porter with full complement of flavors, one of the best I've had. Will buy again.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

BBD 7/14/15. Pours a beautiful deep dark ruby that approaches black. Outstanding head volume and retention, world class lacing.

Rich nose of dark chocolate over a rich caramel malt base with a touch of roast.

Light medium body with a smooth texture that lacks creaminess. Above normal carbonation with a nice burst of effervescence in the middle and a prickly finish.

The flavor profile is less intense than expected, a bit complex and very well balanced. It begins with a slight bakers chocolate flavor that flows into a mild herbal bitterness in the middle. The richness of the nose never expresses itself. Roast appears in the middle - finish transition. Caramel never really becomes significant. The finish is a slow fade of roast and herbal hops.

Old rating. Bottle from Old Town. Dark brown to black color with a thin tan head. Huge coffee bomb on the nose with undertones of roasted malt and chocolate. Body is thin and light and very drinkable. Some dark fruit and licorice noticeable as it comes to room temperature. Nice smooth finish. A really great porter.

Bottle - 355ml. Pours a black body with brown glints and a thin beige foamy head. Nice malty/hoppy aroma with woody, spicy, and roasty hints. Its well balanced taste carries oaky, liquorice, cocoa, and nutty notes. Ends with a long bitter/roasty finish. Interesting.

Not a whole lot of smell there, smells of coffee...not much else. Tastes of coffee, wood, and nuts. A tiny bit bitter as well. Very light in terms of drinkability, similar to an ale I would say. Used to drinking stouts when I drink a dark beer, and when drinking a porter, I tend to get surprised that they are so light. Still very good however, would recommend if you are wanting to try a very high quality porter with the porter flavor.

3/29/15 (Bottle) - Black thin pour, minimal tan head, mild carbonation. Chocolate dark roast coffee aroma and taste, very pleasant. Texture light and thin, light carbonation, nice clean taste. Overall very good beer.

Pours black with a hint of brown. Small head, minimal carbonation. Aroma of roasted dark chocolate coffee grinds. Rich taste with coffee upfront melting into dark chocolate and milk mixed with more coffee. Brewed according in compliance with the German beer purity laws per bottle. Goes well with Gordon Lightfoot, you know which song.

Cocoa roasted malt aroma and flavor. Full bodied with a dry finish. Smooth Porter. Bit of a lactose smoothness. Pretty enjoyable and well done Porter 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma chocolate, coffee, roasty, 
Appearance red, brown, dark but not opaque
Taste medium sweetness, lightly bitter, 
Palate full body, thick feel, soft carbonation, 
Overall very nice tasting beer that I would suggest to a friend
Easy drinking porter. A little to light for my liking. More hops than Im used to in a porter. Solid flavor though with a dry finish. Decent but not amongst my favorites.

Smooth, dark, coffee-chocolate taste...there is nothing I don't love about this beer. It goes with everything, and light enough to drink any time of year. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a highly carbonated dark cola. Brown cream head. Licorice and toasted oat aroma. Toasted oatmeal cookie taste with balanced licorice bitter. Light and slightly sticky mouthfeel with a light chocolate aftertaste.

Pours a deep brown with minimal head. Aroma is sweet. Toasted malt with hints of caramel and toffee. Toasted malt flavor leads before the coffee and chocolate come in. Nice dry, dark chocolate finish with a clear hop presence. Very good.
One of my favorites. Great flavor yet still smooth enough to drink all day. I recommend it.

Pours a dark brown. Consistency is thin, slightly oily with very thin head and some lacing. The aroma is somewhat sweet and pleasant. There is some carbonation and a slight bitter aftertaste. I did not like this very much. It was too light for a Porter and the bitterness was not very enjoyable.
Dark brown pour with a white head. The aroma has milk chocolate and coffee. It has a medium body with sticky texture and average carbonation. The taste is mildly sweet with a more roasted finish.
Nice subdued flavor. A tiny bit smokey. Nice sweet bitter kick. Smells sweet like molasses. Slightly creamy.
Great dark color, rich. Robust chocolate notes. Smooth flavor, lasting palate. Solid entry

Roasted coffee and chocolate billow out from the pour. Dark carbonated light lacing with toasty finish. Was looking for a nice sweet finish but was suprised with a toffee dryness. Good offering but just was hoping for a photo finish.
Has a nice coffee aroma. It has a slightly strong coffee taste but not as sweet as other porters. Slightly bitter after taste.
Bottle. Dark brown with a medium off-white head. Stong chocolate aroma. Medium body and carbonation. Slightly sweet with hints of bittersweet chocolate and coffee. Just a great, smooth porter.

Bottle. Dark not much foam. Good roasty aroma when poured bit not much when the head goes. Bitterness from the hops is mellowed by the roasty porter chocolate and coffee notes. Clean on the pallet w a dry finish. Good porter that I will buy again

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

The aroma is a malty chocolate and is very pleasant. The brew is dark and cola like, letting some light through to create a rosy hue. Head thins to an almond sheen. As advertised, the taste is an interesting blend of chocolate and coffee. Very, very nice. The mouth feel is a really pleasant thick oil. The aftertaste is malt and chocolate. This is one pleasant porter. Love it!
Decent porter offering. Finish is bitter and less sweet than I typically like. Dark coffee or black in color

Best Porter Ive ever had in a bottle. Nice black as night pour with a generous beige head. Good carbonation touches of chocolate and coffee on the initial palette. Excellent aftertaste. Not too bitter. Outstanding Porter.

Pours a dark brown with thin off white head which disappears quickly.....aroma of coffee, chocolate, licorice......taste is very smooth with coffee large up front, touch of licorice, nice bitterness hitting late. Well done.

Pours a dark black with tan head. A strong cocoa and light coffee aroma. A nice mix of chocolate, coffee, and caramel. A good mix of sweet and dry, but not as creamy as I expected. Still, very delicious!

Pours a dark rdish brown with a medium tan head. Aroma is cocoa powder and very light roast. Flavor is robust for a porter, with some cocoa powder and roasted malt. A well done porter. Very balanced and smooth, highly recommended.
Heavily roasted coffee, dark chocolate, toasted malts and milk. Great body and a creamy feel without being too heavy.

Very good porter, very traditional in color, aroma and color. Hints of chocolate, vanilla and roasted malts. Finished with a nice smokiness, with hints of chocolate. One of the best porters I have had.
A really good porter, nice dark color though not totally opaque. Roasty malty flavor with nice smoothness. I could stand a little more sweetness to round it out.
A great porter. Full bodied and easy to drink. Dark color and strong chewy finish.
This was really nice. Great chocolate and coffee flavors while also being a bit hoppy.

Bottled. Pours pitch black with pillowy tan head into a pilsner glass (not my choice). Aroma is lots of chocolate and coffee. Really nice and full actually. Taste is coffee bitterness up front with a chocolate sweetness in the middle of the mouth and a pleasant coffee bitterness finish. Not as weak in the body as many porters but not as robust as some stouts. Overall, a much better Porter than I remember.
This is one of my all time favorite beers. Lots of chocolate and coffee with a perfect balance of sweet and bitter. I just wish I could get it locally.
Bottle thanks to Alex. Pours a dark brown and beige head that diminishes to nothing. The aroma is roasted malt and chocolate. Thin mouthfeel with strong roast, dark chocolate, light dryness. Good.
Quite nice, very on point for the style. Nice roast in the aroma, and a nice bitterness and roast to the chocolate and malt, balanced well with hops. Very enjoyable.

This is a great beer..pours black with a hint of amber leaving a two finger tan head..nice lacing..the aroma is bittersweet chocolate with a nicley balanced coffee note and a hint of smoke..i can deffinatley taste the malt here..almost like chewing on some two row before throwing it in my mash tun..then the chocolate mid palate and finishing with a mild black coffee..kinda reminds me of dunkin coffee..not to bitter but just right..and then there is that subtle hint of smoke.over all impression is absolutley stellar..I dont know which porter I like best..Edmund Fitzgerald or Thirsty Dogs Old Leghumper..but then again i think might just like local ohio beers better than anything..and with great lakes, thirsty dog, and hoppin frog within an hour drive from my place who could complain.

Pours a dark brown with red around the edges. Tan head with medium retention. Nice lacing in the glass. aromas of burnt dark chocolate Vanilla smokey and bittersweet. Very nice porter. Will definitely drink again.
Dark brown appearance, rich chocolatey scent. Chocolate and dark malts in taste, smooth easy drinking porter.
Pours a dark brown with a slight reddish hue. It has a nice creamy head and some head retention. Tastes like burnt coffee and bitter, dark chocolate. A very nice porter!
A nice bodied porter. A tan head and chocolate taste that can be hoppy as well. Smells roasty and well done.

On tap (growler). Barely translucent dark brown with a small amber head. Coffee and a tiny bit of hop in the flavor, with a finish thats a little more sweet than bitter. A really solid porter; Im a big fan.

Medium beige head very dark brown pour medium carbonation aromas sugary coffee roast chocolate caramel cocoa the flavours roast coffee chocolate sweet caramel medium bitter grassy note oily to creamy touch the finish best tastes sweetness roast bitter finish smoothness nice on palate

Pours dark translucent mahogany with a thick foamy tan head. Aroma is roasted grain and honey. Mild carbonation in the mouth with coffee, chocolate and roasted grain on the tongue. Medium bodied with a slight oily texture in the mouth. Finish is a tad bitter. This is a pretty good Porter.

Pour from a 12oz bottle. Dark brown but clear brew with tan head - translucent when held up to the light. Nice aroma of roasted grain with ints of coffee and cocoa. Taste is semi-sweet roasted grain up front with an emerging complexity of grain, roast and moderate hops in the finish. Fine and well balanced. Rock solid porter.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown with amber highlights. Foamy tan head. Nice lacing. Rich aroma of roasted nuts. Roasted malts and coffee upfront with a nice bittersweet finish. A light unsweetened cocoa hint as well. Pretty solid porter. Im digging it.
Aroma of roasted nut and caramel. Dark amber almost black appearance. Tastes of roasted nut/chocolate. Good.

12 oz. bottle, sent from wilco (thanks a lot, Mike), pours a dark brown with an amber tinge and a medium tan head. Nose is soft, with notes of cocoa powder and very light roast. Flavour is robust for a porter, with notes of dry cocoa powder and rather robust roasted malt. Not quite at stout level body, but quite robust nonetheless. This is pretty much everything you could ask for in a porter. Highly drinkable, highly flavourful, and balanced. Excellent stuff.

Appearance: Very dark brown, some tan head.
Aroma: Dark malts, roasted, some smoke.
Taste: Lots of dark malt, roasted. Slightly burnt and smokey. Nice!

Info: 26/10-2014, 229/300, BB: 9/12-2014

Bottle from the signature lounge overlooking the Chicago skyline. Pours a dark brown with a beige head. Nose has roasted smoky coffee and malts. Bit of chocolate in there. Taste is very roasty with a smooth coffee finish. Nice dry bitterness.

Bottle to snifter. Pours very dark brown. With medium head quickly dissipating .Aroma of roasted malts and light chocolate. Smoky coffee flavors with a bit of a bitter aftertaste.

12 oz bottle, poured into a pint glass at 50 degrees F.

A: Pours a deep, dark brown, but clear enough to see through. What little head forms is thin and quickly dissipates, though the beer leaves nice lacing on the glass for a moment ere it slides back into the liquid. 

S: Slightly smoky dark roasted coffee and 90%+ dark chocolate riding a charred grain malt aroma, with some hints of sweetness around the edges.

T: Oh, thats malty. Dark, charred roasted grain, deliciously bitter, with the black roasted coffee and extra-dark chocolate notes clearly present. There are some hints of campfire smoke and cherry wood, or at least the flavor I get off of meat smoked over cherry wood. The finish is a deeply satisfying bitter roasted grain.

M: While rich, the mouthfeel is surprisingly light, given the nose and flavor profile. It manages to feel light and drinkable, without being too watery.

O: This is just a good, solid porter. Whenever I meet someone who doesnt yet know what a porter is, I introduce them to the style with this beer. It generally changes expectations as to what a porter should be.

Aroma-Dark chocolate, smoke
Appearance- Deep rich reddish brown, thick fluffy beige head.
Flavor- Starts sweet but quickly the smoky bitterness kicks in.

"pours pretty dark, almost stoutish in appearance. smooth tan head. aroma is smoke, chocolate, and hops. body is medium at best but smooth and its richly flavored and robust. smoke, coffee, cocoa, bittersweet finish. one of the better porters out there...no surprise from this brewer. thanks louis for the trade!"

On tap at Grandma's Sports Saloon. Really great beer. Thick black color but very smooth.

Dark dark black pour. Bitter sweet chocolate and coffee that has bolf hops and gentle carbonation with fresh light finish. After bitter that lingers perfectly!

Pours a deep blackish brown from the bottle with thin tan head. Aroma is weak, soy and chocolate with slight roast. Taste is way more toward the roast and chocolate with a nice deep soy back end. Solid porter.

Pours a dark brown with garnet highlights and has a beige head with good lacing. Aroma of chocolate, roast and light brewed coffee. Taste has some bittersweet chocolate that leads into a nice roastiness and coffee bean flavors. Moderate amount of roasty bitterness with just a slight bite. Finishes nice and dry. Mouthfeel is somewhat slick with a light/medium body and moderate carbonation. Really nice, straightforward Porter. A good marker of the style.
Pours black with a big foamy head. Roasted malt, sugary cream and toffee aroma. Dark roasted malt flavor witb some burnt character. Dark roast. Draws down soapy. Lots of bite. A robust porter.

Bottle: Deep brown, almost black with some translucency only at the edges. Light-tan head mellows out thinly & spans across the top of the brew; moderate lacing left behind. Aroma of roasted malts & light chocolates with an underbelly of creamy smoothness & a hint of bitterness biting softly towards the back-end. Flavor opens up a bit more with added complexity; roasted malt, burnt campfire wood, roasted nuts, coffee beans, & mildly charred grains. The finish exhibits a very slight floral & earthy hop bite, ending with a bittersweet chocolate malt flavor that lingers for a while. Moderately creamy body, perhaps a tad thin. Very nice porter.

A very light border. Slight chocolate flavor an coffee. Bitter finish. Had a draft at Gideon Welles. Brown incomor with a tan head.

This is a great porter. The nose is roasty and chocolate with a piney hop presence. The taste is really well balanced with hops coming in at the end. Great stuff.

12oz bottle. Dark brown with a frothy beige head. Flavors are raisins, chocolate, roasted malts, coffee, caramel and molasses with herbal and cola notes. Light to medium body, soft carbonation, thin texture.

This beer is the bomb. A very dark pour with a small tan head. Aroma is dark roast. A bit thick in mouth feel, but not cloying with good carbonation. Flavor is perfectly balanced with dark roasted chocolate and coffee notes, a good hop bit and nice alcohol burn.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2016 On tap poured into a shaker. This has a nice, warm nutty, warm caramel aroma with a coffee and cacao note that gets stronger near the end of the drink. Its a dark, viscous looking brown-black with a tan, creamy head, lots of messy lace, and a retained, thin fluffy ring with a dusty surface. The taste is a medium / medium light coffee bitter with a medium syrupy, malty sweet. The oily texture has a light, soft, nearly flat carbonation. The medium full malty body has lots of coffee and caramel notes with creamy lactose finish. Theres also tones of nuts and grass with a light, mellow, but lingering, coffee ground aftertaste.

Bottle. Been looking forward to trying this one for awhile. Pours cola brown with khaki head. Aroma: milk chocolate; deep roast, bordering smoky/spicy. Caramel atop dark fruit. Taste: moderately sweet; stale hops (months before "best by" date); lots of chocolate with a moderately bitter roast finish. Lasting honeyed sweetness. Medium body, chalky texture. Overall: probably biased because of its place in my beer drinking journey, but I prefer black butte.
Bottle. Pours black with white head. Aroma is chocolate, slight bitterness. Taste us the same, light bitterness, chocolate, caramel sweetness.

pours unclear medium dark brown, red tint, with a very nice loight beige head, some retention and lacing. gently smoked roasted malts, dense and complex chocolate, raisins - or chocolate-coated raisins aka glossettes *TM, caramelized nuts, lean red fruitiness. mdoerately low carboantion, light body - oily but never too heavy, assertive yet never harsh grassy-smoky-piney-slightly earthy-bitter coffee finish. very solid porter.

From the 12 fl. oz. bottle conveyed to me from a non RB-member. The pour is a deep reddish-brown color with a long lasting tan head. The aroma on this is a delightful collection of milk chocolate malts, smoke, and earthy hops. The body is in the medium range. The taste is much like the aroma with that milk chocolate goodness, smoked cheese, and clean, but vibrant finish. One of my favorite styles taken to a higher level.
Dark and robust. This brew is very tasty, very nice for a cool fall night. Definitely worth a try if you like this style.

From a bottle. Pours dark brown and makes a nice light brown head. Smells of caramel and malt. Tastes of coffee and toffee.

Classical American porter from Ohio, apparently a rerun of a beer that existed already in the roaring twenties. Thinnish but stable, yellowish beige head, very dark bronze colour, approaching black, clear. Delicate and quite complex aroma of dark malts, cacao powder, bitter chocolate, coffee, raisins, dates, pear syrup, bourbon, kahlua, liquorice. Dark fruits taste with smooth, resinous but light and powdery mouthfeel, complex maltiness with chocolate, nuts and caramel, in the end also a roasted bitterness of bitter chocolate, finishing in an assertively hoppy, bitter tail. Very well-balanced and justly famous.
Pours a dark brown. Aroma and taste are chocolate, coffee, and roasted malts.
This is a great go to Porter. Rich, chocolatey, roasty, vanilla, coffee, just great. Exactly what I am looking for in a Porter without the high abv. Great balance with the hops as well. Solid.

Nice complex porter. Dark brown pour. Aroma of cocoa, roasted malts, peat, oak. Taste was equally complex with strong but bittersweet chocolate presence and some dark fruits. Medium bodied and easy drinking for a porter. Excellent.

Aroma is of fresh chocolate brownies mixed with roasted malts and burnt coffee. Sweet cocoa and oak are also in the mix, no hops present and alcohol is very light. 

Pours a 1/4 inch cappuccino head, body is black with mocha highlights. Head retention is good and lacing is above average. 

Tastes of charred oak followed by sweet coffee and burnt malts. No hops are detected and alcohol is slightly in aftertaste.

Beer is light bodied for a porter but has a nice creaminess like its on nitro. Carbonation is above average and finishes a bit dry.

Overall, beer is exceptional for the style. Full flavored, light bodied and session able but with a kick.
Roasted coffee and chocolate aromas. Dark brown-black with a lasting tan head. Dry, roasty, a little charred tasting, subtle dried fruit. Medium-full bodied.

From a bottle in Grand Haven MI. Pours brown with a creamy tan head. Aroma is chocolate and roast. Thinner bodied. Smooth beer. Very nice.

Transfer from BA review on 8-28-12 - 
 Served on tap in a 10 oz chalice glass

 Appearance  Served a deep brown color with a small off white head. The head fades rather fast to give only a light amount of lacing.

 Smell  The aroma is a wonderful mix of roasted malt and chocolate as well as a light caramel sweetness. With these aromas is a very light dark fruit aroma of plum and raisin as well. Overall the aroma is nice and sweet.

 Taste  The taste begins with nice roasted malt and some slightly bitter coffee notes. As the taste advances a sweeter chocolate flavor greets the tongue. The chocolate is soon complemented with some dark fruit as well as caramel flavors. These sweeter caramel and dark fruit flavors last to the end, but there they end up fading, resulting, in the end, a nice semi-sweet cocoa flavor that is left to linger on the tongue.

 Mouthfeel The body of the brew was on the average to slightly above average side with a carbonation level that was on the slightly lower side. While the body was lighter then would have been nice for the roasty and cocoa flavors, the carbonation was right on par. While the body was lighter, when complemented with the carbonation and smooth flavors, it did make for a very easy drinking porter.

 Overall - A tasty brew with some nice roasty and chocolate flavors. Easy drinking and good.
Tap. Dark amber pour with a tan head. Chocolate, vanilla, coffee. Milky and silky medium body. Very nice
Coffee and chocolate on the nose and in the mouth. A good porter.... lacked a little depth for my liking.

Pours dark brown with an amber tint and a tan head. Roasted malt aroma with tobacco, molasses and chocolate. Flavor starts with a sweet caramel malt, followed with roasted malt and chocolate finishing with coffee and smokiness. Really nice beer. Thanks Maxbier for this one!
Great porter, nothing experimental about it, just the right amounts of coffee/chocolate/toast taste. Probably the only good thing about Cleveland.

Bitter at the start. Drank from a bottle. Perfect notes of chocolate and coffee with a bit of sweet in the end.

Deep cola appearance with a thin tan head. Roasted yet sweet aromas are softer and more appealing than a stout. Some hops begin to come out in the flavor and provide a contrasting bitter undertone. Thick and soupy mouthfeel is delicious in a darker beer. Great stuff!

Ive recently heard about this beer in the local paper so while visiting the Blue Dog I picked one up. 
Well, this beer pours with a great tan head, dark brown in color. When held up to a light I can barely see through it.

Bottle. Taste- robust is a good word for this. Chocolatey, coffee and hard water. Prominently hopped. Great porter.

Enjoying this one after a solid three under round of disc...thanks to the dude in the swamp for 2 champion plastics for ten bucks keep swamp diving dude...nose is minimal..light malt coffee and chocolate....mouth is same but flavors more present...first porter i have ever pounded....great beer!
First time drinking and it lives up to the hype. Hints of cocoa and chocolate. Very easy drinking...makes me wish I had bought a 6pk instead of a single bottle!

I had this on tap at the Brickhouse in Davidson, NC. It is very dark, almost black. There is some lacing on the glass. It has a roasted malt aroma with chocolate and coffee notes. It has a rich flavor with are roasted on the palate with chocolate. It is not bitter, very smooth on the finish.

Bottle. Dark brown/black with garnet highlights and a small tan head. Aroma of dark chocolate, coffee, toffee, and roasted malts. Medium body, roasted malt, light coffee, and some bitterness with a dry finish.

It appears dark and opaque. It has a dark black color with deep crimson highlights when held up to light. The head is tan, thick and foamy with good retention. Some light tan lace slowly sides down the glass, chasing the head, as I drink. The aroma is full and rich. It has notes of caramel with a strong dark roasted malt presence that has a deep roasted espresso character. Its flavor has deep chocolate roasted malts with flavor notes of coffee and cream with bittersweet chocolate. The hops play well off the malt and further develop the bittersweet chocolaty flavors before slowly fading out into the finish. The palate is smooth, creamy and slightly slick with mild carbonation and a medium to full body. Outstanding. This porter is one of my personal favorites, with a wonderful balance of flavors and drirkability. I would highly recommend this as a stand alone drink or even pairing it with your favorite chocolate.

A robust easy drinking porter. Hits all the right notes. Wish this was more available in my area, would be a regular in my rotation.

One of the first porters that I regularly drank. For the price it is still a good porter. It no longer ranks at the top for favorite based on taste alone. Has a bitterness to it - like the dark chocolate used for baking. Also roasted malt and coffee. A dark brown color. It is a bit light in body. Not as complex as some of my current favorites, but still one I will buy on a semi-regular basis.

Dark and black with rimming little lacy head; aroma is slightly malty roasty and hints of vanilla; Flava is robust roasted malt; feels light per style with much fizz; finishes tangy malty roasty long and dry

One of my favorite offerings from Great Lakes Brewing Company, and they have a bunch of good ones. Reasonably priced, and is named after a tragic shipwreck on the Great Lakes. What else can you ask for in a Porter?

Pours hazy brown with a bit of lasting frothy tan head. Aroma is decadent with hints of bakers chocolate, a bit of coffee, and some hop notes near the finish. Full body and a medium to heavy long lasting sweet taste. Great Porter

Oh good grief. Ive never rated this and Ive had this more than enough times in my life. Well, no time like the present to do this.
Almost always, this has been poured into a pint glass. I honestly cant think of anytime Ive ever had this in any other vessel.
The appearance was a nice dark brown close to black color with a nice tan/white one finger foamy white head. This head lasts for a good minute before it gently dies. Once it dies, theres a nice speckled lacing sticking finely to the glass.
The smell had a nice balanced allocation of coffee to chocolate malts, dry yet somewhat bitter and still even a decent sweetness all combining very nicely.
The taste was bitter, yet dry, still a decent sweet and bringing in a nice roasty sort of flavoring. The aftertaste was mainly a dry coffee with still a slight chocolate coming in. There was a nice dry finish.
On the palate, it sat about a light to medium in body with a decent sessionable quality about it. The carbonation finishes somewhat smooth surrounding my mouth and tongue.
Overall, I say this is an absolutely excellent American Porter, more than worthy of having again. Kudos to whoever lives in the distro for this excellent beer and kudos to Great Lakes for making an absolutely excellent brew.

A- Opaque dark brown color and a tan creamy head with good retention
S- Strong chocolate, roasted malt aroma 
F- Slightly sweet, malty roasted chocolate flavor with a clean, silky sweet finish
M- Creamy, medium to full body, moderately low to medium carbonation
O- This beer is dominanted by a silky smooth, creamy, sweet chocolate flavor. It is a very nice porter and Ill be back for more. It goes very well with bbq!

Serving type: on-tap

Bottle at home in Salisbury - picked up at De Cicco Armonk. Pours brown with a creamy, light beige head. The nose holds milk chocolate, nips of lactose, burnt leaves. Medium sweet flavor with sugary chocolate, restrained roasted malts, light earthy and toasted leaf bitterness. Medium bodied with fine, massaging carbonation. Sugary dark malt finish with more milk cocoa, some ripe and dark fruits, more leaves, faint tang, cherries, chocolate. Pretty decent.

From a bottle. Pours very dark brown with a creamy, bubbly beige head. Smells like booze and sweet chocolate, light roasted earthiness. Tastes like sweet roasted grains, malty, light booze, light booze.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with creamy tan head. Aroma is chocolate and roasted malts, raisins, fig, light coffee, and faint burnt caramel. Flavor is nicely balanced roast, dark chocolate, espresso, medium bitterness, and faint sweetness; rich, roast finish. Medium body and carbonation.

Bottle from the middle of nowhere. Pours a dark opaque black with a thin layer of tan head. Aroma of coffee and roasted malts. Taste is great, with a well balanced coffee and roasted malt combo with hints of chocolate.

Bottle poured into a DFH Ale signature glass-- Im keeping this short because I havent had a Porter that doesnt look and smell like a Porter. This looks and smells like a Porter, which is good. Has a mild coffee taste with a little cocoa (?). A little thinner than Im used to in Porters. If you like coffee youll like this beer, I dont so my rating may be a little lower than others.

Dark reddish-brown pour with a creamy, tan head that stays long. Thick curtains. Nose is rich malty goodness with bold caramel and vanilla notes and a subtle hint of pepper. Taste is well-balanced. Medium body. Soft carbonation. Very nice porter.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A classic porter from Great Lakes. Reviewing from draft served in imperial pint glass. Pours a deep, dark coffee color with a tan head. The coffee and bakers chocolate notes are apparent from the nose on this, and come right through from the first sip. There is a reassuringly medium body here - with appropriate carbonation. An excellent porter, which does a fine job of providing roasted notes with a solid hop profile underpinning everything to keep this lively.

Aroma is roasted malt and chocolate cannot discern much of any hop character. Appearance is deep brown with Ruby highlights approaching black in color with a medium tan head that quickly dissipates. Head should be a bit larger and longer lasting for a robust Porter. Flavor is heavy roasted flavors with coffee chocolate and some Burnt toast flavors. Hops make some presence with a dryer lingering roast finish. Mouth feel is medium to medium light body though it probably would do better as a medium heavy Mouthfeel. Carbonation is moderate with some alcohol flavors. Overall it is a roasting first toast robust Porter needs a bit more mouth feel but is very well balanced and smooth.

From a bottle. Pours black with a creamy head that dissipates to a thin layer. Aromas are sweet chocolate and toffee with notes of vanilla and coffee. Flavors are coffee and dark chocolate upfront that give way to hints of dried fruit and finish with gypsum, licorice and a slight hop bite. Creamy mouthfeel. Deliciously smooth. Not a heavy beer, but big flavor! This is an excellent, velvety porter. Maybe the best Ive ever had!

Dark brown/black, dark brown head. Aroma of caramel and roasted malts and malty sweetness. Flavor is rich roasty malt flavor with caramel and nice balance of hop flavors. Finish is caramel/toffee flavor sweetness and slight hop bittering. Very good porter.

This porter is robust but Im going to overlook it as one that claimed a chocolate/coffee taste and barely delivered.
Some thing about the palette left me thinking... cheap.

Pours mahogany, some light some through, finger of creamy tan head. Aroma bready, caramel, roast and chocolate malt, earthy hops. Taste folows nose, very slight bittering from roast malts, caramel, chocolate, earthy hops. Mouthfeel fuller side of medium, lower carbonation, slight roast and hop astringency, balanced finish. Overall one of the best examples of a robust porter made, very tasty, complex and balanced, drinks well, can have a few of these!
Bottle, pours almost black with a beige head, tastes of roasted malt, chocolate, and coffee, slight bitter finish with the hops, very nicely done, a solid porter

12 oz. bottle in a pint glass. Appearance is dark brown/black with a ruby tint and a thin tan head. Aroma is roasted malts, coffee, dark chocolate, and other dark malts. Taste pretty well follows the nose. Id rather the coffee characteristics were a bit more muted, but it was great otherwise.
Bottle. Pours black body with some creamy tan head. Nose is coffee and chocolate. Taste is basically the same.
Bottle into a tulip glass. Pour is a dark ruby black. Aroma is coffee and chocolate. Taste is a crisp rich chocolate malt, rich and full. Finish is clean and full body.

Dark brown to black with some ruby highlights. The dense thin tan head disapates to a thin ring around the glass. Big roasty aroma with chocolate and coffee notes. Roasted malt, dark chocolate, coffee, toffee, and vanilla cola. Moderate hop bitterness that kicks in at the finish. Medium body and carbonation. The mouthfeel is smooth with some tingling from the carbonation and hop bitterness. Nice blend of roasted malt and hop bitterness.

Poured from bottle from cellar. Pours a dark reddish brown with 1 finger tan head. Aroma - dark chocolate, dark dried fruits, slight hint of yeast. Taste - dark chocolate, coffee, malt, little earthy in the middle. Finish is moderately long and segues from coffee, to malt, and back to coffee. Carbonation is lively and a touch prickly on the palate and down the back of the throat. Not my favorite porter, but probably in the top 10.
black, hazy, frothy, tan foam, caramel, chocolate, toast, basement aromas, smoke, vanilla, woody, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, full body, creamy, thick feel, flat, long finish,
Part of a flight, on draft. Clear dark brown pour with a small head. Nose is roast/coffee, malt. Flavor follows with a bitter finish. Decent but probably over-rated on this website.
Very good porter, smoky toasted malt, good lacing, head was a little weak but still not bad, from pint glass.

Draught. Not much head. Aroma is very nice rich light roast and sweet. Flavor packs more roast, light wood, light milk sweetness and lactic bit. Feel is slick and a little wooden. All around lovely beer. Simple in the best way.

On tap in Alpena Michigan. Review from notes

A - Black body, with 1 finger of creamy tan head.

S - Coffee, creamy chocolate, roasted malts, dark bread, yeasty

T - Follows the nose with creamy chocolate, cold coffee, roasted and roasted malts. Hops are there to support but stay in the shadows of the chocolate and coffee duo. The chocolate turns to to a more bitter bakers chocolate toward the dry finish.

M - Very creamy feel, lushes sudsy carbonation, dry bitter finish.

My 1st beer from Great Lakes and it will not be my last. Theres not alot going on, the chocolate and coffee are the stars and the are showcased very well.

Serving type: bottle

11-16-2013

Bottle received by my secret summer Santa 2013. Thank you jsquire! Pours dark reddish brown with a thin slightly fizzy beige head that quickly dissipates without leaving much trace on the glass. Smell is sweet and malty with roasted malts, sweet dark bread, burnt wood, caramel, smoke, moist soil, molasses, hay, sweet liquorice candy, coffee, cocoa powder and lemon zest. Taste is sweet, bitter and malty with roasted malts, caramel, sweet dark bread, brown sugar, burnt wood, moist soil, minerals, bitter chocolate, burnt cereal, golden syrup, smoke, dark roast coffee, wet stone, moss, hay and lemon peal. Mouthfeel is round, tiny watery, slightly dry, soft and light to medium bodied. Finish is bitter with roasted malts, pumpernickel bread, burnt wood, moist soil, hay, burnt caramel, smoke, bitter chocolate, dark espresso coffee and wet stone. Great balanced robust porter!
Sampled on tap at the brewhouse. A nicely well crafted brew with a mild hop palate and smooth malts. A dark rich porter with a warming malt roasted base.

The beer pours a dark, coffee brown with a small head of medium sized, tan bubbles and a middling retention. In body, the beer appears clear but nearly opaque from its darkness, slight hints of ruby and garnet can be seen when held to the light, but no particles seem to be present. On the nose, the beer smells of toasted oatmeal bread, rich caramel sauce, soft burnt popcorn, and fresh coffee beans moving into instant coffee mix. Light dark chocolate can be sensed from time to time in the nose, but the overall impression is of instant coffee, toast, and caramel sauce. On the tongue, the beer tastes smoothly sweet with a nice roasted bitter finish. Just a touch of acidity and a little hop bitters can be sensed in the beer towards the finish. In flavor, the beer begins as burning caramel sauce, working into light roast coffee, caramel malt, and a touch of herbal bitter hops. Light burnt popcorn flavors can also be sensed. The finish is of a middling length and is herbal bitters mingling with burnt black malt, touches of coffee, and just a hint of dark chocolate. The aftertaste is nearly non-existent. In the mouth, the beer feel on the light side of full-bodied, with a very smooth, silky mouthfeel that is just gently chewy. Carbonation is middling with a soft prickly scrub on the palate. The mouth is left a little wet with saliva but only a soft astringency on the tongue, and little else. Overall, this is a nice porter. I could put a couple of these back on a cold winters day and be happy, and this would pair very nicely with a thick stew or shepherds pie. Its not my favorite in the style, honestly, but I think that is because it is so classically a porter that it doesnt stand out much to me. I would have this again for sure, but I dont know if I would buy it again.

Draft. Inky black pour with off white head. Awesome aromas of coffee and chocolate. Smooth and easy to drink with a thinner mouthfeel than the appearance indicates.
(from notes)
(Bottle). First session beer for New Years Eve 2013. Well roasted malty flavor with smooth palate. Some faint bittersweet cocoa & coffee flavors. A solid porter. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
One of my favorite overall beers. Taste is not overwhelming and does not linger. Fairly pricey around $ 12 a six in my area.

Thanks to Jrod1969 for this extra!
Best by: 5/11/11
Poured to NB globe.

A: Pours a deep black ale with single finger light tan head which dissipate quickly and leaves a ring on edges. Does have some lacing, but transient and scattered. Good looker.

S: Excellent nose. Biscuit, roasted malts, light choco malts. earthy tones. Very good.

T: Yum. Nice biscuit, bittersweet cocoa, dark special malts ensure this beer hits you with the resonance of a virgin experience. Outstanding taste.

M: medium heavy body with high carbonation. Wish the carb was a hair lower, but I can always shake that into submission. Dries the palate just slightly.

D: I would drink this all night, but its my only bottle. This beer is sooo awesome. I will now be looking for a clone recipe.

Serving type: bottle

Aroma is very earthy. A bit of hops. Looks pretty good. Dark brown. Head is minimal. The hoppiest porter I have ever had. Very earthy. Metallic. Dirt taste. Light. Rough on the palate. Hops are too intense. Dirt taste lingers in the finish. A little strange this is supposed to be like the best porter. It stays true to the style buy too.much hops and earthiness for me.
Bottle from Total Wines, Sterling VA. Near black with a decent tan head. Big chocolate and roasted malts, with hints of vanilla and oak, a touch of hop and dryish finish. Excellent.
Dark brown ale with a thin off-white head. Has a roasty, coffee aroma. Flavor is roasted malts along with some bitter hops. Pretty good, with some decent carbonation.

Pours a dark motor oil brown. Small tan head. Wonderful aroma of roast.coffee and caramel. Taste is deep roasty ,nutty, coffee with hints of chocolate. Smooth mouthful with medium carbonation. Very good stuff.
Very solid. Dark pour with thick mocha head. Nose of roasted malt and coffee. Taste is a great balance of roast, chocolate, and coffee. Great stuff.
12 oz. Bottle. Pours a dark brown to black hue with a nice brownish head. Chocolate and coffee notes hit the nose. Taste is smooth and complex. A fantastic porter.
Bottle pour dark brown with a tan head. It taste smokey. It's bitter sweet with some chocolate and coffee. It's good. I love porters. This is pretty good. Well balanced.
Pours dark brown, thin light tan head. Chocolate and coffee aroma. Big coffee, roasted dark chocolate, not much hop presence. Light to.medium body to light carbonation. Good stuff.

Nice coffee and chocolate with a bitter bite.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Spicy nose with charcoal. Not quite black. Hints of amber bakers chocolate licorice. Some rustiness. this is a very good porter.

This is a fine porter, dark brown in color with orange-red hues and a light brown head. It smells sweet and roasted, with chocolate and a touch of light coffee grounds. Delicious! Its just as delectable in the mouth, with a complex, dark, charred wood-like flavor thats soft and a little reminiscent of cocoa powder mixed with coffee grounds. As complex and dark as it sounds, its very easy on the palate, well-dosed with alcohol and body to offer one of the most balanced, deep, and enjoyable standard porters out there. It finishes slightly dry, with coffee, cocoa powder, and something that reminds me of figs. This is really delightful and very well-done.

On tap at Ashleys, Ann Arbor. Pours nearly black with red at the edges. Rocky head that sticks all over. Aroma: coffee, creamy chocolate, caramel. Taste: roasty and creamy sweetness with chocolate and coffee notes plus a mild but balancing leafy hop undertone that hints at citrus as it fades. Medium-full bodied, chewy/full texture, dry finish.
UPDATED: FEB 17, 2017 Bottle. Pours a dark red brown with a beige head. Aroma is roasted, alcohol, coffee, malt, Flavor is roasted, coffee, alcohol, malt, chocolate. Very good porter.

Dark roast coffee nose. Dark opaque brown with medium tan head. Coffee bitterness followed by malt. Heavy body, thick mouthfeel. Decent porter.

Bottle to a cup at the Ohio State vs Indiana tailgate. Dark brown, tan short lived head. Roasty maltiness and notes of cocoa with coffee... An excellent porter ...

Bottle. Pours Coca Cola brown with an off white head that falls quickly. Aroma is dark malts, caramel, raisin, dark chocolate. Taste is caramel malt, dark chocolate, coffee. Finish is raisin and coffee bitterness.

Pours almost black but has an edge allows you to observe a crimson hue. The beer has impeccable clarity and when held to the light you can see the stream of bubbles rising in the center of the glass. Fat tan head of foam that falls well and leaves sheets of lace to fall back down into the beer as you drink. The suds refresh with each tip of the glass. 

Nose is brilliant. Sophisticated roasted malt. Blackened, bready, but not crusted or burned. Toasted perfectly smooth. It has a the light scent of creamy caramel. A light touch of brown sugar, bold espresso that is smoothed out by dark bittersweet chocolate. It has a cookie like dryness even on the nose and a light and delicate hop herbal. 

Taste is sensational. The malt rolls out of the glass, supple, creamy, like velvet. Soft and graceful. The caramel stays light and lightly sweet with a bit of nut to it and that sweet little bit of cream to fill up the palate. The coffee and the dark chocolate gives it oomf and a burly quality that is very dynamic. It finishes dry and with an endless grain. The hop herbal balances this perfectly for an aftertaste that is filled with soft dark bread. The body of the beer is medium and it approaches chewy but stays just shy of it. It has a little bit of thickness and it feels great on the palate. 

This beer has a radiant and strikingly handsome appearance. The nose is dapper and full of rich deep scents. The taste is smart and it dazzles with its depths and with its light sweetness. Engaging. Simply one of the best porters.

aroma is brown sugar and a little bourbon-like. pours dark brown with a quickly dissipating head. flavor is dark chocolate, a bit of toffee or butterscotch, more dark sugar but not too much. somewhat oily finish on the tongue. very nice.

Aroma is very subtle. Nice smooth flavor drink though. Roasted malts, bit of cocoa, and it's bubbly on the tongue.

Dark clear ruby with a pretty thick off-white head. Aroma of roast and ash, quite strong, some bitter chocolate and espresso. Taste roasty and dry, chocolate, charcoal. Ash developing in tongue. Very nice dry porter.

12oz bottle from Reg, Thanks! Pours a dark reddish brown, hardly any head. Roasted coffee and malt aromas. Give this some time and the chocolate starts to show up in the nose. Dark brown/black color; Medium creamy body; Aroma of sweet toasted malt, coffee, some cocoa, & milk chocolate; Flavor of roasted sweet malt, caramel, chocolate, and coffee; Finish is fairly bitter; Nicely balanced; Very nice porter.

Dark cola-colored beer with a medium beige head that lasts a while. Nose of brown sugar, medium-dark chocolate, and liquid smoke. A: Very Dark red, light does shine through when held in front of a light, frothy creamy head about 1 finger. Lacing is present, clinging to the side of the glass.

S: Roasted malts, and dark chocolate comes through. It smells sweet and inviting.

T: Sweetness hits you right away with a nice dark chocolate undertone. A bite of bitterness right after you swallow. Aftertaste moves from bitter to sweet as it progresses. This is superbly drinkable.

O: Right now my favorite Porter, beating out the Founders Porter.

Vary dark Red Brown, Almost Black, with Huge Foamy Head, Lots Of Lacing. Chocolate Aroma. Sweet, Chocolate, Roasted Malt, Vanilla, Bitter Coffee Ending. Rather Thin. Easily drinkable, enjoyed it. Found one more of my favorites. Real Nice. Recommended....

Bottle poured into a Pint glass, Best By: 12/12/13 A VERY conservative pour left me with a frothy khaki three finger head. This porter is a deep, dark brown that only shows through when held directly to a light source. The head takes its time to settle in, leaving behind strands of lacing. The aroma is unbelievable, through a slightly stuffed noise Im still pleasantly overwhelmed. Chocolate, bread, coffee. The taste follows suit. What a magnificent beer. Unexpectedly drinkable for a porter, with a medium body. This will definitely be finding its way back to my fridge, likely with a few other offerings from Great Lakes Brewing Co. to sample.

Pours black with a medium, fluffy, tan head and some lacing. Aroma is roasted malt and chocolate. Flavor is roasted malt, coffee, caramel, chocolate, vanilla, and nutty notes. Medium body with some carbonation. Very good.

Wanted this one for a while. Finally got some and Im not sure if I just wasnt in this mindset or maybe I just didnt like it so much. I thought I would have liked it more. Ill need to try it again.

Pours a dark brown with a generous tan head that subsides, but sticks around throughout the glass.

Smells of chocolate and lots of roasted malt. A little earthiness too from the hops.

Strong chocolate/roasted malts flavor with just a touch of spiciness. Heavy bitterness from the chocolate, but not overpowering as in some other porters.

Pretty thick although not syrupy at all. Good carbonation level for style. Its there, but not too much.

My go to as far as a regular porter or easier drinking sixer goes when Im around the Ohio area to pick some up. Not my favorite beer ever, but absolutely top notch for the style.

04-11-2011. 12 oz bottle poured into a pint glass.

A: Dark brown, nearly opaque with ruby highlights when held to light. Rough pour produces a good inch of tan head that dissipates down to about a centimeter, leaves great lacing down the glass.

S: Smells like milk chocolate and cream, coffee, some light burnt notes, simple but very appealing.

T: Starts with a real nice coffee and milk chocolate flavor, similar to the nose. Some smokey and caramel notes in the background. Ends with some nice roasted malts, like black coffee, and some hops. Semidry finish.

M: Medium bodied, good carbonation, rich, creamy mouthfeel, with a nice roasted finish, leaves just the right amount of coating on your palate.

O: Excellent, very tasty and highly drinkable. Its definitely my favorite porter and probably in my top beers of all time.

Pours a dark brown with a red hue. The offwhite head stays for a while and leaves fair lacing. Aroma has some nice (lightly roasted) coffee beans and a little hops. Carbonation level is medium, well made. This is a really good porter!

12oz bottle. Pours a deep, dark brown color with red highlights and a creamy tan head. The aroma is full of roasted barley and coffee with a bit of chocolate. The taste is toasted and roasty, bitter, spicy and dry. Hop bitterness is there, too along with some caramel through the finish. All the flavors intensify as the the beer warms. Medium bodied, rich, creamy, moderate carbonation.

Nice porter. Good body, bit creamy. Toast malt, bit of coffee maybe, smooth aftettaste.

Some porters go for smooth and some go for earthy, and to me this a raw earthy porter. Intial taste is like a chocolate/roasty espresso milkshake, and then fades to pine, then peanut, then an ever so subtle blackberry finish. Really good, a top ten porter for sure.

Pours deep brown, almost black in color with about two fingers of head with good lacing, somewhat cream colored/tan foaming head. Smell is strong, coffee, dark chocolate, vanilla, with a roasted malt, almost nutty character. Taste is roasted, malty, bitter chocolate, coffee. Not heavy or sticky.

bottle. Dark black colour, creamy head. Aroma of coffee and roast. Taste shows some fruity sweetness. Very nicely balanced, very enjoyable beer. Thanks to random guy in Buffalo beer store who suggested I try a few Great Lakes brews, they have all been top notch.

I poured into a 3 Floyds pint glass from a 12oz. bottle. Thats good karma already!

Ap: Inch thick head upon first pour. The frothy, creamy consistency stayed on the beer throughout the session. Not totally pitch black, but the darkest brown you could imagine. Beautiful beer!

Ar: Mild roasty coffee with a prominent hazelnut quality. Sweet, without being too.

T: Perfectly balanced - almost more of a stout, due to the lack of BBQ-like smoke flavor that I usually associate with this style. I detected a flash of fig-like fruitiness on the finish. Ahhh...

P: The creamy thickness of the beer cannot be bragged about enough. ABV is virtually undetectable.

O: ABV is reasonable and the ingredients perfectly balanced. I think Ill have another!

Overall: This is one of those rare beers that defines the style. Awesome and then some!

Bottle from Tim... Thanks! Pours a brown root beer like color with a small tan head. Smell is molasses, raisins, malts. Taste is a bit of bitter coffee grinds, slight chocolate, and some resin hops. Taste is nicely dry with a lingering bitterness. Great porter!

12oz bottle. Poured with 3/4in tan head. Aroma of coffee and chocolate. Full, creamy mouthfeel. Dry and bitter but not overly so. More coffee, cocoa and dark fruits. Spicy hop bitterness. Roasty dry finish.
12 oz. bottle. Mahogany brown with a short tan head. Roasted malt aromas with licorice, coffee, bit of smoke. Medium carbonation, hops, chocolate, licorice flavors. Slightly dry finish.
Draft. Black pour with light brown head. Roasted malt, coffee and some hop freshness in aroma. Flavor is bitter chocolate, and light hops up front, and finishes very roasted and dark chocolates.

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2013 Great Lakes Edmund Fitzgerald, in a 12 oz bottle with the ship painted on the label. Brewed under the Bavarian purity law, nice. Says it is a world champion gold medal winner, nice. Served at about 45 but ill let it cool down some more before tasting.

Pours with a nice, thick 2 finger caramel colored, sandy looking head. Leaves some amazing lacing as it dissipates in due time. The beers color is dark and rich with shimmers of ruby/brown near the edges and when held to light.

Smell is heavily, heavily of dark roasted coffee. A bit of bittersweet dark cacao lingers over the top. A fine scented beer.

Nice mouthfeel, it is on the watery side but it is also creamy and smooth which works well with these heavy flavors, and the carbonation is spot on. Flavor is of bittersweet chocolate coffee. Nice and robust. Has a little bit of sourness I typically seem to find in American porters, and a nice sweetness. Slight hop in the finish (this seems to be what this brew is known for). No alcohol present making it higher than normal drinkablity-wise for an American porter.

Overall a solid American porter, it doesnt get much better than this for this style.
A cola colored beer with a small tan head. The aroma is cocoa and milk sugar. The flavor is smoky, roasted cocoa, kind of burnt and bitter.

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2013 Not too much aroma.   Great first couple of sips.  But gets more an more "hoppy" the more you drink.  Not big hoppy fans, so that doesnt work for us.

Pours a really dark brown with a little red around the edges and a small tan head. Lots of milk chocolate on the nose, nice coffee and toasted malt, a slight nuttiness and surprisingly hoppy. Nice hoppy nuttiness up front on the taste, strong coffee note, light chocolatey taste and slightly sweet toasted malt. Delicious, though I still think Founders might have done a better job.

UPDATED: APR 25, 2017 Bottle in May 2013 Very dark orange brown pour. Nice foamy tan head. Great dark chocolate. Well blended roasty dark malts. Not too sweet. Some coffee ashy notes. Medium body. Nice complex stout flavors. Having a nitro draft again at Bru Craft in April 2017. Not as extraordinary as I first thought. Much less interesting as it warms. Solid Porter but meh overall.
This is a fabulous porter.  Malty, chocolate and very smooth.  Just a wonderfully balanced brew.

Dark brown, thin beige head. Slightly metallic aroma of chocolate, roasted malt, and hints of coffee. Mild sweetness punctuated with a little spice. Medium-bodied, a little thin, and little to no alcohol presence.

Truthfully, Im not a big fan of porters. Its not that they cant be good, but theres probably more bad porters out there than any other style of beer. This one is very decent, however. Very bitter with lots of raw coffee sensations, along with a roasted chocolate feeling on the tongue. Theres no medicinal mouth-feel here, which is good, but it is somewhat harsh. A success, but not something Id want to drink too often.

Poured from a bottle into a glass. Extremely dark pour, neat black with a light brown head with some good lacing. Aroma is nice and roasted malt and coffee. Taste is a good mellow hop presence followed up with coffee and a hearty nutty and roasty flavor. Smooth mouth feel with medium carbonation. Truly a near perfect porter.
Poured into English pint glass. Dark chocolate aroma, chocolate, coffee taste. Dark in color, small but long lasting head. A wonderful porter. Glad Great Lakes is now in New Jersey.
Pours black with creamy head. Smells of roasted coffee and hint of chocolate. Taste the same. A bit on the bitter side. Nice mouthfeel and smoother than expected. A big well made porter
Tasted from a 12oz. bottle. Poured a dark reddish-brown with a beige head. Roasted malt with coffee/chocolate aroma and taste.
Bottle at home. Pours a black with minimal head. Aroma of bitter chocolate. Taste of dark roastiness with a brilliant touch of chocolate bitterness. Among the very best Porters.
Bottle from Tria in Philadelphia, PA. Great porter paired well with some cheese by the wonderful people at Tria, elevating my experience significantly.

12 ounce bottle. Pours a translucent cocoa brown color with a large rocky beige head. Aroma has notes of espresso, milk chocolate and light smoke. Upfront, flavor is complex and flavorful with notes of bittersweet chocolate and smokey roasted malt. Mid taste brings dark roast coffee and spicy hops. Subtle bitter hops finish this porter nicely. Undoubtedly, one of the best American porters I have yet to taste. Silky, smooth, complex and flavorful. Outstanding!
Donker, bijna zwart. Weinig schuim. Gebrande koffie, caramel. Bitterzoet, licht droog. Medium body.
