I do love stouts, but porters are just behind them.  As far as porters go, this is one of the best.  Aroma of coffee and chocolate, and you can definitely taste it.  Slightly bitter like you would expect, overall a very pleasant experience.

brown ale enables enough light thru. medium perhaps wheaty body with coffee, chocolate some caramel vanilla like sweetness slightly burnt. some citrus/ pine hop in my opinion (as a hop head). a busy brew with all of this and balanced nicely.

Pour is deep, dark brown with a small light head. Aroma of dry roasted malts, bit of coffee, not much else. Flavor is of light chocolate, coffee grounds, spice/yeast. A bit over-carbonated and watery for my tastes.
UPDATED: MAY 14, 2013 Bottle. I love porters and this up near the top for me. Nice dark color. Great coffee chocolate smell and taste. Great feel in mouth.  Not too heavy.

Edmond Fitzgerald  porter from Great Lakes Brewery in Cleveland OH (check out the great song from Gordon Lightfoot)

Aroma nice roasty malt. Chocolate and slight coffee 

Appearance dark brown/black with a beige tight creamy 1 finger head 

Taste smooth malty chocolate with a slight bitter coffee finish.  Mild bittering hops 

Mouth feel. Smooth creamy slight to moderate combination.  Mild dry finish 

Overall a very solid beer. It has won Gold medals at the great American beer festival and is well deserved.  I would drink it again 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a clear medium brown with a foamy tan head.  Smells of chocolate, light roast coffee.  Taste is sweet and bitter - light chocolate, hint of coffee, some spicy hops with a floral note.  Very smooth and highly drinkable.

Pours an opaque very dark brown with glints of cola brown around the bottom edge when held to the light. Coffee and a bit of cocoa on the nose. Thicker consistency, but too much carbonation too quickly. Big coffee flavor. Some lactose, but not enough, in my opinion. The coffee flavor is nice, but the coffee acidity is barely tempered by the creaminess. The carbonation tends to overpower the lactose feel and flavor. Its ok. I was excited to get the chance to try it again. Id had it several years ago. But, more recently, theres been quite a bit of hype about it. I dont feel its lived up to it.

Delicious connection of beer with with comfort zone. It is just enough strong flavor to remind you that you are drinking beer and enough palpable flavor to make you want to taste every drip. Excellent.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 ounce bottle.  Pours a very dark brown with a nice tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, caramel, malt, and coffee.  Taste is chocolate, caramel, roasted malt, coffee, smoke, and a bit of hops.  Excellent!

Ordered on-tap at Olives in Roseville, MI.

Appearance: A pretty perfect looking porter. Pitch black color. A beautiful little head on it. Great lacing throughout the glass. 

Smell: Not bad, not great. I didnt get much. It sort of is similar to the taste, but more muted.

Taste: Easily the best porter Ive had. I havent had many, but I HAVE had Founders Porter, and this trumps that without question. Theres almost a slight earthy flavor upfront, with that great, to-be-expected coffee and chocolate flavor through the rest of the sip. Really great.

Mouthfeel: Probably because I had it on tap, but creamy and delicious, like a good porter should be.

Overall, one of the best beers Ive had, period. I drank this with FISH AND CHIPS and loved every last drop of it. Theres really nothing bad to be said about Edmund Fitzgerald, but it does have me wondering. Why does "Great Lakes Brewing Company" exist in OHIO when they have ONE Great Lake bordering their state? Also, the Edmund Fitzgerald sunk in Lake Superior -- a Great Lake nowhere near Ohio. While I dont get the reasoning for the name of the brewery or the beer, this is still quality.

UPDATED: JUN 15, 2014 Bottle share at Sybarite Pig. Dark brown, deep amber pour. Light head and some lace. Has a deep coffee aroma with currants, raisins and roasted nuts. Taste is not heavy but large coffee taste. A little heavy on carbonation and a little yeasty. Pleasant after taste and a mild finish. Mouth feel is pleasant.

Not quite the fan as others seem to be, but still a very good porter! Some dark chocolate and a hint of coffee with a slightly dry, bitter finish. Lots of roasted malts with hoppy overtones that Im, personally, not really looking for in a porter. A great representation of the style that deserves to be tried... just not my cup-o-tea, erm... beer.

Tap. Pours deep brown to black with a small tan head, creamy with nice lacing. Aroma is coffee, chocolate, roasted malt, light mint, vanilla. Flavor is the same, lightly sweet and just a bit of bitterness. Medium body, creamy mouthfeel. Quite nice

Bottles, pours dark brown or light black with thick head and lacing. Aromas of roasted malt, chocolate cake, rich barely, nice hops, and coffee. Medium to fuller bodied for a porter. Light carbonation to give it a super creamy mouth. Really enjoyed this one.

12 oz. bottle. BBD 4/10/13. Pours a medium thick, well retained, light beige head, with some lacing, over a clear dark brown (SRM 30) body......nose is light coffee, chocolate, light toffee/caramel, hints of smoke.....taste is chocolate, coffee, light toffee/caramel,hints of smoke,  finishing with a moderate, but lingering roasted malt, hop bitterness.....mouth feel medium,  minimal astringency, carbonation adds a medium foaminess. This is a well done Robust Porter and meets the style almost exactly. The roasted malts are in ascendance, with the hops present but not dominant. Complexity in both aroma and flavor are exactly where they should be. BJCP 8/3/16/5/8
Chocolate malt aroma hits the nose instantly upon pouring.  Chocolate and coffee in the flavor.  Deep sweet malty taste with a bit of smoke.  Great stuff.

Edmund Fitzgerald pours milky and dark. The beer has an excellent wet sandy brown head with solid lacing. The aroma is rather roasty with chocolate and coffee malts. The flavor is somewhat smokey, coffee and chocolate malts up front with a floral hop finish. Overall this is a delicious porter and I recommend it to everyone.

Draft sampled at Frankford Hall courtesy of Andrew. Pours a deep black body with dark brown head and lacing. Aroma is deep roast, dark chocolate and sweet roasted malt. Mouthfeel is medium with notes of rich roast, chocolate, light hop and sweet malt. Overall a very solid porter.
Nice porter, poured from a bottle, bit of coffee and chocolate and a nice bitter taste.
Very true to style.  An unbalanced harshness to it, though.  Malt is overly agressive.  All around a fine beer, especially for style, but comes up a bit ordinary.

Got a six pack as a gift for Christmas.  Just not a fan of this style of beer.  Never been a coffee drinker and this porter has hints of chocolate-coffee flavor.  My guess is that porter fans would find this beer enjoyable, just not for me.
Very good beer overall, roasty aroma, chocolate, coffee, taste, and strong finish, best before midnight.
Edmund Fitzgerald Porter is my favorite from the Great Lakes Brewery.  I make a visit there 1-2 times per year to fill a growler fresh from the tap at the brewery.
Huge fresh brewed coffee nose with hazelnuts for me. Almost overpowering. Palate was a good surprise with chocolate spice and caramel. Bitter finish but overall well done.
I was quite surprised by this beer. The dark malty colors also came across in a caramelly-nutty aroma. The body was very smooth yet full bodied. The aftertaste was a bit of spice and lingering.
Very dark brown.  Smoky, dark malt, licorice,  lingering smokyness.  Good stuff for something always easy to find.
Dark brown and almost black with a frothy head that dissipates rather quickly - taste includes coffee-chocolate notes. This is a medium bodied beer.

On tap at ChurchKey. Dry yeast takes the stage first and foremost. Too much so, in fact, as the dryness tends to dwarf the roasty base. I enjoy the body and appearance. A solid porter, not hype-worthy.

Bouteille 12oz, courtoisie de Hogtownharry ou Blankboy. De couleur noire-brune et opaque. Nez de malt rôti, moyen de café, léger de chocolat noir avec des notes de caramel, de fruits (raisins et cerises noires), de noix et de houblon herbeux aux petites notes résineuses. Moyennement ronde en bouche avec un pétillement moyen et une texture légèrement crémeuse. Goût très légèrement fruité (léger de raisins et de prunes et traces de cerises noires) aux notes faibles notes lactiques (chocolat au lait) ainsi quavec des traces de fumée de bois lors de lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute rapidement un goût moyennement de malt rôti (faibles notes brûlées) avec des notes de chocolat noir, de caramel, de mélasse ainsi que quelques traces de pain grillé puis en finale on distingue progressivement un goût légèrement plus amer et sec de café noir et léger de houblon assez herbeux avec des notes résineuses et de de noix. Post-goût long et un peu sec, léger-moyen amer de rôti, léger de café et de houblon herbeux, avec des traces de chocolat noir, de fruits (moût de raisins et pelures de prunes) et de noix.

One of the beers i always keep in the fridge.  Consistent good, roasty taste.
Great Lakes is good for a handful of good beers, just as a Stone, Bells, etc

While this one is not as dark as their Blackout Stout, I enjoy this for being a happy medium between that and their lighter beers. Has the usual coffee-chocolate taste as another user has said. Though this one is nice and filling and is a great American Porter.

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2013 Dark brown pour with light brown head. Smells of caramel, roast nuts and coffee. Roast coffee and chocolate dominate with a bitter sweet finish. Bitter hangs out just a little to long, but still great.
Im not changing my rating, but damn.  Just had this with a Hersheys milk chocolate with almonds.  Nice.
This one had to grow on me. At first it has a familiar coffee-chocolate porter body but is followed by a bittersweet and savoury finish. The more you have it, the more you fall in love with it.
Dark brown with a medium tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, big chocolate notes, light smoke. Rich, sweet flavor with some light bitterness. Super smooth palate. Long delicious finish.

12oz bottle. Dark, dark brown, not quite black, 1" light brown/tan head, medium lacing. Sweet, roasted aroma. Taste is same, very mild bitterness, perfectly balanced and S M O O T H with a clean finish. If there is a better porter, I really need to try it!

Draft. Pours black with medium head. Light lacing. Aroma of chocolate, coffee and fig. Staple Porter. A true "go to"!

----Hophaze out

Very dark brown pour with quarter inch cream head. Eggy scent, cream, malt and bitter licorice like aroma. Moderate carbonation, tangy mouth feel. Wash of roasted flavors. Dark dried fruits, fog, nuts and bitter licorice, it gives way to a flat citrus hop taste. Finish is slightly dry and sour/lactose-laden. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 ounce bottle into signature pint glass, best before 4/22/2013.  Pours crystal clear very dark reddish brown color with a nice 1-2 finger fairly dense khaki head with nice retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers.  Spotty soapy lacing clings down the glass.  Aromas of chocolate, caramel, roasted malt, toast, toffee, light coffee, light citrus, and earthy hops.  Damn nice aromas with nice balance, strength, and complexity.  Taste of milk chocolate, caramel, roasted malt, toffee, toast, coffee, cocoa, and light herbal.  Light amount of roasted coffee bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of milk chocolate, caramel, toast, roasted malt, toffee, coffee, and light herbal on the finish for a good bit.  Fantastic balance of robust flavors with nice roasted malt complexity; and zero cloying flavors present after the finish.  Medium carbonation and body; with a smooth and creamy mouthfeel that is very nice.  Alcohol is very well hidden with only a slight warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is a fantastic porter!  Fantastic roasted flavor balance and complexity, with some nice hop balance; and extremely smooth to drink.  A highly enjoyable offering as expected; one of my top favorite porters.

Aroma: rich chocolate, coffee, some toffee, some piney hops.  Pours black, khaki head with good retention and lots of lacing.  Flavor: big chocolate and roast presence, coffee, pleasant sweetness nicely balanced by the hops.  Medium body and carbonation, very smooth and drinkable.  Really great brew.
Good full body with a bit of a roasted sense to it.  Nice malt flavoring as well.

bottle.  light brown with ruby highlights and small tan head.  roasty, burnt nose.  flavor is dry and unsweet with charred roasted grains and bitterness.  faint floral hop notes in finish with a medium body.

Bottle from my secret Santa. Pours clear dark ruby with a big creamy tanned head.Aroma of dark chocolate, very weak roasted malts. Taste is roasty dark bitter chocolate, nice soft mouthfeel, lingering dry and roasty chocolate finish. Very good porter.
UPDATED: FEB 28, 2014 Dark but not pitch black. Medium to full body. Flavors are all well balanced with nothing overtaking. Smooth and satisfying

Head- 2 fingers of light tan lusciousness with a moderate amount of lacing. Smell- roasty but a little sweetness is in there too. Taste- chocolate and roasted malts, not much of a hop presence. Very smooth and drinkable. Overall- very pleasing porter!
Bottle, OH.  Nice roasted malt flavors sit well with the hops and the faint sweetness.  This is a porter I can enjoy for a short session on a regular basis.

Bottle.  Poured a deep, dark brown with a beige head that stuck around for a bit.  Aroma was of dark, roasted malt.  Flavor followed with a hint of chocolate and perhaps coffee.  A good porter.  Id definitely have it again.

The one thing that stood out while drinking this porter; the head lacing is incredible.  Looked like a frosted-rings glass when I finished. Pours coffee dark with tan head of about 1in in stem glass. Aroma is typical porter with chocolate/roasted coffee smell, maybe a hint of raisin, and resin from hops.
Good blend of hoppiness and bakers chocolate in the beer flavor. Good to excellent finish. Better than average but not perfect. 4 out of 5

Aroma of coffee, roasted malts, and chocolate. Pours an opaque black with a quickly dissipating tan head and minor lacing. Taste is rich. Roasted malts, rich smooth coffee, hints of chocolate with a nice bitter note in the finish. Medium-full body with medium soft carbonation. Overall, this is an excellant porter. Very tasty. Very rich. Vey drinkable.

Fairly black color..bottle pour into pint glass..1/2 finger head that is light brown..typical porter aroma..nose is pleasant..notes of cream,vanilla, chocolate and a bit of anise..mouthfeel is quite nice..getting the smokey notes on the finish as well which is enjoyable..dark and rich..a very solid porter...

Was honestly hoping for more from what I have heard about this beer. I think I rated this higher than I should. Color is black with ruby highlights and a white head about 1/2 finger white head. Aroma was very much the roasted malts with a hint of cocoa. Taste was similar to the aroma with high carbonation and a light mouthfeel for a porter.

Draft at CLE. Pour a deep, dark brown color with a nice, frothy off-white head. Nice coffee and dark chocolate in the aroma. Not too overpowering in the taste. You can definitely sense the coffee with the chocolate in the background. A very well done porter.
Black pour with a beige head. Aroma is roasted malt, bittersweet chocolate. Taste is roasted malt, chocolate, and a dry aftertaste. A tasty beer. Nice lacing.

A: Malty. Some underlying caramel. No real hop presence to speak of.
A: Poured clean, dark brown. Opaque so it looks black. Poured with a fizzy, tan head that dispersed to nothing fairly quickly.
T: While the caramel tones from the aroma are there, a nice roasted coffee quality becomes apparent. Roast, but without any real acrid bitterness. Hops balance out the finish with some flavor and dry bitterness. The parts all work together.
P: Full and well carbonated. At first glance, the carbonation gave the beer and head an almost cola-like appearance. 
O: Solid porter. Very well balanced. Each piece leads into the next with nothing dominating. I can see this becoming a regular beer to keep on hand.

Pours dark, translucent brown..nearly black, but not quite.  Aroma of roasted malt, caramel corn.  Flavor is roasty, lightly sweet, a touch of bittersweet chocolate, an interesting malt flavor, with a semi-dry finish.  A fairly unique porter.

12oz bottle thanks to SpdKilz, appreciate it man. Dark black color, good head. The aroma is smoky sort of, dark malts and a hint of smoke like a burnt match, average. The flavor is better, roasty porter with a hint of chocolate and coffee. Im not sure why this is a top beer, tastes like an average porter to me.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-12-2011 18:43:06

Pours a ruby black, very little head retention and lacing. Aroma is laden with blackstrap molasses, as well as light roasted malts, coffee, roastyness. Body is somewhat light for the style, flavor is roasty and very floral. Tastes wonderful, just not my thing i think. A decent porter, not one of my favorites though.

What a nummy beer.  Not my favorite porter, but this one definitely has a great malty, coffee, chocolate flavor.  More chocolate than coffee (I imagine thats the idea) and I liked that.  Poured into a tulip (is that appropriate? I think so) and the head endures for a long time.  Residual sticky head on the sides of the glass, amazingly dark color; beautiful.  The taste is a medium-heavy sweet with a very hidden hop presence.  Must say I hated it the first time I tried it but feel like Im appreciating more subtle brews as I try more.

[bottle--thanks, Brad!]
Equal portions of vanilla, chocolate, and coffee in the nose along with faint accents of dried fruit and toasted hazelnuts. Opaque brown-black under a lasting, thin, light brown cover. Grainy vanilla and mocha flavour with a prominent sweetness complemented by a sweet, warming alcohol. A dark chocolate bitterness is there but balance is toward the sweet. Toasted hazelnuts come in late and this complex, sweet and grainy brew finishes relatively dry. Seems way bigger than only 5.8% abv. Full body, medium carbonation, surprisingly clean finish.

Bottle (12 oz). Traded by northropfrye, thanks Andrew! Dark brown with a medium mostly lasting beige head and some lacing. Aroma of coffee, roasted malt and chocolate. Taste is about the same but smoother with hoppy hints. Mouthfeel is a bit thin compared to aroma and taste. Slight acidic presence. Great complexity for a low abv beer. A very good and easy to drink porter.
Heavy but counterbalanced by a roast & chocolate fusion that makes the flavor outpace the weightiness

Bottle poured into pint glass.Nice, dark mahogany color, dark khaki head with great lacing. Dark bittersweet chocolate & coffee on the nose and moreso on the tongue. Enough hop presence to balance everything out. A go to porter. Nicely done.
This beer is the definition of a porter. It is excellent in every critical category. It every homebrewers dream to make beer like this

Black with little head. Aroma is coffee and chocolate. Flavor adds some smoky malts and some hop bitterness. Great body. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2013 Dark mahogony/red tones.Frothy creamy  lasting  tan head. Lacing.
Aroma of toasted malt,smooth mocha,herbal/earthy hops,slight good funk.
Great tasting smooth roast hops,mocha,some  hop herbal in flavor and bitter.Some roastyness in finish with the bitter. Balanced semi sweet with the mellow bittering. Awesome beer ,awesome aroma and taste.

A rich, dark porter with oak and malt flavors. Definitely for someone who likes dark beers that don't have to be chocolaty or milky. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Tap. Chocolate and molasses nose. Dry slightly hoppy and bitter taste, finishes with coffee roast. Easy drinking nicely done porter

on draft. poured dark brown color with little head...what was there left nice lacing on the glass...was a bit to cold at first. let it set and taste the magic. the aroma of roasted malts and bits of chocolate. nice little hop presence...the flavor was great. the roasted malts and chocolate combined with the hops created a wonderful blend in this porter. forgot how really good this one is.
Bottle->snifter.  Black pour settles to dark brown,little head with lace.  Very malty with some chocolate and coffee bitterness.  Overall a very very good beer.

Pours almost black, with a huge brown head and amazing lacing.  Aroma is roasted coffee.  Let it warm up a little bit out of the fridge to get the complexity of the flavor.  Taste is coffee with a little chocolate, with hops adding more dimension.  Palate is outstanding - very smooth.
Poured from a 12 oz bottle shared at home. Pours a reddish brown with a short-lived tan head. Aroma of coffee and chocolate. Smoky notes. Bitter finish.
Dark brown, almost black with brownish foam head. Aroma is roasted toast and chocolate. Taste is bittersweet chocolate, coffee and toffee. Short aftertaste. (Cleveland 201210)

Pours dark brown red with a large tan head. Smells chocolaty and roasted. Taste is roast and chocolate, hints of dark chocolate, and a bit of a burnt character. Medium-bodied with a smooth texture and soft mouth-carbonation, Great Lakes Edmund Fitzgerald Porter finishes with a tiny touch of bitterness.

Draft at lucky lab. Pours black with red around the rim of the glass. There is a small off white head that stays for a bit. The aroma is weak but has some light coffee and chocolate notes. The taste has a big mocha hit with a nice coffee bitterness on the finish. Mouth feel is medium.
Dark brown in colour. Not very pronounced aroma, but theres a maltiness coming through. Taste is dark chocolate, malts, and a touch of coffee. Not bad.

Very nice deep pour, black-brown with a true brown head.  Nice mouthfeel with a pleasing thickness, Mr. Fitzgerald stands up so far to the test of a good porter.  Theres nice roasted malt flavors, a touch of chocolate or coffee (but not an overabundance of either), and there is a truly pleasing malt sweetness that ties it all together.
Great smooth porter. Not chocolate or coffeee...just a smooth porter. Absolutely will have again.
UPDATED: JAN 26, 2014 Stout is very pleasant in aroma, dark appearance as expected, excellent taste, but is a little light on the palate.

Sparkling Palate. Not sure if it does it for me. Not sure if it does not. Light coffee flavor. Heavy and filthy taste. I feel a little dirty drinking this. A little wild. Did I just break the law?! Slight fruit notes. Did someone shave apple or pear bits in my glass?! Am I dreaming?! I feel as if I am on a sinking ship heading towards the bottom of a shallow giant and dirty lake. Well done  Edmund. The finish is cold and distant. Im shocked. Would I ever be so bold as to submerge myself in this wreck ever again? LIKELY.

Poured from 12 oz. bottle. 

Opaque, deep raspberry brown with small tan head and very good lacing. 

Aroma of coffee, chocolate, caramel, dark malt and a hint of peat. 

Taste of coffee, chocolate, dark roasted malt and toffee.  Stunningly delicious!  Wow.

Medium body and high carbonation join together to produce a rich and satisfying mouthfeel. 

An exceptionally good beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Great aroma, chocolate milk color head.  Belgian lace all the way down the glass.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours black. Fresh roasted coffee bean aromas. Flavours are dark coffee and toasted malts. Maybe a touch of dark chocolate. The palate is exquisite. Lightly carbonated, but mostly silky and soft...long lasting coffee finish. Very nice.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2012 Pours black with light head. Rich roasted coffee and chocolate nose. Flavor follows the smell, with very light carbonation. Robust mouthfeel. Good stuff. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Very dark brown with minimal head. Aroma is smokey, earthy hop, alcohol, and roasted malt. Flavor is mildly sweet with a moderate bitterness, but doesnt linger. Medium to heavy bodied. Nice strong porter.
Dark red color with creamy tan head. Nutty, roasted, caramel smell. Tastes the same along with coffee. Malty, and not bitter.  Rich feel with minimal carbonation.
Solid. Compared to Founders porter, this is a little less smooth and delicious. On its own, delicious.

12oz bottle into a pint glass.

Pours an opaque black with a thick one finger head. Really amazing head retention and lacing it just sticks around forever.

Aroma of dark chocolate and espresso. Tons of roast character and just a little bit of spicy hops.

Flavor is really where this beer stands out. Ridiculous amount of roast, chocolate, and coffee without a bitter, astringent mouthfeel which is hard to do. A real nice balance between chocolate and coffee with some hints of caramel thrown in. Mouthfeel is just a little on the thin side which is about the only drawback.

Really a world-class beer here. Just an amazing aroma and flavor without crazy amount of alcohol or bitterness. Everyone should try this beer at least once.
Bottle. Very dark - opaque.  Roasty, deep almost smoky aroma. Very good - strong, roasty coffee-like flavor. Nice hoppiness, too.
This is by far one of the best dark beers out there. Im not even joking. If this is available in your area you must buy it right now. Go. What are you waiting for?

Fresh bottle in a pint glass. Pours a rich dark brown/black with a fingers worth of tan head that leaves ok lacing. Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, a little smoke and dark fruit. Taste is more roasted malts. Toasted barley, coffee, a little semi-sweet chocolate, and a touch of cream. Mild hop bitterness at the end. Thin mouthfeel and easy to drink a lot of. Great porter, one of the best.

Bottled.  Pours a deep ruby brown.  Beige head with good retention.  Caramel and coffee on the nose.  Bitter bite of roasted malt up front, great notes of dark chocolate and bittersweet coffee.  Warm alcohol finish with final dry kick of pleasantly bitter roast malt.  Rich, smooth mouthfeel, full-bodied.  A very good porter, nicely balanced and warming.

On tap at Philadelphia Airport. By far the best of the three Great Lakes beers I sampled. A deep chocolate brown colour with a thin cream head; and an aroma of deeply roasted chocolate malts; the flavour was like liquidised chocolate fudge cake, rich and sweet; but then theres a good dry hoppy bitterness to coutnerbalance the sweetness and reveal some deeply toasted malts.

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2013 One of the best porters around, period. Extremely balanced flavor, pillowy texture and cream colored head sit atop a lovely dark brown pour. Velvet texture, bittersweet bakers chocolate taste compliment a hoppy, coffee beer.

Soapy black pour. Great smell of espresso, oak and roast. It has a certain indefinable quality. Not exactly chocolate...not exactly coffee. Smooth and bitter with a great balance of hops, malt, and sweet fruit. Medium carbonation, medium body

This was one of the first really good porters Id ever had.  It was the only beer being sold at the Chicago Symphony at the time, it is reoriented my perception of good porters.  It was certainly the first Great Lakes beer Id had (and would have for awhile considering I lived in Louisiana at the time).  Since then, Ive discovered that this is a good example of Great Lakes consistent quality.  Rich, dark, with a syrupy chocolate goodness.  Perfect balance with the hops and a touch of dark fruit.

This is a great porter from the great lakes. Pours dark with a thick coffee colored head. Strong coffee and dark coco notes. A great beer for tailgating or day drinking. You cant go wrong with this one.

Draft. Pours dark with a persistent tan head. Sweet, smoky aroma that goes over to the taste. Taste is a bit overly sweet with the perfect balance of toasted malt. What every porter should strive for.

Aroma: malt and chocolate come through in the nose. Appearance: dark brown with a tan two finger head. Taste: lots of dark, roasted malts.  Sweet chocolate also comes through. Palate: pretty thick in the beginning and smooths out for a sweet finish. Has a slight bitter finish as well. Overall: this is a very well put together porter.

Solid porter, very smooth finish. Flavor is of chocolate and coffee,  without the smoke porter finish I dislike so much. Mouth feel is a bit oily, but overall palate is excellent. Pour is dark brown black with creamy white head.
Great porter for the money. Had in bottle. Good malt and hop balance. Lots of flavor packed in.
Solid porter.  Roasted caramel malt nose with thick fading head and persistent lace.  Dark mahogany brown.  Aggressive hop finish on a standard porter.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2012 Aroma is chocolate, roasted malts, some coffee. Appearance is dark, opaque yet a slight ruby. Tastes of roasted malts, coffee, caramel and then some chocolate at the end. The mouthfeel is not too sticky, but it hangs around. Overall, for my second porter I think I chose wisely, I would definitely drink it again.

This is one of my favorite porters and probably the best beer from Great Lakes at least of the ones Ive had. Pours a dark ruby/black into the glass with a creamy tan head. Big coffee, chocolate, and roasted malts on the nose. The flavor is exceptional, lots of coffee and chocolate characters, very rich and robust. Finish is long and creamy. Delicious!

Poured into a Williamsburg Winery wine glass.

A: Pours a dark brown body betrayed by its ruby red edges near the glass. It also features a three finger light mocha colored head with a nice frothy texture and spots of decent lacing.

S: Chocolate, roasted malt, dark fruit, coffee, brown sugar, and a touch of earth. Really fantastic; proof that an excellent smelling beer doesnt need to be in your face to impress.

T: This is a porter that eschews boldness for subtlety, and its all the better for it. An initial wave of chocolate hits the tongue, followed by notes of coffee, roast, smoke, raisin, hazelnut; while the finish sees a return of the coffee notes along with a slight noble hop component. Finish lasts a long time, as well. One of the more complex porters Ive had, yet all of the notes in the flavor profile are balanced with one another. Only real flaw is that mine was served a bit too warm, and it negatively affected the flavor slightly; course its not like it really matters...

M: Has a medium body, with a dry, long lasting, bittersweet finish and decent carbonation. A textbook porter in this regard.

O: If you want proof that a light(er) beer can satisfy as well as some of the big, bruising behemoths in the beer world, look no further than this bad boy. Not only that, its hella drinkable, to boot! Ill definitely be on the look for this one in the future.

12oz bottle. Courtesy of mike67. Pours a deep dark reddish brown with a medium brown lasting creamy head. Aroma and Taste of rich dark roasted chocolate malt, some caramel and liquorice notes, and yeast with some bitter notes. Palate is a rich full body, slightly oily with good carbonation. Finish is of roasted caramel malt, dark cacao bitterness, some hops bitterness ending with some lingering dark chocolate notes. Overall a great tasty and all around solid porter.

Pours a dark brown with a dissipating tan head and aroma of chocolate and roasted malt. Taste is of sweet, of chocolate, roasted malt, liquorice, and coffee with a toasty, bitter finish. Well balanced and great tasting brew, nice flavors brought out.

Pours a dark deep black color with a small head. Nose is a clean roasted chocolate malt. Taste is full of flavor, with deep dark chocolate and coffee notes. Finish is bittersweet and moderately long. Very nice porter ! Quaff Score 8 / 10

I was surprised by the sweet coffee notes, like I had a house blend with two sugars. I used to work nights, after my shift I would love to have two of these before calling it a day. Nothing bad to say about this one.

Balance all the way through, and a finish that may rival the best beers Ive ever tasted. Nothing ever seems overpowering, as if everything is working together all the time. Yet it remains complex even after you swallow and the flavors are still on your tongue. All the smells above seem discernible, in addition to a lingering fruitiness that I cant pin down. Amazing.

A-- Poured dark brown and settled black. One finger light brown head, good lacing with it. No visible carbonation.

S-- Roasted malts, chocolate and coffee. Chocolate is dark and rich. Coffee and malts were a little thin.

T-- Coffee, chocolate and a little bit of lemon bitterness.

M-- Coffee and chocolate feel with the lemon being in the middle of the palate. Lower medium carbonation and a big robust feel. Bitter coffee finish.

D-- Easy to drink and a nice porter. Quite complex and well balanced.

Strong aroma w/ strong coffee flavor. Bold in taste & appearance. Light creamy head that dissolves quickly & goes down smooth...

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Chocolate coffee deliciousness.  This is a heavy flavorful porter that goes down smooth. One of my favorites.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Botlled. Thx to my summer Santa gt2. Dark Brown coloured. Dense light Brown head. Aroma of Cocoa, chocolate, roast, sweetness, grass, light herbs. Flavour of Cocoa, chocolate, roast, grass, Vague smoke, vague fruits. Medium to full bodied. Roasted bitter end. Nice.

On draft at Churchkey in D.C.

A: Very dark brown with a thick inch of beige head. The retention is excellent and the glass is coated with sticky lacing.

S: Roast, chocolate. The aroma is more subtle than the taste.

T: Wow. This beer is fantastic. Rich and roasty with delicious chocolates.

M: Great feel. Medium bodied with perfect carbonation. Chocolates linger in the finish.

D: I could easily throw back several of these.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 12-05-2010

12oz bottle. Rating #1356. Dark brown/black color with a small tan head. Dark chocolate and a slight coffee roast in the aroma. Mild flavor up front, a dark fruitiness that I wasnt expecting, very nice, follpwing that was more chocolate and coffee. Tasty stuff. (2442)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Coffee, toffee, molasses notes from an almost Stout like dark brown pour. Thick light brown head
Pours a nice ebony/brown...thick head.  Aromas of chocolate, coffe and roasted malt.  Smokey flavor initially, with tiny hints of chocolate.  Bitter finish, almost too much.

Bottle into pint glass.
A- Deep brown, 1 finger light brown head
S- Roasty, malty, even a bit of rye
T- Not very malt, a bit of roast, tastes a bit thin overall.
M- Thin, crisp carbonation
O- Probably wouldnt buy again, nothing special, nothing to warrant the price or the high ratings.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 06-09-2012 03:16:28

From tap at Churchkey. Pours hazy dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma is fruity, dark roasted malty and light caramelish. Smooth fruity, toasted malty and medium sweet. Bitter and lingering fruity into the finish.

Pours dark brown with khaki head. Smells of smooth velvety barley and kinda buttery. The taste is nice and smooth, very easy and rounded. A smooth light semi sweet chocolate covers the grainy earthy body. Mild hops balance nicely to an almost dry finish. The carbonation is also light, almost creamy making the whole brew very smooth and enjoyable even as it warms. Top notch 6 pack porter.
Had this one at Melt in Cleveland. Outstanding porter with a bit more smoothness, sweetness, and great weight on the palate.
Bottle pours a brown beer with a tiny tan head. Scent is sweet chocolate malt and coffee. Taste is same with roasty notes.

(12oz bottle) Dark brown, opaque body with a big light brown head, leaves some lacing on the glass. Dark roasted malt, caramelized sugar, some coffee and chocolate notes. Light-medium body, moderate carbonation, ends a little watery. Flavor is sweet; burnt notes are muted, not as strong as in the aroma. Lots of fruit (berries, cherry, citrus peel); bitter finish and aftertaste.

Bottle on a July 2012 trip to Ann Arbor. 

Cocoa nose, slightly ashy. Good balance of mild sweetness with drying coffee. Nary a flaw in sight, but could not be more different from the orchard-fruit of a Fullers porter. I can see why this is a classic, but for me it lacks the spark that would push it into the 4s.
Bottle: Fruity aroma of plums, cherries, roasted malt, burnt cacao beans and some acid. Black color.  Flavor is medium sweet, malty, roasty with notes of  cacao, fruity with notes  of dark fruits.

Cereal flavor on the front with a sweet finish on the palate.  Raisins notes with a hint of smoke.  Pours root beer brown with a slight tan head that thins to bubbles.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. The pour was a deep dark pitch black with a huge (3-4 finger) medium tan frothy head that was fully lasting and possessed excellent streaky lacing.

The aroma was of roasted chocolate malt and leathery yeast with notes of dark chocolate, roasted coffee, molasses and a touch of smoke.

The taste was very malty with a mild sweet chocolate note at first, but then the taste shifted slightly to a mild bitterness with a good strong coffee presence and a light sweet molasses ending. The flavor hung on for a very long time proceeding the swallow with a nice bitter coffee taste left to linger on the taste buds.

Mouthfeel was almost full in body with a dry oily texture and a medium carbonation.

Overall this is a great tasting Porter that was quite easy going down and had an exceptional bold robust flavor, making this one hek of an enjoyable drinking experience

Bottle from trade. This one came as an extra, and it's excellent, perhaps my new favorite porter next to Fullers (it is a bit "fuller" though...no pun originally intended). Aroma is lighter than the flavor, yet both are roasty, chocolately, and light roast coffee (along the Kona line). Just a great, full mouthfeel with a smooth palate. I held onto this one longer than the 'enjoy by' date, so I imagine this wasn't what the brewer intended (I.e. subdued, if not non-existent hops). Still, a great beer!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A - Pours a dark brown color with a big finger-plus of frothy brownish head. The head fades down very slowly leaving behind some nice lacing.

S - Aroma is a mix of coffee, roasted dark chocolate, with some vanilla sweetness and a touch of smoke character.

T - Starts off with a mix of dark chocolate with some like smoke and vanilla bean and a touch of licorice. Through the middle, come coffee comes through with some more roasted flavors and a bit of bitter cocoa. The finish is a mix of dark chocolate, vanilla bean, coffee, and licorice.

M - Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth with a dry, roasty, and sweet finish.

D - Very drinkable. Really nice balance of flavors and it really goes down smooth.

Sample at the brewery but I swear I have tried and/or bought this beer at several points since moving to OH. Anyway, a classic porter: nice dark roasted malt with hints of chocolate and coffee. Straight from the script.
Poured from a 12 ounce bottle. Roasted malts, chocolate, caramel malts, fruity. A nice roasty beer, a little sweet, but a good beer none the less.

Poured into a mug from a 12 oz. bottle. Pours a black color with alight tan head that doesnt last very long and didnt leave much lacing.  Aroma of roasted malt, heavy on the coffee and light on the chocolate. Awkward bitter initial mouthfeel but hard to put my finger on it. Notes of the coffee and chocolate. Light on overall flavor but heavy on the mouthfeel. Maybe its the higher carbonation. Back-end is a little smoother with tastes of coffee and maybe some caramel. Overall a decent beer, not sure if Id buy it again.

Bottle while in bed at 5 wasting the afternoon away in some dive hotel in west virgina.  pours jet black with nice head.  great rich aromas of chocolate and coffee.  tastes smokey, and of chocolate, cola, coffee, earth, and wood.  its rich and creamy but quite drinkable.  delicious

Aroma/Malty-Ligth, Appearance Head/size-small, Head/Color-light brown, Head/Longevity-fully diminishing, Body/Hue-light, Initial Flavor/bitter moderate, Finish Flavor/bitter ligth, Palate Body/light, good beer
Smells of coffee of chocolate.  Taste is the same.  Great representation of the style.

Pours a deep black with brown edges, nice tan head sits on top. Light lacing on the glass. Smells sweet and slightly roasted. Tastes great especially for it being a 10 dollar 6 pack. Sweet, smokey, and toffee.

Bottle.  Pours black with a medium tan head.  Smell is initially dark but sweet roast, tinge of smoke, coffee and cocoa.  Taste is sweet, yet dark on roast, chocolate and burnt old coffee.  Slight veggie hint in the finish.  Medium mouthfeel with creamy finish.  Nice overall.

Pours deep dark and black. Carmel head and sticky lacing crowd the glass. Aromatics are fairly absent (my beer was poured a little bit too cold). First taste highlight the higher carbonation and strong roasted flavors present. Secondary tastes are Carmel, coffee, and malt.

Pours nearly black with ruby backlights...short tan head.
Scent is coffee, a little smoke, dark chocolate...
Flavour is semi-sweet chocolate, smoke, a slight coffee/ hoppy bitter.
Really enjoyed this one.

6/1/12- Dark brown and ruby highlights with a 1f khaki head. Aromas of coffee, brown sugar, and smoky charred malts. Medium soda-like mouthfeel with poppy carbonation. Coffee, vanilla, caramel, and a slight hop and smoke bitterness on the lingering finish. Pleasant sweet porter that's balanced with nice hop and smoke presence. This I'll have again.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Porters are crowd pleasers and this one fits the style.  Its a little more carbonated than I prefer, and Id like to try the nitro version. Its nutty, malty, and a deep, dark brown.  Theres a nice dark brown foam on top too.  Coffee bounces out, and if it werent for the spastic palate feel, it would crack my list of top porters.

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2013 This is the best 9.99 you can spend on a 6-pack of beer. What a wonderful brew! A friend said you couldnt beat the Edmund Fitzgerald for the price and boy was he right. Cant wait to try the entire Great Lakes lineup now.

Snifter from bottle. A: slight chocolate, slight coffee, slight hops. App: very dark cola color. 3 finger tan head. T: slight dryness and chocolate on the front, chocolate and almond in the middle, and slight chocolate on the back. P: very low bubbles, medium linger.

Just an all around pleasant porter from Great Lakes; hints of bitter dark chocolate, charcoal, and hops with lingerings of toffee and spelt. Really good stuff. And as usual, pours black as Batmans cape.

Pours a pitch black with a full, long lasting tan head.  Could be mistaken for a Guinness even.  Aroma is quite potent, quite smoky, heavy in coffee and chocolate.  Taste is less smoky, but contains a good deal more of chocolate and coffee.  Heavy in these flavors, yet not very sweet or bitter.  Very smooth and creamy.  Very satisfied with the full and robust impressions, this is still lighter and quite refreshing, even in the heat.  This one is excellent.

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2012 Got this in a summer variety pack on a recent trip to Ohio.  Poured dark black into a glass with tan head.  Aroma smelled rich and complex, sensed coffee, chocolate, roasted malts and some smokiness.  Taste was thick and full, not expected of a regular porter.  Very much enjoyed.

pours black with a great beige head. Aroma is very fishy. not very nice. Flaour is fantastic. bold roasted malts and chcocolate. very drinkable. medium body. very nice full palate. a very tasty beer.. but the fishy, soy sauce aroma is a real let down.

Black in color with shades of red at the edges of the glass. Thick, resilient tan head. The flavor is complex - hoppier than usual for the style. Roasted malts, medium sweetness, & a hint of coffee. Medium bodied. The finish is a little bitter (in a good way). Another great beer from an under-appreciated brewery.

Botled.  I had  been tasting a lot of porters, and this was the last of the night.  It really stuck out unexpectedly, after I thought my palate was about done.  Rich and complex, with smokiness, chocolate, and a full mouthfeel.

Bottle at windy city red hots - served in the bottle, so cant really comment on the appearance. Aroma is a bit mocha, which I like. Taste is a kiss on the bitter side without being annoying about it. Overall, I like!
Truly one of the nicest porters Ive had. Roasty chocolate malts, nutty taurine flavor with a hint of vanilla. All tastes come at the right time and finish cleanly.

The beer that made me fall in love with porters! 

Dark Opaque Black, Coffee, Chocolate, Cocoa and burnt malts are all very rich in both the scent and flavor. Great way to introduce someone to the Porter/Stout beer scene!

This has quickly become one of my most favorite porters out there that I can reguarly get at the store. Pours a dark brown, semi-translucent black color with an ash/brown head. Aroma is coffee chocolates, bittersweet, toasted malts. Palate is a sweet, smooth, solid, creamy one. Flavor is coffee, chocolate, with bittersweet malts. So good.
Rrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrdedrrdd via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Not much head retention but decent lacing. Lighter kind of black colour. Smells like roasted malt, a little blackened caramel. Good carbonation level. Light coffee taste on the after, some alcohol and a decent overall body. Pretty good. Bottle from Wegmans in Niagara.
deep brown, nearly black. aroma of coffee and chocolate. very smooth. rich maltiness, again with coffee and chocolate goodness. an excellent porter.

Thanks Beersis

Pours deep deep red with less than a finger of off white head. 

Smell is roast and coffee, very well balanced.

Taste is great. Creamy and choco, coffee, and roast. Well done.

MF was medium bodied. 

Good beer.

One of the very best porters Ive had; its brews like this that remind me why I love this style so much. The taste of Cleveland, to me. A soft coffee/chocolate flavour balances just so perfectly with the aroma. The aftertaste just leaves me smiling. Wish it were available here.

[Thanks to MatSciGuy]. 12fl. oz. bottle. Poured ab lack beer with a nice formation of an off-white head, nice lacing, decent lasting and dense. Aroma is moderate bittery, smoky, toasty and roasty. Flavour is moderate strong roasty, licorice, with hints of black coffee and black chocolate, slightly spicy and smoky. Carbonation is medium. Body is medium. Texture is slightly oily.

Originally reviewed: 12/3/08. Pours a deep dark cola color with about an inch and a half tan head. Pretty good retention and excellent lacing rings. This beer looks good. Smells like a usual porter. Some roasted chocolate, some espresso, slight burnt scent. 

Porters are one of my favorite styles, but this one is one of the best Ive had. Great roasted flavors pull through, but dont leave the burnt bite at the end. Some nice cocoa flavor, but not sweet. Very smooth and creamy, but with a crisp mouthfeel. This beer is plenty drinkable. Highly recommend.
On draft pour.  Pitch black.  Nice body.  Nice chocolate malt.  Well balanced,  light coffee,

I'm not enough of a beer snob yet to know all of the reasons why, but I am sure that I really didn't like this beer. Maybe it'll grow on me, but the one I had, packaged in a bottle served in a pint glass, didn't bring me any joy.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Yet another amazing beer and my personal favorite porter for drinkability and style. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This is a very good porter, though not the best Ive had.  Next Ill try Founders which everyone says is better.

Aroma is of bitter/semi-sweet chocolate with french roast coffee and toasted nut of some sort.  Maybe even a bit of maduro cigar.  Its robust but not overpowering.

Its a pretty dark brown beer.  Very little light comes through.  Starts with a brownish head that dissipates fast.  Very little but nice lacing.

Taste mirrors the aroma except its more bitter.  Besides the chocolate and coffee being the main tastes coming through, there definitely is a bit of toasted nut and maybe weirdly enough, even a bit of oyster.

Its medium bodied and has some decent carbonation.  It has a slightly more bitter finish than I am used to for a porter.

Overall its a pretty good beer and worth drinking again.

From bottle into Lagunitas mason jar. Pours dark brown with a weak head. Aroma is classic porter, leaning more towards the roast side than the coffee side. Flavor covers the spectrum from earthy to chocolate to roasty to malty. Lots of burnt toast in the finish. Another really solid offering from Great Lakes.
Tap at Blue Tusk. Lots of coffee and roasted malt. Lively carbonation. Pours black with great lacing. Lovely beer.

Draft pours a very dark brown nice head. Smells tastes of roasted malt coffee small amount of chocolate. Theres not much I can say about this maybe my palet was tired idk I traded to my buddy for his hopper beer. Too much roastedness going on. Could take it and I normally would like a beer like this.
Dark brown pour, ample tan head,  Some coffee and caramel but predominantly roasted malts.  A solid brew but not on the level of the best (such as Founders).  A bit too malty for my taste.

UPDATED: NOV 10, 2012 A great looking porter. Pitch black, thicky cream head that stayed for a very long time.  Rich coffee and chocolate aroma with a hint of cream. Great taste of coffee and chocolate, nicely balances.  Light grassy hops. The creaminess from the head comes through too. Very smooth finish. A really good porter.
This is a spirited porter.   Dark orange glow through the glass.  Gorgeous to look at.  Very enjoyable.

Clear dark brown with a fine brown head and minimal lace.  The taste is black coffee and malt that grows as it moves through the palate, finishing with a dry, bittersweet hop bittering.  A solid porter in the grand tradition - not overly assertive, plenty to enjoy.

Black with hints of ruby and copper in it. Nice off white head. HUGE roasted aroma with hints of coffee and subtle traces of chocolate. Huge coffee taste with notes of chocolate, its just enough to attempt to balance the bitter roastiness, assertive in everyway.
Draught at Lexington Beerworks. Creamy slight chocolate and roast porter. Good overall, but not as rich as a body as a Founders.

Bottle.  Appearance: very dark brown almost completely opaque with 1 mocha tan head. Aroma: very roasty malt and sweet milk chocolate aromas with hint of vanilla.  Taste: big roasty coffee notes up front and throughout, some of that sweet milk chocolate but much less than was on the nose, some touches of dried fruits that I cant put my finger on (maybe hop florals/citrus), finishes very bittersweet dry coffee and some hops. Mouthfeel: thin to medium body and mild to medium carbonation, dry aftertaste. Overall: its a very good porter.  The hops really make themselves more present than Im used to which I love.  I just really enjoy a stout a bit more.  Porter to me is like a watered down stout.  But, for the style (and honestly in general) its a really solid beer that I would definitely buy again.  Its the first Great Lakes beer Ive had and very promising to me.

Bottle. Pours black thin brown lacing.  Roasty coffee and chocolate aroma. Taste is good balance of sweet and bitter, quite roasty and malty. Full body, lingering roast and hop finish. Very flavorful and drinkable porter.
In my opinion, the best porter on the face of the planet.  As good as they come.

Bottle. Reddish black color, tiny head. Nose of milk chocolate and yeast. Excellent smooth body with layers of toffee, chocolate cake, and heavily creamed coffee. One of the best, most sessionable full-bodied dark beers I've had.
Oh yeah. This one is dark and rich, Coffee flavors really come through on this one. Its super satisfying.
Nice dark brown color with a thin, quickly dissolving head.  Nice aroma with a hint of coffee.  Nice full body with a full creamy, coffee like finish.  A very nice porter.

12 oz. bottle pours an almost opaque dark brown, with a small tan head and a little lacing.  Aroma is malty with lots of chocolate and a bit of roasted coffe and caramel.  Taste is on the sweet side with some hops coming out in a drier finish.  This one has more carbonation and a thinner body than what I expected from a porter.  Still, a very enjoyable porter which I have tried several times before and will return to again.
Very smooth Porter not too malty, but still tastes like a Porter.  Not a strong Porter and it depends how you like Porters.  Personally likes Founders the best, but this more crisp with subtle taste.

Head: poured from bottle with thick off-white head. Good head retention, leaves significant lacing.
Color: Black, Not transparent. 
Aroma: Lightly coffee, malty 
Taste: Roasted malts, coffee, noticeable carbonation for a porter. More watery than silky. 
Finish: Coffee, light bitterness in aftertaste Lingers. 
Overall impression: Pleasant beer all around. Lot going on in the initial taste, leaves a nice light roasted taste in the finish. A warming, relaxing beer probably best drunk in the winter season.
Dark almost opaque brown color. Tan creamy head with good lace. Good balance Carmal malt and floral hops. With good feel on the palate.

Dark brown body with a nice tan head. Full malty, chocolate, and caramel aroma - with a mild scent of coffee in the background. coffee, roasted malt, dark chocolate flavor - followed by a lingering coffee aftertaste with a little roasted malt bitterness. Nice smooth mouthfeel, although just a little thinner than I prefer in a porter.
A strong mix of smoky, chocolatey, coffeey goodness. A bit strong on the smokiness is the only negative to this porter. Definitely one of the beers that could take the place of meat in a meal!

12 oz bottle pours black with a tan head.  Aroma is roasted malts and coffee.  Taste is malts, coffee and bittersweet chocolate.  Really nice beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: NOV 7, 2015 Nice, clean porter with a mellow aroma of roasted malts and dark chocolate and a bitter taste that continues these notes, with an incredibly nice dark chocolate and coffee finish. The mouthfeel is thin but refreshing. Very good.
Bottle, so aroma and appearance tough to rate, however the taste and palate make up for that. Wonderful balance with roasted malt flavors. Lingering but not overpowering finish. A great porter.

From notes.  First reviewed 12/8/2010.  Poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a pint glass.

Black mixed with walnut brown color with a ruby tint, not really much light escaping through here. A nice creamy tan head forms with the pour. 
The lace lingers a few centimeters above the beer level and inches its way down.

Milk chocolate, caramel, and roasted coffee dominate the nose.

 The milk creamy sweetness starts out the flavor by combining sweet caramel, a latte like espresso flavor, and some roasted malt. A kick of spice and herbal hops impart a light hoppy bite. The finish keeps a good part of the coffee, cream, and herbal hop flavors.

Creamy smoothness and carbonation with a full body. Although the start is very creamy, the feel becomes more dry toward the end. 

I found this to be a very drinkable porter. Great Lakes has some very good offerings, and this falls in their category of well-done, medium ABV, drinkable beers with some character.

Appearance: traditional porter color with brown highlights. Creamy head that disapates quickly 

Smell: hint of coffee aroma 

Taste: very good with a hint of malt and hops. Nothing un settling here. 

Mouthfeel: excellent, very smooth. 

Drinkability: I personally dont find many porters to be session beers... but this one is to me this is what a porter should be.

Rated via BeerBuddy

Pours black with thick and creamy tan head. Mostly diminishing, but it leaves some noce lacing. The aroma is coffee, chocolate and caramel. The flavor starts rich and roasted - chocolate and caramel, and it ends with some piney bitterness.

Nice appearance. Brownish head. Dark brown cloudy body. Appears heavily carbonated. Ive been waiting to try this one for a while. Bittersweet finish. Sticks to my mouth and lasts a while. Nice beer for the price. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Really good beer.  The aroma is malts and light sweet hops.  The taste is roasted malts coffee and finishes hoppy.

Draught pours deep brown with a khaki head. Aromas are chocolate and vanilla. Tastes are cocoa, chocolate syrup, vanilla and roasted malt. Very smooth and creamy mouthfeel.  Like velvet, very good. Up there with Founders Porter, which is saying something.

Poured into a shaker from a 12 ounce bottle best before 7/1/12.

A: Clear deep garnet body with a thick dense rocky head. Very appealing.

S: Rather faint sweet milk chocolate. I wish it were stronger here.

T: Sweet milk chocolate into a slightly roasted coffee and ending with bitter dark chocolate. Good balance here.

M: Medium bodied, slight sharp carbonation hits the tongue late.

O: Not as flavorful as other offerings like Founders Porter, but still a solid and very easily available porter worth trying.

Outstanding porter, bottle. Dark pour, blah, blah blah, buy it, drink it, and come tell me what you didnt like. Perhaps it wasnt the fine body and malty roasted coffee notes. Perhaps the bittersweet finish wasnt quite right, oh well, please let me know your Porter that does it better than this one, 
I have sampled plenty side by side , and this one is no slouch.
Dark translucent brown with a tint of red and a thin tan head. Roasty malt, cocoa, coffee flavor with a slight bitterness. Strong and punchy finish. A very good porter.

Ill admit im a Great Lakes fan. All of their beers are solid and very drinkable.
This beer pours dark dark brown and only allows a little light around the edges. Good size tan head on my pour out of the bottle. I was a little congested when tasting this beer so I couldnt get a great whiff. The only smell I could get was a malty aroma.
Strong porter flavor - coffee, chocolate and toasted malt at the end. Medium heavy mouthfeel. A great porter that embodies the style.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pretty good porter, not exceptional but rather easy drinking, Id try it but dont love it.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Nice dark color, quite a light scent. Has a decent caramel/coffee taste, with a weird burnt after taste.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

black, no other Color of note. Minimal caramel head. The first aroma that jumps out at me is black licorice. Lots of coffee, with almost a sugary licorice finish. The barley in the beer is evident here as well.

Bottle. Roasted coffee scent with a dark brown/black appearance, brown around the edges with the help of light, a white head fading to a ring quite quickly. The palate was a frothy, almost creamy texture, with a medium body, and the taste was roasted coffee that had a bit of chocolate note peek out after warming. Cant beat this porter for the price! Lots of bang for your buck.
Draft. Not a whole lot of aroma, slight malt sweetness. Head quickly disappeared, but the body and flavor was outstanding. Malt creamyness with just a hint of hops.

This beer is a frequent visitor to my beer glass. The beer was chilled and served in a Imperial Pint glass.

Ar- Darkly roasted and even ashy malty aromas plenty of cocoa aromas waft throughout the aroma. A bit earthy and even somewhat smokey at times. 

Ap- The body of the beer is dark brown almost black. Ruby highlights are noted when held up to light. Thick tan colored head resolves to a ring of foam.

T- Bitter sweet cocoa and darkly roasted malt leads the flavors. Vaguely coffee flavors remind me of the nutty acidic funkyness of Ethiopian Yreegif coffee. Ashy finish to the roasted flavors in the finish. 

P- The body of the beer is medium and moderately carbonated. Long lasting roasted flavors make this beer linger.

O- This beer is hands down my go to porter. I love the nicely roasted and char notes. Very well balanced and very easy to drink.

Okay ratebeer. It would seem Ive gotten in a sort of slump. You see- My ratings have no scale to them. None! Almost all of my ratings range from 2.7 (bad) to 3.7 (excellent). Ive had enough! Ill go back and fix my ratings. I swear!

This beer is the first with the new rating system. I like it. I really like it. Porters smell delicious. This is a less sweet smokier beer. Not very chocolaty. Burnt in a good way. And from cleveland too! Im happy with this.

Pours dark dark reddish brown with a good size frothy head.  Not much by way of smell that I could come up with....(might have something to do with the environment in which I enjoyed the brew).  Tastes great.  Chocolatey and coffee.  One of the best porters Ive had.

On tap at the White Stag in St Charles, IL. Black pour with a beige head. Aroma is roasty malt, some coffee and a little chocolate. Flavor is chocolate, a little caramel malt, with some bitter earthy coffee and roasty malt.

12oz bottle to a Samuel Smith imperial pint glass.  The aroma is that of chocolate and toffee.  It smells nice.  The appearance is a very dark brown.  I would not quite call it black.  Some light shines through.  A creamy head, minimal lacing.  The taste is bitter chocolate, creamy, with a hint of toffee.  The mouthfeel is that of a medium-bodied porter, very carbonated.  Slightly dry finish.  Overall its an exceptional porter.
Palate: slight smoky smell. Appearance: typical, dark porter. Taste: burnt coffee (in a good way). Palate: Full-bodied taste from sip to aftertaste.  A good, solid porter.

Pours black with a light tan head. 
Nice coffee aroma, some bitter dark Choclate, 
Flavor is of dark bitter Choclate, roasted espresso beans, a little dark fruit and roasty malt.
Interesting mouthfeel, pretty high carbonation, medium full body.
This is a pretty nice porter, defiantly worth a try.

12oz bottle - pours very dark amber with beige head and decent lacing.  Nose is roasted caramel malts and coffee.  Aroma is quite roasted.  Dry and tastes bitter.  Medium to full body and sticky texture.  Long finish.  Somewhat smoky aftertaste.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2013 A: Dark brown body. Light tan head which forms a nice skim after settling. Not much in the way of lacing.

S: Roasted coffee. Smokey chocolate. Some dark fruit... figs or raisins.

T: Nice, overall smokiness. Dark chocolate. A touch of caramel. Some more dark fruits towards the middle.

M: Smooth. Not terribly creamy. Clean finish.
Very dark brown pour with a thin grey head. Chocolate, coffee, caramel, and hints of manure-earth leads to milk chocolate and roasty cocoa nib. Hints of butterscotch in the finish. Ok but not great.

Bottle. Pour is black with a tan head. Aroma of chocolate, roast, coffee, tobacco. Taste is moderately bitter, roasty, with coffee notes. Palate is soft, creamy, average carbonation, lightly roasty/bitter finish.
Black beer!  Bown head.  Roasty roasty with burnt coffee and some chocolate flavors.  Mmmmmmmm.  Quite delicious indeed.

Ar: Ash, charcoal, some coffee - slight pear fruitiness.
Ap: Black, with a medium tan head - moderate retention, fair amount of lacing.
T: Ash and chocolate up front - dry roast mingles with medium-high bitterness - malty cocoa with some cherry and pear - medium-sweet throughout.
P: Medium-full body, medium carbonation - slick with some solid substance on the palate - finish is dry.
O: Delicious porter, one of the greats - aggressively roasty and supremely flavorful.

12 oz bottle. Surprised I hadnt rated this previously; picked up a bottle of it recently and decided to finally rate it. Pours a light black color that has hints of red when the light catches the edge, as well as a small light  tan head that dies quickly. Smells of chocolate, coffee, malt, oats, and some nuts too. Tastes of light chocolate (almost a mocha flavor), some oatmeal, and malt. Decent flavor to it, but not terribly heavy either, as it goes down smooth. Overall a very good porter.

This is a nice Porter.  Roasted malt, chocolate, coffee and hops.  Medium bitterness that doesnt linger too long.  Relatively thin body, but plenty of flavor.  It reminds me of Bells Special double cream stout.

Bottle at home, from my Maudite glass. Pours clear black, with a moderately-long lived cream-coloured head which leaves really quite nice lacing. Nose is smoke, ash, red licorice, nice roastiness. Flavours of surprisingly bitter roast, which is perfectly balanced out by some nice sweet licorice/berry/cocoa notes. Some real coffee here too, especially in the finish. Lovely stuff.
Brown/black with a creamy brown head.  Nutty, roasty aroma, and chocolate espresso taste, with a creamy mouthfeel.

Poured a very dark brown, almost black, with a thin light-tan head.  Aroma is very roasted with lots of chocolate and caramel.  A touch of coffee as well.  Taste is a tad bitter and very roasted, almost burnt.  Not too complex, mostly one-dimensional.  Good chocolate flavors however.  Finish is also roasted and chocolaty.  Overall nice.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown, almost black with a frothy large off white head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate and dark fruit. Taste has a smooth palate with soft carbonation, notes of coffee, chocolate and a hints of dark fruit and nuttiness. Texture is creamy and inviting to the next sip. Bitterness is almost not present at all. One of the better porters I have had and one of the easiest to drink of the style. Delicious.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2012 This beer has a roastiness to it and the coffers flavor sticks out to me most as an aftertaste while I?m sucking my teeth between sips. This isn?t my favorite porter but this is a great beer.
Bottle thanks to rc0032.  Pitch black with a light cream colored head.   Nose is rich chocolate, roasted malts, and light vanilla.  Excellent on the palate, roasted malts, wood, and light chocolate.
some chocolate and coffee. didnt get any roastiness. very sweet. not bad just not very good either.

Bottle from SS 2011, thanks 
Appearance: Pours clear dark brown with a mediums sized beige head and good lacing 
Aroma: Roasted malts, roasted coffee and chocolate 
Taste: Roasted malts, dark roast coffee, grainy with bitter chocolate in the finish 
This is a very nice porter, roasty and smooth

Bottle. Dark brown color with a modest tan head that quickly disappears. The nose is nutty and of roasted malts. The taste is moderately sweet, with a bitter, dry finish. Nicely balanced and understated. The palates medium, the carbonation soft. Overall, this is a beer thats limited in ambition, but does a really good job of getting the basics right. Nice.

Bottle.  Pours a deep brown-black with a thin tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts.  The flavor is also predictably malty, with a touch of bitterness from the hops, and an interesting earthy character.  A bit of coffee, too.  Smooth mouthfeel, quite carbonated.  A nice porter, though not quite as excellent as I had remembered.

Bottle - Pours nearly opaque black.  Medium tan head.  Smokey aroma.  Flavor of coffee and dark chocolate.  Some lacing.  Nice rich & roasty coffee mouthfeel.  This is one heck of a beer.  I cant believe I waited so long to try it.  Really really nice.  This will now be one of my favorite porters.

Cant believe i havent rated this one before. Tap at Grumpys northeast. Pours jet opaque black with a khaki off white head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, and a tad of wet wood. Really nice. Soft carbonation with a slightly silky mouthfeel. Perfectly balanced flavored of roasted malt, bittersweet chocolate, roasted coffee, and a hint of dark fruit. Just a hair of espresso bitterness on the finish. A wonderful porter. One of my regional favs.

Bouteilles de 355 ml. Arômes très invitants de malt fumé, de chocolat au lait et de grains torréfiés. Robe brune foncée aux reflets roux, effervescence moyenne et peu de mousse. En bouche, la bière montre une belle complexité maltée, jouant sur des notes de tourbe, de chocolat au lait et dorge torréfié. On remarque également une présence assez importante de houblon résineux et herbacé. La texture maltée est très intéressante, même si la bière nest pas particulièrement sucrée. Finale présentant une belle amertume de torréfaction et de houblon. Un très agréable porter.

Pours mahogany-tinged black into a shaker. Off white head recedes to hug rim.  Minor pit fruit and chocolate aromas. Thin, with dark resin and chocolate front to back and through the lasting resin finish.
jet black/ malty and hop aroma/ taste is rather light with some chocolate and coffee

Dark brown pour with ruby hues, this tan lacing.  Aroma of coffee, raisin, chocolate, a bit of woodiness.  Taste is more complex - im getting Dark chocolate, raisin, coffee, dry plum, coffee, cocoa, dark toffee.  medium bodied, creamy mouthfeel and low carbonation.  Very good.

Bottle,many thanks to coldbrewky. Dark brown almost black color with medium beige head. Aroma of milk chocolate, caramel, dark fruit. Taste, coffee, chocolate, plums, roasted malt, earthy hints. Coffee bitterness in finish. Nice.

bottle from Andersons General Store. Pours black with a thin khaki heads. Nice aroma of roasted malts. A bit of chocolate on the tongue but the mouthfeel was thinner then I was expecting which became slightly off-putting. Finishes clean.
nice chocolate taste with a hoppy bitter kick.

This is a fine porter.

Pour is dark brown, slight shading of red, with a foamy light brown head.  The nose is very roasty with hints of raisin, chocolate, and caramel.  The taste is much like the nose with a slight bitterness than is perfectly balanced by a sturdy malt base.  The body is appropriately heavy for a porter but does not linger overlong on the palate.

Porters are not typically my preferred style, but this is one worth having on hand!
Simply one of the best porters you can find anywhere.  Particularly good when fresh off the tap at the Great lakes Brewing Company.

12 oz bottle brought back from Wisconsin. Pours brown/red with a foamy, creamy light tan head that leaves some lacing. Aroma is bittersweet chocolate, coffee, caramel and a light roast. Flavor follows the aroma with lots of chocolate, coffee and a roasty bitterness. Medium to full body with soft carbonation and a creamy mouth feel. This is a great Porter, I could see drinking lots of this if it was available in Alaska.
Bottle. (On vacation in WV a month ago.) Dark brown with foamy light brown head.  Roasty + raisiny aroma. Flavor roasty and smoky. Lightly bitter - not too sweet. Light mouthfeel felt balanced.

Sampled on tap pours black with a reddish brown head.  Aromas of chocolate and coffee also some wood.  Flavor is a bit bitter bakers chocolate up front with a licorice coffee taste.  Body is heavy and creamy. Finish is hood leaves a sweet burnt sugar
Bottle.  Roasted aroma with some chocolate.  Deep brown black, light head.  Full body nice bitter but soft with ahold finish.  Very good porter.

bottle.  Poured almost black with a ruby hue. Coffee, dark fruit aroma, a bit sour. Medium-full mouthfeel, some dryness. Rich roasty dark fruit flavour, hints of bitter dark chocolate and an herbal hop hint. Not overly dry.

Draught, 5.8%. Good roasted chocolate aroma. Black colour. Big stable light brown head. The flavour is nicely roasted with a good coffee note. Not sweet, but more sweet than bitter. Well-balanced. Good mouthfeel. Very good and very pleasant.

Black pour with a massive tan head that persists.  Classic chocolate and coffee aroma.  Flavor of bittersweet chocolate and coffee with a lasting bitter finish that adds to the drinkability.  Thick mouthfeel with prickly carbonation underneath.  My first Great Lakes beer.  Awesome!  Cant wait to try more from this brewery.
Fantastic porter.  Smooth chocolate and coffee entry, with satisfying hop bite finish.  Worth seeking out if you like balanced hoppy porters.

Served on tap at The Map Room.

Aroma: Chocolate covered caramels.  

Appearance: Black with an off white head that quickly recedes to a thin layer atop a sea of black.  Minimal lace but a large meniscus around the inside of the glass.

Taste: Dark fruit and roasted malts dominate but with a grassy/piney hop note.

Palate:  Medium bodied with a slick texture that coats the mouth.  Carbonation is average.  

Overall:  The hop flavor is a little distracting and Id like to see more roasty malts, but overall this is a good beer for a dreary afternoon.  Not the best of the style, but I would definitely order again

bottle recd in trade; thx emacgee!  nice aroma MUCH caramel; slight roast and other goodies.  almost gave it a 2 in palate; surprisingly thin.  taste was good - smooth blend of malts little hops and the toffee sweetness.  understated but good

Can You ask for a better porter? If its not Flossmoor Stations Pullman or Founders Porter....then nope. So much flavor. Pour os 
Itch black, nice off white head. Perfect carbination and body. Full flavored and super nteresting. I love the hop presence and the finish leaves my mouth watering.

Bottle... Poured deep, dark brown with a light, tan head. Light body, with very faint roast, nutty tones and worty malt. Some dark fruit tones, a strong ale yeast presence. A sweet cream-like tone too.
Drank out of bottle, no glassware available, deep rich coffee roasted flavors. Malty lightly bitter finish. Very delicious

Pours dark red with beige head and great retention.  Aroma is dominated by roasty notes of coffee and chocolate.  Taste is the same but with hints of pumpernickel rye and green, earthy hops.  Body is medium-full, creamy, avg carb, dry roasty finish.  Overall, Great Lakes makes incredible middle-quality 6 packs.  This beer is one of my go-tos and my favorite session porter.
Aroma of roast coffee and a bit chocolate.  Pours deep brown with a small head.  Tastes of coffee, bitter dark chocolate and dark fruits.  Outstanding porter.

Bottle via buddy Art.  Slate black and mostly translucent.  Centra core of darkness.  Thinner fizzy head.  Nose of dark malts and earth.  Moderate to heavy body is widly arrayed with bithing citrus hop quickly overtaken by licorice tone.  Nuttiness and sweet caramel.  Lots going on in such a small bottle.
Tap at brewery Pours a very dark brown, almost black with a yellow / copper head. Nice lacing. Has a nice smoked smooth taste.

"The Legend lives on from the Chippewa on down.....of the great Beer called BLATZ........"  Thanks to Gordon Lightfoot for the inpsiration.  This junk definitely makes my junk, look like junk.  Or not.  Its pretty good, but if the "crew and good captain" of the Edmund Fitzgerald would have had Blatz onboard the night they sunk, I daresay they could have swam back to shore with the greatness that Vals finest pumps into you.  Is it in bad taste to name a beer after a doomed vessel?  And what about the Exxon Valdez, maybe there should be a beer named after that one....after all Captain Joe Hazelwood was half bagged up when he drove his ship up on shore!  Stick with Blatz, and youll be sailing the "HIGH" seas in no time.  Trust me, Ive been to Milwaukee!!
Bottle from craft beer outlet. Nice dark coffee/chocolate aroma and flavor. Would definitely have again.

Nice roasted chocolate/coffee aroma.  Pours a dark black, with ruby highlights when held to the light, and a full light tan head.  This is a really well balanced porter, nice roast flavor profile, with just a hint of bittering hops.  Theres a long roasted finish to go along with it.  Light mouthfeel, with a touch of slickness to it.  This is definitely a porter to try.

This is just a very well-balanced porter.  Love how the roasted character interacts with the chocolate notes and that tiny hop bite at the end is beautiful.  A great example of the balance between complexity and drinkability.

pours dark brown with a thick tan/ lt. mocha head...nice lacing and retention.  nice roasty aroma with a hint of chocolate.    flavor has significant chocolate and roasty malts, hint of coffee, and some earthy/spicy hop notes...good balance.  mouthfeel is creamy and the finish is dry and roasted...nice!
Medium bodied porter. Bitter chocolate and roasted malts predominate. Nice dry finish. Not a bad beer to enjoy if you have a layover in the Cleveland airport.

Bottle- Pours a virtual black with a deep ruby hue around the edges. Tan head that fades to nice lacing. Roasted malt aroma with chocolate and a bit of coffee. Enticing without being overpowering. Has a bittersweet chocolate taste with some roasted malt. A nice subtle bitterness and a clean, dry finish. Medium body, very smooth and creamy excellent balance. Excellent Porter to measure others by. Another delightfull beer from Great Lakes.

Notes of chocolate, roasted coffee, and resinous hops.  Slightly ashen taste when still chilled, which fades as it warms.  However, it becomes a little watery as it warms.  Despite these small flaws, one of my favorite Porters.

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into Nonic Imperial Pint.

Appearance: Looks black but glows ruby red around the edges. Light foamy tan head and light lacing.

Aroma: Roasted malts, chocolate and coffee. Standard Porter aroma, but done well.

Taste: Bittersweet malt taste of roasted barley, dark chocolate, coffee and a touch of licorice. Somewhat smokey. Just slightly bitter toward the end, mostly from the high level of roasting.

Palate: Unbelievably smooth, rich body with low carbonation and a dry finish. Just slightly on the thin side and prevents a perfect score here.

Overall: Very smooth, easy to drink Porter that does everything right. That said, by playing it safe, it does not quite hit the stratosphere.

This is Great Lakes  porter Edmund Fitzgerald  It pours an incredibly dark, almost black, amber color. Its full and smooth with a complex, smokey flavor mix of chocolate and coffee with just a hint of bitterness in the back of the throat. Fantastic lacing, too.

As it warms, the bitterness does get a little more aggressive, but its far from overpowering. Outstanding example of the style. Might have some rivals, but there is nothing better

Grade: A

Bottle.  Pours a rich dark brown with a thick tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt, hint of coffee grounds, molasses, and tootsie roll.  Flavor is similar, lots of roasted grains, some charred malt, hint of chocolate, and caramel.  Pretty tasty porter. 
7/4/7/4/14 [3.6/5]

Pours dark, almost black garnet with a nice tan head.  Aroma is roasty malt, coffee and a bit of chocolate.   Flavor is dry roasted barley and chocolate with a substantial bitter finish.  A good one to savor all night long.
Tap at Churchkey. Black pour. Absolutely delicious classic porter, with notes of roasted malt, cream, and cocoa. Truly yummy.
Aroma is coffee and chocolate malts. Taste is toasted coffee malt with medium bitterness. Overall a solid porter.
