12 oz bottle got in a trade with drfabulous. Used a pint. Thick frothy, bubbly head. Tons of spotty lace down the glass. Nose of roasted espresso beans, chocolate powder with lots of roasted notes. Excellent flavors of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee and hops. Very carbonated and light on the tongue. High drinkability, very smooth and flows well. Finishes slick. High end for the style. Really glad I had a chance to try this, thanks Jeff!!

12oz bottle. Dark brown with a ruby twinge, pale brown ring of head. Chocolate, moderate roasted malts, smoke, dry, coffee. Somewhat sweet but bitter, very dry, some chocolate and more roasted malts at the end. Good but porters still arent my thing.
Bottle. Dark, almost black pour. Aroma of sweet malts and roast and coffee. Hint of chocolate upon drinking. Touch of smoke in the finish. Heavy but not over bearing palate.

(Courtoisie de JB84)  Le liquide est brun foncé.  La tête mousseuse est petite.  Le nez est doux, marqué par un malt chocolaté et par des touches torréfiées.  Des parfums fruités se font sentir.  Le goût est bien peu différent : le cacao et le caramel rencontrent des fruits foncés et du café.  La bouche est moyenne avec une effervescence plutôt modérée et une texture plus ou moins légère.  En finale, quelques notes de réglisse (la combinaison des malts et des houblons?) chatouillent les papilles.  Très bonne bière.

From notes: pours a deep nutty-brown with a dark tan head reminiscent of a stout.  Chocolatey aroma with a slight smokiness to it.  Palate was deep and slightly heavy, but pleasantly so.  Rich nutty and chocolate flavors with a very slight smoky note in the finish.  Very good.

Served on-tap at the Brewhouse Grille into a standard pint glass.

A - Pours plain old black, with ruby red highlights, with a small half finger tall mocha head leaving light lacing down the glass.

S - Smells of rich chocolate malt, caramel, coffee with creamer, and some dark chocolate. Solid nose but nothing too mind blowing.

T - Plenty of rich chocolate up front slowly giving way to a mix of coffee and roasted malt. The finish is a mix of chocolate sweetness and dark roast, lingering for a short time. I really like this one a lot.

M - Heavy body and flavor with moderate carbonation. Creamy feel with plenty of lingering sweet roast in the finish. It was a tiny bit on the watery side.

O - This is a solid example of an American porter. The flavors are spot on and it is easy to consume. I just wish more breweries would brew porters just like this one.

Opens with a roasty aroma with licorice and chocolate notes, and pours dark but not heavy.  Taste is very well balanced once it reaches 50 F (10 C).  Medium body, light carbonation, and a rather short finish.  Compared to its archrival Bells Kalamazoo Stout, it seems a bit bland.

Two problems here. One, I always want a porter to be bigger and stronger than it is. Im always comparing porters to stouts. This isnt usually fair. However the Edmund Fitz cares less about what I think and what I compare it to. This porter stands out for flavor, boldness, and balance. Not to mention that it still manages to be stylistically correct. The other problem was that the next beer we tasted was a DF Head/SN Life and Limb. Uh yeah... its not fair to compare anything to that blissful goodness. Regardless of my shortcomings and ramblings, Edmund Fitz is another of the slammn good beers from Great Lakes. Holy Crap, this brewery is getting it done and doing it right. Cheers to you guys!!!
Pours a very dark brown body with a foamy white head. Bitter chocolate and a bit of toffee, with a mild dry finish. Good but a little thin.

Bottle. brown beer with a cream colored head. Chocolate and light nutty aroma. Chocolate and light nutty flavor with light roast. Medium-plus bodied. Chocolate and light roast lingers with light vanilla.

Poured a dark brown reddish color.  Medium head.  Aroma of cocoa mostly and roasted malts.  Med lite bitter, med lite sweetness.  Med bodied, creamy palate.  Nice roasted malt flaovor with smooth chocolate bits and mild bitter end.  Well done.
Deep black/brown in the glass with a thin tan head. Nice roasted malt profile with coffee and chocolate notes. Medium mouthfeel, keeps a nice balance. Excellent porter.

Date: July 29, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: Apple Valley Liquor, Apple Valley, MN Appearance: Dark brown with almost no head and no lacing.  Aroma: Roasted Coffee.  Flavor: Roasted coffee, light chocolate, medium bodied, slight carbonation and a slight bitter finish Other: Tasty porter though not terribly complex, like the historical reference to the Edmund Fitzgerald.

Petite bouteille avec encore une très belle étiquette. Gracieuseté de Patrci et bue en sa compagnie. La robe de ce porter est brun avec de beaux reflets rouges. La mousse est brune. Le nez est de chocolat en poudre (Quick ou Frys ? et des notes fruités de la levure. La bouche est mince, elle est tout de même bien agréable. Lamertume des grains rôtis et la touche métallique en fin de bouche ajoute à laffaire. 6+/10

From notes: Very dark, with a frothy head and good retention. Smoky, somewhat metallic nose. Coffee is very pronounced throughout. Smooth, creamy. The mouthfeel really pretty good and finishes clean. Alcohol is well hidden. Malty backbone, much like the nose. Somewhat watered down and I cant pick up much at first. Not overly complex with isnt necessarily a bad thing. A good straightforward porter, although Im not as impressed with it as others. The drinkibiliy is pretty good on this one and the balance is nice. Overall, a very solid beer.

Pours very dark brown with some deep red when held to the light and little head. Roasty coffee and chocolate on the nose. Flavor is more of the same, but not too overwhelming. Light to medium bodied palate, and not too thick. I only go for a porter once in a while, and this is a solid rendition of the style. There are a couple others I prefer, however.

Bottle from trade. Pours dark brown with an off-white head. Aroma is lightly roasted malt, chocolate, cocoa, and brownies. Taste is a little more complex than the aroma, with a nice light roast, coffee, chocolate, some soy-sauce, and a nice tart berry skin finish that rounds out to a lightly bitter end. Mouthfeel is thin but to style. This is a very traditional porter that lacks the harsh roast and thicker mouthfeel that others possess, and it makes an excellent session beer.

Bottle. Opaque black with decent light tan head and lace. Mocha, choc, roast and citrus tangerine, melon, apricot hop aromas on the nose, hazelnuts and vanilla. Med body, med carb decent caramel sweetness letting go for a lighter roasty finish with lingering choc and mocha notes plus light citrusy melon hop flavour. Very satisfying and moreish beer.
Had a coconut stout before this one so might be scewed. Has a nice chocolate caramel aroma. Nice bitter aftertaste.

Pour from the bottle into a pint glass at room temp.  The aroma of this porter is rich with solid notes of molasses, chocolate, and roasted grains.  A strong roasted flavor balanced out any sweetnes from the malts, with very little hops character.  Edmund Fitzgerald pours a little thinner than expected, but has a dark chestnut color that is spot on for the style.  I enjoyed this beer greatly.

Bottle...  Poured deep, dark brown with a light, tan head.  Light body, with very faint roast, nutty tones and worty malt. Some dark fruit tones, a strong ale yeast presence.  A sweet cream-like tone too.

Bottle pours brown with a khaki head.  Aroma shows plenty of roast with caramel, coffee, chocolate, and a touch of smoke. Flavor shows the same with additional notes of licorice and a hint of dried fruit. Overall body is light to moderate and finishes with nice, balanced, roasted bitterness. A little on the thin side, but lots of porter character and extremely easy to drink. No complaints here.

Before IPAs became my favorite beer style, porters were my favorite.  Actually, porters are a very close second.  This beer is a good reason why.  Black pour, brown head.  Smooth, creamy smoked flavor.  Excellent!!
Bottle to pint glass.  Pours a very dark brown, almost black with a yellow / copper head.  Nice lacing.  Has a nice smoked smooth taste.

As advertized, the aroma is roasty, dark chocolate, coffee.  The appearance is deep brown/black, cream/tan head.  The flavor is chocolate, roast coffee, brown sugar, sweeter than the aroma implies.  The finish is piney hops, lingering.  medium/thick in body, creamy mouthfeel.  Excellent.

Rich, chocolatey brown with a thick and tan, three-finger head.  Slowly, steadily receding lacing.

Very full bodied and sweet aroma.  Chocolate, caramel, and toffee.  Very full and complex scent.

Taste is a bit sweeter than the aroma lets on.  The chocolate, caramel, and toffee are there with a nice edge from hops and carbonation.  And good dryness in the middle.  Finish is a bit like chocolate syrup.  

A solid beer.  I bet Id appreciate the second one more.
Massive coffee flavor and smell.  Plenty of hops to balance out the massive malt here.  Chocolate in finish and aftertaste.  At times this almost tastes burned, but in a good way.
12oz bottle. Dark dark pour with a thin off white head. About as dark as a porter can get. Aroma is mostly chocolate, malts and slight espresso bean. Flavor is bitter and chocolatley. A great porter!

A 12oz bottle from Chucks poured into a Sam Smith English Pint. Bottle expires 9/3/11.

Dark brown with a good amount of tan head that sits and lingers for a while. 

Smells very malty. Roasty coffee and chocolate. 

Taste is medium bitter. Very very strong coffee taste. 

Medium-light bodied and textured. Above average carbonation. Very long coffee finish. 

Overall its a pretty good beer. A little more carbonated than I would like but Ill definitly be buying this one again on my next trip to Bowling Green, KY.

12oz bottle, unknown date.  Big thanks to Adam for hooking me up with a 6-pack during his visit to Ohio.  Served at cellar temperature.
Pours dark brown with red highlights and a two finger foamy active light brown head that leaves some clumpy lacing and holds a wispy cap.
Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, some smoke, burnt toast, a touch of dark fruit and maybe a little bit of grassy or herbal hops.  Good to very good strength.
Flavor is more roasted malts, some coffee and a bit of chocolate, smoky, toasty, fair sweetness and a touch of bitterness from the hops on the finish.  Minimal alcohol.
Mouthfeel is on the thin side of medium, medium to high carbonation.
A very good Porter but not quite as robust as the Founders or Smuttynose offerings.  Ive been wanting to try this for years and glad to finally get a hold of some.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2014 Deep brown with amber hues.  Aroma of coffee, toffee, and caramel.  Flavor is roasted malt, coffee, brown sugar.  A bit more caramel than I care for.  Finishes with roast and mild hop bitterness.

Bottle @ home, courtesy of LeopoldStoch. Very dark brown appearance with a two to three finger tan brown head. Dark roasty, coffee, mild chocolate, a touch bitter, chocolate malty nose. A touch bitter but on the other hand, a sweet, chocolate, roasty, light coffee, dark malty flavor with a slightly bitter chocolate, roasty aftertaste. Very nice, full flavored porter.

12oz bottle from Downer Wine and Spirit.  Pours a deep brown color with a light tan head.  Aroma is roasty, malty, nutty.  Medium on the palate with average carbonation.  Flavor is a little sweet, a little bitter, roasty, nutty, with a clean, bitter-coffee finish.

12 oz Bottle.  Appearance is black with copious beige head.  Aroma is fine with strong notes of coffee and chocolate as well as some hints of floral and fruit.  Taste is similar with coffee and bitter chocolate dominant as well as some subtle fruitiness underlying the bitterness.  There was also a firm hop character as well moving into a moderately bitter finish.  Palate is medium-bodied, slightly thin mouthfeel, a plentiful but soft carbonation, and a nice long, somewhat bitter aftertaste.  This is a wonderful Porter.

12oz bottle. Nearly black color with a red hue, taller tan head that quickly dissipates. Very good aroma, chocolate coffee taste gives me the first impression of a stout. Hops taste balances it. Description is pretty much spot-on, bittersweet describes taste perfectly. Pleasant aftertaste that lasts for a bit.

One of the best Porters I have had. Lots of roasted, coffee, chocolate, slightly fruity and malty aroma and flavor. Full bodied but still very drinkable. Excellent ... and Im getting pretty loaded, hehehe.

Pours a dark ruby-brown with a slight white head. Smells of coffee, dark chocolate, and sweet roasted malt. Nice taste of caramel and coffee, with a bit of smoke. Smooth mouth-feel. Probably my favorite porter behind Founders.
Bottle from Cavie.  Dark pour with an off-white head.  Aroma is roasted, vanilla, kinda fruity, and ash.  Taste is sour chocolate, roasted, and dry bitterness.
Bottle courtesy weihenweizen. Clear dark reddish brown color with a off white head. Aroma is roasted malts and dark notes. Flavor is roasty and chocolate notes. Bitter finish thats dry.

Appearance:   clear dark ruby-red, short bubbly off-white head, minimal lacing.   Aroma: dark chocolate, toffee, coffee, slightly piny hops.   Taste: freshly brewed dark roast coffee, bitter chocolate, notes of charred wood, hint of black licorice, and resinous hops.   Finish: pleasantly lingering mellow and dry bitterness, with lingering dark, bitter chocolate and coffee.   Notes: Terrific porter.  Extremely easy drinking, full of complementary flavors.  Its the total package.
Bottle. Just your typical easy drinking, flavoursome porter. Some nice roasted coffee and toasted malts in there. Bitters for a fair while. Solid

A: Very dark with some pretty good lacing as it goes down.

S: Caramel malt; slightly sweet with some chocolate.

T: Caramel and coffee tastes with some chocolate in there.

M: Fairly full and chewy.

D: Nothing really stands out about it, except that it all tends to meld together quite well creating a very drinkable porter.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-01-2009

Pours very dark reddish-brown, nearly black, with moderate bubbly tan head that leaves some lacing. Aroma is mild smoky coffee and chocolate. Taste starts out lighty sweet with caramel flavor before the roasted malt and slightly bitter coffee/chocolate flavors come through. Mouthfeel is lighter than expected based on appearance and aroma, but I wouldnt go so far as to call it watery. A very well-balanced and easy drinking brew - I could easily do a session with this one. Well done GLBC.

12 oz. Served in an Odell stem glass. Notes of coffee and chocolate aroma. Receding head with good lacing. Great color with a hidden brown underneath. Caramel flavor is great. Tastes of roasted malt dominate for and after, with little black, patent malt etc noticeable. Watery but 5.8%. (SO notes hazelnut aroma.)
12oz bottle in Chicago. Great little porter. Tasty, smooth but robust. Sweet thin front end finishing rich and roasty. coffee, some hops, a bit smoky.

As it is poured in to a tulip glas is shows strong browns with reddish highlights and a lt tan head that sheds to a strong lacing in the glass.

The aroma is of smoked malts and sweet carmel undertones of chocolate, yum

Tastes amazing like it smells, nothing unexpected, but then the floral notes of a mild hops comes in, hardly any bitterness.

This just feels good in the mouth, creamy soft notes and a very mild bitterness that makes it a soft complex drinker.

Overall I really like the sample from glbc, a very good example of a Porter. I could do a session on this one and not feel overly full.
Pours out dark with a decent head.  Weak malty aroma.  Subtle coffee flavor.  Strikes a nice balance between malt and hop presence.  Very smooth.  Goes down easy.
Chocolate malt and black coffee, slightly bitter finish. Beautiful dark color and good head retention. Robust and equally fitting with chocolate cake or beef stew.

My favorite American Porter (non-imperial).  
Bottle and glass.   
Taste: its as if the nutty and coffee flavors are balanced against each other and come and go -- very complex and pronounced tastes.  Viscosity: somewhat watery, a little thick ~ Paulaner Hefe-weizen.  Overall:  Great one time only or for session.
(bottle) clear dark brown with medium brown head; aroma starts with roast, then gets a hint of soy sauce and caramel ; balanced flavour (on the dry side), slightly oily palate; very good overall

(12oz botte).  Pours dark brown with tan head.  Light carbonation bubbles.  Aroma has load of chocolate, coffee, caramel, vanilla and some florals. Taste is roasty bitter with a sweet malt backbone.  Thin bodied with a creamy texture.  Bitter finish.  Nice porter.

12 oz bottle from a selection from Ottos in MIlwaukee.....great place for singles.  Nose is hoppy with a touch of chocolate....as it the taste....goes down way too easy.  Definitely one of the better / best porters...almost (almost) makes you sad the winter is ending.....well done.
12 oz bottle, pours deep walnut w/ foamy peaty head, aroma is mostly cocoa w/ some roasty notes, sweet malt up front with strong coffee on back end, delicious smooth porter

The beer pours black, not super black with a lot of brown in the light. There is a light mocha head that only rises about 1 finger and is gone quickly not leaving behind even a trace. There is poor lacing. 

The aroma is super light. What does come through is a bitter chocolate with a smidge of alcohol.

The taste keeps in line with aroma as it is very light, but smooth and mostly in the flavor of light bitter chocolate. 

The feel is on the lighter side but has nice sustaining taste.

With the low abv this is drinkable, but why not move on to something a litte more high powered.

Overall, this porter is ok, but doesnt live up to the hype, let alone me a top 100 beer. There are too many better, fuller more flavorful porters to keep drinking this.
Chocolate and coffee always taste great together and this beer makes the combo stay alive.

Very dark brown pour with red tones. Big foamy head.
Aroma is sweet chocolate and a lil vnailla.
Flavor is clean chocoalte and roastiness.
A bit thin for a porter but tasty.

I cant believe I have waited this long to try this beer. As good as the rating says, this one isnt too splendid. Kind of empty tasting, though I did start the night off with two Stouts, and am following Edmund Fitzgerald with a third Stout.

Pours a dark black with a healthy head. Beautiful for a porter. Aroma is very smooth, just some slightly roasted malts. Flavor is a touch grapey, but its hard to miss the coffee. This is a great Saturday breakfast porter. Best porter yet.

recieved in trade, thanks to huey782.

Poured jet black into Snifter. ruby highlights in the light, it doesnt look thick, seems to move around the glass easy. nice thick foamy 2 finger head. clings to the edge of the glass, slowly crawling down the side of the glass as I take sips leaving some trellising.

Shoved my nose down into this guy and pulled out roasted espresso bean, cocoa powder, and some hints of hops which I really liked. I wasnt really expecting that, made me excited to take a sip.

this beer is quite tasty, its not like chocolate, its more like cocoa powder and roasted espresso bean. It brang memories of chewing on espresso beans to my mind. It took work to taste the hops that I smelled. I though they would be more apparent but this is still a wonderful beer.

mouthfeel. I think the reason it was more like cocoa powder then chocolate is because the beer seems a bit watery. Just goes down real easy, hard not to just make this dissapear in a quick few minutes. hankered down to let er warm a bit.

drankability is great as it tastes amazing, isnt thick or chewy, and doesnt have any hint of alcohol. I could have a few of these pretty easily. since its not overly sweet or creamy I think it would play nice with a meat and potatoes meal. Roast beef, Sirloin Steak, T-Bone steak... garlic mashed potatoes and cranberryd green beans with almond slices.

one of my favorite porters out there so far, dark black pour, great chocolate/coffee aroma, flavors are the same well balanced chocolate and coffee flavors with a nice slightly bitter finish, will buy again for sure.
UPDATED: FEB 1, 2014 Gives Samuel Smith a run for its money.   Very full bodied beer, much like the rest of Great Lakes beers, just a great beer.

This porter has some bite.  Theres good flavor but the hoppy kick is just a little too much for me. Not too much hop just not subtle enough or something.  I dunno, its just not very well balanced to my palate I guess.  Pisses me off cause everyone else seems to love it.  Mommy, whats wrong with me?  Definitely a unique brew, you wont find many porters like this.
UPDATED: AUG 1, 2011 Deep dark pour, light tan head, thick coffee and chocolate, nicely bitter finish. Very, very nice, indeed.

Pours a solid brown with dark ruby highlights when held to the light. Smallish tan/white head that laces the glass all the way down. Aromas of cocoa, roast coffee, chocolate, and some restrained hops in the back. Smells wonderful! Taste is a roasted chocolaty coffee and citrus hops. I taste a bit of dark dried fruit towards the end that fades into a roast bitterness to finish. Creamy and oily mouthfeel. Great porter, I wish I could get this one locally!

All Cleveland jokes aside, there are no mistakes here - not by a lake and not by the beers these guys make.  This one pours a deep dark blackish brown with just the faintest ruby highlites at the upper corners of the glass just below a rich chestnut head.  Aroma of freshly roasted coffee, bittersweet chocolate and toffee.  Smooth coffee and mild caramel notes are up front in the first sip followed by a finely orchestrated medley of rich chocolate, toffee and a hint of vanilla.  Silky mouthfeel and a long, well balanced finish with just the right amount of hops to give it a pleasingly crisp finish.  Who knew that an unfortunate cargo shipping accident would give rise to a classic song and now a classic porter!  A new legend lives on!

On tap...Overall a very well made brew. Aroma of coffee, chocolate and toffe. Beautiful black appearance almost cola like in color, with thin brown lacing. Taste of heavy malt, chocolate and coffee, thin watery palate with just the right amount of carbonation. Will drink again
Dark brown pour with a middling tan head.  Slight hint of over percolated coffee roast.  Nice finish but has a slightly heavy taste.

Bottle pours dark brown with persistent tan head.  Aroma roast.  Taste coffee and roast.  Palate fairly thin and carbonated but I liked it.  Finish bitter roast.  Alcohol not apparent.  I didnt get much in the way of hops.

MUCH better as it warms, Im tempted to drink it room temperature next time.  Solid porter.

"The legend lives on from the Chippewa on down of the big lake they called Gitche Gumee. " Or can you seriously say that Gordon Lightfoot isnt rambling through your head when you pick up this beer? The Edmund Fitzgerald Porter likely takes its name from the fateful ship and not the folk-fried song and yet it is nevertheless a fantastic porter in its own right. A porter in the American tradition, it emphasizes the sharper, edgier, aspects of a porter.

Tasted on 1/17/11 from a 12oz bottle purchased from Wisma, best before 06/26/11.  Pours a very dark but clear amber with a ruby tint and a thick beige head that slowly recedes, leaving lace on the inside of the glass, to fairly thick but unevenly spotty lace.  The nose is just as described, bittersweet chocolate and coffee with a ton of darkly roasted malt, and resinous grapefruit hops.  The flavor is sweet with chocolate up front, moving to the more bitter roasted malt and coffee, and finishing with the resinous grapefruit peel hops.  The body is medium with average carbonation and a long roasted and hoppy finish.

Poured into a pint glass.

4.5 A: Dark brown, almost black color. Two fingers of light brown head with good retention and tons of lacing.

5.0 S: Lots of roasted barley and oakiness with vanilla, nuttiness and espresso. Has an almost bourbon type aspect to it.

4.5 T: Taste is really good, but not as good as the smell. Its basically a less intense version of the aroma. Roasted barley, oak, vanilla, espresso all come back again.

5.0 M: Medium body. Good carbonation. Really creamy. Perfect really

5.0 D: This is a very fine dark beer. I must say I love it.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 07-10-2009 04:32:59

Aroma of chocolate, coffee, and roasty.  Pours a beautiful opaque brown, with a tan head of medium thickness.  Taste is hints of dark chocolate and coffee.  Velvety in the mouth.  Can easily be confused for a stout.  Overall a great porter.

From notes:

Pours a very dark chestnut brown that appears pitch black in the glass with mahogany edges when held to a light source and a thick frothy, pillowy tan head that isnt gong anywhere. Excellent retention, only slowly fading into a lasting cap that coats the glass with streaks and spots of soapy lacing.

Very roasted malt aroma with hints of silky chocolate, caramel, oatmeal and slight burnt toast.

Chewy medium body thats on the fuller end with lots of silky chocolate and roasted malt flavor. Slightly acrid and overly roasty but their is a lactic cream presence that smooths things out. Hints of milk chocolate, oatmeal, licorice, hazelnut and subtle hops with a dry finish. Well balanced and very quaffable. We have a winner here.

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2012 Pours dark brown with moderate tan head.  Forward roasted & coffee malt aroma & flavor, a hint of citrus hop flavor.  Heavy body with a moderate bitterness from the hops & dark malts.  A WI "not bad"
Pour dark brown with tan head. Mild coffee chocolate roast malt and a generous amount of hopsaroma. Tasted of good coffee and malt but was very lacking in body. Overall good beer.

Porters have always been safe bets for me, but none have really knocked my socks off. Great Lakes Edmund Fitzgerald Porter, however, comes awfully close. This is a beer with the lighter body of a porter, but the robustness of a stout. APPEARANCE AND AROMAI poured a 12oz bottle into an English nonic pint glass. The body appears to be black, but is actually dark ruby red. It initially forms a generous, dark tan, soapy head - which dissipates slowly and leaves a little lacing on the glass.The aroma is quite inviting with roasted malts, coffee, dark chocolate, oatmeal, and what I like to call "a dairy scent most stouts and porters seem to have."TASTEBefore I came to appreciate craft beer and especially stouts and porters, I always found beers like this to have a "cough medicine-like" taste. Drinking Edmund Fitzgerald I can still find that flavor, but now I rather enjoy it. That taste is a combination of roasty malts and a sweetness of chocolate. Not that this is chocolate beer per se, but there definitely is a confectionary flavor to be found here.The first half of the beer is rather mild, but the second half is quite robust. Whereas most American porters tend to have just a hint of chocolate and coffee on the finish, they are very overt here. Theres not much bitterness to speak of, and certainly no lazy hops hanging around on my tongue afterwards. The coffee-like taste and bitterness is only momentary and the aftertaste is short and sweet (literally). However, this tidy finish is actually what prevents Ed Fitz from being a great beer since its so enjoyable while its in the mouth you want more.DRINKABILITYThe porter has been a "working mans beer" for centuries, and this beer definitely follows the mold. For such a seemingly strong palate, it has a very thin, light mouthfeel. It also seems to be more highly carbonated than most porters, to point of having a soda-like sensation. At 5.8% ABV, Edmund Fitzgerald Porter is something of an all-purpose beer. It would probably work best as a pub beverage, but I could see this pairing with meals that dont have a lot of spice. It would also work well as a session beer, or an after-dinner liquid dessert.FINAL THOUGHTSIve yet to encounter a porter I would consider an amazing beer, but Great Lakes Edmund Fitzgerald comes very close to that title. I enjoy its good taste, and the easy drinkability seals the deal. At $8.49 for a six-pack its also a fantastic bargain in the craft beer world and could entice some Joe and Jane Six Packs to give it a try.NOTE: Watch the video version of this review at:http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jwYa5C6TSpE
On tap at the Grafton. Black with half inch tan head. Aroma is roasted coffee. Flavor is toasty, nutty, and bitter chocolate. Outstanding porter.

Pours a beautiful brown, yet almost block color out of the bottle. Smells of roasted malts of the bat. Nice complex chocolaty and coffee scent. Nice medium tan head. Tastes incredibly enjoyable off the bat. Tastes of chocolate and coffee, like the aroma, make up the majority of the taste as well. Has a nice enjoyable nutty finish. Another one of Great Lakes Brewing Companys damn good beers. This is one of the best porters available in the United States. 

BUY THIS BEER & ENJOY!
Dark brown with a chocolate head. Aroma is nutty, chocolatey, some coffee. Taste is similar; warm and hoppy, delicious. My favorite of the Great Lakes Brewing Company.

Very spectacular dark brownish/black color with ruby/red highlights at the bottom and through the middle when held against the light.  Rich, creamy, smooth looking tan head with tremendous retention and full lacing.  The head settled to an attractive film across the top.  A nose of bitter chocolate and toastiness.  Some roasted coffee and mocha seemed to be balanced near perfectly with the chocolate.  Not the strongest smelling Porter I have ever encountered, but impressive none the less.  A heaping portion of chocolate slaps the taste buds while the roasted coffee mellows out the sweetness.  Somewhat bitter, but in an oh so balanced and pleasing way.  I dont see how many Porters could taste better than this.  I think Im in love with this taste.  Medium mouthfeel.  Silky, smooth and dry.  Somewhat oily and blankets the tongue, throat and roof of the mouth with plenty of flavor.  This is a great Porter.  One that Im going to try again and again.  Very easy to drink and very pleasing to the eyes and taste buds.  Cant wait to pick this up again.  A real excellent experience when sipping on a cold night.  I believe I could set a few of these back without even batting an eye.  Not filling.....  just good all around.

A: Poured into a snifter. Color is pitch black with some ruby tones when held up to the light. Light tan head on top with a low retention rate. Light lacing.

S: Sweet breakfast malts, molasses, caramel and toffee.

T: some toffee off the bat. great roasted malts hold this beer up. Strong coffee finish. No big hop characteristics, but some mild ones are present.

M: smooth and creamy. mild carbonation level. perfect body.

D: very smooth. Perhaps the most solid porter that I have had. Great representation on the style.

Pours a beautiful almost black, with hints of crimson in a well-lit room. Two finger foamy and tan head. Smell is of chocolate, coffee, and roasted malts. Dark chocolate and coffee make up the bulk of the taste as well, with a slightly nutty finish. Mouthfeel is creamy and warming, very enjoyable.
Very typical porter. Pours dark and has a roast, chocolate, coffee feel.  More bitter than sweet.  Not as much body as others but it works.

Had a mini Porter tasting, first off: Great Lakes Edmund Fitzgerald Porter.  
Dark with ruby highlights shining through.  Nice tan head, faded away quickly, sticking to the glass.  Mild aroma of carmel, roasted malt, chocolate.  Aroma and taste got better after a few extra minutes of warming.  Taste is smooth and exceptional.  Not as thick and heavy as Founders but just as tasty.  Roasted malt, chocolate, coffee and hops.  Very carbonated and light on the tongue.  High drinkability and tasty porter.

Bottle from Breez Thru.  Pours a foamy cola with ruby highlights.  Aroma is coffee, bittersweet chocolate and soy sauce.  Taste is roasted coffee, soy ( or teryiaki sauce?? ), some sweetness from the chocolate.  A bit thin.  Very nice porter!
Dark dark brown-red edges, lumpy light drippy lacing, tan foam.  Aroma is roast and licorice, dark fruit and chocolate.  Taste is almost smoky roast, more anise, chocolate.

Bottle from a Kroger in Lewisburg WV. Heavily roasted barley malt aroma.  Ruby black, clear, with a thin tan head, minimal lacing. Roasted malt flavor initially, black cherry skins at midpalate, hazelnut finish. Tasty and complex without being domineering. Nice porter, well deserving of acolades.

Bottle via trade with jsquire, thanks Jeff! Pours black (clear, super dark ruby when held to light) with a 2 finger, sudsy, tan head that has great retention and leaves nice lacing. Aroma is roast, chocolate truffle, toasted nuts, lacto sweetness, sweet, toasted grain, caramel and light roast coffee. Flavor is roast, dry chocolate, chocolate covered coffee beans, over toasted white bread, toasted wood, cereal and planty/floral hops. Palate is light bodied, creamy on entry and slightly slick the rest of the way with a light, but sharp carbonation. Fantastic porter, not quite as impressive as I remember it being 4-5 years ago, but really good.

Wonderfully brought to me by my Girlfriend when she cam back from North Carolina. Pours a deep black, weak head with some nice lacing. Coffee and burnt chocolate, a bit of malty bitterness. A great porter.

Poured at the speed blogging - Beer bloggers conference 
Great dark malt aroma with caramel. The flavor light roast and caramel also. This was a great beer.  I could taste the light hops made for a great dry and mild finish.
Very dark brown in color - almost black.  Notes of chocolate and coffee, with a deep, bold flavor. Bittersweet and very hoppy.  A great porter!
On tap in a tulip.  Pours very dark brown with a beige head.  Aroma of chocolate, and some light hops.  Flavor of chocolate with a smoky/roasted note.  Average texture.  Not bad for a porter.

This one poured with very minimal carbonation and no head.  Very little lacing.  The malts were definitely multi-layer with the chocolate/coffee thing going on prominently.  The surprise was the citrus/pine hop combo.  Balanced very well.  I recommend it.
user_location: Lake in the Hills, Illinois, USA

text: Winter in the Midwest is offset by the appearance of several superior seasonals including this delightful creation from Great Lakes. The chocolaty scent of a freshly poured Edmund Fitzgerald and the oh-so-gentle sweetness of the taste lead to just a hint of bitterness on the finish. Im grateful that this brewery is represented at all my favorite Milwaukee-area beer stores and that this porter has again arrived.

I have been waiting awhile to taste this porter and I was not let down.  Strong malty flavors with hits of coffee and some chocolate.  Not heavy thoug.  Light as a feather.  Nice carbonation too.  Lovely all around.  Wish I saw it more in LA.

On draught at Finnigans Wake. Pours a deep prune-cola into the glass with a lightly retentive eggshell head that leaves spiderweb lace. The nose is roasty with some nice vinous and grain aromas. Super silky on the palate, lots of roasted coffee beans, almond skins, cabernet notes, dry black malts, and finishing with an almond skin dry-hopped back. Smooth body and superb integration, deeply complex yet uber drinkable. Great, great brew!

On tap at the Map Room, Chicago. Dark brown, mahogany highlights, dense finely bubbled almond head generating thick sheets of lace. aroma of milk chocolate, brown bread, hints of vanilla, toffee, and roast. Silky creamy mouthfeel. Flavours of chocolate, toffee, cream, and cigar box. Perfectly balanced, incredibly drinkable, worthy of the accolades.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Aroma: sugar and bread, sweet; Appearance: coffee brown, almost opaque but not hazy, tan head; Taste: prominent roasty, toasted malt flavor, some caramel, subtle sweetness of dried fruits beneath it all, wonderful taste, makes a very good impression overall, especially so for a porter; Palate: roastiness can be mistaken for coffee in the aftertaste, hops lingers, good carbonation, just enough to be a good sipping beer, not too much; Overall: there is a lot going in this brew, and I really enjoyed it, one of the best Ive had from the Great Lakes selection, I like to enjoy it with or immediately after dinner

Clear dark brown in color, long-lasting light brown head with excellent lacing down the glass. Medium-bodied, smooth and creamy mouthfeel, lasting finish. Toasted, malty nose, chocolate malt as well as a touch of sour aroma. Malty flavor, some chocolate balanced by a dry earthy finish. A fine example of a porter. Good character and complexity.

This is one of the countrys benchmark beers for porter.  It delivers everything I look for in this category of beer, making it in some ways equal to, in some ways better than the great Deschutes Black Butte Porter.
On tap at City Tap House.  Pours a dark brown color with a caramel colored head.  Has an aroma of light roast.  Sweet roasty taste with gentle bitters.  Thin to medium mouthfeel.  Excellent Porter.

Bottle. Pours a deep brown color, not much light coming through this one. Flavor is toasted malts, mild dark chocolates, and a hint of coffee. Medium to light bodied. Finish is surprisingly hoppy and slightly dry. Good easy drinking porter.

Pours deep, dark, black-brown with a slight tan head that pretty quickly dissipates. Aroma is overwhelmingly coffee and dark chocolate, but breathing it in through your mouth hints at some serious hops before ever taking a sip. Flavor is rich with coffee, chocolate and a good amount of bitterness on the finish - not at all overwhelming. Maybe even a little smoky. Just branching out more into porters, stouts, etc. and this is quite tasty.

Bottle at Monks porterhouse.
Mailt and chocolate aromaa. Some coffe and lots of milk chocolate.

Bottle.  Aroma is coffee, burnt malts, and dark chocolate.  I pick up some spice notes, along with some vanilla, noble hops, and sweet malts.  Palate, is creamy and smooth.  Flavor is chocolate and a little bitter.  Hops come out some.  Finishes a little dry.

Bottle, pours black brown wit a fluffy tan head. Toast, malt, and dry dark fruit aromas blend with bitter coffee, dark fuit and hops resin flavors. A great porter when consumed just under room temperature.

Bottle. Pour is brown black with a creamy tan head. Aroma is roasted malt with some dried prunes  and coco. Taste is roasted malt and coco with hints of coffee and some bitterness. Palate is full and chaulky with a nice dry finish. Solid.

12oz bottle thanks to Marcus.

Appearance : Pitch black medium foamy head. Light lacing.

Aroma : Strong coffee and roasted malts. Light raisins with some mollases. Very rich. Wow ! Very rich and strong aroma. Light resinous hops. Some cereals.

Taste : Nice roasted malt and big coffee. Finish is coffee chocolate and roasted malt. Nice hops also. Light fruits. 

Overall : Wow this is very good. Arguably the best porter Ive ever had. Such powerful taste and aroma in such a low alcohol beer. Great hops and roasted malt on taste. Awesome finish that lasts for a long time. Nose is very roasted.. like slightly burnt. Im adding 0.1 overall because they managed to make this so low alcohol.

the legend lives on from the top of the bottle on down...... anyway, I digress.  this is a very nice porter and Im glad my glass is full right now.  but, it has a little ways to go before it catches Founders porter.  .  .  .  . the searches all say theyd a made whitefish bay if theyd put 15 more beers behind them.

Whole Foods, DC ($10): Pours black with beautiful head. Aroma of light coffee, and bittersweet chocolate along with roasted malts. Creamy texture. Tastes of espresso beans. Some chocolate. Finishes off with the bitter hops that linger mixed with the roasted espresso beans flavors. Everything is perfectly balanced, giving the taster a beer equally creamy and bitter.

Poured into a frosted pint. Appearance is a dark brown, almost black with a good sized tan head. Aroma is chocolate and licorice. Taste is like chocolate and coffee as well as the aftertaste. This is a fantastic beer. One of my favorite porters.

Dark brown with light brown head.  Deep ruby and transparent when held up to a very bright light.  Aroma: pumpernickel, sweet chocolate, very mild forest.  Flavor: sweetness hits first, followed by immediate burnt bitterness on the back and sides of the tongue.  Slight caramel.  Hops are definitely present, but blend in very discretely with the burntness.  Solid; its bursting with flavor. As it warms the (hop) bitterness becomes a bit too much, perhaps too much cohumulone?
UPDATED: SEP 25, 2010 Bottle thanks to MSante79. Black pour. Nose and taste of roasted malts. Medium body. Not much else to it. Some chocolate, but not enough to set it apart from others.
Had at Great Lakes tasting at Fizz. Very good Porter but much more hoppy than I expected. Serving: Bottle

OK, THIS is why a good porter is fun to drink - full and malty enough, lots of chocolate going on (and toffee nut coffee) and the body doesnt kill you after one serving.  Its clear dark dark brown with a light brown head, aromas suggest flavors to follow. Extremely pleasing dryness to balance the solid mat backbone. Be interested in aging a few, nice beer!

On tap at East End Alehouse.  Pours a deep dark brown color with no head.  Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, and a bit of hops.  Super creamy with chocolate bittersweetness balanced by roasted malts and hop bitter finish.  Great beer!
Poured nice and dark with beige head. Aromas of chocolate, coffee, and slightly roasty. Tastes like it smells. A well balanced Porter, smooth and not too heavy.
12 oz bottle. Pours a dark brown almost black with a nice tan head. Nice chocolate mocha taste with an aftertaste of coffee. Good porter to enjoy with a nice big piece of chocolate cake

12 oz. bottle. Appearance- Dark opaque brom with some reddish hues. Fine robust head that leaves plenty of lacing behind. Aroma- Roasty, coffee, some chocolate, mild sweetness. Taste- Mildly sweet . Chocolate roast with some coffee in the finish. Bitterness balnces well with the roast. Palate- Smooth sily medium mouth feel. Overall- Wow! What a nice porter. Rich in flavor though not astringent or overwhelming. Very drinkable. This is the last in the variety pack from this brewer and I have not been dissappointed. They are good at what they do.
Tap @ Great Lakes - very tasty porter. Arouma of espresso and chocolate. roasty, smooth and creamy body. Finishes with nutty, earthy bitterness.

6 pack from Itaca, NY. dark brown with light lacey head. leathery fertile soil aroma. strong roasted nut flavor with coffee toast finish. slight bitter sour mouthfeel, but full of flavor. great name, love the history of the ship, which is why I searched the beer out. well worth it. picking up a case when i go to the Ithaca brewfest.

Shared with ibrew2or3. thanks Dave.
light brown, tan head.
holy goodness, packs a nice malty profile, loaded with chocolate, roasted flavors, dry and crisp palate, lasting coffee mouthfeel with a touch of smoke in the finish.

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2011 From a bottle into a snifter.  Pours a dark brown with a tan head.  Aroma of bittersweet chocolate and roastiness with a bit of coffee.  Taste is roasty with bitter chocolate throughout.  Mouthfeel is a bit thin but smooth.  Overall a terrific brew, Im lucky to live in a place with a consistent supply of it, soooo delicious.
Great tasting beer but must drink it above 50 degrees F.  An almost black beer with a  rocky tan head.

Pours dark brown with a beige head.  Aroma is coffee,  chocolate, earthy, roasty and coffee.  Taste is sweet with some bitterness on the finish, the coffee undertones come through.  Very smooth and velvety and one of the best porters Ive had.
Pour a very dark color with a nice thick tannish head, aroma is earthy with a hint oc chocolate and coffee to it, taste is very smooth with a great chocolate taste, a darn good porter.

Bottle: Pours very dark, with a modest tan head. Smell is distinctly like a sweet coffee, flavors of bittersweet chocolate, roasted coffee, malt, and hops. I was surprised at how smooth this brew was to drink, in spite of the mild bitterness. Fantastic.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2010 An excellent beer. Great mix of hops, malt, roast, sweet, and bitterness. The color is gorgeously dark, and has a nice head. Porter is the style of beer I drink least, but this one is great.
Deep amber color with a really rich aroma. Unlike other reviewers, I dont taste as much coffee in it but its definitely there along with some nutty flavors.

I dont know if its just a phase but i was really into porters is a wee lad, and then moved on, the sweetness was crushed by the west coast ipa invasion. But, on that note, this is some tasty stuff. Ive had this for some time, but drinking it before the pull date, but just couldnt pull the trigger on a porter night, im glad i did. Deep dark pour, great nose with deep roasted malts. Taste was a nice coffee/ chocolate balance throughout to the finish. Very light mouthfeel, but very drinkable. Good stuff.

Draught at the Churchkey in D.C. Poured coffee black with a thick white head that faded slowly as the beer warmed. Aroma was big coffee, chocolate and some earthy hop notes, the flavor was similar except adding a little licorice into the mix. The mouthfeel was medium thick, and it felt real good sliding down the old gullet. One of the better porters Ive ever had, wish it made it out here.

Bottle. Poured a near clear dark brown with a hint of red and a light brown head that dissipated to the edges. Aroma was full of roasted malts with some backing chocolate and coffee. Flavor was similar with roasted malts in the beginning that are joined by a semi-bitter chocolate note and coffee note.

12 ounce bottle.

A: Pours a dark brown, with ruby red peeking through the corners, and a tan head.
S: Belgian chocolate and coffee.
T: Sweet Belgian chocolate followed by coffee and roasted malt.
M: Medium bodied and well carbonated.
D: Wow. After having tried Founders offering as well, I dont know which is better, but a side to side tasting is probably in order.

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2010 Bottle.  Pours nearly black with a small tan head and not much lacing.  Beautiful aroma:  deep, rounded roast malt, sweet, chocolate.  Flavor follows aroma, but hops and coffee appear in the finish.  Has a slightly creamy, lactose flavor.  Medium, almost even light palate.  Fabulous beer from beginning to end.

12 oz, bb 10/18/10. Opaque with a lasting film of cream. Nose is a nice melange of ash, chocolate, caramel, and espresso. Flavor is dark roasted walnut, coffee, cocoa. Nice touches of wood, smoke, black pepper, iodine, and vanilla on the finish. The dark roast becomes a bit overpowering after half a glass though. Smooth, medium-heavy body is slightly sticky,  and acidic/astringent enough to finish just dry.

Just surprised by this. Fairly cheep but one of the better porters Ive tried far. Very dark, a nice, deep roast, but very drinkable.Small bit of sweet in the the after taste, and maybe even a bit of sour. Just terrific.

Draft. Absolutely impressive near-black beer with deep, roasty character yet easy drinkability. Real harmony and balance of flavors here... Impression of sweetness but moderate roast bitterness, good body. Very likable.
Since I tend to favor Porter, my rating for this is a bit biased.  It is a good beer though.

An aroma of a smoky charred oak, and a deep and satisfying taste of charred oak and chocolate; the aroma doesnt tease with this beer. A very light creamy texture, and a descent head. A dark, almost black translucent color. This beer is seriously amazing, especially with chocolate cookies ala mode.

Pours a dark ruby red to black with a nice 2 finger tan head.  Smells strong of oatmeal and a bit of bitter chocolate.  Has a nicely carbonated, not too thick mouthfeel.  The taste nice roasty malts, with bitter chocolate and a great hop presence.  This is a great refreshing porter and I could have many of these throughout the night
Great aromas of chocolate and roasted coffee, smooth and flavorful, with malts and chocolate/coffee/a hint of smokiness.  Absolutely delicious.

ruby brown pour with a thick tan head.
aroma is coffee, dusty chocolate. 
Flavour is roasted malt. slightly nutty, nice coffee tones through the middle, dry chocolately finish.

Over the past months, Great Lakes has skyrocketed to one of my favorite breweries. Everything that they make is just of an unbelievable quality. The Edmund Fitzgerald Porter is no exception. Its everything that a porter should be: dark, rich chocolaty sweetness with a bitter aftertaste akin to coffee. Its just an orgasmic explosion of all of my favorite flavors, and the key to Great Lakes success in their rendition of the porter is that they nail the balance of these flavors exquisitely. The first thing I notice when I sip one is that sweetly sparse flavor of dark chocolate, which quickly gives way to a bite of iced coffee. If you let a single swig go unaccompanied for too long, there is a twinge of unpleasant bitterness, but otherwise its titties in a bottle. The only better porters out there that Ive tried are Bells, and quite possibly Hoppys.

12 oz. bottle, consumed on 7-6-10. Sharp aroma of dark chocolate, roasted coffee been, crystalized brown sugar, caramel, and toffee. Pours a dark brown (though not as dark as somer porters) with a ruby hue. Clear liquid. Moderate amount of even, thin, beige/tan head. Produces good lacing. Dark roasted malts dominate the flavor. Some chocolate, but the coffee taste is too strong for me, someone who cant stand coffee. Milky taste develops eventually. Dry, bitter aftertaste. Light to medium body. Soft in the palate. Highly drinkable in terms of palate effects, though the sometimes unpleasant flavor doesnt help matters. Edmund Fitzgerald seems well made, but the problem for me is that its a porter (i.e., Im not a fan of the style). Oh well.

Probably one of their best beers, aroma of roasted malts... Flavor is malty with a lot of chocolate notes initially but with a coffee finish on the palate... Very complex for a porter, a true flavor explosion... Well done great lakes

Pours brown with a tan head. The aroma is very chocolaty with some lactose and roasted malt. Smells rich. The flavor is the same with lots of chocolate and plummy notes. Pretty sweet with a nice roasty finish. Light on the palate, but tasty. A nice porter.

Draft @ The Map Room, Chicago, IL. Pours a dark amber/brown color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity roasted malty chocolate and caramel aroma. Fruity malty smooth caramel and chocolate flavor. Has a roasted malty caramel finish with hoppy hints in the aftertaste.

Huge off-brown head on black.  Pleasing roasted malt aroma with light chocolate notes.  Classic roasted malt taste with bitter chocolate notes.  Not as much smoke in the taste as I would have thought.  Quality brew nonetheless.
Pours a black with a nice 1 finger tan head. Aroma of subtle chocolate. Bitter to sweet. lots of smoked malt and hints of bittersweet chocolate. Okay beer.

Pours a very dark brown with just a slight deep reddish tint - about 95% opaque, with a beautiful thick foamy white head.

Aroma is a delicious bouquet of roasty malt, chocolate, and coffee.  Flavor is remarkably similar with just a slightly hoppy element added in to give it a slight twinge of bitterness in the finish.

Incredibly easy to drink with excellent balance between being smooth and syrupy this is an amazing medium-bodied beer.  Really really tasty!  Will DEFINITELY be drinking more of this!

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2010 Puts the "Robust" in Robust Porter more than any other that Ive tried.  Flavors of BBQesque smoke, cocoa, and roasted malts overwhelm and swarm the palate.  Bitterness on the end is slight, coffee-like, and while tolerable, not ideal.  Remarkably dry, incredibly flavorful, and Im probably underrating it overall.

Little head. Aroma of chocolate and coffee, I mean fresh brewed. Color is almostpitch black, just a slight noticeable brown. Tastes lighlty of milk chocolate, with a stronger coffee domination. Other coffee flavored porters have a burnt dark roast flavor and gross aftertaste, this is played down and tastes of fresh brewed coffee and the aftertaste gives you more chocolate mixed in. Great beer, will drink again.
chocolate, coffee, caramel, roasty, black, cloudy, brown foam, frothy, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, full body, creamy, oily feel, soft carbonation, long finish,

Draft at Great Lakes Brewery in November 2008.  This is one the most well balanced porters and dark malt beer I have ever tried.  Dark brown with good head.  Aroma and flavor consist of chocolate and coffee, but the coffee comes off as coffee and not as burn roastiness, which helps keep this porter smooth and balanced.  Mouthfeel is thin but this makes for a very drinkable beer.  Complex flavors and aromas meld well together.

Bottle thanks to cmillward: Poured a black with a fast acting frothy tan head. Aroma is gritty coffee grounds and roasted malt.  Taste is a bitter dark chocolate with a mocha coffee finish. Very sweet and dry finish.
Nice grainy caramels in the aroma. Rather roasty emphasizing roasted barley, nutty, some chocolate and coffee. Very firm hop bitterness, with some c hop flavor.
Maybe not as impressed as my fellow RBs. Nice black pour with a tan head. Malty smoky aroma that leads to a malty smoky flavor . Maybe a tad thin in the finish. Not bad but not my favorite porter.

A sentimental favorite, so may have overrated it but inarguably a great beer. Deep coffee flavors with chocolate. A bit smokey and caramelly. If had to have one beer to drink the rest of my life, a definite contender.
Medium in mouthfeel, but amazing aroma of roasted malts, and a a perfect balance of malts and hops to keep the avoid the the overpowering roasty flavor most porters have.  Delicious! Very drinkable.

12 oz bottle from Princetons.  Dark brown pour with a couple fingers of tan head.  Aroma and flavor are both very much the chocolate and coffee mentioned in the commercial description. Mouthfeel isnt too thick, the hops come through in finish but I would have never guessed this was a 60 IBU beer.  Very easy drinking porter.

Normally I find porters kind of dry (pun) but this one has a dark mocha roasted juiciness with a sweet hoppy oatmeal rye nut flavor to go along with it. Only drawback for me is the rather wet finish. I want this on tap!

Appearance: Ruby highlights flow through a dark brown body with a light mocha head with fair retention and nice lacing.

Smell: what a nose...can you say coffee and chocolate all the way? well edmund fitzgerald porter can and does.

Taste: Lucuious tasting roasted malt, coffee, and chocolate blended to perfection. Really the best tasting porter I have had so far. Not overly bitter either which is nice. But of the bitterness that it does have, dont be fooled into thinking it all comes from the coffee / chocolate flavors. There is a definite hop bite in the finish which is really well done.

Mouthfeel: Actually a bit thin in my opinion but not to the point where it ruins the brew in any way. I just think this is an area for improvement.

Drinkability: excellent nose and taste combined with a slightly thin mouthfeel equals easy drinking!

Hats off to Great Lakes Brewing...

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-30-2008

Bouteille de 12 oz achetée chez Half Time (Poughkeepsie, NY). Arôme: Odeur de café torréfié avec une pointe chocolatée. Apparence: La couleur est brune-noirâtre. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de café et de chocolat avec une pointe de caramel. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement minérale. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de café en arrière goût. (Rating #3022)

A very dark porter, with a smooth medium bitterness, and a slight sour bite at the end.  Nice, but somewhat short lived head.  Very light nose with a nice caramel aroma.  Good medium-heavy body feel in the mouth, with nice carbonation.  Overall I was surprised how well this beer tasted. I would recommend this to those who love a nice dark beer.

Great Lakes has arrived in MN this week! :) 
Grabbed a 6er at Blue Max. Beer has a nice roasty aroma. Color is a rich, dark brown. Pours with a one-finger tan head. Nice smooth flavor, yet still boasting a hoppy presence with complementing notes of coffee, chocolate, and a slight nutty flavor. I will try to drink this often. Look for more Great Lakes ratings soon- I grabbed 3 different brews today.
12 ounce bottle courtesy DLD trade-a dark brown pour-tan head-aroma and taste of some coffee-roasty, -nice slight bitter roasty finish

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2013 Aroma: Moderate coffee roast; more smokey than I remember; bittersweet cacao. Appearance: Nearly black with a frothy mocha head that settles into a ring. Flavor: Roasty smoke; bitter cacao; rather dry all around with not a hint of sweetness. Palate: Medium body, slick texture, soft carbonation, bitter finish. Overall: Nice one to return to after a few years; its held up very well. A very good Porter to have around.

Serving: Draft.
It pours a dark brown with ruby highlights and a small, light tan head.  The nose is very roasty with notes of lightly roasted coffee, some chocolate, and roasted malt.  The taste mirrors the nose but with more of a hop prescence.  Some caramel and fruit flavors join the party as the beer warms.  Medium bodied leading to a long, roasty finish.  It is an excellent porter that is definitely worth trying.

Bottle courtesy of jprime. Slightly reddish brown pour with a thin veil of foam. Aroma is quite hoppy, smells like an american barleywine. Hops, molasses and rich malts. Taste is quite sweet, old hops, and more molasses. Palate is thin and sticky almost no carbonation.

pours a lovely almost-black brown with a thin beige head. nose is big with caramel, leather, cigar, chocolate, coffee, and roasted malts. a little nutty as well. flavor is big and chocolatey, with a nicely balanced roasted malt flavor and some slight bitter notes as well. finish is long, a little bitterness developing. thick and creamy, almost the consistency of a root beer float. pretty awesome.
Pours a dark brown/black with a thin head. Armoa is full of coffee, and a tad of chocolate.Flavor was the same, not too sweet, not too roasty.

Aroma is of ale yeast, toast, and moderate earthy hops.  Clear brown with dense beige head.  Flavor is smoke, caramel, chocolate, coffee.  Medium-heavy body and full, smooth mouthfeel.  Moderate carbonation gives it just a little bite.  Finish is perfect balance of sweet / bitter / dry.  Alcohol is well-covered.  Excellent.

Milk chocolate, toasty malts, cocoa, and a feint herbal nose.  Black coffee, burnt sugar, toffee, with a touch of hops in the back ground,   Mouth feel starts a little on the lively side fading into a pleasant firm smoothness.  Finishes with a lingering roasted malt character and a dash of hop resin.  Well done!
Draught.  Not a huge head.  Nice aroma, chocolate without being overly sweet.  Very nice. Good hops balance.

Poured from 12 oz bottle.  Aroma is rich with roasted chocolate and malt.  Pours black with a thin head.  Taste is very smooth, chocolate and a hint of coffee with subtle hops.  Truly a fantastic porter, one of the best out there.
Aroma - roasted/nut/malt/chocolate.  Not a big fan of the taste/palate or finish.  Seems a little over-carbonated.

This is a great porter. Pours dark brown with very thin tan head. The taste is very chocolate with some coffee flavoring with a refreshing almost minty hop aftertaste. Its very good. This is the most refreshing drinkable porter Ive had. I recommend it.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-08-2007 00:23:44
12oz bottle courtesy StFun.  The aroma is chocolate and soy. The flavor is light roast with lots of milk chocolate and a hint of coffee. Not too bad!

Pours a 1/2", frothy, light brown head.  Clear, deep brown body with some ruby.  Aroma of light roast and dark chocolate.  Bitter chocolate flavors with some sweet caramel and lightly roasted coffee.  Nicely balanced and layered.  Medium-light body with average carbonation.  Malt is balanced by both hop and a pleasant roast bitterness.  Slightly sticky finish with a touch of residual ash.  Overall a very nice porter.

Pours a dark reddish mahogany with a a creamy tan head, mostly diminishing, with a fine long lasting lacing. The aroma is of coffee, caramel and roasted malt. Very creamy and full bodied; a rich feeling on the palate. Great long lasting finish, leaving a slightly burnt malt taste, but crisp and very mellow. Nicely carbonated. A great accompaniment to any hearty fare, including steak, burgers, brats, or stew. or to use when I simmer my ribs.

Bottle - Pours opaque black with a big, fat tan head. Love the aroma -- smooth, caramel malt (that seems to be in several of the GL beers) with just enough hops to balance out. Theres a little coffee, chocolate, lactose, and metal. Taste is dark burnt malt, coffee, wood, bitter chocolate. Smooth, creamy, and easy-drinking.

A nice, balanced porter that isnt trying to blow my head off with chocolate, coffee, or ABV!  Pours a clear dark brown/mahogany with a perfect sudsy cream head.  Aroma is a great mix of almonds, roasted marshmallow, and earthy hops.  Flavor is a bit unexpected, as the hops cut right through the chocolate and coffee base to dominate the front of the palate...slowly fades into more traditional roasty flavors.

A touch thin and strong on carbonation, but its a tasty little brew.

A dark reddish brown porter with a thin off white head. In aroma,nice light chocolate, with mineral notes. In mouth, a bitter herbal chocolate with nutty notes, coffee grinds, not bad, medium bodied. Tasted at CNY brewfest, Feb. 6 2010.

Pours a dark ruby-tinged sable that is somewhat translucent with a decent pale tan head. Aroma is strong and smoky, mainly of fine roast coffee. Flavor is like a fine mocha, slightly sweet and with a firm molasses undertone. Texture is smooth, tingly and edgy. Definitely worthy.

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2011 Deep brown color with a creamy tan head that has excellent retention. The aroma is full of roasted barley with a sweetness that reminds me of molasses. Also get notes of toffee. The flavor is incredibly balanced with roasted malt, chocolate bits, and subtle hop bitterness. Get a touch of smoky notes with a semi sweet and dry finish. The body is medium and creamy. This is a PRIME example of a robust porter. One of my favorites.

Bottle from a trade with phaleslu. Pours brown with tan head. Aromas of roasted malts and chocolate.  Roasted malts and bittersweet chocolate flavors. A touch of sweetness. Medium to full body with mild carbonation. A really nice porter. Thanks Peter.

This is good.....real good.  Great balance between all the components.......extremely drinkable. Nice roasted, smokey aroma with some sweet element like cola or brown sugar. Toasty and rich on palate with creamy texture finishes with a milk chocolate element.

Pours a near black brown with a small tan head. Chocolate and roast are most pronounced in the aroma. Nice clean flavor with chocolate, roasted coffee, and tobacco. On the sweet side. Full bodied with a long bitter finish.
Great malty aroma with hop undertones. Pours a dark black but little head or lacing. Taste is a well balanced porter with great hop balance.

Sampled at Central New York Brewfest, Syracuse NY. 06FE10.
App.:  Deep brown with reddish hues, tan rim.
  
Aroma:  Kinda stark and stern, British malts, some coffee and chocolate notes, a bit of resinous hops, restrained.
  
Palate:  Medium body, moderate, yet aggressive effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Black coffee and leafy resinous hops, some earthy, austere malts, some chocolate and vanilla pokes through, fair; dry with decent bitterness and a grape-like, dark malt finish.

I bet Gordon Lightfoot would like it.

A: Edmund Fitzgerald pours black with a layer of tan foam.

S: An absolutely amazing chocolate aroma is the first sensation I experience. Excellent roasted malt aroma and some mild coffee come through as well. There is a sweetness that I generally find in milk stouts, but was quite a pleasant surprise.

T: The flavors are pretty much right on target with the nose. A great sweetness and tons of chocolate come through first. The roasted malt and coffee follow those up and provide a somewhat bitter finish.

M: The body is on the fuller side of medium, with moderate carbonation, and nice creamy mouthfeel.

D: Im glad I was able to pick this one up. A great balance of flavors and a nice mouthfeel help this one out big time. I wouldnt hesitate to buy this one again.

12 oz bottle. This was a good example of what a standard porter should be. The subtle aroma has a nice variety of roasted malts and nuts, a indistinct hop presence, and minor mocha. Nothing mind blowing there, but still quite pleasant. On the pour, a beautiful soapy bubble head, that when dissipated makes the beer look much more like a cola. The flavor and feel here however, far exceed any cola. Again, nice  roasted malts mixed with nuts, caramel, light mocha, and a earthy hop. Even though theres not a lot of distinct hop qualities here, its still well balanced. Some carbonation in the feel, mostly smooth and fairly dry through the finish. There may be nothing too incredibly special here overall, but the balance and overall drinkability make this one nice.

Bottle pour.Dark brown with a good beige head.Aroma was roasty with chocolate and coffee coming through.Taste was the same just a little more of the roasted malt and slightly bitter,dark fruit hints as well.Really good.
UPDATED: FEB 1, 2010 Very good porter, dark brown to almost black in color with a tan head. Tastes of bitter slightly burnt chocolate and coffee.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2010 12 oz bottle, amazed I havent rated this considering the amount of times Ive had it. Pours an extremely deep brown nearly black with a fluffy light tan head. Aroma is rich roasted malts, nicely deep milk chocolate and bitter dark chocolate. There is a distinct dark fruitiness in there too, maybe some plum and cherry. Flavor is even better, very robust and complex malt character, a nice bitter lightly burnt note along with more chocolate, caramel, coffee and nuts. Just enough of a floral hop note to add a balancing effect. Nice mediumish creamy body and a soft carbonation. Really great porter, one of my favorites.

Best Porter I have had...a lot of them dont have quite the flavor that Im looking for but this bad boy did.  Tons of roast and malt, little chocolate, etc.  Very full flavor but without being heavy.  Great stuff

Draugh at Churchkey.
Opaque black with a large beige head that disappears quickly and leaves great lacing.  Aroma of chocolate and roasted coffee.  Taste begins with sweetness then turns slightly bitter and dry, and finally a finish of port wine.  Interesting and complex.

The beer pours dark brown with an off-white head. The aroma is basic porter, roasted malt with a little bit of coffee. The flavor is more of the same with roasted malt, chocolate and coffee. There are also some hops to stop the beer from being too sweet. Creamy mouthfeel. A very good porter.

355mL. Pours a deep ruby with a cola-like fizzy head that dwindles to nothing. Aroma is dark chocolate, cocoa, some ash. Taste is sticky malt, some ash, pervading unsweetened chocolate bitterness. Dry on the palate. Fizzy carbonation. Lots of ashtray.
This has to be one of the best porters on the market.  It has a smooth crisp taste.
A dark brown beer with a nice aroma of roasted malts and faint chocolate and coffee flavors.  A little bit of balancing hops.  The body follows the aroma.

( 12oz bottle thanks to BA zdk9) pours very dark brown with nice head and tons of creamy lacing. Nose of aromatic hops, coffee, chocolate-covered oranges,  pine, and bittersweet chocolate. Taste is unsweet but creamed coffee, semi-sweet chocolate and a balanced spicy hop profile. Creamy well carbonated palette here. Very good porter!

Picked up a single 12-oz bottle at Three Cellars in Franklin, WI. Pours a semi-clear very dark brown colored brew with a thick tan head that has nice retention and lacing. Aroma of roasted dark malt, a hint of smoke, chocolate and coffee. Taste is medium bodied, soft carbonation with flavors of roasted dark malt, coffee/chocolate with some dark pitted fruits and some floral hops. Finish is smooth with some light roasted dark malt with just the right amount of clean aftertaste.

Poured from a 12oz. bottle into a pint glass.

The color is a deep black with a nice maroon hue when held to the light. A finger and a half of light brown head with some nice lacing

The smell is a nice malty flavor that just holds you attention for a moment or two. The flavor is a bit of a mellow malty roasted flavor.

The taste is a nice roasty, smooth malt flavor with some nice slight chocolate milk flavor. Some nice slight coffee flavor hides in the background and can mix in from one sip to the next.

The feel of the beer is really smooth. It goes down with a little wisp of a alcohol bite. It have a nice drinkable feel and goes down well.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2010 From an old rating note:  12oz bottle from Andersons in Toledo.  Dark brown pour with medium tan head.  Aroma of coffee, chocolate and nuts.  Taste follows suit.  Definitely need to have this one again - my porter palate has broadened quite a bits since I tried this.  RE-RATE (2/28/10): bottle once again from Andersons.  Yeah, Id pretty much stick to my first impression.  thin palate.  light bitter chocolate.  Ok - not what I like in a porter I guess.
Tap. Very dark pour. Roasty nose with sweet malt elements. Roasty flavor with coffee and chocolate. Really good stuff.

Bottle, pours a very dark almost black with a red hue with a huge tan head. Aroma, very bittersweet maybe chocolate and toffee and coffee and something uber sweet. Taste, like old coffee- been sitting too long and is very strong, some chocolate smoothness creamy. Not bad.

Bottle, best before 04/22/10.  Roast, tar, chocolate, woody nose, light coffee roast.  Superb.  Pours a deep brown with a lacing, rocky tan head.  Medium-light body, dry and somewhat filling.  Deep roast flavor, real depths here, with tar and wood, light ash and smoke, lesser coffee and chocolate.  Earth (soil) with just a light hop presence in the back, but again earthy and meshes well.  Creamy and smooth, low-medium bitterness.  Buzzword here is balance; for all the intense flavor, all elements are blended well and none really stick out.  An exemplar effort.

Pours dark, slightly ruddy when held up to the light. Topped with a light tan head. Nose of chocolate, roast and bit of sweet caramel with a light earth and pine hop presence. Flavor is roast, some coffee, chocolate, a bit of roast acidity and a solid bitter finish. Very tasty. Solid porter.

This is what a porter should be. Perfect balance of chocolate, roasted, burnt, and sweet malt. Very easy to drink. Not too sweet, and still a nice rich body. There isnt much more to say other than this is what a porter should be.

A: Deep dark brown with maroon hints bleeding thru. Big khaki head that dies down nicely. There is some lacing left behind as I pounded this bad boy.

S: Aromas of black coffee, bitter chocolate, buttery toffee, and raisins.

T: Very bold and complex porter. Nice rich roasted dark malts. Chocolate and coffee dominate. There is a buttery vanilla taste in the background which makes this one especially nice.

M: Full bodied with a creamy feel.

Edmund is a nice porter that feels a bit thin on the palate.  This might be a little too hoppy for me; I would have liked some more malt for balance, but this is very nice.  Honestly not really detecting the coffee taste--as advertised--but I usually dont.

See thru chestnut with a rocky tan slowly fading tan head.  Patchy lacing.  Aroma of caramel, coffee, roasted malt, dark fruit and a touch of sourness.  Taste of caramel, dark and roasted malts, coffee with a peppy finish.  Creamy body with a fuller mouth feel than most porters.  Decent enough.

Bottle. Dark, fairly viscous, with a nice tan head. Aromas of chocolate, plums, coffee, and malt. Flavor is packed with rich chocolate malt, with a little roasty coffee note in the background, maybe a little smokiness. Palate is just barely on the thin side of where Id like it. Overall, a unique and very nice porter, and well-priced in a sixer.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2010 Refrigerated bottle poured into a tumbler.  Pours a dark brown with ruby highlights with small beige head and a little lacing.  The taste is roasted malts, hops, coffee with a hint of chocolate, and a long dry aftertaste.  Best porter I have had.
A lovely porter with a bit of a bitter aftertaste. very flavorful thick beer

Pours black with small head. Smells of malts, coffee and chocolate. Taste follows the nose with coffee, chocolate and a small hop bitter. Finishes with a long semi dry bitterness that lingers. Good sipper.

Overall, I expected a lot more from this. But it was basically a non-descript beer. Mild aroma ( typical porter, roasted malt and coffee). Mild flavors, no bitterness. Mild mouthfeel. This was just all around average to me, but would make a great session beer.

UPDATED: APR 29, 2013 From trip to Cleveland in September.

Nice sweet, chocolaty aroma.  Darker mahogany color.  Nice mildly hoppy taste with decent malt.  A nice tasting porter.  I enjoy this beer, and wasnt a big porter fan going in.

Enjoyed from a 12oz bottle on many occasions.  The beer pours a deep brown to just slightly lower in SRMs than totally black with a tan head.  Carbonation is med-low.  The nose is initially of coffee and roasted malts, with some malt character, and just a slight touch of hops.  The palate is roasty and coffee-like up front, and then transfers into a clean American-style porter on the back-end.  Slight mid-crystal malts are detectable in the mid-palate to finish.  The latter is clean and semi-dry.  Overall, a classic robust porter.

An extra point just for the name!  Bottle at 1016 at the Genesee Grand in Syracuse, NY.  Roasted caramel malt and toffee aroma,  Dark brown and ruby appearance.  Chocolate caramel taste followed by a slightly bitter hoppiness.  Very good beer.

Fluff tan head- black as night color.  I picked up some sour cherry in the aroma- interesting.  Nutty flavor, touch of cherry again, roasted malt, hint of burnt bitterness in the finish.  Smooth, but too light carbonation- makes the body a touch watery, which is a slight distraction.  I like the roasted smoky finish.
Bottle, thanks Nolan. Pours mostly black with a brown/ruby edge. Roasted malt/coffee flavor. Smooth with slight carbonation. Easy drinking and an excellent 6-pack candidate.

Courtesy dragonstout. Pours a nearly black body topped by a small, tan colored foam that quickly recedes to a thin film. The aroma is really nice showing hints of dark chocolate, roasted coffee, cream, and some earthy hop bitterness. The flavor follows with the dark chocolate and toasted caramel malts balanced nicely by some roasted coffee, earthy hops, and vanilla cream. Medium to full bodied with balanced carbonation that leads to a long, roasted chocolate finish. This is a really nice porter.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2010 A solid, comforting porter, just the thing on a chilly halloween night.  Nice aroma of malt and molasses.  Subtle, hoppy nose. Body is tobacco, carmelized brown sugar and finishes bittersweet (but not in that order).  This is an impressively elegant yet robust beer that walks the line between the unassuming, refined nature of its british roots and the agression of the American Craft Beer Movement.  This is my first beer from Great Lakes but I will have to try some others and see if they are as good as this one!

Deep dark brown to black color. Cream medium bodied head. Dark roast style coffee aroma most present, with hints of chocolate. Strong taste of coffee, with hints of chocolate.  very low bitterness, mostly bittersweet, as the bitterness seems to come more from the coffee malt than the hops.  Great Porter, very clean and a fairly simple, dark but well balanced taste.

This is a pretty good porter.  It has a nice strong roasted mallt, chocolate, and coffee flavor.  THe head is a nice and near the beer surface.  Ths is a good after dinner beer or could go with a good steak.

(Bottle, Monks Café, Wallingatan, Stockholm) Dark brown colour, almost black. Pale brown head. Malty, roasted nose with notes of ryvita, tobacco and chocolate. Malty, roasted taste with chocolate, dark rye bread, raisins, blackberries, a touch of smoke and tobacco. Nice dry finish with a chocolatey bitterness. Medium body, fairly dry. Nice, dry porter with a different tobacco touch.

wonderful- pours with the color and head of a cream soda -  nice toasted marshmallow aroma, chewy roasty nutiness with a little hop presence in the background,  a really top notch beer all around, no weaknesses

Bottle.  Pour is clear dark brown with small tan head.  Really pretty light. Aroma is light coffee and malt with a hint of hop.  Mouthfeel is more velvety than expected, really nice.  Flavor is roasted malt, light coffee finish with a malty sweetness and a nice hop presence. Good stuff.
Well, The best american beer. Tastes better all other porters, I dont find anything wrong with it at all.
120z bottle pours very very dark with only about a 1/4" light tan head. Nice aroma of chocolate and coffee. Drinks much bigger then the 5.8% ABV.  A very very good Porter.
12oz. pours dk brown with bubbly head. aroma is little coffee and a little tin... taste is pleasant with some coffee and a bitter finish. much better mouth feel than aroma
Deep brown, thick head.  Light roasted flavor. Smooth, thin mouthfell.  A decent porter.

Sampled at WBF in Duham - this beer came highly recommended and did not disappoint.  Poured a dark reddish brown - almost black - color with a foamy tan head.  Nice aroma of chocolate and a french roast coffee.  Nice smooth taste of malt, chocolate, and dark coffee with a hint of licorice and bitterness.  Perfect carbonation.  Very solid beer that I will be very happy to see if/when they start distributing in NC.
From a bottle poured black with a fair amount of head.  Nice sweet malty flavor with a lasting bitter coffe aftertaste.
Aroma of big roast burnt, some smoke, caramel and chocolate... Dark brown, clear... Flavor of chocolate, roasty, slightly smoky, and a touch dry in the finish, very good...

Bottle. Pours very dark with only a thin sheath of head. Transmits only a little light, looks reddish-purple in the light. Aroma is of chocolate and coffee, smells delicious!! A long, complex flavor.
