Take your first sip carefully and think about it for a good minute. Very smooth, pretty well balanced. This is a GREAT porter!
Great dark brown/ruby color.  Good flavor with a bit of coffee and chocolate hints.  Nice finish that leaves a light burnt taste, which is not too heavy body.

Draught at Map Room, Chicago. Deep brown pour with nice beige head. Coffee/chocolate aroma. Tastes of chocolate, caramel, malt, sweet, coffee. Really smooth drinking and well balanced porter. Very enjoyable.

Bottled at Monks Café, Wallingatan, Stockholm. Pours out in a dark brown, almost black colour with a small tan-coloured foam. Rich, complex and rounded aroma of dark coffee, cookies, milky chocolate, leather and nuts. Medium-bodied with touches of black coffee, burnt caramel, crackers, mild smoke and cocoa. Long roasty finish of dark chocolate, coffee, burnt caramel, cookies and leather. An incredible tasty and balanced session porter!

Bottle at Monks Cafe, Stockholm. Dark brown beer with a thick beige head. Sweet malt, sweet pipe tobacco, caramel and chocolate in aroma. Flavour is light smoke, caramel, hops, chocolate, light coffee and tobacco.

Location: 12 oz bottle that jcos brought back from Cleveland, 9/10/09


Aroma: Roasted malts dominate the nose, bit of chocolate, coffee, mild hops

Appearance: Dark brown color, bit of red, quickly dissipating beige head

Flavor: Nice hoppy porter flavor,balanced and flavorful, long, bitter finish

Palate: Medium-full bodied beer with a long finish, smooth

Overall Impression:
My first Great Lakes beer (but not my last...Thanks, Justin!)  This is a tasty beer for sure.  I like the addition of a bit more hops then are standard for this style to the traditional porter flavors that you find in this beer.  Nice amount of body, nice taste, nice from start to finish, a nice beer, that I think is rated very accurately.
Subtle, roasted aroma. Beautiful dark, opaque appearance. The flavor is so smooth, not complex but just right for a porter.

Pours a cola like color nice tan head good amount of lacing aroma of chocolate and coffee taste of chocolate and roasted coffee with a bitter finish very easy drinking and smooth porter if you like chocolate this ones for you
Brown pour with a slight beige head.  Coffee bean and dark malt aroma with some chocolate overtones.  Flavor is great chocolatey, nutty, coffee bean.  Mouthfeel is silk.  Great porter.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2009 12 oz bottle (Wine Works, Springfield, OH) - Aroma: low hop, mod malt (chocolate) Appearance:very dark brown color, light tan head ; Flavor: mod. to high malty (chocolate, coffee) mod bitter (malt and hops), low sweetness, no fruity; Mouthfeel:high body, mod. to high carbonation; Overall: nice dark malty beer.

Bottle at The Gambier Grille.  A little smoother than the Anchor Porter and more balanced coffee/dark chocolate notes.  Creamy over the palate but not coating.  This one really stands out in the Great Lakes line up.

Bottle. Dark brown with a reddish glow and a fine, tan head. Nutty, chocolatey aroma; slightly fruity, with raisins and dried fruits. Roasty flavor with cocoa/chocolate, a bit of coffee. Slightly smoky with dark fruit and a bitter roasted finish. Very well-balanced and flavorful with a full, smooth, mouth. Good stuff.
This porter starts with a roasty flavor then  right to a chocolate/coffee mouth with a creamy finish.  Wow, this is a great beer!  One that you want everyone to try . . . right away!
Bottle: pours a dark reddish-brown with a tan head, roasted malts and a little chocolate in the aroma, taste is bitter coffee, dark chocolate, some bite, thin mouthfeel.

The appearance is a deep, rich reddish brown. Light needs to push hard to get through. Two fingers of large puffy light brown/tan head.

The smell is sweet and bitter. Cherry and cocoa/mocha. Bitter coffee beans. Dark chcolate, some raisin and prunes. Lots of strong, dry cocoa.

The taste is sweeter on the palate, but with a bitter swallow. First sip is sweet stone fruits like raisin, grape and dates. A hint of plum. Sweeter than the average porter. Some dark cherry.

The feel is thick and creamy, almost like chocolate milk. It is hella good, even if a tad sweeter than normal.

Tap at The Map Room: Deep ruby brown beer with a lacing creamy tan head. Nice aroma- some apparent fruity malt character of toasted coconut, raisin, mild roast and a smoky peat like note. Nice creamy body. Firm malt character in the flavor with some soft sweetness, yet it remains soft and fluffy. Some toasted marshmallow and coconut with a peat like mild smokiness and later long roast. Balanced, bold and long flavors. Nice.

Poured from bottle into pint glass. About a finger of head that dissipates quickly into a small cocoa layer with an interesting but minimal lace. The beer is not quite "none more black" but its damn close.

Smell is a good strong toffee scent, a light hint of chocolate, and a roasty coffee smell. Excactly what I want from this style.

Taste/Mouth - The beer is carbonated just right and meduim bodied, with the beer seemingly going through distinct phases of taste as it coats the palate. Opens up robust and roasty and then finishes with a creamy/coffee/chocolatey aftertaste.

Drinkability is very good. I dont see why this wouldnt be a perfect session beer. Great Lakes is a name which I greet with high expectations and thankfully this Edmund Fitzgerald was able to live up and perhaps exceed the standards that I have come to leave GL with.

Bottle at cellar temperature.  Its dark brown, almost black with a thick, creamy "coke-float" of a head, two inches thick.  The aroma is wonderful, very balanced: creamy fresh coffee, milky chocolate; its slightly lactic with subtle nuts in the background.  The mouthfeel is terrifically smooth and full.  There is plenty of green hops in the flavour, more coffee, hazelnut, chocolate.  The finish is long and full of coffee.

It pours opaque brown, almost black in color with a thick foamy creamy tan head...somewhere around two fingers thick, that thinned rather quickly.  The head has left nice sporadic lacing in the glass.  Its aroma is quite light, but has hints typical of dark beers like this - milk chocolate, dark French or Italian style coffees.  There is also a bit of a hop flower presence in the aroma.  First sip is very carbonated, has a medium mouthfeel, a slight bitterness, one that you would get not only from hops, but also from coffee that has been sitting around for too long.  It has a lingering taste though, maybe a bit nutty.  Very enjoyable.
Pours black with a small white head.  Aromas of bitter dark chocolate.  Flavors of roasted coffee and chocolate.  Medium bodied.  Nice finish.

Ridulously good!!!!! This is the BEST porter that Ive ever tried....Im surprised that Im just now reviewing it since, Ive been drinking it for awhile now. Pours the beautiful dark, dark brown....with these amazing reddish hues. Looks interesting...with a beautiful light tan head. This ship smells of cocoa powder, coffee grounds, dark fruit and a definite hoppiness. Upon tasting its very light yet bold in flavor. Starts with dry cocoa powder, an oakiness follows and then malt. The finish is all hops..a light, bittering flavor realy complimets this beer. Pretty Good!!!

This is a good porter! I need to get some more. Coffee dominates the Edmund Fitzgerald. Roasted malt, missing an equal amount of chocolate but who cares? Surprisingly bitter for the style but an interesting asset that sets it apart from others in the style. Wish the head waited a little longer to die.

Creamy and dry coffee notes, one sided but very full.  Dark rich brown, fluffy tan head, strong lacing.  Dry and bitter coffee notes, strongly burnt.  The 60 IBUs is VERY surprising, Ive had this bottle for a while but still cant imagine that theyve fallen off this much.  Dry and bitter mocha finish in the back of my mouth.

Bottle.  Clear, but very dark brown pour with nice average carbonation and a mellow aroma of roasted malts.  Flavor is initially peat, bitter chocolate, roasted malts and mellow and a little tobacco and smoke on the finish.  Well done.

He poured deep brown-black into my glass and almost billowed over in a frothing explosion of dark tans and feisty bubbles. As he starts to settle into his new surroundings, deep amber sap can be seen glinting around the edges and bottom while his cover sticks like glue. Wafting my way are those oh-so decadent aromas of cocoa beans, coffee grinds fresh from the grinder, oak and smoke, nutmeg and cinnamon, maple drizzled raisin bread, dark chocolate powder, bakers chocolate, and chocolate covered coffee beans. Yeah, I think that covers everything; quite a bit to take in at once, but I am certainly not complaining. Judging from the plethora of dry aromas and oak, I expect a fairly dry palate and I am not disappointed. His body is rather light, balanced by a dry body of wood, powdered dark and bakers chocolates, and ground espresso. A faint smoky presence slowly permeates the palate and lingers in each breath. Balancing his dry personality is sweet maple drizzled atop warm raisin bread while cinnamon and nutmeg sprinkles give him spice. Crunchy, bitter and sweet chocolate covered coffee beans snap and pop atop my tastebuds as some licorice root compliments further notes of oak with the smoke continuing to subtly permeate. Lip-smacking, thirst-quenching, drool-inspiring quaffing ecstasy, I sadly bid farewell to Mr. Edmund Fitzgerald as we part ways with one last moment.


From the Dortmunder Gold to the Edmund Fitzgerald, Im not sure where I can go next, though I am sure it can only get better. Great Lakes, brew on for I shall continue to drink on and somewhere in-between, may we meet many more times.

Bottle via trade.  Dark brown, nearly black with a thick tan head.  Coffee and roast on the aroma.  Flavor is coffee, chocolate, caramel and roasted malt, lingering much longer than you expect.  Smooth, flavorful finish with coffee and mild hop bitterness coating the mouth.  Good stuff.
Deep brown with a dark tan head. Flavors mix coffee and caramel nicely. Medium-bodied; very pleasant. Doesnt hold its head very well.

Bottle courtesy of TampaBrew.  A dark brown beer with red highlights and a creamy tan head.  Nose has a big roasted character with notes of bitter chocolate and anise.  Medium bodied maybe a bit thin with soft carbonation.  Big roasted flavor with chocolate, some bitter hops, and coffee.  Finishes mildly bitter.  Very good.
Poured a deep brown. Nose is coffee, sweet malts and some floral hops. Flavor is coffee, roasted grain, hop bitterness, cocoa and some soft vanilla. Nice porter.
bottle, dark coffee colored with slight foam, aroma has  a sweet espresso aroma, flavor has lots of malty, sour roast with a bitter coffee bean finish

12 oz bottle.  Pours a dark brown with ruby highlights.  The tan head is very thick, dense, creamy, very persistant, and is very sticky.  Smells of coffee, cocoa, and sweet roasted malt.  Tastes of roasted malt, sweet dark fruit, chocloate, hints of vanilla. and a long sweet aftertaste. Body is nice.  Lots of lacing...Excellent beer.

12oz bottle. Pours black, but not thick, with foamy light tan head. Smells like smooth chocolate. Tastes like a super smooth cup of coffee, mixed with chocolate. The smoothness is what gets me. A very good porter we have here. I was not let down by a friend that raved about this brew.

12 oz bottle compliments of the great DrBayern, (thanks again Matt),  red shine and lasting foamy light tan head. Very nice nose with notes of coffee and light fruit. Solid roast throughout the aroma - slightly acidic smelling. Wow! The body is outstanding. Huge coffee notes at the front with a smooth chocolate middle. The coffee kicks in and out throughout to create and maintain a bold, roasty fan-porter-tastic taste.  Very easy porter to consume, excellent beer.
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottle, $3.49 in LA.  Pours dark brown with a medium sized beige head.  Aroma is saturated with dark chocolate, roasts, coffee and vanilla.  Incredible aroma!  Flavor follows suit with a bunch of coffee and dark chocolate upfront, followed by a finish of lingering roasty bitterness.  Just an excellent offering, very well balanced, wildly flavorful (especially for the ABV!), and a satisfying finish.  Palate is medium, and supports Fitzegerald well.

Good-sized, persistent head with some great lacing.  Very dark, not-quite black body.  Nose has some good floral hop aroma, but any of that is overpowered by the chocolate-coffee malts in the taste.  Very, very good.

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2009 Bottle. Very dark brown with two fingures of dark head.  For sure taste the coffee, but was not overpowered.  Hops were well mixed and had a slight taste of chocolate and maybe caramel?  Overall, roasted very well and not too bitter.

Bottle.  Pours a clear cola brown with a large light tan head.  Coffee, roast, chocolate on the nose.  Medium bodied, light echo of all of the lovely aromas, with a nice roast note coming through.  Finishes with a very soft bitterness.  Very tasty.

Tried it on tap in pizzeria in Fayetteville, WV.
 Pours darks brown. Nose is bready, toasted malts, coffee and dark fruit. Full body with coffee, sweet dark fruit flavors and long finish of hops and sweet juicy malts. What a great, complex, balanced porter.

From a bottle. Rich coffee, chocolate, roast, and sweet tart aroma. Pours super dark brown with hints of ruby light through the edges. Taste is nice and roasty with lots of coffee taste. Quite smooth and drinkable, fairly balanced, although a little too ashy and not as fruity (yeast-wise) as I prefer in a Porter. All around good beer.

Bottle as part of a 6-pack.  Ive had it quite a few times bottled, but never rated it.  One of my favorite beers, hands down.  Pours a very dark brown, almost opaque, even when held to light.  Tan head, fades quickly but leaves nice little islands.  I love the aroma - chocolate + delicious roast comes through.  Super creamy beer, exactly the way I like it.  The taste is the best part though - coffee, chocolate, roasted malts - all come through with a nice bitter finish.  The slightly bitter finish really puts it over the top when compared to other beers of the style.  Almost perfect.
Draft pint from Arnolds in downtown Cincinnati.  Very dark brown pour with light tan head.  Smooth, roasty, chocolaty, malty, with coffee aroma and taste, too.  Excellent, well-crafted porter.

Wedding Anniversary 2009<
br />5/14/2009:  Great Lakes Edmund Fitzgerald Porter has always come across as a very roasty and robust porter.  It drinks more like a full blown stout, but is quite good and very respectable nonetheless.  This beer is near black in color.  It has a medium-full body that provides some heft to support the roasty, bittersweet chocolate aroma and flavor.  There are even some notes of coffee and black barley.  Overall this is a well-crafted, robust porter that still stands up today with all of the the other new and extreme beers.
Pint (draught) at Mulligans Hyde Park Pub in Cincinnati, Ohio.  Rating #921 for this beer.

Wow. Simultaneously a very typical porter in terms of appearance and palate but totally exceptional in flavor. Roasted coffee and chocolate aroma gives way to excellent coffee/caramel/chocolate taste with a nice level of bitter hops to balance it out. Loved this the first time I tried it and like it even better now. Fantastic stuff, a perfect session beer.
Black por with a nice tan head......roasted note in the aroma and a very deep and rich malt flavor. Creamy and very, very drinkable.....unbeliveable. So good and finishes soooo clean. WOW

Bottle thanks to coyotehunter. Pours with a near black, brown body with red highlights and a creamy tan head. Aroma of cocoa powder, smoke, cherry and light coffee grounds. Taste is a classic, but clean strongly roasty porter. Cocoa and and a bit of smoke. Good solid tasting, well made porter. Some hop bitterness. Went decently well with Key-Lime pie. Lively carbonation, creamy.

Pours a dark ruby red with a medium off-white head. Coffee, caramel, and vanilla on the nose. Taste of coffee, chocolate, caramel and slight alcohol. Dry, smooth, bitter finish. I am not a big fan of this style, but this truly is an exceptional beer.

Dark brown, damn near black with a tan foamy head. Aroma is a bit low, but whats there is a bit chocolatey, some coffee, and a touch of roasted malt. Flavor is mediocre of that listed above, but a thinnish mouthfeel. The closer to the bottom I get, the better it is. Still, missing something.

12oz bottle.   Dark brown with a medium beige head.   Dark chocolate and caramel aroma.   The flavor has a definite roasted coffee edge, but is balanced by sweeter chocolate and malt flavors.   Medium bitterness and fuller malty character.   Medium bodied with medium carbonation.   solid stuff with a good mocha flavor going on.

33 cl bottle, Mulmur, ON, Canada (via Kalamazoo). Deep brown colour, creamy head that leaves some nice lacing. Roasted barley aroma, some plumbs and cherry notes as well, with a touch of alcohol. Nice coffee flavor, bitter bite on the sides of the cheeks, but smooth and creamy finish.

12 oz bottles from Kryptic - thanks! Dark brown with a big beige head. Sweet malt nose, carob and chocolate, something is just a tad off, lightly veg. Decent chocolaty flavor, sweet malt, some herbal bittering. Still, tinged with a veg note, not much but it was there, and detracted from the experience for me.

[Bottle] Pours cola brown with a dark tan head. Aroma is cocoa, brown sugar, coffee, and deeply roasted malt. The taste is chocolate again, charred malt (maybe a bit too heavily roasted at times), vanilla, some alcohol, and decent bitterness towards the back end. Mouthfeel is fairly thin, long, smooth, and has a slightly dry finish. Really a very solid porter.

Bottle with great thanks to Cheapdark!
This is one damn fine beer, the first porter to compete with Anchor in my book. The beer pours with a tight small head and a hazy ruby color. The aroma is vanilla and mocha with strong chocolate notes. The aroma is simple but pungent and very effective. The flavor is at first roasty coffee with plenty of vanilla with some chocolate and some berries. This beer besides all of its vanilla and chocolate remains dry and the hop bitterness shines through very well. The texture is creamy and silky. Just a showboat of a session beer.

12oz bottle from pimpp - thanks, Patrick! Surprised that I hadnt rated this before, as Ive had it - and enjoyed it - many times. Its a rock solid porter to be sure. Dark brown pour, with less carbonation than youd expected. Strong malty nose, with an abundance of sweet rich chocolate. Body is pretty good and the flavor is more on the chocolate side than the roasty depths. Definitely a good one.

12oz bottle. huge aroma of coffee and chocolate jumps from the glass. Pours dark black with a nice lasting brown fluffy head. taste of sweet malt with a nice chocolate finish with just a touch of hops in the background. Delicious!

Truly one of my favorite porters ever.  Even as Great Lakes languishes in mediocracy, Edmund stays on top.  Just had a pint at the brewery, and it was so fresh with roasted malts and hints of coffee and even some chocolate.  Medium bodied yet complex and full of flavor.  Of all the usuals in the GL lineup, this beer is my favorite.

Bottle from my bro, who got it from my other bro.  Anyway, pours blackish brown, large tan head.  Roasted malt and dark chocolaty aroma.  Roasted nutty flavour with a distinct note of coffee.  Overall an excellent beer.  Great Lakes does it again.

2009 Bottle - Thanks BrewCzar! - Pours deep brown with a small creme coloured head...aroma is roasty malt, coffee and creme...flavour is similar, cocoa, coffee, charred wood bitterness, sweet malt that gives way to the bitter aspects...finish is a nice balance of both caramel and char...very tasty!

Bottle.  Pours a deep brown color. . very close to black.  A large beige head.  The aroma is pretty sweet and malty. . very little hops, obviously,  Taste of sweet chocolate toast.  Palate is pretty nice, full, complex, a little chewie.  A great porter.  One of the better Porters out there, up there with Founders

Pours a dark, tarrish brown that is completely opaque. Aroma is a collection of chocolate and roasted malts, with a nice, "Perfect Porter" light chocolate-tinged white head. At first taste, the Edmund Fitzgerald demands your attention with a bit of bitter bite. Yet with every drink after that the coffee and dark chocolate notes fill both the palate and the scoresheet. One of, if not my favorite American Porters.
a good porter slight high on the taste of hops flavors  of chocolate and coffee. pours a creamy light brown head with a sticky texture.

Bottle - Pours opaque black with a big, fat tan head. Love the aroma -- smooth, caramelly malt (that seems to be in several of the GL beers) with just enough hops to balance out. Theres a little coffee, chocolate, lactose, and metal. Taste is dark burnt malt, coffee, wood, bitter chocolate. Smooth, creamy, and easy-drinking.

12oz bottle via trade at DLD. pours a very dark brown with hints of red and a thin light tan head with solid retention. aroma is very nice with bitter coffee, cocoa powder, roasted malt, and a hint of smoke. flavor is outstanding with big, semi-sweet chocolate, roasted malts, and smoked wood with a great hop balance and notes of red apple skin with a long, bittersweet chocolate and roast coffee finish. mouthfeel is smooth with medium carbonation. overall, and excellent porter.

12 oz bottle.  Pours very dark brown with a lasting beige head.  The aroma is heavy on the chocolate with some notes of coffee and roasted malt.  The flavor is again ripe with chocolate and roasted malt, but adds a hoppy bitterness for an added layer of complexity.  Medium bodied and easy to drink.  It is a pleasure to have this available all year as a go to beer when needed.

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2009 Bottle poured in the VIP lounge of the WBF Raleigh. Yeah, Im very important like that. Pours near black with a beige head. Solid roasty coffee-chocolate nose malty taste with a big of hops as well.  Slightly thin.  Very good. Rerate: Tried again, and damn, this is good.

Bottle from the Great Lakes sampler box. Pours black with a big frothy tan head. Definite bitter, roasted chocolate smell. Kind of a thin mouthfeel for a porter but a great blend of choclate and roasted malt. A very solid brew.
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: UPDATED: MAY 6, 2009 12 oz. bottle (2009) in a shaker. A superb brew really. Pours a very deep, clear chocolate color w/ a thin beige head; aroma is sweet and malty, some smoke; medium-thin body w/ flavors of chocolate, smoke, roasted malt, honey and the perfect hops balance; finishes dry w/ acidic coffee bitterness. Nicely done.
Black with thick foamy tan head. Light choco coffee aroma. Bittersweet choco coffee roast.

12 oz bottle...pours very dark brown almost black. Great fluffy tan head! Aromas of bitter chocolate/cocoa, coffee, heavily roasted malts. The flavor was a little more bitter than most porters. Definitely got the chocolate, roasted malts up from and a sweet fruity presence on the back palate. Fairly bitter, lingering aftertaste. Overall, a very solid porter.
Tap at Brewpub. Bitter dark roasted malts. Rich coffee beans and a nice creamy feel. Great.

12 oz. bottle thanks to Neil (thanks Neil).  Best by 05/30/09.  Pours black but not as black as a Baltic Porter.  Big roasted malt flavor.  Great smoky and chocolate flavors.  Very light hop presence.  Exactly what a porter should be.  Hard to imagine a better example of a porter anywhere.  Top of its class.
Great color and lacing of the glass. Chocolate, coffee roasted flavors and a good aroma. I thought it had a little bitter of an aftertatse though.

Bottle at Table (Murrysville). Pours a dark brown, small tan head. Aroma is touches of malt, chocolate and coffee. Flavor delivered big time on what the aroma promised, really well put together blend of toasted malt, bakers chocolate and coffee. A little sweet and bitter at the same time. I like this one.
Poured black with a tan head. Aroma of coffee and plums. Lots of coffee and chocolate flavor. Some sweetness from the fruit.

12 ounce bottle from a six pack picked up by my brother-in-law for Easter. Now this is a porter! Poured a dark black color with a one finger width brown head. It had mahogany tints around the side of the glass also. The aroma consisted of coffee, bitter chocolate, sweet malts and some subtle, dark fruit. The taste is along the same lines with bitter chocolate and roasted malt being very noticeable and the coffee and dark fruit hiding in the background. Finished with a bitter taste that was very pleasant. Overall, an exceptional porter. I am extremely happy that I was able to have this one and am looking forward to the next time I get to have it.
bottle.  roasty chocolate coffee.  really like this porter.  One of my favorite porters.

Bottle from trade with Yetiman420.  Pours dark black with a khaki head.  Nose is dark malt, alcohol, coffee, and a hop or two.  Flavor is assertive, but different from aroma.  Lots of chicory, roasted malt, and hops that linger after malt and coffee have boarded the train.  Roasty finish to this medium-bodied porter.  Very good.
dark brown pour with small light brown head. aroma of roasted malt. great porter taste. i like this one, cant wait to sample the others

quite an amazing session brew ... the smell is awesome ... very roasty, good stuff ... good headring .. pours a dark brown/black ... medium lacing ... good stuff, i enjoyed it and can see the session hype ..
Ah what a great Porter! Had a great roasted  aroma and a strong chocolate taste. Felt great going down, and its pretty easy to drink for this style.
UPDATED: MAY 18, 2009 One of my favorite porters. Since this is an old review, Im going to have to come back to it now that I can review properly.

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2009 On tap at Capones, thanks Matt!  Pours a deep black with 3-4 fingers of head which stays around a long time.  Aroma is deep and burnt chocolatey.  Taste is the same as the smell.  Mouthfeel is rich and dark, like drinking a very full bodied expresso.  An excellent porter, the best Ive ever tasted.

Bottle from Archer Liquors. Dark brown color with ruby notes and a decent tan head. Aroma of darkly roasted malt. Medium body with mild carbonation. Flavor is quite nutty, with dark toast malt and some coffee and chocolate. Its quite tasty. It finishes a bit astringent. Its sweet but bitter. Amazing stuff. Quite unexpected.

Draft. Included as part of a sampler at the brewpub in Cleveland. I remembered liking pretty much everything but do not remember specifics.  Do remember that they have an excellent brewpub with excellent beer. The EF Porter is the one I remember most and liked the best out of all the offerings.

On tap at Coles, Buffalo. Appearance: Black, small pancake coloured head. Aroma: Malt, coffee, slight chocolate and slightly nutty. Flavour: chocolate, coffee, well balanced with malt and hops. Very enjoyable indeed.
This is just delicious.  It may in fact be my new favorite porter.  Complex without being muddy, beautiful look and mouthfeel, wonderful on the tastebuds.

12oz bottle. Pours black with a tan head. Aroma of of coffee, bitter chocolate, malt, and brown sugar. Taste is of bitter chocolate, coffee, roasted malt, brown sugar, and a nice hop taste underneath. It has a nice porter taste, with a hop character that makes it very drinkable. Body is medium, with lots of carbonation. Mouthfeel is surprisingly light, making it go down easy. One of the most drinkable porters that doesnt compromise flavor for it.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Sweet coffee aroma with black currant. Dark brown colour, light brown head, good lace. Sweet, bitter, coffee, roasted, very malty. Medium body, sandy mouth feel. Flavourful yet straightforward porter.
UPDATED: JUL 18, 2009 Bottle.  Pours a very dark brown with a thick tan head.  Aroma is malt, chocolate, and a little hop.  Flavor is strong coffee and dark chocolate.  The best porter Ive ever had.

Pours a dark, tarrish brown that is completely opaque. Aroma is a collection of chocolate and roasted malts, with a nice, "Perfect Porter" light chocolate-tinged white head. At first taste, the Edmund Fitzgerald demands your attention with a bit of bitter bite. Yet with every drink after that the coffee and dark chocolate notes fill both the palate and the scoresheet. One of, if not my favorite Porter.
Bottle. Dark color, tan head that never completely leaves.  Aroma:Roasted malt, Chocolate hints. Flavor:  Perfect balance of roasted chocolate, coffee and hops.

12 ounce bottle courtesy of dankman. Thanks! Pours a mahogany color with a small head, good head retention and lacing. Aroma is roasty and nutty malts with rich chocolate notes. Taste is roasted malts, nuts, chocolate, coffee and minty hops. Medium bodied.

Bottle, pours deep earthy garnet with hints of ruby with a small tan head. Redolent of roasted barley, coffee, caramel, sweet dark fruits, citric hops, some alcohol. Flavor is roast barley, caramel, toffee, sweet malt, coffee, subtle chocolate mixed in with the dry bittersweet hops at the end. Palate is a little too carbonated leading the body to feel somewhat like a soda, it is however nicely warming in the end which is rather distinguishing.

Pours a dark brown opaque color with a small tan head. Nose of roasted malt, coffee and sweet malt, nose is overall ok. Initial taste of roasted malt, caramel, chocolate. Mild bitterness in the mid palate to finish. Dry finish, light body. Palate duration is  above average. Head retention is good. Looking for more flavor. Overall a decent porter but nothing special.

Poured a clear deep brown color with a red tint and beige head.  Mild coffee and roasted malt aroma.  A touch of smoke and sweetness mix together.  Roasted malt flavor.  Semi-sweet.  Dry mildly bitter finish.  Light body with a long finish.
Ive had both bottle and draft. It is good out of the bottle and great on draft. Almost black. Good roast coffee aroma. Good mouthfeel, finishes bitter with some chocolate flavor. A very good porter.

A good porter. Dark brown to black pour with a thin dark tan head. Main aroma/flavor is roasted coffee with some undertones of dark chocolate. Some flavor is detectable, but mainly only in the bitterness. Smooth mouthfeel for easy drinking.

Chocolatey aroma with some roasted malts.  Pours very dark brown almost black with a thin tan head.  Roasted malts and sweet chocolate with some roasted coffee.  Very easy to drink a great session porter.

UPDATED: AUG 11, 2016 Re-rate 8/13: Bottle sample at a tasting at the kerenmks place. Thanks kerenmk. Blacvk-colored, not opaque, with a light brown head. Nice roasty aroma with coffee and a bit of cocoa notes. Nice roasty flavor, bittersweet with a bitter finish. Medium-bodied. 7/3/7/3/14=3.4
(11/6/08) Bottle at The Drafting Room in Spring House. Thanks David T!  Very dark brown color with a beige head. Aroma of dark chocolate. Sweet flavor of roasted malt, chocolate, some coffee and some nutty notes and a drier finish. Medium-bodied. Tasty. 7/4/7/4/14=3.6

On tap @ Barcade Midwest Fest.  Black with lasting flat brown head.  NIce roasted chocolate coffee and mild fruit aroma.  Roasted robust coffee chocolate flavor with minimal fruit and clean dry mildly bitter finish.  Very nice and flavorful robust session porter.

12 oz bottle courtesy of Acknud. Pours a dark brown w/ ruby highlights with a receding tan head. Aroma is malt, chocolate and coffee. Flavor is pretty much the same, heavy on the malts, a little chocolate, a little toffee and some coffee. A bit of hop bitterness in the finish. Very enjoyable porter. Highly recommend it.

12oz bottle.  Brown-black-red color, with a frothy head.  Sweet chocolate-toffee tastes, medium-bodied, and smooth on the palate.  Crisp hoppy balance, fades into malt sweetness.  This is a well done Porter, solid all around.  Nice aroma as well.

12oz bottle courtesy of Bounty628. Pours a murky dark black color with a one finger tan head that settles slowly and laces the glass. Aroma is roasty and malty with notes of ripe dark fruit, coffee, toffee, dark chocolate, molasses, some hints of wood and vanilla. Flavor is also roasted and malty with notes of dark chocolate, ripe dark fruit, toffee, coffee, and slight notes of smoke and wood. Generally medium body with a pleasing coffee and chocolate finish.

12oz bottle. Pours a dark brown/black with a small tan head. Nice aroma and flavors of roasted malts, dark chocolate, and coffee with a surprising finish of hops. A thin mouthfeel with a hint of carbonation makes this easy to drink. A fine porter.
12 ounce bottle available at Archer Liquors Chicago, IL for $1.60 Excellent!
Creamy head and light body with roasty and chocolatey flavors.  A pretty good session beer for a porter

12oz bottle pours a dark brown / black with a one finger tan head which dimishes into a ring.  Aromas of coffee, chocolate and some smoke.  Flavors a very much the same roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, and smoke.  Palate is smooth and has a nice bitter finish, just the right amount.
Draft. Pours a dark brown with tan head. Nice roasted malt nose. Flavors are roasted malt with nice coffee hints. Good porter!

Bottle at the Winking Lizard Crosswoods location.  Pours darkest brown, black with a huge tan head.  Rich roasty aroma with lots of malt and coffee.  Flavor is coffee and hop with some sweet chocolate.  Outstanding porter.

UPDATED: MAY 11, 2009 An incredibly smooth porter with a nice chocolaty flavor.  Good aroma that comes out whether served on tap or in bottle.  (Aside: Great Lakes uses this to make a fantastic porter ice cream)

12 oz bottle served at Charlestons (New Lenox, IL). Pours a ruby over midnight hue with small tannish head that dissipates fairly quickly. Aromas are roasted malt, cocoa, and a faint touch of coffee. Initial is a nice toasted malt character, touches of bittersweet chocolate, and some subtle coffee grinds. Roasted malt and touches of chocolate dominate the body, a touch of creaminess lowers the bitterness and makes this upper medium bodied brew very welcoming, silky as it goes down. Very nice.

Draft at Capones. Poured a deep dark brown with some red highlights on the edges. Sweet aroma of chocolate and coffee. Flavor was more tart with some coffee, bitter bakers chocolate, honey sweetness and some green vegtables in the background. Once again another very enjoyable beer that was slightly differenet from the norm. Good stuff.

On tap at the Map Room, Chicago. Edmund Fitzgerald is a very deep brown beer with lovely chocolate, roast and coffee flavours with a surprisingly hoppy finish which is most enjoyable. A beer which makes me miss Cleveland.

bottle.  pours a deep black with a 3 finger tan head.  good quarter inch head lasts throughout.  very smooth over palate - like melted chocolate with coffee and roasted malts with a hint of smoke.  slight bitter finish.  wonderful porter.
Bottle. Pours dark brown with thin tan head. Aroma is dominated by espresso and cocoa, with notes of smoke. Flavor is espresso, but balanced sweet malts and hop bitterness. Finish is slightly bitter.

12oz. bottle. Pours a clear brown/mahogany, with a light tan, foamy head, and creamy, stick to the glass, full lacing. The nose is of dark chocolate, smoke, and dark roast coffee. The aroma notes lessen in the taste along with some malty sweetness and nice hop balance. The body is medium, with a little fizziness in the carbonation. The finish has some light astringency. A very quaffable porter!

12oz.  Tasty!  Poured a beautiful porter pour with dark dark brown and a small tan head.  Nose is beautiful, especially as the brew warms to room temp shows lovely roasted notes of smoke, chocolate, and espresso.  While nose isn’t as complicated as some, the body brings some lovely sweetness that adds complexity.  Moderate carbonation, overall a very nice and drinkable porter that isn’t overwhelming in any sense.

Bold aroma, dark fruits, toast, chocolate, smoke.  Pours an opaque black with a significant loose tan head.  Not much head retention, only temporary lace.  Big roast flavor, toast, chocolate, smoke.  Th e bitterness comes across as a licorice hint.  The smoke still lingers on long after the swallow. Very drinkable, but noticeably thin bodied.
My fave Porter..... dark brown poor small head.  Nutty with a nice roasted coffe and chocolate finish very smooth.
Draft - Excellent porter with lots of malt and mild bitterness.  This porter was excellent with lots of choc and cream coffee flavor.  Really well done

The legend lives on...  This was a great beer!  Nice and dark with a great maltynose with some chococoffee going on.  Nice tan head that lingered.  Nice balanced mouthfeel with a nutty taste going on followed by a cocoa-coffee thing.  Bittering was great, wonderful finish.

pours an almost opaque dark brown with wonderful red tints and a creamy brown head...aroma of chocolate and coffee with hints of malty sweetness. wonderfully complex flavor starting with a sweet chocolate, giving way to robust coffee flavors, balanced by a perfect amount of bitterness, smooth medium body...what a wonderful beer. very happy with my purchase!!!

Brewed in the USA !!! Courtesy of AFI96, thanks waylo. Pours a very dark brown / garnet color with a small tan head. Aroma of cocoa, caramel, and malts. Taste is of chocolate, brown sugar, and coffee. The mouthfeel is dry and well balanced, but i must say it’s not quite what i expected.

Bottle thanks to Daniel. I’ve been waiting for this beer for some time! Pours a dark black with lots of ruby colors coming through when light shines in. A medium light brown head. The aroma is very nice; tons of chocolates, roasted malt, and loads of milk coffee. A very nice flavor; lots of sweet and rich roasted malts, some nutty aspects, light milk coffee and chocolates, and all of it is well balanced by a smooth hop finish. A creamy and full mouthfeel. Excellent.

12oz bottle shared with BeerGestapo. Brown pour with garnet edges, topped by a small khaki head. Smells of cocoa, earth, and caramel. Tastes of dark chocolate, cocoa, earth, and coffee. Finishes fairly dry with lingering coffee flavors. It was alright but I expected better from this brewery.

Bottle.  Poured a dark brown color with a two finger tan head.  Aroma of chocolate and roasted malt.  Flavor contained coffee, chocolate and roasted malt.  Medium body with medium carbonation and a creamy mouthfeel.

RATING 600. (12 oz. bottle served in pint glass on Nov. 10, 2008- 33 years to the day she sank in Lake Superior)  First off, thank you for trading this to me RCL, and for not putting me on about the "rarity" of it unlike someone else here that I tried to get it from originally. Again, thank you RCL.  Poured blacker than that late autumn night about to being hit with the 3 sisters, a woven like 2 finger tan head formed and laced.  Aroma of nicely roasted malts and dark chocolate.  Hits the mouth with wide and rich body, malt covers the entire palate nicely, many chocolate notes everywhere, finish begs for another sip.  A brew worthy of it’s name.

Pours a deep non-tranparent black/dark brown color with a thick tan head. The head disapates slowly after a minute or two. Smells of chocolate and roasted malts. Has a chocolate and coffee taste and is extremely drinkable. I wish I had more than just one bottle.

12 oz. bottle from world market

Serving type: bottle, 11-13-2008

Bottle, courtesy Ughsmash! Pours translucent very dark brown with ruby lights and a thick and lacy tan head. Aroma of coffee, licorice and chocolate. Medium-light body and carbonation. Bitter-sweet chocolate taste with coffee, brown sugar and roasty malt. Dry espresso finish. Enjoyable.

Dark rich pour, with a creamy off white head. Good lacing on glass. Roasted coffee smell with a hint of carmel and chocolate. Flavor is complex and well balanced, with a nice bittersweetness to it. A well rounded porter.
Draught at GABF 2008. Black - brown head. Burned, licorice, cask carakters, english licorice, lactose, dryness, berries, chocolate, smooth body. Nice - but plain.
bottle. has a roasted malt aroma with a hint of chocolate and coffee. pours a thick black with little head. has a very smooth malt taste with a dark chocolate aftertaste.
Pours black, with  tan head.  My advice is to let is sit out of the fridge for five minutes before drinking as that seems to let more of the malts come through in the flavor

Bottle.  Poured a black color with a very nice tan head.  Aroma of coffee, chocolate, and roasty malts.  Medium body, creamy texture, soft carbonation, and a nice, long finish.  Flavor of coffee and chocolate with a slight bitterness in the finish.  Overall, this is an awesome beer!  I would highly recommend it.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2009 An awesome porter. Pour is completely opaque brownish black with a tan head and ruby lining. Aroma is bitter chocolate, malt and coffee. Huge coffee flavor with a hint of bitter chocolate. The mouthfeel is super smooth and creamy if you let it warm up. A hint of bitter hops on the finish. One of Great Lakes best offerings.
Bottle.  Pours a brown black body with a tan head.   Sweet and mineral chocolate, silky chocolate.  Coffee bitterness, and a noticeable hoppy resin.
12 oz. bottle.  Flavor and aroma of bitter chocolate, coffee, and some smokiness.  A touch of sweetness.   Very silky smooth, straightforward for all those strong flavors.  Mighty fine porter.

Pours a brownish black, with a a fluffy head that is off white.  the aroma is coffee, caramel, and malt with nice lacing.  Strong coffee flavor, and a mild hop at the finish, this is a good brew.  would recommend

Courtesy of Sammy. It’s transparent black/brown with a red hue and a creamy head. The aroma has notes of chocolate, roasted malt, dark fruits, licorice and light sweetness. The flavour has sweetness and a light dry and roasted bitterness, notes of chocolate, roasted malt, coffee, dark fruits, slightly bitter licorice and the finish is dry. It’s nice and uncomplicated.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2011 
Date: October 12, 2008
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting, Cellar Party
Appearance: clear dark brown with ruby edges, fine tan head, sudsy lace
Aroma: dry rich chocolate aroma
Flavor: rich chocolate flavor, just a touch of caramel sweetness, nice balancing earthyness, light roasted gives it a coffee finish
Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 14/20
Rating: 3.4/5.0Drinkability: 8/10
Score: *** /4
12oz bottle.  clear, dark  brown color.  aroma of toasted malts.  Flavor of deep roasted malt, coffee and even a little bittersweet chocolate. .  Very roasty.  Finishes with a bold hop character.

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2012 Pours a dark brown/black that shows some light. One finger frothy tan head. The nose is very well balanced,  lots of bread and biscuity notes with a lightly grainy character and an upfront herbal/leafy hop character.  Hints of a caramelly sweetness.  The flavor shows some bakers chocolate and a hint of roast, very biscuity malt character and a medium bitterness.  Medium bodied with a dry finish and crisp feel.
Very similar to Bell’s Porter but this brew has a creamier mouthfeel and a more bitter finish and because of that, I like it better.
Draft @ Capones:  Poured a dark dark brown with not much head.  The aroma was chocolate roasted malt.  The flavor was chocolate, nutty, sweet and malty.  Delicious!  Overall and excellent Porter.
pours a dark black brown, mild head, dry palate with chalky feel, light sessionable quality, rather smooth.

Pours deep brown with a small head.  Aroma of roasted malts and chocolate.  Very fizzy almost coke like in taste.  A little thin with toasted malt and chocolate in the taste.  Dry finish.  Wasn’t expecting the carbonation, which was th eonly downside to this one.

12 oz bottle.
Rosy and dark brown pour with a small, fizzy, dark brown head that leaves quickly and remains slightly lacy. The aroma is heavily malt backed with some notes of roast, sweet and dark chocolate, and a bit of mocha. There is a presence of bittering hops too. Light bodied with a standard watery porter taste. Not complex at all. Roasty, chocolate, coffee...the usual. Slightly more bitter than most, leaving a nice and dry aftertaste that lingers for a decent amount of time. Overall, nothing to write home about, but not bad.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 OK this brewery is starting to wow me. Rich black brown with slight red tint when held to light. Not much head. Aroma is rich in chocolate malt and is pure and toasty. Fairly fizzy and carbonated. Clean, toasted chocolate malt flavors. Slight hint of bourbon. Excellent off-dry finish is more-ish. Very robust, hearty, toasty, and good. No nonsense.

12oz bottle.  Poured a dark brown / red color with a medium sized, tan head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of roasted malts, bakers chocolate, light smoke, and a bit of caramel malt. Taste was sweet chocolate, more caramel, fudge, roasted malts, and some nuts, but really reminded me of a tootsie roll.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2009 Bottle.Poured very brown to black with a large creamy light brown head. Aroma starts bitter and changes to sweet, chocolate, roast, and coffee. Good lacing and retains a small head the entire way. Body is a little thin. Oily mouthful. Unsweetened chocolate, coffee, and a great hop finish that leaves a sweet aftertaste. The malts become more prominant as this beer warms making it even more enjoyable.
Nice !

Pours a nice deep brown color with a nice off white head.  Aroma is coffee and roasted malt with a hint of cigarette smoke?.  Something a little sweet there too.  Flavor is very smooth.  Nice roast and a bit of chocolate.  Just a twinge of bitterness on the back end.  I can’t tell if it’s roast bitter, or hops bitter, but I’d lean more towards roast.  Very nice beer.

Bottle from strykzone.  Thanks!!! I have been wanting to try this for a long time.  And it is a good one.  Dark, dark brown color with a medium sized light brown head that disappears prett fast.  leaves some good lacing.  I smell some chocolate, roasted malt, toast and some coffee.  Flavor is full of roasty character:chocolate, weak coffee, and a good backbone of hops...but no bitterness.  NIce job GL.
From bottle. Pours deep brown with red edge.  Aromas of chocolate and smoke. Tastes include coffee and roasted nuts.  Very smooth.  Superb effort from the Mistake on the Lake.
Smells of coffee and chocolate. Looks dark with a small head. Tastes like chocolate, coffee, with a hint of citrus. All of this with a smooth malt finish. A very good porter.
On tap at the Map Room. This opaque black ale poured with a fluffy tan head and coffee aroma. There is a very mellow roasted malt flavor with a smooth bitter finish. Very tasty.

Bottle. Pours deep ruby brown with a beige head. Roasted aroma with chocolate and and orangy citric hops. Smooth body. Chocolate malt and a bit of a roasted flavor, with sweet fruity orange and a nice hoppy and roasted bitter finish. Very well balanced.

Great Lakes Edmund Fitzgerald Porter is a dark brown ale with a red-orange hue and a beige head that has some oily bubbles on it.  It fades to a leathery film and leaves nice lacing on the glass.  It has a roasty chocolate armoa that’s sweetened with malt.  It is full bodied with a light finish.  It leaves the mouth a bit chalky.  It has a roasty flavor with good balance.  The hops seems almost minty.  There is a note of coffee and the whole flavor is quite dry, unlike the aroma.  Nice!

draft at maproom.... took me awhile to get to this but glad i finally did..... dark semi-transparent brown pour with a moderate light brown head.... aroma of roasted malt and chocolate notes.  a generally sweet profile.... roasted malt abd bitter chocolate flavors with a nice balance of sweet and bitter.  really drinkable.

Thanks to Crizay for this.  Pours dark brown, red highlights, with a light tan head that lasts a while.  Aroma is...off?  I get a bit of coffee, dark rye, cocoa, but there’s something really off.  It might be oxidation, diacetyl, or a lethal combination of both, but it’s the dominant feature.  Taste is less affected, and there’s nice dark chocolate, coffee, rye, roasted almonds and a pleasing astringency, but there’s too much weird buttery sherry poking through.  Finishes great with a nutty roasted coffee bean and dark chocolate flavor.  Medium bodied and fairly creamy.  Could be nice, but something weird happened here.

On tap @ Coles Buffalo NY. Along with Smutty my go to porter. Rather shocked I have not rated this yet. Pours a deep dark brownish black. Aroma is full of roasted malts, slight bitterness, some chocolate. Nice fuller mouthfeel. Great porter

@ the tasting session by Joes. A dark red/brown colored beer,  with a small beige head. An aroma of dark fruits like prune, dates and raisins. The taste of dark roasted malts, dried dark fruits. Its dry bitter. The aftertaste is also dry bitter. A very good beer.

On tap @ Maproom. Solid Porter!  Dark, almost black, but with some ruby around the edges. Nice white head, an excellent contrast. Smell was very pleasing. The taste was great. Chochlates, coffee, and all around goodness.
12 oz. bottle. Just a very solid porter! Good color, nice brown head and full of flavor!

Pours dark mahogany with amber hues on the edges. A half-inch head of beige had moderate retention and smears of lacework lasted throughout.

Roasted coffee, dark malts, caramel, nougat, and oreo shells fill the nose. Very clean and balanced, with a high level of complexity for a porter.

Fullish bodied, shy of thick. A happy medium between chewy and ordinary. Creamy.

Roasted malt, coffee, bitter chocolate, and an underlying fruit note lead off the pallet. 
A firm, drying bitterness follows through along with brownie bits and biscuits.

Finishes with lingering bitter chocolate, and fading cookie crumbs.

Nice job on this one, very quaffable without being boring.
Bottle.  Pours very dark, not black.  Brown head, condenses to very fine head.  Fairly carbonated.  Smokey, a little bit of chocolate.  Mildly hopped.

12oz with the Flying Burrito Brothers playing (Gordon Lightfoot kind of sucks). Chocolate coffee...normally two flavors that I could live without. When combined in the form of ale, we get the Edmund Fitz Porter. While not as crisp as some Brit porters, or as big and heavy as American porters, it finds a nice centerqueef. Overall, very tasty, well-rounded and complex and incredibly easy to drink. Meow. Even tastes good on a hot summer night, just feeding the ol spider, makin that sucker grow. Tonight a grasshopper, tomorrow a centipede. Life is good.

12oz With Gordon Lightfoot playing in the background - Black liquid under light brown head.  Chocolate malt to beat the band.  Bitter chocolate on the front, fading to malt then a brush of bitter hops.  Really well built and well thought out.
Bottled brought back from WV! Pours a dark thick color with a small tan head. Smells of roast and chocolate. Tastes very chocolaty and roast with malts, that lingers on the palate. Good Porter!
Bottle, pours a dark brown with a thin head.  Aroma is soft and sweet of chocolate and malt.  Pretty clean taste and a filling body.

GABF 2007. A brown beer with a thin tan head - too light in color for a porter. The aroma is sweet with strong notes of chocolate and malt. The flavor is sweet with strong notes of chocolate as well as lighter notes of roasted malt, leading to a dry bitter chocolaty finish. It has a nice body.

UPDATED: APR 29, 2009 This is one Great Lakes better brews.  It pours a very dark black color and the head remains throughout leaving beautiful lacing on the glass.  The aroma is strongly of roasted coffee and small hints of chocolate.  The flavor is more of the same.  The beer is rather smooth and surprisingly easy to drink.  Easily one of the better porters Ive had.

Poured from bottle (8/2008).  Nice hit of coffee in the aroma.  Looks like a porter should - dark, thin persistent tan head.  Nut , coffee and cocoa in the flavor.  Not as oily feeling as other porters.  Hops present in aftertaste.  Smooth finish.  Well done.
user_location: York, SC via NJ, South Carolina, USA

text: Smooth drinking.  Dark brown pour.  Aroma of toffee, chocolate and coffee.  Taste is similar to aroma.  Nice drinking porter.
on draft at Kuma’s Corner. pours dark brown with khaki head. aroma is nutty, bready, and milk chocolate. actually it tastes exactly as it smells with a touch of roast and coffee. really great porter.

Whoa. This is the best beer I’ve had from Great Lakes Brewing Company. Dark, almost black. Tan head is beautiful. Dark chocalate and silk in the taste, feels great in the mouth. Some nuttiness in the aftertaste. Aftertaste lingers a bit. A brilliantly executed porter.

I just poured this into the beer glass, it pours a dark, but slightly see through black, with little off white head. At first sip, I’m thinking I might have gotten a bad bottle, especially given it’s score. It seems a bit over carbonated and less malty than it should be.

pours a very dark brown with at nice lasting tan head.  Aroma of dark chocolate and espresso with faint hops.  Flavor similar with roasted chocolate malt, coffee, and a perfect amount of hop presence in the finish which is a pleasant deviation from most porters.  My favorite porter and my favorite from Great Lakes.
Draught in a sampler at GBL in Cleveland. Dark opaque brown. A deep, easy-drinking porter. Flavors of thick, roasted espresso beans and mild chocolate. Nose like cold-brewed coffee.

Bottle from Capone’s.  Almost tastes more like a stoudt than a porter.  Pours very dark with a thin off white head.  A bit thin on the palate but very well balanced.  Very roasty will obvious notes of coffee and chocolate.

Can’t believe I’ve never rated this beer.  I’ve drank so much of this stuff and it would probably be the first beer I’d put on a home draught system.
Dark brown in color with a nice frothy sheet of head on top.  Taste is roasted malt, some chocolate and coffee.  There are surprisingly quite a bit of hops present.  Medium mouthfeel with a little bit of bitterness.  Great beer, very sessionable.

12 oz bottle.
aroma is of malt,coffee,bitter chocolate. 
taste is good, maybe a little thin. a porter complexity for sure. a little more hops than i like for a porter,overall a great example of the style.

Sixer from The Rock...Beautiful brown brew with a nice lasting billowy tan head. Not much lacing.  Aroma is sweet malts (caramel?), chocolate, and roast coffee. Nicely carbonated. Nicely balanced flavor, with the sweet chocolate and malts rounded out with some bittering hops and lots of roast flavor. Very smooth and drinkable.

One of the better Great Lakes brews, not huge fan of them overall.  Aroma comes in nice and subtle of roasted malts with hints of coffee coming through.  Nice dark brown color with a tan head.  Roasted flavor is smooth, coffee and chocolate going through before its over, finishes bitter.  Finish is better than I find most Great Lakes brews to finish, hence me not being a huge fan of them.
Great Lakes Sample Pack from Woodmans Oak Creek. Smooth and well balanced. Great color and firm head. Coffee and malts are near perfect in combination with slight carbonation.

Got this on tap at the Yardhouse in Glenbrook, IL. My girlfriend likes this beer, if that tells you anything. Awesome color, chocolately roasty nose and taste, dry finish. Great beer, arguably the best from Great Lakes,

12 oz. bottle.  Dark brown color with thin, light tan head.  Aroma of chocolate powder.  Nice roasted chocolate flavor.  Smooth and silky.  Long lasting bitter finish.  Another great one from Great Lakes.

Pours a pretty dark brown.  Chocolate, coffee, slight blackberry.  More carbonation that some for a porter.  Also a little more of a hop bite, and finishes crisp and clean.  All and all a good porter, would recommend.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: Pours out a dark redish brown, light tan head and great lacing.  Nose- powdered chocolate milk, red fruits and faint roast.  Taste- medium to light bodied with relatively high carbonation.  Figs, raisins, dark chocolate and burnt toast.  Finish is quite burnt.   Initially I thought this brew was light on flavour but grows on me through the course of the bottle and it warming up.  Very nice porter and I lift my glass to Gordon Lightfoot for bringing back memories on his haunting song whilst enjoying this fine porter.

Poured very dark brown, almost black with a tan head that receded to a ring around the glass. Rich smell of cherries, cocoa, some espresso notes, molasses, and currants. Amazing smell, especially for a regular porter. Roast coffee upfront, before leading into cocoa and some hoppiness, then some of the dark fruit comes through before a dry coffee finish. Medium carbonation and light to medium bodied, pretty slick and oily on the tongue. Really a joy to drink, I wish this was easier to get here in Iowa.

UPDATED: FEB 21, 2009 Another great beer from great lakes.   Pours black with a nice creamy head.  hints of coffee and roasted chocolate.  have never really had a bad porter but it is fair to say this is the best i have had.  It just seems to be everything one would look for in this type of beer.
Has a nice, but not strong aroma and holds a fair head.  Tastes of coffee grounds with some sweetness and citrus in the aftertaste.  A good example of the style.

Pours a clear dark brown, looks the way pepsi cola does on  a warm summer afternoon, inviting. Wonderful roasted aroma. Smells the way a chocolate flavored medium roast coffee would, sweetened with brown sugar and maple syrup. The flavor is everything the aroma promises, wonderful. Like a perfect cup of coffee. The palate is a but thin but fits well with the beer. By no means am I disappointed. Bring on some more!

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2012 12 oz bottle courtesy of  lb4lb. Pours an opaque dark brown color with a small khaki head that quickly fades to 1/8 inch and holds. The aroma is moderate in strength with mocha, a bit of molasses and spicy burnt toast. The taste is roasty with walnuts, blackened barley, dark chocolate and biter-sweet cocoa. The mouthfeel is smooth and creamy. The finish is medium in duration, dry and clean. Overall: One of the better porters I have sampled, complex, delicious and easy drinking. Rerate 3-27-2012. Bottle from freehafe. Thanks.

Got a sixer of these in erie PA. Pours decent dark brown with a light brown semi frothy head. Smells of roasted malts, chocolate with a little hoppyness.
The flavor here is slightly different than expected. This seems to be more hop driven than malt, almost like half N half. It starts of a little hoppy then the chocolate and roasted malt takes over ending on a somewhat bitter note. The mouth feel is medium in body and almost to the point of being watery but not quite. Leaves a medium burnt aftertaste. All around pretty darn good and well balanced with some complexity. Cheers!

Bottle courtesy of goryshkewych. Lightly acidic chocolate and coffee aromas insinuate the beer’s thickness. Brown sugar, molasses, and cinnamon are also prevalent in the nose. Deep brown-amber with a swirly thin head. Very roasty flavor, sweet roasted malts give a bitter/sweet contrast without hops coming into play. Reminiscent of a perfect cup of coffee, acidity and roastiness in perfect balance. Mouthfeel is sharp and carbonated, but impressively full-bodied.

Bottle. Pours a very dark brown to nearly black color with a fluffy, light brown head. Excellent aroma of dark roasted malt with just a hint of chocolate. Dark, roasty, malty flavor with a bit of biscuit and chocolate thrown in for good measure. Some hop bitterness and flavor in the background. Nice, chewy mouthfeel. This is an outstanding porter.

12 oz bottle at brewpub.  My tour guide made this sound like Great Lakes pride and joy, telling us that it had won more awards than any of their other beers, that it had been rated as the best porter, and that it had won more overall awards than any other beer.  It goes without saying that most of this seems like total bullshit.  Anyway, it had a near black pour with a minimal khaki brown head.  Aroma was all coffee and roasted malt.  The flavor was good but not too complex, mostly just coffee, burn malt, and smoke.  It was pretty drinkable, but not nearly as smooth as other porters I have had with higher abv.s.  It was medium bodied on the palate with trace carbonation.  Overall: this was a good beer, but not nearly what I expected after its intro by my tour guide (even knowing that most of what he was saying must be incorrect).

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2008 12 oz bottle.  Pours nearly opaque dark brown with a nice light tan head.  Aroma is strong, roasty, sweet, dark chocolate.  Flavor is delicious, roasted coffee, bitter dark chocolate, a bit of sweetness.  Lightly bitter and roasty finish.  If anything, the bitter chocolate flavor might last a bit long, but for me that just lets me enjoy it longer.  Yep, this is great stuff.

Poured from a 12 oz. bottle.  Greyish chocolate look.  Molasses, cola syrup, milk chocolate, vanilla aroma; all toasted malt and brown sugar and cookie dough, with a lick of basic sugary sweetness throughout.  Foundational, with no nuances, and firmly set.  Dry, full, polished porter flavors; crisp leafy bitterness and a firm bittersweet nuttiness that dries out the wet, molasses-soaked maltiness quite nicely.  Pear and apple skin mid palate offering the simplest of tart fruit flavor, wetting a bit with a juicy fig like sweetness in the mid palate; this in tandem with all that molasses and coke syrup sweetness tends to allow a cloying quality to peek through, but its tamed easily by meatiness, delicate brown spice, and calm bitterness.  Milky, medium body is very soft, with just the right feathery touch for a traditional porter; plenty of pale malt doughiness in a warm, generous finish.  Exemplary.  Thanks Tyler!

(bottle, thanks Tytoanderso!) Pours dark brown with an off-white head.  Aroma is pretty simple, but very pleasant with lightly roasted malt, chocolate, cocoa, and brownies.  The taste is a little more complex than the aroma, with a nice light roast, coffee, chocolate, some soy-sauce, and a nice tart berry skin finish that rounds out to a lightly bitter end.  Mouthfeel is pretty thin.  This is a very traditional porter that lacks the harsh roast and thicker mouthfeel that others possess, and it would make an excellent session beer.

Presentation: It was poured from a 12oz bottle into a pint glass. It appears dark and opaque. It has a dark black color with deep crimson highlights when held up to light. The head is tan, thick and foamy with good retention. Some light tan lace slowly sides down the glass, chasing the head, as I drink. The aroma is full and rich. It has notes of caramel with a strong dark roasted malt presence that has a deep roasted espresso character. Its flavor has deep chocolate roasted malts with flavor notes of coffee and cream with bittersweet chocolate. The hops play well off the malt and further develop the bittersweet chocolaty flavors before slowly fading out into the finish. The palate is smooth, creamy and slightly slick with mild carbonation and a medium to full body. Outstanding. This porter is one of my personal favorites, with a wonderful balance of flavors and drirkability. I would highly recommend this as a stand alone drink or even pairing it with your favorite chocolate.
12 oz. bottle.  Really tasty, this one has a lot of sweetness like brown sugar, but theres a solid bitterness under the surface.
Had this bottle from Variety pack.  I nice tart porter with a hint of hops good color and fair head.  Some citrus which i liked in the style.

Bottle courtesy of either Gillard or poonpillager. Pours dark brown with a one finger tan head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate and coffee. Taste is the same as aroma. Medium thin mouthfeel with a mild amount of bitterness. Very good.

12 oz bottle.  (bb 10/01/08).  Its a fine line between a porter and a stout, and this porter gets pretty close.  (Not that theres anything wrong with that).  Deep chestnut brown with a small, creamy beige head, and smelling of sweet chocolate, roasted malt, and oreos, this could easily be confused with a stout.  The taste leans back toward a porter, though, with more sweetness and less roast than you find in most stouts.  The body is medium to full, and the carbonation is about where it should be.  Good stuff.

Pours an extremely dark brown color with a nice brown head.  Has a really attractive roasted malt aroma that begs you to drink.  Flavor is malty blend of chocolate and coffee that is nicely balanced with a significant hops presence.  The mouthfeel is very pleasant and the drinkability is very high.

Bottle courtesy of goryshkewych, thanks George. Pours a dark brownish black color with a foamy brown head. Aroma of chocolate, coffee, roasty malt. Flavor is coffee, chocolate with some bitter hops in the finish. Nice porter.

Bottle courtesy of fiver29 & BR007.  Pours a clear dark brown/black with a 2 finger fluffy off-white head w/nice lacing.  Nose is chocolate and coffee with a sweet toffee-like background.  Palate is light roasted coffee and chocolate upfront that progresses into a bitter hoppy finish.  Lighter mouth feel.  Would be better with a more full body, but still a great porter.  Thanks John and Brian for the beer!  Ive got that song stuck in my head now though...

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2009 12 oz. bottle - big thanks to fiver29 for the trade; jet black with thin, cream-colored head; sweet, roasty aromas come right at you; a tasty mixe of chocolate and coffee with a mild roastyness - very pleasant aromas; accordingly, it drinks equally rich and smooth with a thick, creamy body; very soft and tasty; flavors of mild coffee and sweet chocolate; perfect run from nose to flavors to texture and finally to finish; just damn good across the board and  perhaps my favorite porter to date
Dark, chocolate coloured body. large full brown head. very sweet and full on the palate. aroma is of carmel, tobacco and smoke. taste is of chocolate and almonds.

Taupe head, moderate lacing, good thin cloud cover over the black walnut-crimson hue.  Nose of dutch cocoa powder, cold coffee, and hop spice.  Excellent creaminess on the palate  soothes the coffee and the malt presence sweetens the cocoa.  Balanced finish leading towards a roasted hint of smoke with a lingering hop fade.  Well made, tasty, refreshing and thought provoking.

Dark brown with small white head. Scent of coffee and chocolate. Palate has more bread in it but is a nice balance. A little salty of an aftertaste. Palate is a little clean for me. Good, not the blackout though.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2008 12 oz bottle with a 5/7/07 "best by" date.  Not sure what theyre talking about, but this one ages absolutely fantastic!!  It definitely has thinned a bit, but the flavors all blended together like magic on the tongue!  Goodness...!!!

12 oz. bottle courtesy of my Secret Santa. Pours black with a moderate tan head that lasted through the first third of the glass and left partial lace.  Very pleasant aroma of chocolate, lightly roasted malt, and some coffee.  The flavor is a bit more tilted towards the malt with some coffee and chocolate detected as well.  Moderate bitterness at the finish.  This is a very enjoyable porter.

Sampled at the Savor DC event.  Pours a heavy looking opaque black with a whispy white head.  Malty aroma with roasted nuts and coffee.  Flavor is sweet and nutty and very well rounded.  Finish is clean and dry.  One of the better dark beers sampled at this event.

This is the beer that turned me on to craft beer years ago at Mad Mex.  I remember more hop bitterness behind porter elements.  Whether that is true or not many traditional porter elements are present here withouth the excessive sweetness growing in craft porters.  Aromas of nutty chocolate give way to raisin and soy flavor.  BTW love the raisins and soy sauce porter description.

Bottle courtesy petrucci914. Pours a blackish red with a thick white head. Aroma is very big roasted grain, chocolate malt and fresh ground coffee. Taste is roasted grain and coffee. Very smooth and easy drinking. Finishes with just a hint of coffee. Very nice.

Bottle. [<a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?UserID=7  target=_new> Courtesy of Boutip]. Clear dark dark red brown color with a large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, chocolate, coffee, light roasted. Flavor is moderate sweet and moderate to heavy bitter with a average to long duration. (Malt bitter). Body is medium to light, texture is watery, carbonation is soft. A bit borring and thin but okay beer. (080408)

Sample at West Lakeview Liquors, Chicago, Great Lakes Tasting.  Opaque black color with tan head.  Aroma is a good amount of dry smoke and roast, perfectly instyle.  Flavor is roast and smoke once again but with a good amount of chocolate and subtle hop bitterness as well.  Medium, creamy body.  This is very nice and very much what Great Lakes does, prefectly well-balanced, instyle beers.  I could see even people who dont like "dark beers" digging on this as well as experienced imperial stout fans.

12oz bottle: Pours a dark black color.  When put in front of a bright light it gives off a bright ruby glow.  Fairly long-lasting creamy head.  Roasted chocolate aroma.  Initial flavor was of  bitter cocoa, as the beer warmed it took on more of a smoky taste.  Surprisingly lighter body than I expected.  Laced nicely as it went down.  A very solid beer that I will definitely have again.

Ive drank my share of porters, and for the life of me Ive never had one that I could point out that was "that much" different than a stout.  To me, this beer is a porter...  I know what it is now.  Aroma is roasty, with some earthy hops.  Smells like fresh baked cookies in some ways.  Flavor is cocoa and coffee hints, with roasted malt through and through.  Finish is dry bitter.  Beer pours just south of opaque, with a creamy tan head that sticks all the way to the bottom of the beer.  Trying this beer is like trying the style for the first time for me.  This is a very good beer.

this beer poured a deepest black with a nice one inch thick head.

the smell was big on coffee and malty sweet. i also pick up some toffee smell. there is a bit of alcohol smell in there as well.

the taste is chocolate and toffee and a bit bitter, but superbly balanced. this beer got MUCH better as it warmed. very roasty.

the mouthfeel is pretty full and is what i expect from a great porter.

wow, what a drinkable beer. a superb porter that i could drink quite a few of.
This beer is excellent, especially because im from cleveland.  its hard to come by on a college budget but i enjoy it when i can.  more bitter than my normal beer.

Pours black as night with a hint of ruby around the edges. Head is small but dense and lingers throughout the session leaving decent lacing.  Big time roasted malt smell with strong coffee and dark chocolate aromas. Definite dark fruit smell as well with a very nice faint hop smell to balance everything. One of the better porters Ive smelled.  Roasted malts form the backbone with a pleasant sweetness dominated by chocolate. The finish is actually fairly bitter with a lingering coffee aftertaste.  Light to medium mouthfeel with decent carbonation.  As sessionable porters go, this is near the top of the list. I could easily drink a few of these in an evening and I would seek it out.

12 oz bottle.  Pours very dark, looks black til you hold it up to the light and see some hints of ruby, 2 cm of a light tan head that is slowly diminishing.  Aroma is malty, bitter chocolate, dark fruits, and some coffee as it warms.  Initial flavor is sweet chocolate and coffee.  Flavor ends similarly, but with some malts and hops to complicate the flavor, let leaving it balanced.  Some lacing, limited carbonation, medium body, and limited alcohol presence.  Overall a drinkable beer and the best regular octane beer that Great Lakes puts out.

12oz bottle.  Aroma is roasted malt with notes of chocolate, coffee, pine hopps.  Average sized off-white foamy head that left great lace and lasted for the most part.  Very dark mahogany hue that lets very little light through.  Flavor is roasted sweet coffee and cocoa then turns nicely bitter.  Palate is watery smooth and soft with a nice clean finish.  Light bodied, a real session brew.  A very good porter; clean, complex, well balanced, and delicious.  Top notch.
Bottle pours a black color with a tan head.  Has a medium mouthfeel.  Tastes like chocolate upfront, caramel/roasted malt sweetness, then finishes with chocolate that makes me want more and more.

Poured into my awesome new Kuhnhenn pint glass, thanks adam!

A- Pours a deep mahogany color letting almost no light pass through. A small one finger head tops the beer however it stays there for quite a while.

S- Smell is predominately roasted malts, a bit of sweetness. Not the most aromatic brew but decent none the less.

T- This is what I think a porter should taste like. Roasted malt flavor which leads into slight hints of coffee with an underlying sweetness the fades to a touch of hop bitterness in the end. Not an extreme brew by any means just well balanced and easy drinking.

M- Medium viscosity with quite a bit of carbonation, makes for easy drinking.

D- Its great to see a top 100 beer that is not so extreme. Ive gotten tired of giant bash your face in stouts and imperial porters where I feel like ive been hit by a freight train after each sip. This is a welcome break from that complexity and just brings to the table a simple, good porter. Definitely an excellent session beer, I would not hesitate to seek this out again and again.

Pours a rich mahogany color into a pint glass. As I hold the glass to the light, beautiful ruby highlights ring the glass. A creamy head develops and leaves a thick, lasting layer of off-white foam floating on top. 

Aromas of cocoa, freshly ground coffee, fruity and malty. Slightly reminiscent of graham crackers. 

Taste is exceptional, and definitely lives up to the reputation. Slightly sweet, with milk chocolate and cappucino dominating. Again, I am tasting some graham cracker maltiness and a slightly sour flavor as well, which balances the sweetness. And I almost forgot the hops hiding in the background which lend a fruity crispness to the beer. 

Mouthfeel is rich, creamy and has a nice, drying finish. Coffee flavors linger ever so slightly, encouraging you to have another sip. Flavors of dark chocolate remain in the mouth while you ponder how good this beer is. 

Highly drinkable. Goes down very easy, ABV is moderate, making this beer one that you could easily have several in a sitting. 

Overall an exceptional brew!
Can taste the coffee and chocolate, a nice roasty porter... I am a big fan of Great Lakes.. never met a Great Lakes that I didnt like

*really like it would buy it*

aroma: smells nice! clean hints of quality booze. yummy chocolate type aromas.  app: eh.. do porters ever look good?? it is black/brown water.  flavor: yum! very nice roasty cocoa. good good flavor with no bitter sour backdrop to spoil the day. very great session beer.  thin and refreshing not to bubble trouble. OA:  really like this indeed i do. it is mild easy and refreshing yet full of yummy flavor.
Bottle. Peach and a bit of roast and laurel in the aroma. Thin. Malty, roastflavor with laurel, coughing syrup and apple. Pleasant and easy to drink.

Pours almost completel black in color with a tan head. Aroma of chocolate, coeffe and vanilla. Taste is very creamy with a nice burnt coffee taste and a bitter hoppy finish. Probably my favorite of the style.
Bottled. Almost black in colour with a small tan head. Malty with roasted notes of dried and dark friuts and a hint of chocolate.

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2010 Pours thin but near black with a large frothy/creamy beige head.  Large sweet coffee ground aroma.  Wonderful roasted malt flavor, slightly burned and some coffee  beans.  Mellow with a little bit of milk chocolate.  Doesnt taste quite like 60 IBUs. Very easy drinking, slightly thin, but milky.    

- On draft it was very hoppy.  

[rerate 2.7.10] bottle that I forgot about from early 08/late 07 sometime, BB 7.26.08.  I thought this might just be a waste, especially after I opened it and smelled the oxidized hops, however, this actually aged pretty wonderfully even in the poor conditions I kept it in.  Quite creamy and richly chocolatey without a slight acidic sourness that is quite fitting.  Smells identical to  an aged imperial stout actually.  Pretty nice.  . . . . . . . . . . . .
[about half a dozen glasses on draft] damn this beer is good! so hoppy and roasty and super easy drinking without ever getting boring! love it

Bottle.
Clear brown coloured with a small beige head.
Sweet and light roasted aroma of liquorice and dried fruits.
Sweet flavour of caramel, dried fruits and liquorice with roasted notes.

A Mes rate: Bottle at Toms UGT Pt. 2.Attractive dark amber brown colour. Rich roasted chocolate malt with a slight dryness. Slight coffee in the finish but otherwise it is straight down the line roasted chocolate malt. Excellent length. Straight down the line but I have to give it kudos for now being over the top.

Great porter.  Nice aroma of malt and hops.  Slightly sweet.  Very drinkable.  Medium body, big flavor.  Roasted, chocolaty, very subtle black licorice flavors.  

on tap at four winds
Bottle at the cads disco dance-off tasting. Alround rating: Roasty, ash, chocolate, harsh over stewed coffee, quite thin and perhaps overly carbonated. Filtered and pasturised?

Bottle at Magic_dave6s disco dance tasting. Nose is toasted malts, dark brown with a thin beige head. Some chocolate. Mouth is watery burnt malts, finishes lasting and overly malty burnt. Watery but alright.

Great porter.  This is a porter I think everybody would love, not too too burnt toast, but just right.  Flavor is a bit mild, but inviting with of course a roasty and hop prescence.  Its apperance is very dark, common of the porter class.  Its flavor is a complex array of chocolate and coffee w/ some hop as well.  Its utterly smooth for a porter.  This is good stuff.
Bottle at Toms Glasgow tasting 2 ... Deep brown ... peaty woody nose ... sweet little smokey some caramel malts as you swirl ... Bland up front but more character in Background.
