UPDATED: MAY 1, 2009 aroma of smooth oatmeal and roast. flavor has porter chocolate/coffee notes but also some cola and even root beer. nice carb. mouthfeel is far from sticky, a great porter...a great use of roasted malt.
Bottle.  pours dark brown with small tan head.  nice combination of coffee and chocolate. A lot of flavor considering the low alcohol.
12oz bottle. Pours black witha small tan head. Aroma of malt, coffee and chocolate. Flavor is  the same. Finishes bitterseet. Wish it had a little more umph.
Very Very good.  Nice Strong robust coffee, chocolate, malt mix flavor.  At 5.8 a very drinkable beer.  I could have a lot of these.

12 oz bottle:  Pours an almost opaque black color with little to no head.  Aroma is deep dark chocolate and a light coffee note as well.  A nice roasted caramel malt characteristic as well, but Im not really detecting a "bold hop presence" as it says in the description.  Taste is wonderful thats where this beer comes through.  Lovely chocolate and roasted malt characteristic as warming on the body and the coffee flavor comes through.  Aftertaste is really good as well with a lingering chocolate/coffee taste that makes this a really nice porter.  Overall, Dang this stuff is good.  I would buy it again in a heart beat.

A very nice offering from Great Lakes with this beer. Its one of the porters that stands alone, IMO where it really doesnt blur the lines between stouts and porters too much. A chocolatey/coffee aroma (more chocolate than coffee)...fairly simple. Appearance is dark brown, nearly black with brown edges and a nice off-white 1-finger head. Flavor is moderately sweet, chocolate, some roasty/coffee notes and maybe a touch of toffee. Easy to drink. Nice beer.
Bottle. Dark red brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is roasted, alcohol, coffee, malt, Flavour is roasted, coffee, alcohol, malt, chocolate. nice beer.

12 oz bottle shared with JesseM, RyanMac13 and beerguyryan. pours dark brown with a average tan head. roasted malt aromas with some coffee and caramel. flavours are well put together and the 60 IBUs helps make this a very well balanced and enjoyable porter.

12 oz. bottle shared with Matt7215, RyanMac13, and Beerguyryan. Thanks Matt! This was infinitely better than the porter Id had before it. Aroma is much nicer, more porter-like, a tad roasty, but defined more by the sweeter elements like chocolate and molasses. Taste, very nice, noticeably more hoppy than other porters Ive had, loaded with black liqorice and toffee. Very nice. It only looses points for over-carbonation, which had a negative effect on the mouth-feel.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a dark brown, creamy light brown head.  Smells of chocolate and coffee, and tastes about the same.  Good medium to full body with a creamy feel.  Taste sticks around, which is nice.  Beer Club favorite for March 2008 tasting.

Visually a step above Blackout due to a creamy tan head, this beer pours a deep mahogany.  Aroma is charcoal and Starbucks.  Flavor is all porter, a little hops in there that made it unique but doesnt have the richness of Olfabrikken or Alpha Klaus.  Glad I had an opportunity to try.

Bottle poured into a tulip glass produced nice tan head that dwindled to a thick lace all set on top of a black body

Aromas of coffee and roasted malts a little chocolate and some hops 

Sweet flavors of malts and coffee with a light hop bitter. This is a really well balanced in the flavor department 

Medium body with a good amount of carbonation but still smooth  

It has good drinkability I could handle a few of these a night
Easly my favorite Porter.  Pours smoothly and produces an ample head.  Has a strong and striking taste, deep in flavor and most certainly long lasting.

On draft at Sharp Edge, Creekhouse location in Pittsburgh. Poured dark brown almost black and a  tan head. Aroma of  roasted coffee and chocolate malts. Taste is of smooth roasted coffee with touches of chocolate sweetness. Very drinkable and very nice.

Bottle. A clear, ruby-brown porter with a beige head. Dryish aroma with dark chocolate, bitter chocolate and some sweetness as well. Chocolate, roasted malt and a little touch of alcohol in the aroma. Medium to full body, rather dryish and dusty. Fruity and chocolatey finish. "Quite nice" I wrote in my notes, but that is sure an understatement. A really easy drinkable porter with lots of flavor and not so much alcohol. (080118)

Bottle. Dark red, almost black body with a medium beige head. Aroma is slightly roasted malt with a hint of liquorices. Flavor is smoked malt, some coffee and a pleasant bitterness. OK, but not fantastic.

bottle - Pours dark brown with a thin tan head.  It smells of coffee and dark roast malt.  The coffee accented roast malt flavor has a good hops balance.  its medium bodied and finishes with light, lingering bitterness.  Excellent porter.

Bottle.  Pours dark brown/black, a slight red hue when held up to the light.  Thin brown head.  Aromas of coffee, chocolate and a little pine.  Taste is nice, roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, a little smoke and a little bit of a hop bite.  Medium body, a little chalky.  Good beer.

Very solid porter, one of the better ones I have had.  On draft, pours a dark brown with a tan head.  Nice aroma of chocolate and coffee.  The flavor is the same, nice bitter chocolate and a bit of coffee and a little bit of hops.  Very well balanced and easily drinkable.  Great Lakes puts out some good stuff.

12 oz. bottle.  Impressive pour, rich chocolate color topped off by a thick brown head.  Aroma of dry roasted grains and coffee.  Body is just about right, not too thin with a chocolate malt flavor.  Some bitter coffee in the finish.  Hops really stand out in the finish with a robust bitterness.  A solid take on a classic style.
Very strong coffee aroma and taste. malty with a very long finish. Different but good.
From great lakes sampler pack, Really nice porter a little more hops than typical but still well balanced. Far and away the best beer in the sampler.

A nice port which was part of a sampler pack and were all but gone at the end of a party sept 1.  Hope to get this again, would like to try on tap!  Nice roasted aroma and taste.  Dark chocolate and coffee flavors with some sweetness.  Good balance and smooth.  Would like to try again real soon.

This is a good one. I would have to agree with a earlier poster and say that porters sometimes are a little to sweet for my liking but this one is not. Nice balance of hops, roasted malts, and chocolate flavors. Great beer.

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2016 2/11/08 - Decent. Deep red brown in color, brief pale head. Lots of flavor - balanced but with a definite preference to the hops, slightly sweet on the edges. Dark roasted coffee, a little treacle and licorice, a little bittersweet chocolate.
Light on the palette compared to some, but flavor intensity llingers well.
12/15/16 - Id adjust my assessment to slightly sweeter, and add a light creaminess to the palate.

Usually I feel porters are a bit sweet for my taste, but this one holds up. Hops from the aroma, then tons of roasted barley flavor with tons of hops, also with a great finish. A smooth drinking nice bodied beer.

A bottle from a Great Lakes variety pack. It poured a dark brown with cherry highlights around the edges. There was a very thin head that disappeared quickly. A very nice aroma of dark chocolate and roated coffee. The flavor was also of a good dark chocolate and hints of roated coffee. There was just a hint of a bitter undertone and a real nice mellow finish. Very good Porter!!

Nice roasty aroma with hints of chocolate and coffee. Taste is more roasted/toasty malts with a definitive chocolate backbone. Nice balance between the chocolate and roast/coffee. No dominate flavors. Soft carbonation with a medium-full body. Bitterness is subdued, but notable. Really good, but not "great".

Had the pleasure of sampling my first Fitz. at the Great Lakes Brewery in July. One of my all time favorite Porters. Bottle pours dark amber/ black.Perfect rosty malt aroma. Not too dry. Chocolate and coffee flavors. Steller.
Almost opaque dark brown pour with a decent tan head. Nice roasted coffee aroma. Flavor is roasted malt with a touch of chocolate. A bit thin in body, but flavorful. Not bad.

UPDATED: APR 23, 2010 OK I had to rerate this one because when I first joined ratebeer I really thuoght this tasted like crap but now that my taste buds have been trained this is a great porter with chocolates,coffee and yes a pretty good hop presence

From a variety 12-pack. Very dark, but I could see my fingers through the other side of the glass. The head lasts. This is a nice dry porter, very roasty (smoky even), coffee-ish. Soft body, perhaps lighter than expected. Still one of my favorites in the porter/stout family.

Bottle.  Pours very dark brown with thin, long lasting tan head.  Aroma is roasty coffee and bitter chocolate.  Flavor is roasted coffee, some bitter chocolate notes, and maybe some smokiness.  Very well balanced, but perhaps a bit acidic.  Mouthfeel is very nice, not as thin as a lot of porters.  Very drinkable and pretty delicious.

Appearance: Pours a not quite opaque, dark brown body with a small, fizzy light khaki-colored head.

Smell: Aroma of cold coffee and unsweetened chocolate with a faint whiff of acrid smoke and pine.

Taste: Bittersweet chocolate flavor with some roasty coffee and a slight caramel sweetness. A teaspoon of cherry cordial comes and goes with a quickness. Hint of roasted nuts. Resinous pine hop presence provides a touch of balancing bitterness. Piney, mocha-ish finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation.

Drinkability: A quality, well-balanced porter thats full of flavor and easily drinkable.

(Bottle, thanks Degarth. Best before 10/02/07) Pours very dark brown to black with a brown head. The aroma is roasted and toasted with tones of chocolate, coffee and brown sugar. Undertones of dark berries, nuts and oven roasted root vegetables, wet stone, citrus and rhubarb. The flavour is roasted with tones of coffee and chocolate. Undertones of nut cream and a light citric hop sting. The mouthfeel is dry and light sourish from the roasted grain but otherwise very smooth, creamy and velvety. Light to medium bodied. Where are the 60 IBU?

12 oz bottle shared at Foam Rangers club meeting.  Pours dark with an off-white head.  Good smell of coffee and roast malt.  Taste is coffee with a hint of chocolate.  Mouthfeel is medium-to-thin with a little carbonation and some bitterness at the end.

Pours very nice dark brownish/black with decent tan head. Aroma is mostly hearty roasted malts with a hint of chocolate and a similar spicy hop aroma utilized in their Holy Moses white ale. Flavor is excellent, full bodied, sweet roasted chocolates and a hint of the bitter hops at the finish. Excellent porter.

Poured the expected dark brown with a super thin brown head that receded quickly and provided no lacing.  The aroma was a very nice blend of chocolate, roasted malt, coffee and a thin bit of spicy hops cutting through.  The flavor was roasted malt and coffee with chocolate softening the hard edge.  Nice bit of smoke as well.  The mouthfeel is average and the finish is succinctly bitter.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2008 From bottle... pours dark brown with thick creamy head. Full, roasty chocolate aroma. and translucent. Sweet malty taste with some bitterness. Very nice to drink. This is a really good beer, and I can probably throw back a good number of these.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2008 Pours an opaque very dark brown to black.  Average to small head, tan in color.  Aroma and taste are dominated by coffee/burnt coffee and chocolate tones.  Some hoppiness to the taste, but not too much.  Quite a bit sweeter than most other porters.

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2008 Pours pretty black with a medium tan head and a decent amount of lacing.  Aroma is dark chocolate and coffee.  Taste is very much chocolate and coffee; rather sweet.  Was surprised to see this being a porter.  Tastes like a lot of other sweet or oatmeal stouts.  Very good!

This is a really good porter here.  Very dark and smoky.

Almost opaque black pour with a smallish tan head.

Smells very smoky and dark.  As this warms up, the aroma becomes much more intense and dark.  Very nice.

Nice dark chocolatey smoky taste that is a little thin as far as the mouthfell goes but still nice.  As it warms,  it does get considerably better.  Still a little thinner than some of the true elite porters but as far as being one that I can get on a consistent level, this is the best one out there. I will definitely keep this around.

Black beer that lets just a little bit of light through, small tan head.  Smells of coffee, chocolate, caramel, toasted hazlenut.  Tastes of all the above plus citrus hops that were buried in the aroma.  The finish is dominated by espresso.  Prasctically perfect porter.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2008 12oz bottle shared with ealdent. Pours an opaque black with a medium-sized tan head. The aroma is roasty with lots of black patent malts - some chocolate mixed with some burnt toast. There are also hints of hops in the aroma. The flavor follows the nose: thick black malt character with lots of burnt and dark chocolate flavors. There is also a firm level of fruity, floral, bitter hops. The finish is full, roasty, and bittersweet. The mouthfeel is full in body and has just the right level of effervescence - not quite creamy, but suitably lightened. Overall, an extremely well-made robust porter.

A solid porter, with a tad more hops than most porters Ive had.  Pairs great with a steak at the Great Lakes retaurant.  Anymore, however, it seems to be lacking the fruit sweetness and complexity that I have grown so fond of.  It does have a nice medium mouthfeel and a refreshing amount of hops.  Certainly worth a try, especially with red meat.

Almost black opaque pour with a huge chocolate milk head that dies kind of quick but laces nice. Smells of ground coffee, sweet malt and a hint of hops. Tasty brew. Delicious roasted coffee, sweet malt, and a bitter finish. Medium in the mouth with nice carbonation. Sessionable indeed.

A very nice porter. Pours inky black with an off white head keeps decent lacing. Taste of toffee and burnt caramel. Decently hopped. Not too heavy, and at 5.8% ABV a very nice balance of alcohol. Hops a stronger presence than most porters.

Poured dark brown with a light brown small head.  Big lacing for a small head.  This beer has a huge nose.  Aroma of toffee, coffee, and bitter chocolate. The taste is very good as well. Tastes close to the smell, toffee and some sweetness initially with coffee and roasted nutty flavors finishing.  A distinct burnt flavor comes through as well.  Excellent mouthfeel, what a good porter should have, with a stickey mouth and heavy body.

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2009 Pours a dark, dark brown with a slight red tint. One-finger, thick tan head. Aroma is full and fragrant and sweet, definitely coffee tones.  The flavor is nicely sweet, but not too sweet. Not too bitter either. Theres a nice balance of flavor. Theres certainly a bit of coffee taste, but not bitter like it usually is. Also has a sort of brown sugar taste. Very smooth. Overall, very nice. One of the best dark beers that Ive tried.

12oz bottle from my Secret Santa. Pours opaque brown, nearing pitch black with a creamy, lasting khaki head. Pleasant porter aroma: roasted malt, wet wood, light coffee, semisweet chocolate and a curious hint of green apples. medium bodied on the tongue, but quite creamy with nice fizzy carbonation. The roasted malt and hops are balanced nicely. Nice, but not overpowering coffee and dark chocolate notes interweave with grassy and earthy hops. Quite a nice porter.
Great smooth porter.  Coffee and hazelnut flavors.  Dark brown and black with a light head.

Very large 2+ inch high tan head of fine creamy bubbles.  Light carbonation.  Rich milk chocolate aroma with lots of roasted grains, a hint of coffee and a bit of licorice.  Color is a very dark brown boardering on black.  Dark roasted grain, more coffee and carbon.  Bitter dark chocolate.  Medium bodied, dry and slightly bitter palate.  Long roasty flavor and finish.  Lingering bitterness and some coffee.  A very good porter.

Pours brown-black with about 2 fingers of tan-cream head.  Roasted malt and hazelnut odor.  A hint of dark chocolate- starts off smooth, and ends up with a coffee and burnt toast aftertaste.  Quite good.

Black color. Persistent thin layer of foam. Some aroma of roasted malt and ashes, burnt paper, light rhubarb. Smooth mouthfeel, with a good flavor of caramel, dark chocolate and delicate roasted malt; quite sweet. Good.
super pitch black decent tan head, nose is toffee, and coffee. very rich, good mouthfeel good bitterness.
12 oz bottle. Dark brown, almost black with a nice tan head. Caramel, chocolate and a hint of coffee in the nose. Big malty flavors, lots of chocolate and coffee, very nicely balanced bitterness.
bottle.  maple pour iwth thin tan head.  nutty malts, mild sugars, caramel, smoke and floral hop aroma.  earthy organic body.  nutty malts, mild smoke.  dry and bitter coffee finish.

Pours dark brown with a red sparkle and a creamy tan head that doesnt stick around long.  Smells of chocolate, toffee, some figs and raisins, hints of licorice, coffee, some peppery splashes.  Taste yields a layered malty backdrop with some nice accompanying malt.  Roasty qualities are also present, but not overly done.  Mouthfeel is slick with some nice fruit and spice at the finish.
Bottle. A dark red brown beer with a beige head. Dusty caramel malt, fruity, chocolate and light coffee aroma and taste. Medium body with a dry finish. A good porter!
Easily the best porter out there.  no flat cola taste.  full bodied, full character.  great conditioning!

Thanks to kryptic for this bottle. Nice rich, dark reddish black pour with a cocoa colored foam head. Roasty nose of coffee and cola. Flavor is robust coffee, maybe burned a bit, and some cocoa. Mouthfeel is creamy and full flavored, but a bit watery. Nice porter...thanks kryptic!

(Bottle 35,5 cl) Courtesy of sk8viking. Dark brown with a tint of red and a creamy, light brown head leaving some lacework. Lightly burned malts and a vague acidity in the aroma. Medium body with hard roasted malt accents and a fruity touch. Dry, malt bitter finish. 171107

Bottle, lot 3602AW?, two months until "best before" date. Deep reddish brown, fleeting fizzy head, zero lace. Cola smell with chocolate and smoke undertones; dusty heating duct staleness. Identical flavor: sugary cola again, vending machine coffee, cheap artificial chocolate flavor. Lactic tang. Weird neutral vegetal quality mung sprouts or tofu. 60 IBU, my ass... there is no hop flavor/aroma/bitterness whatsoever. Is this a joke? Gross, watered-down skim milk palate, sharp and yeasty. Chalky and stale instant coffee granules aftertaste. Pretty awful, to the point of being unfinishable. Absolutely hideous beer.

10-17-07 bottle. 
Blood red black color with fluffy beautiful lasting head.  Roasted bitter sweet smell.  The aroma is rich and creamy and just begs you to taste it.  Great cocoa and coffee flavor - although slightly watery.  But, overall a great Porter that I would love to have again!
12oz bottle-pours a tan head and black color.  Aroma is mild dark malt-slight molasses, dark fruit.  Taste is dark malt-slight molasses, dark fruit, faint hops.  Medium body.  OK/mild carbonation.

bottle courtesy of ucusty....thanks for knocking down my wants list....BB1/28/08
pours very dark brown with red hints and a  small cocoa colored head. powdered cocoa aroma with some roasty metallic malts. flavor is bitter/burnt/roasted malts with some chocolate and a nice ashiness. dry finish and lingering aftertaste are of coffee. nice acidity in the mouth feel with lots of carbonation. a little thin and lacking depth but highly drinkable in quantity.

Draft. Served at cellar temperature. Poured a dark dark brown color with orange highlights. Head was three fingers high with good retention and lacing. Smelled of caramel, butterscotch, and light roasty malt. Slightly sweet on the tongue with mild roasty bitterness throughout. Flavor was dominated by roasty malt with a hint of cardboard.
Oily in color with a bone color head which had great lacing and retention.  Aroma was a mix of dark chocolate and coffee.  Flavor was similar with a slight hop kick giving it an almost dry finish.
Bottle: Very good porter.  Pours very dark with a full head.  Aroma and flavor of roasted coffee.
nice full-bodied dark pour.  a hint of coffee in the scent and taste.  no way this is 60 IBUs.   must be hidden by the roast.  a little on the thin side.
I like this the best of the year round Great Lakes brews.  A little chocolate and coffee and great mouthfeel.  If youre going to try Great Lakes and like porters, this is worth a try.

This porter poured a dark black colour with a nice smooth tan head. To the nose there was scents of molassass, caramel, brown sugar and malt, maybe a little cocoa. First taste was roasty with a full flavour of smokey/burnt malt. The finish had a flavour of coffee and a wee bit of hops. Palate, burnt.
I had this one a few times, i liked it but wasnt great. it was free so, i drank it.

UPDATED: OCT 26, 2007 Pours a dark brown with a light tan head.  Nice roasted aromas with chocolate, coffee, nuts, and slight pine.  Taste is the same with moderately roasted notes throughout, with a nice sweetness, and slightly bitter backend.  I cant find the 60 IBUs in this one, as much as I anticipated.  Its very well balanced and rich.  I think its too thin however, the mouthfeel is off with a thin, carbonated, filmy texture.  I must say, it does get better and better every time I drink this one.

Bottle.  Very dark brown color with a nice beige 2-finger head on this one.  Roasted aroma comes through.  Nice beer flavor with a coffee-ish chocolate taste left in the mouth.  This is a very nice beer that I will try again and again.

Thanks to Julys Santa for this. Pours out a dark brown with a moderate tanish head. Chocolate, roasted malt and slight nut/earthy notes on the nose. Flavor is complex, roasted malt, chocolate, slight coffee and slight bitterness on the finish. Very well done

Really nice dark earthy taste, I didnt get the chocolate taste until the aftertaste came around. Coffee flavor throughout, a little thinner body than I thought, one of the better porters Ive been able to find.

-bottle ordered from Archer Liquors
Dark brown pour with a slightly transluscent look to it, giving it a ruby tint.  Nice tan head.  Chocolate and coffee roast dominate the aroma as to be expected here.  Flavor is solid, with a standard roastiness and bittersweet chocolate like flavor, but the body is a tad thin.  Nicely balanced beer, good flavor, and enjoyable, but could benefit from a bit more body.  Very much worth trying.
This was a very good porter...reminded me of Deschutes Black Butte Porter...I would definitely recommend this beer.
another one of my favorite porters, this one is very smooth and has some great chocolate tones and a good arrangement of hops
A stout with plenty of character but sort of a hollow shell in body. The meaty, smoky aromas emanating from the bottle are a little off-putting, unless youre standing around an outdoor fire.

Had this beer on 6/7/2007.  Aroma is a nice toasted scent.  Color is solid black with good carbonation and a very tight head.  Taste is roasted and dry.  Starting with a medium body goes down crisp.  Finish is a nice roasted malt flavor that ends with a dry feel.  It seems more Stout like then Porter.

Wow, I think I cant thank ruffian enough for this treat. Magnificent porter, sausagy, tiny hints of smoke, very hoppy for a poster, perfect creamyness balanced with superb carbonation. Magnificent beer

Bottle.  This is my favorite porter to date. It is priced low enough where it can double as my "go to" porter for any occasion, which is great.  Aroma is satisfying, appearance is dark with a small head that leaves adequate legs on the glass.   Mouthfeel is creamy (yet carbonated), soothing and somewhat sweet. I think the flavor is excellent, and it goes wonderful with many types of food.  An outstanding porter that gives me utmost respect for the brewery.  This one is always in my fridge.
UPDATED: OCT 28, 2007 Bottle. This one was maybe a bit overcarbonated for me. Smells & tastes of coffee and chocolate. Smooth finish. A very good porter.
12 oz bottle thanks to blankboy.  Lots of roasty chocolate and coffee on the nose.  Nice burnt malt flavor too.  Decent porter dustiness in the finish.  Very good

12oz. bottle - pours very dark brown with ruby highlights under light and a mocha head on top which eventually dissipated to a thin, satiny layer. Aroma is of coffee first, choclate second, hops third, and nutty toffee fourth. Flavour is of more chocolate and coffee along with some smoke, with a very well balanced hop presence which carries on beautifully into the finish giving this porter a nicely bitter/sweet character. The texture is velvety and rich. Excellent porter. One of the best Ive had.

Pours a nice dark brownish/blck color with a small tan head. Aromas of coffee and chocolate.Nice big bitter coffee flavor followed by a sweet chocolate aftertaste. Hint of hop bite in there as well.Very good!(Thanks Brewblackhole)

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2010 Nov 2005 - Poured dark, dark brown with nice foamy head...little bubbles remained on top during the whole beer. The taste was predominantly roasted malts. Coffee and chocolate were mildly noticeable. Very dry finish with a little hop kick in the end, which I dont usually like in this style, but fit well here. A well done brew.

Aug. 2010 - Not much to add on the additional review.  Full of chocolate, roast and some sweetness.  Not overly dry, as noted originally, but full of flavor and very well done.  Bumped from 3.9 to 4.1

Virtually black body with mahogany edges.  Small cream colored head settles quickly to a thin, bubbly rim.  Sudsy lace does not stick around for very long.  Coffee, chocolate, and cream scents combine to create an ultra-attractive mocha milkshake aroma.  Resinous, piney hops follow quickly behind, adding a surprising, yet welcomed earthy element.  The flavor isnt quite as impressive, but its appealing nonetheless.  I picked up burnt caramel and toasted grains in addition to the aforementioned mocha and piney hop elements.  The body tips the scale slightly towards medium-full.  Smooth, with a moderate coffee finish.  Really nicely done porter.

Aroma is smokey, alcoholic and salty. Entering this Im a bit surprised that its only 5.8% ABV. Still a nice aroma :)

Fresh hoppiness over smoke and a touch of liqorice. Very nice but Id fancy it a bit more assertive.

Sip for sip, one of the best porters out there.  Leans toward stoutiness, but helps to prove that porter is often a better beer than stout--more complex, rounded and satisfying.  It captures your mouth.

12 oz  bottle from capones.  Dark brown with some ruby highlights at the bottom of the glass.  Small tan head.  Aroma is chocolate, coffee, and some light floral hops in the background.  Taste is alot of chocolate, mild roast/coffee, with light notes of molasses, licorice and tobacco.  Medium bodied, perfectly balanced IMHO for a porter.  Finishes with some chocolate and light sugar, as well as a mild roast and hop bitterness.
Draught at Capones. Black body with nice head. Nice aroma - roasty, light hops. Creamy mouthfeel with a light hop bite. Smooth. Finish is pretty bitter. Nice porter.
very dark almost black look tastes a strong chocolate and coffee taste  great beer!
Had this on tap in Michigan.  Barely any aroma.  Flavor dominated by chocolate and roasted caramel flavors.

From the bottle (Bonus from mreusch, thanks Matt!) Pours a dep chocolate brown with a lot of carbonation causing the creamy head to fizz and dissapate quickly. The nose is smooth with coffee & a little chocolate. Carbonation makes it a bit sharp, but after letting it warm in my hand for 5 minutes, it mellows out & subtle notes of coffee are most prominent, with a touch of chocolate. with a slight bitter finish. Good beer, but still a bit too carbonated.

Pours a dark brown with a medium, creamy light brown head.  Pretty roasty aroma, with a good dose of chocolate and nuttiness to it.  The flavor has a big coffee character, backed by some roasted malts, and dark chocolate.  Wow, this is tasty.  Seems really well balanced and quite flavorful.  The coffee smooths out in the finish making way for the chocolate and roast to take the stage.  Awesome porter.
Pours Black. Not much head, but what there is , is tan .First taste is smooth for a dark beer . after taste has a nice chocolate., coffee finish that could be a little stonger .

Brown bottle, 12 ounces, nice gift from Boutip (please, keep presents like this coming), best before 09/11/07, savoured on September 4 2007; eye: black, opaque, nice creamy café au lait head, good lacing; nose: nice roasted malt, vanilla, dark chocolate, cocoa, lactic; mouth: creamy, nice roasted malt with an enjoyable acridness, light vanilla, a bit lactic, dark chocolate, bitterness appears towards the end but, to me, seems way below the 60 IBU presented in the description above, finale in roasted malt with the acridness being not as enjoyable, slightly sweet, mildly bitter, full body, slightly oily texture, a bit thin, a bit harsh; overall: really good and an extra point for the enjoyment provided by listening to Gordon Lightfoot singing The Wreck of the Edmund Fitzgerald

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 12 onces, cadeau de Philippe Boutin (continue à mamener de si bons présents!), meilleure avant 09/11/07, savourée le 4 septembre 2007; il : noire, opaque, belle mousse crémeuse café au lait, bonne dentelle; nez : beau malt torréfié, vanille, chocolat foncée, cacao, lactique; bouche : crémeuse, beau malt torréfié avec une pointe âcre agréable, légère vanille, un peu lactique, chocolat noir, amertume apparaît à la toute fin mais me semble plus faible que les 60 IBU annoncés sur RateBeer, finale en malt torréfie avec une pointe âcre un peu moins plaisante, très légèrement sucrée, moyennement amère, corsée, texture légèrement huileuse, un peu mince, légèrement râpeuse; en résumé : très bonne, et un point de plus pour lavoir déguster en écoutant Gordon Lightfoot interprété The wreck of the Edmund Fitzgerald

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2008 bottle. pours black with a lively tan head.  aroma of barley and sweet cocoa.  the first sip is quite thick and rich.  clean malts, excellent bitter sweet chocolate and undertones of espresso. finishes with a brief splash of water which helps  keep the palate fresh. nice moderate carbonation with tight crisp bubbles.  the palate became thinner toward the bottom of the glass.  re-rate: tasted much more tart hops this time around.  dropped down impression. this is on par with the rogue mocha.  id like to taste the two side by side.

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2010 Thanks to Secret Santa crizay for this one!  It has been quite a few years since I have had this one, and it was happily just as good as I remembered.  Pours black, decent head.  Enticing aroma of bitter chocolate and coffee.  Flavor is a fantastic blend of coffee, bitter dark chocolates, and espresso bitterness on the finish.  Rich and satisfying, a highly enjoyable beer.  Rerate from draft at Cleveland Airports Great Lakes brewpub.  Just like I remembered, no change in score.  A great beer.

Good porter but not as great as some people think.....at least i didnt think so. Lots of chocolate there, but still seems somewhat light on the ol palllllet. I did get some nice hop bitterness out back, which was nice. Not one of my fav porters, probably good cause i cant get it around here!

350 ml bottle mailorder form Archerliquor.  Dark brown with a ruby tint and a fizzy tan head.  Sweet chocolate and cherry aroma.  Creamy palate.  Milk chocolate and oatmeal taste with some roasty notes.
Pours dark brown with a lightly tan, moderate head. Aroma is mildly chocolatey. Moderate mouth feel. Flavors of vanilla, coffee, chocolate, and some hop bitterness.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2008 12 oz bottle courtesy of Miketd!  Thanks!  Very sessionable beer!  Only thing this beer lacks is strength!  pours black with a bittersweet chocolate aroma. nice hear and great lacing. coffee, roasted malts, and chocolate for flavors. has definate a chocolate aftertaste

12oz. bottle from sams chicago. good looking chocolate ruby color. moderate tan head. fantastic full aroma of bitter chocolate and robust malt. excelent chocolatey flavor with plenty of robust coffee and bitter flavors. light fruity cherry flavor appears just before the dry finish. a terrific example of one of my favorite styles.
12oz at local pub.great malty and chocolate aroma.notes of chocolate and citrus.one of the best porters ive had.

Wonderful, complex aroma with a distinct chocolate flavor.  Not a whole lot of body despite the fact that it starts off with a strong chocolate taste and finishes roasted and mildly of coffee.  Not the biggest fan of Porters, but this one is quite drinkable.
it is indeed complex with some roasted malts and dark chocolate and a great finish, but i wouldve liked it a little stronger more
Poured black with nice size tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, and some fruit. Big flavor of coffee followed by some chocolate and fruit. A real roastyness finish.

Bottle from Capones - thanks for making all those long trips Matt!  Havent had this one since before I started rating so I decided to try along with my favorite porter - GLI Chocolate Thunder.  This guy has a nice dark brown body with a med-large beige head.  Aroma has a nice roasty malt essence with bits of nut, coffee, and chocolate poking through.  Flavor is pleasantly complex with roasty malt and chocolate upfront, a nice hop finish towards the end with coffee throughout.  Just a solid, tasty porter that I can drink lots of.  As for the Chocolate Thunder?  Still my top pick, but EF is the perfect porter for pre-meal and during the meal, while CT is a fantastic dessert.  Thank god I can get such great porters in PA!
UPDATED: OCT 21, 2007 I enjoy this beer, but not in the summer.  A little bit of a light body for a porter but has all the same tasty goodness of a heavier beer.

Bottle courtesy of my friend Alan. Last of the set. He picked up some Great Lakes stuff while on vacation in Pennsylvania. He had some other but the last three I havent rated before. Near black pour to me, but the lightning in his basement isnt exceptional. Small tan head. Nose is roasted malts, coffee, and dark chocolate. Light hops too. The least "attractive" of the beers we had but only because of the extreme heat. Taste is more roasted malts, cold coffee, hops and bittersweet chocolate. Palate is moderately tingly and not too heavy, for a porter.  Finishes with more roasty malts, coffee and chocolate. A by-the-numbers porter but delicious nonetheless. Would be a fine session beer in, say, November.

Bottle.  Poured a dark brown color with a medium light-brown head.  Strong lacing.  Aroma is very coffee-like with hints of roasted malt and chocolate.  Mouthfeel is nice.  Flavor is heavy in coffee, with a chocolate finish to it.  A very nice porter.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2009 Clear dark mahogany with good, creamy and fizzy head / Nose of tobacco, coffee, and root beer / Medium body, effervescent and creamy, with good balance of roast malts and hops on the fine, dry finish / Deep roast flavors of dark roast coffee, tobacco, and unsweetened chocolate / Lighter, easy drinking, but with excellent, complex flavors.

One of the best porters Ive had by a long shot. Black (why should I come up with a clever adjective? Thats what it is), with a decent brownish head. Mild body. Roasted coffee and some herbal hops. Quite. fairly bitter in the finish. No nonsense, just great beer.
Black in colour with minimal head and lacing.    Smells of coffee and chocolate, malty.  Tastes smooth and matly.  Very full tasting and very nice.

Bottle-Transported to Florida via Chicago.  Pours a solid black color with a small head that leaves a minimum amount of lacing.  The aroma knocks you back with roasted coffee and chocolate.  The taste has a nice full amount of chocolate and caramel, slightly roasted.   Overall, the beer has a nice chewy feel throughout the drink.  Fine, fine stuff.

Dark dark brown, darker than many stouts, with a thin tan head.  A creamy, slightly roasty, slightly mocha nose.  Rather sweet, with perhaps a spot of coconut.  Low cabonation, though smooth and creamy.  Quenching still, just right for a porter (even if this is more of a light stout).  A sweet round porter, that parallels many sweet stouts.  Lightly roasty coffee and caramel malt.  A bit chocolate.  Round, slightly dry finish with linger roast.  Not freaking bad, worth a rebuy.

Thanks to dpjuart for the bottle of this. Light smoky aroma, kind of a hint of meaty broth and light metallic tang. Chocolate malted milk with bitter coffee and toasted-burnt grain. Tootsie Rolls and light bitter hops. Dark brown-red clear, with cocoa colored foamy lacing head. Medium-heavy body, with medium carbonation. Starts with nice chocolate malted sweetness, bitter coffee and a hint of burnt grain. Good sweetness to it. Soft maltiness leads into a very mild bitter burnt nutty finish, while maintaining some sweetness. Light metallic broth flavor, however. After is rather dry with a bit of smokiness to it.

An excellent beer withall the qualities a beer should have. Words cannot describe beer made like this one.
If you want an accurate review of this beer, buy some. You wont be sorry.

12 oz. bottle from MrBendo.  Pour is a very deep brown with ruby highlights.  A really nice looking rocky khaki head tops the beer.  Aroma is pretty faint with roasted malt and a hint of hoppiness.  Taste is mostly the roastiness with a nice sharp bitterness to the finish.  Some lactic sweetness in there as well.  Nice Porter.  Thanks Todd.

Nice malty, coffee, chocolate aroma.  Very aromatic. Poured a nice brown.
Nice tan-brown foamy head, that quickly receded into a foamy thin cap, left nice lacing. A very nice malty, chocolate, coffee flavor that starts out medium sweet then changes into a plesantly medium burnt bitter taste with hints of dark chocolate. Neither is overpowering, but pleasant and strong enough to make you want more.  A really nice balance. Full Bodied, thick creamy texture, medium soft carbonation,  a plesant medium bitter smoky finish.  I enjoyed this Porter quite a bit. Will definitely buy again. :)
Great job by Great Lakes!

Mothers milk? No but close enough for a hot July day. 

Great Lakes Edmund Fitzgerald Porter is really much better chilled colder than the 55 degrees the brewer recommends. The aroma escapes and wreaks havoc the moment the bottle is opened. You either drink it or you know youll be sorry.

This is a full-bodied brew splashed upon the palate, smooth on the descent and it doesnt leave a lot of bad memories for your tongue to argue with afterwards. The bottle says bittersweet coffee-chocolate but theres no suspicion you are sipping a latte hybrid. Its beer, good and wholesome and far better than what we expected from this brewery. 

...

Pours a cola like brown color with a thinning khaki head. Aroma is chocolate and coffee.Flavor is rich.Chocolate and coffee with very minimal bitterness.Nothing too complicated here.Finish had some chocolate aftertones.

Bottle.  Poured a rich dark chestnut color with a light tan head.  Great chocolate and light coffee aromas with a small bit of hazelnut also.  Sweet and roasty notes on the taste, neither being real strong, but the flavor is great because of the balance.  The roastiness picks up on the finish nicely.  A tasty porter.
@ GLBC Beer School, This one was alot better than i remember the first time, tons of roasty coffe chocolate flavors, which finishes nicely, this is good.stuff.

Poured a solid borwn in color that did allow some light to seep through. However, the light was very thin and weak. Slight tan head that receded to a thinner film. Nose is malty with some bits of smokey wood rising out of its depths. Flavor is quite nice. Not overly done with the smokiness but just the right amount that it holds up well without wearing out the tastebuds. Little bits of licorice candy as well. Heavy peated malts too. Medium mouthfeel that thickens as it warms. Too bad I only have one bottle of this beer.
POurs a beutiful black/brown with notes of coffee and toast malt.  The flavors drive the palate and you get a depth of cocoa and choco;ate.  The beer drinks quite smooth.

Who would have thought that such outstanding beer could be produced and bottled in Cleveland?  
Everything you want in a bottled porter, taste, aroma, finish.
The only one Ive ever tried that tops this a Samuel Smith Taddy Porter.

Pretty damn morbid name for a beer.

But I have to recommend this heartily.
A very good porter, it has very good malt character of roasted, burnt and nutty malts which leaves a smokey finish.  There is a bitter finish from the hops with a slight metallic finish.

[384-20070630] Tap @ Great Lakes (Cleveland, OH). Malted roast aroma mixed with chocolate hints. Dark dark brown body with a medium-lasting foamy tan head. Very coffee-like flavour, malt roast. Full body seems thinned. Expected it to be thicker but good as it is.

This outstanding porter pours deep black, blessing your nose with a mingling of semisweet chocolate notes offset by grains. The palate is unsweetened chocolate frolicing with with light oat notes and a pleasing coffee accented hops and just the right level of alcohol warming. One of the best porters Ive gotten my hands on in a while.
UPDATED: JUL 4, 2007 This porter is different in that it is really hoppy for the style. I like it that way.

12 oz. Bottle at the Coney (6/3/07, June Beer of the Month).  Pours dark brown/black with a small, thick head, chocolate color.  Roasted aroma, hint of coffee.  Tastes of roasted malt with a predominant hint of chocholate and coffee.  Pretty damn good.
12oz bottle.  Chocolate brown pour with small head, smells of well-roasted coffee.  Minimal lacing, average carbonation.  Very tasty, following the chocolate and coffee hints early.  Good porter.

(Bottle) Pours a brown color with tan head. Aroma of cocoa and expresso. Taste is very similar, with a nice full palate. Remarkably smooth tasting. Expected a little more alcohol in this one, but a good session beer.
UPDATED: OCT 14, 2007 Bottle , gift from Stegosaurus. Thank you little brother this Porter Kick ASS !!! Nice roast and chocolate flavor and very very smooth !!! I loved it.

Bottle, thanks to adrian910ss, pours a coke brown with a thin dark tan head that quickly drifts to a thin covering, minimal lacing.  Nice aroma of coffee and chocolate.  Taste follows aroma very well, with a slight hoppy presence to balance the malts.  Palate is medium carbonation and mouthfeel.  This is one nice porter, and definitely one to keep on regular rotation.

12 ounce bottle.  Best before 8/26/07
Pours dark brown with a medium brown stiff foamy head.  The aroma is huge with coffee with creamer and chocolate.  The flavor is full of coffee and choclate with big time bitterness.  Creamy mouthfeel.  A wonderful beer.

Aroma is mostly roasty chocolate malt with a little tart hops. Pours almost black with a tan head and a reddish hue. Flavor is dominated by the chocolate mocha coffee thing going on here, but there is a balancing hop presence that manifests itself in a medium dry citrus on the backend. Smooth, tasty, and very enjoyable.
UPDATED: MAY 20, 2008 Very bitter roasted malt / chocolately flavor.    Smooth sweetness, and great drinkability.  This is one of the better porters Ive ever had.

Very dark with some red highlights and a mice foamy head.  Strong roasted flavor comes right at you and this one could pass for a stout.  Lots of flavor here, especially for a porter.  Coffee and dark chocolate also are major players in the flavor and the hops make a late appearance. As well as adding tartness the hops provide a surprising amount of bitterness.   In the mouth this beer shines.  It is rich and creamy and feels great.  This is no "wall flower porter" but is robust and full of life.  How can a porter be any better?

Bottle.  Deep dark black in color with a nice off white head. Caramel malty aroma. Chocolatety notes. Malty and roasty flavor. Caramel chocolatey notes. Sweet tasting.  Finish is malty. Full bodied. Rich and smooth. Very drinkable. Ncie beer.
One of my favorites.  Black appearance with a tremendous flavor of roasted malts and a slight carmel sweetness with so much depth

Im a fan of porters-- especially ones that lean to the brown ale, not the stout, in flavor.  This is an excellent example of a porter and I highly recommend it.  It seems to hold up well on draft or in the bottle, since it doesnt have a big hop profile that will fade out over time.

This has been a favorite of mine for quite some time but I have neglected to rate it for some reason. Drank from a bottle pucrhased as a six-pack at International Beverage in Kentwood. 

Pours a dark brown with a nice large foamy head. Smells of chocolate and coffee and makes my mouth water. Taste is similar to the smell but fuller with lots of malt and some hops presence. Although it is strong and a bold beer, the finish is smooth and I could drink a couple of these in a session. 

Probably my favorite porter-even though I may be biased based on its brewery location.

Pours dark brown with a perfect three-finger head. Tantalizing aroma of chocolate and a touch of citrus. Best aroma from any porter Ive tried. Fair amount of flavor, with a medium-to-light body and carbonation. My favorite porter to date.

On tap into pint glass, Clark Street Ale House (Chicago).  Never got around to rating this staple of the midwest beer scene.  Pillowy cookie dough head over a ruby tinged black beer.  At first sip, you know that this is a porter closer to the Baltic side of the spectrum than the English.  Feels like a cold slab of fizzy chocolatey flavor that saves most of its punch for the finish, which is very dry chocolate, wet coffee bitter that is crisp (not a warm immersive bitterness, but rather an aloof standoffish bitter).  The finish eventually fades into lactic sweetness.  Roasty aromas with some toasted malts.  Very well defined, a pleasure to drink.

12-oz. Thanks, SecretSanta! Pours a deep grainy black with occasional amber highlights. Very scant head of off-white film; what there is isnt there long. Roasty, ashy nose. Bold attack with plenty of flavor; medium body and carb. The mid-palate has nice densely packed flavors of chocolate and roast. Exceedingly mild finish. Awesome, rock-solid session beer, though it packs a bit more wallop than the perfect session beer might. A small quibble, though, since its well-hidden, and its up to me not to drink too many of these if I get going on em. :-)

Rated 5/20/06:  Fantastic porter, robust and full absolutely awesome. Pours a thick sticky black with a creamy tan head that lasts. The aroma is filled with dark malts and just a touch of floral hops, it is rather mild especially compared to the flavor. Once you dig into this robust porter the flavor immediately grabs you. Malts o plenty round out the dominant flavor consisting of coffee, chocolate, and plenty of roasted malts. The floral hops become slightly more hidden beneath the intense flavor. Mouthfeel is filling and creamy. One of my favorite local brews that satisfies on tap as well as poured into a glass straight from the bottle. In my opinion this is one of Great Lakes Brewing Cos masterpieces.

Served with a nice head that settled down to a light cover. Lots of lace. More flavor hops than Im personally prefer. Technically superb.  Very dark garnet color. A little boozy. A little too fruity. Still, a very good beer. Sometimes available on draft too at Bodega Brew PUb downtown La Crosse, Wisconsin. USA
sample cup at Chicago Green Fest. Beautiful color. Smooth. Bitter finish.  It could have been smoother and more balanced.  Thier doremunster was great!

Bottle courtesy of Ross Laughter (its pronounced "Lotter" so he says).  Pours dark with a small tan head. Nice lace.  Flavor is heavy on chocolate with roasted malt and coffee undertones. Can really taste the dark chocolate in the finish.  Another great brew from a very solid brewery. Thanks Ross!

Pours with a nice head.  Some chocolate and roastiness in aroma.  Taste is much the same with some coffee and caramel and nuttiness.  Overall it was pretty good, but didnt do much to seperate itself from other good porters.

Bottle: Attractive head with great lacing.  Very sweet chocoalte and cooking spices in the aroma.  Some yeastyness and chocolate bittereness noted as well.  In the mouth this beer starts out mildly chocolately and just builds up from there.  A very nice bitter finish for the style.  Very drinkable and tasty, if uncomplicated.  Only major complaint is that the mouthfeel was a little too crisp for the style.

Poured a dark brown / red color with a medium sized, tan head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of roasted malts, bakers chocolate, light smoke, and a bit of caramel malt.  Taste was sweet chocolate, more caramel, fudge, roasted malts, and some nuts, but really reminded me of a tootsie roll.

a color as dark as night with a white cumulus head.  roasted coffee beans dominates this beer along with bittersweet chocolate and smoke.  i felt the coffee aroma and flavor was alittle too heavy and therefore imbalanced the beer, otherwise good.

This was a pretty good porter for being a regional brewery.  I am a big fan of the Edmund Fitzgerald, this porter was actually really good, will have it again however, not at the local Steakhouse which charges the price of a six pack for 1!
Pours a dark brown with a foamy chocolately head. Smells of coffee with a hint of hops. Taste is somewhat lacking due to bittersweet taste and minimal hops.

Bottle courtesy of Grbdg (thanks!).  Pours your standard black with sizeable tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, coffee, and nuts...very enticing, though for some reason it didnt stick around all that long; it mellowed out quite a bit.  Roasty flavor including chocolate and coffee.  Finishes with a bitter coffee flavor.  The mouthfeel is rather watery though, which was disappointing.  Still, a pretty good porter and I wish it were more available to me.
Bottle sampled. Pours dark with a tan head. Aroma of roasted chocolate malts, hops, nuts, and sweetness. The flavor is sweet chocolate with some roast and nuts, and finishes with a hoppy bitterness.

Great beer. Should be called great beer brewing company. But I doubt that will happen. I know I live close to this brewery just don;t know where it is. Would love to visit. So far all the brews Ive tried have been satisfactory.
Pours very dark with a light tan head that does not disapate quickly.  Smells of a slight hint of chocolate but cannot smell the coffee.  This is really quite smooth and not half bad for a porter

Aroma of roasted nutty malt, coffee, and chocolate.  Pour is black with tan head.  Flavors of coffee, roasted malt, vanilla, bitter-sweet chocolate, and hops.  The only bad part about this brew is that it seems to have a rather watery weak body, but it has a great flavor.

lots of chocolate with some roasted malt and coffee flavor.  the flavor and mouthfeel were both smooth, rounded out by hints of vanilla extract and lots o malt.  yum.  note of warning though:  dont use this beer to play beer pong.  its only good in theory.

12 oz bottle my friend Lizs mom drove from ohio to cali.  thanks to both of you.  Pours black with a big 2 and a half finger fluffy tan head that is slowly fading.  Aroma is roasty and malty with hints of choco coffee.  The taste is robust and mellow and it is very nice and drinkable.    Good every day porter, little thinner than Id like but good.

12oz bottle.  Pours black with just a trace of translucence and a small, light brown head.  Aroma is sweet, malty, and significant chocolate.  Appetizing smell.  Taste is wonderful chocolate.  Smooth, malty, and balanced.  One of the best porters Ive had.

Draft @ Capones.  Pours a deep, dark brown with a 1+ finger tan head.  Aroma is sweet - roasted malts, chocolate and dark fruits (prunes?)  Flavor is strong on the roasted malts, bitter-sweet chocolate, dark fruits (prunes?) and some hops sneeking in.  Quite tasty and wonderfully easy to drink!

Pours inky black with a tan head.  This beer is rife with coffee flavors and a good dose of chocolate too.  Terrific carbonation and a great finish.  Ive had it a million times, and I keep going back for more, this is one of my favorite beers on the planet.

Winking Lizard Tour 2007
UPDATED: JUN 19, 2007 One of the best ever! Nice strong session porter thats dry and aciditic.  Good chocolate notes.  Good black and dirty white appearance too.  I dont know what else to say.

Draft; a really excellent porter.  Aroma and color were sport on; body was thick and creamy.  A good flavor accented by some vanilla and hops, with the normal chocolate and roasted flavor.  Some oakish elements detected.
Draft.  Good head and palate.  Nice porter with good roasted / chocolate flavor, also balanced by oaky undertones.

chocolate, roasty, coffee, smoke, black, tan foam, hazy, medium sweetness, very bitter, full body, thick feel, average carbonation, bitter, A very deep and dark porter, not as good as Fullers London porter but nonetheless a beer worth its value.
Bottle. Dark brown with fizzy head. The taste was caramel, earth and some coffee. Fizzy medium carbonation with light bitter dry finish. Just ok nothing to jump up and down about.

Deep mahogany brown body with a modest, oily beige head.  Nice lush chocolate and debittered malt aromas, with caramel and dark bread crust notes.  Flavor has abundant chocolate and caramel that lingers with tobacco.  Medium sweet and lightly bitter. Very pleasant fireside session beer. Standard-setting porter, along with Anchor Porter.

Black, thick creamy tan head, typical porter look and smell. Chocolate and light roasty bitterness and root beer and very mild acidity. More robust and roasty than, say, Anchor Porter. Well crafted and worth trying.

12oz. Bottle 
Enjoy before 12/16/06

Edmund Fitzgerald poured black. When held to the light there was dark mahogany highlights around the glass and where the light was coming through. Very nice light brown microbubble 1+ finger head with some medium bubbles throughout. Big chunky lacing as I drink.

This beer smells amazing. A lot of toffee and freshly ground coffee beans. Absolutely delicious smelling!

The taste is very good as well. Tastes like it smells with toffee up front. A little coffee coming through and some roasted/burnt malt. It seems Im tasting a little nuttiness at the end.

The mouthfeel is perfect for this beer. Its medium-heavy bodied. A little chewy and coats the mouth nicely.

The drinkability is as good as you can get for a porter. This is toward the top of the list as far as porters are concerned.

Sampled 10/1/06
Lots of roasted malt flavor, and aroma. More hops than many porters. Body on the thin side.
Love it! A well balanced porter that will carry you the whole night through.  Malty with a nice roasted taste. very smooth after taste.  If only I could get some in North Carolina!

Roasted malt,chocolate and some slight coffee in the aroma.Pours a very dark brown with a medium tan head.The roasted malt and chocolate stand out in the flavor.Medium to full mouthfeel with a smooth chocolate finish.
UPDATED: OCT 19, 2007 Very god porter. For an all year round brew by great lakes this is one of the best. Surprisingly thick. Great chocolate and coffee notes.

on Draft...This is a great porter,and I am a Huge Porter Fan.... It is not a sweet porter, but rather a big, somewhat dry porter. It exhibits coffee and dark chocolate aromas white a nice roasted flavor. It has a wonderful head and a dark, almost black body and smOOth as silk.... Love it!!
UPDATED: OCT 8, 2007 An outstanding beer, search out, it will not be let you down. Page 195 of Michael Jacksons Great Beer Guide only 377 out 500 of his Classic Brews to go.
On tap at the Blue Moon in Madison, WI.  Stoutly carbonated, a bit of sting, creamy & smooth.  Nice chocolate roasty character.  Full head, good retention, some lacing.

Bottle. This  porter is a load. It pours very dark, essentially black. Strong aroams of dark chocolate. Flavors dominated by raosted malt, with a coffeelike bitterness, in addition some falvors of dark chocolate. Extremely full bodied.

bottle from brandon: pours a nice dark black with ruby tints. aroma of raosted coffee and chocolate over sweet malts. flavour of sark roasted coffee and some chocolate. finishes bitter and dry almost bready taste too. excellent porter
12 oz. bottle.  Yep, nearly perfect in every way.  Roasty, chocolate and coffee blended for the gods.  And they are happy!!

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2015 Bottle:  A Nearly perfect example of an American Porter in every way.  Great flavor with well balanced mocha and malt.  Exellent slightly bitter finish.  Medium body for great mouthfeel.  One of the greats.

Glad to see Trader Joes actually expanding their brews section and when I saw this, I thought it would be a great cold night for it.  I chilled the bottle in the snow on my back porch, and it was quickly ready to drink.  Pours a black brown with a little beige head.  As it warms back up to the warmer temperatures of the indoors some nice mocha, coffee, chocolate, and very fresh malty aromas come off.  Lots of chocolate, malt, and coffee roast, with a nice raw coffee bean flavor.  Lightly bitter, medium bodied, balanced well.  I remembered really liking this when I had it years ago, and I was surprised how well it lived up to my expectations.  Great beer.
Black in color with small white head. Nice rich roasted malt aroma and flavor with light chocolate coffee flavor. Very smooth, goes down nicely

A very nice Porter.  Quite dark and almost stout-like.  A bit bitter, but very nice.  A little bit of coffee-like, smoky flavor.  I did not pour it out, but I see a nice creamy heaqd inside the bottle.

A winner and of very high quality.

from 12 oz bottl, purchased at trader joes.  Pours black.  Not much light gets through.  Almost 1/2 in. head that turns to thin film.  Nice lacing.  Pleasant roasty aroma.  Nice dark roast coffee flavor.  Not much sweetness.  Good hop bitterness, but not out of balance.  Very good middle flavor and aftertaste that leaves me wanting another.
Pours a thick black with little head.  Has a nice but faint roasted coffee aroma.  It kicks it up a notch in the flavor department.  A very rich roasted taste with a sweet lasting finish.

On tap at the brewery. The pour reveals a clear dark brown color with brown highlights and a thin light brown head. Good and appealing aroma of chocolate and smoked malt. The flavor has the same chocolate and smoked malt, with a bitter finish, but feels more mild and ordinary that the aroma. The body is light with gentle carbonation.

30 years ago the SS Edmund Fitzgerald sank in Lake Superior. The beer, Edmund Fitzgeralf from Great Lakes Brewery certainly does not sing, it rides high in the water.

Pouring a dark brown with a chocolate delicious flavor., this is an outstanding porter. Malt and hops flavor both very noticeable.. Nicely carbonated leaving a very satisfying finish

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2007 Thanks to RagallachMC for the bottle. Pours an opaque brown with a small head. Aroma of roasted grains and chocolate malts. Taste adds spicy perfume hops to the mix. Medium to heavy body. Thick and creamy texture. Medium sweet and lightly bitter. Delicious..

Pours a dark brown with caramel head with a coffee and molasses aroma.  This beer taste like a carbonated cappachino.  The coffee flavor is strong with a hint of chocolate. Finishes with a dry hoppiness.  If you like coffee flavored beverages,  this might be your favorite beer.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2007 this beer has a nice light brown frothy head on it when you pour it in your glass that absolutely looks delicious. The coffee in this is not to strong and then there is some hints of molasses and caramel. It has a fairly strong bitter flavor to it. This is a good beer but nothing I will run out to get again

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2007 What a beautiful beer. Dark brown with a nice light tan head. A real smooth flavor. A great mix of coffee beans, roasted malts and chocolate. Hints of smoke and ash. A nice hop bite in the finish. What a wonderful beer and a awesome brewery.

Pours a deep brown with just a bit of reddish tones coming through. About an inch of tan head. I catch a faint smell of chocolate, very faint. A bit of lace stays behind.

Oh my - what a flavorful beer. Lots of complexity, nothing harsh or overbearing. Coffee, chocolate, roasted malt, with residual toffe-like sweetness. Toss in some mild nuttiness. A hop bitterness balances nicely. Slightly sweet and slightly bitter and slightly roasted in the aftertaste. Smooth body, perfect soft carbonation.

Best thing to come out of Ohio since Chrissie Hynde.

Bottle.  Aroma light cocoa,roasted malts and coffee.  Poured a deep dark brown almost black. Flavor is strong coffee with light chocolate in the background the hops give it a nice bite but dont over power the maltiness.  Palate is medium bodied and creamy.  Like this I do,very much.  Perhaps they could export to eastern PA.  Thanks to whomever sent this to me in trade sorry I keep bad records, guess I need to drink faster.

12 oz bottle.  As described, deep dark pour, tan head that takes its time disappearing.  I like this porter so much I bought it retail price because I had a hard day at work and needed a solid beer I could enjoy.  If you get a chance, try this beer.  Smooth and totally enjoyable.

pours like silk with a thin, modest yet lasting cream-colored head with lots of spritzy-ness...  deep plumb color in front of a natural light emitting lightbulb...with a nose to match .. notes of chocolate covered cherries and plums... bit of coffee...  reminds me of an english styled ale with elderberries ... kinda toasty and nicely hoppy.

This beer is great - better than the Blackout Stout.  Appearance is dark with very abundant tan head (over-ran the rim of the glass).  Aroma is very rich coffee.  Taste is more coffee along with a burned malt taste which is truly excelllent.  Mouthfeel is full, with flavors lingering mid-point on the tongue.  This beer is highly drinkable and very good all-the-way-around.

Tap.   Pours a dark brown color with a smallish tan colored head.   Aroma is toast, malt, some coffee.   Flavor is sweet, roasted malt, touch of chocolate and coffee.   Palate is medium, medium carbonation, smooth, bitter finish.   Paired exceptionally well with the smoked BBQ beef brisket I was having.

Ive been looking forward to tasting this again because I think the last time I tasted it I was influenced by the ambient surroundings.  You know how that is, a beer can taste good just because you are enjoying yourself. I remember the last time I drank this, we successfully started a sportster that had sat in the garage for a decade and a half, it only took three kicks! This is a 12 oz brown bottle.  Upon opening, cannot detect much aroma.  Pours pretty dark in my poor steeler stein, but still not much aroma.  Wait, I think I detect a roasty aroma hint with yeast.  Has an alabaster head that rapidly goes away to leave a ring of small bubbles around the top of the liquid.  During the commencement of taste I sense roasty bitter malt.  The bitterness does not hang on like many stouts, but you can definitely tell its there.  GL is one of the few companies that state the perfect temperature for serving right on the label.  Yes, this is a porter but I think I have tasted better.  This is better than SA holiday, yards gen washington and JW dundees porter but it is not within the reach of yuenglings black and tan or michs new porter.  Finish is a bit bitter and it lasts and lingers for a while.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottle. Earthy malt and yeast aroma.  Dark reddish brown with a fine frothy head of good duration.  Flavor is lightly bitter with a slight metallic tinge initially.  Good smooth finish.  Hints of chocolate, coffee, some citrus hops.  Well carbonated.  Slightly thin mouthfeel.  A good medium porter.

Bottle, poured dark with ruby red, off-white bubbles that swam around for a while, nice lacing on the glass, fragrances of roasted and sweet malt, hint of chocolate, vanilla and/or candy sweetness, nice roasted malt flavor, touch of chocolate and coffee on the tongue, some hop bite in the mouth and a dry after taste.
UPDATED: MAR 7, 2007 had on tap at gios pub.  notes of coffee and chocolate.  very solid beer, highly recomended.

Solid dry porter from pour to finish. Average fizzy light brown head. Dark brown, flat body. Roasted malts with some coffee and chocolate notes dominate the nose. Lightly sweet flavor with bitter finish. Notes of caramel and earthiness. Very dry. Medium body with average to lively carbonation. The major disappointment is its watery texture and a slightly metallic edge in the flavor.

Pours black with a thick tan head that dissipates fairly quickly leaving some good lacing.  Aroma is very hoppy for a porter with roasty malts coming through as well.  First tastes are very roasty and chocolatey but gets increasingly hoppy as you progress.  Very good beer.

This beer is very dark colored with a large tan head that slowly dissipates and leaves a good amount of lacing. Aroma is coffee and chocolate with a slight butterscotch undertone. Flavor has medium sweetness, very bitter and lightly finish. Medium body, oily feel average carbonation.

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2007 12oz bottle- An almost black body with a nice tan head and has an aroma of dark malts, coffee, and chocolate. Taste of coffee, chocolate, and malt with a slight hop flavor. A little bit watery for a porter but overall a nice tasting porter.

Bottled. BB 01/07. Beer is very dark red-brown, almost opaque. The head is average, frothy, light brown, rapidly diminishing head.

Malty with moderate notes of roasted grain, chocolate, coffee, light note of molasses; Hoppy with moderate note of resin; Yeasty with traces of dough, sharp cheddar and basement; Miscellaney include a moderate note of current, light note of smoke.

The flavor is moderately-to-heavily bitter, moderately sweet, lightly acidic with a longish, lighty sweet, lightly-to-moderately bitter, lightly acidic finish.

The body is light, the texture is watery and the carbonation lively.

Good, but kind of grippy and thin.

From a 12oz Bottle, Expired November 1, 2006.  Pours a dark, roasty cedar brown color with fleeting glimpses of a ruby sheen.  The aroma is a pleasant balance between chocolate and dark fruits.  A rich, dark belgian chocolate base is softened by some juicy prune and sticky raisins.  Medium bodied, lightly carbonated mouthfeel.  The flavors are much drier than the aroma suggests, and the body may be a touch thinned by age.  Dark, dry chocolate flavors with a bit of smoked ash coming through on the back end.  More chocolate and a smidgen of prune linger in the final smack with a gentle kiss of minty hops.  Thanks, Tom!

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2009 12 oz bottle courtesy of crizay, thanks. The pour is black with nice brown head. The head left a partial sheet of lacing behind and small islands of foam. The aroma is above average in strength initially and has competing notes of coffee, sweet molasses and chocolate. The taste starts off with a somewhat creamy mouth feel. It has a rich roasty and sweet malt flavor. Slightly tart burnt malt hits almost midway and stays to the finish. I get some chocolate here too. Very nice Porter with a varied malt profile to keep things interesting. The aftertaste is a pleasing chocolate and burnt malt that lingers.

Leaves the bottle a somewhat translucent brown/black color. Shows some ruby red highlights when held to the light. Pour creates a faily tight, 1/2" tan head which disappointingly fades quickly to a thin web-like wisp. Pleasant, but quite restrained aromas of bakers chocolate, roasted malt, caramel, dried dark fruit and coffee beans. Found the palate to be leaning toward the thin side; just a tad watery. Flavor shows off a bit more intensity than the aroma did with semi-sweet rich notes of dark chocolate, French roast coffee, roasted malts and burnt caramel candy. Some faint hop flavors sneak in to invoke some slight bitterness to tame the sweetness. Overall a bit tame but very well balanced. For an everyday porter Anchor would still be my call.

Bottle courtesy of Ohio Dad & best by 7 Oct 06. Poured black in color with a thin tan head. Sweet aromas of milk chocolate and caramel. The flavor was of chocolate and coffee with some grass and bread as it warmed slightly. Medium to full body with a creamy texture. Slightly bitter upfront with a coffee aftertaste.
Tasted much more of the coffee flavor than the choclate. Had a lingering bitter taste after each drink. One of the better Great Lakes beers.
almost black, nutty/malty aroma, wonderfully smooth palate, and excellent dark chocalate/caramel/coffee finish, a great beer from a brewery that consistently puts out awesome beers
UPDATED: DEC 4, 2006 Dark brown with a large head. Malty aroma with chocolate and nuts. Strong smooth taste. Roasted and dry, very good smooth beer. Great aftertaste.

Thanks to my neighbor Jamie for this treat. Dark brown with a brown foamy head. Fabulous solid aroma of malty chocolate with notes of nutty maltness. Very sweet aroma. Inviting. Starts a bit watery but quickly yeilds a delicious bitter bite of coffee chocolate. Roasted, dry palate with a bitter dry aftertaste.

A good overall porter. Nothing to write home about, yet nothing to keep from your parents either. Dark and rich with roasted malt flavor that borders on caramel. The head was small but lasting. You drink this while rocking in a rocking chair.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: One of my favorite beers.  Its only deficiency could be in the aroma category (unoffensive, but not outstanding).  It has a lovely dark color with a rich brown head that is retained surprisingly well.  The flavor is deep and rich, dominated by roasted notes but having a crisp hop finish.  The flavor lingers on the tongue, which is entirely welcome for a beer of this caliber.  Almost more of a stout than a porter, but an amazing beer.

12oz bottle from Premier Gourmet. Pours a pitch black with a 3/4 inch thick tan head. The smell is sweet and heavily malty. It almost smells like Cracker-Jacks. The taste is dark and rich with heavy waves of carmel. The is almost no bitterness. Nice palate too, smooth and not too thick, very easy to drink.

Deep carmel molasses aroma.  Dark red molasses in color with a small tan head that disappears quickly.  Low frothy, but not flat on the palate.  A pleasant drinking porter with a nice Carmel flavor.  The label reports this beer is made from only water, yeast, barley, and hops. It is nice to know that you can drink something that is good for you.  They should put this on the national heath care plan.
Clear brown brew with a nice matly chocolate profile here. I like their brews and this was no exception. Some chocolate cake and some smoke also. Just thin on the tongue

12 oz bottle.  Best by 10/7/06.  Dark brown with a 5 minute light brown head.  Dots of lace.  Dark dried fruits with baked apple and molasses.  Perhaps a bit thin but still glides nicely over the palate.  Vinous then black coffee.  Pleasant bitter, sour, dry finish with licorice left.  Not a big porter but hits all the right notes.

12oz bottle (thanks to GrbDg) poured almost black with a small brown head. Aromas of sweet chocolate and roast with some hop presants. The taste was smooth with a small amount of bitterness and a big chocolate taste. Overall a well balanced porter.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2007 pours black with an off white one finger head and a light to medium body. head does not last to long though but has some nice lacig. small roasty aroma and the flavor is a chocolate coffee, also a small hop flavor as well. not to bad for a porter.

Pours a dark black with a tan head. Smells of dark roasted barley with backdrip of chocolate & coffee.  Strong pronounced flavor of a mixture of chocolate, coffee, caramel & possibly tea.  Love the label.  I drank it while listening to the Gordon Lightfoot song.

This beer is a treat.  Hoppy enough even for a porter to offer me a nice suprise.  Good mouthfeel that, nice and bitter sweet.  Great Lakes offers a great interpretation of the style that porter lover should try.

bottle, head is fizzy brown, body is dark brown.  Aroma is of dark chocolate and roasted coffee.  Flavor is excellent, moderately bitter with some sweetness as well, has the roasted taste that exists in the aroma.  Among the best of the offerings from Great Lakes.

Bottle, BB Mar/07.

Head is initially average sized, frothy/fizzy, brown, mostly diminishing.

Body is dark brown.

Aroma is moderately malty (chocolate/cocoa, roasted grain, nuts), lightly hoppy (herbs, grapefruit), trace yeast (dough), with a light note of cassis.

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.
Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, moderately to heavily bitter.

Medium body, watery texture, lively/fizzy carbonation, lightly alcoholic.

Very straightforward for the most part. Quite bitter in the finish; more so than most porters, and out of balance.  Rather rough.  Biggest disappointment is the mouthfeel, which is watery and overcarbonated.  Expected to like this more, but not particularly impressed.

Had this numerous times over the last few years.  Had a draft a week ago and now a now a bottle.  Pours brown/black, with a tan head.  The 12 oz bottle fills the pint glass to the brim with head.  Rich malt aroma, with chocolate the predominate scent.  Fairly light body, with a good balance of hops.
user_location: Peoples Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text: Chocolatey, strong coffee taste, roasty, dark reddish-brown color and a small disappearing head.  Medium body with a good finish.  Its a good beer, just not what I like in a porter.

12 oz. bottle, thanks to OhioDad for this yummy.  Pours an almost opaque dark brown with garnet highlights and a moderate beige head.  Roasty, chocolate and coffee aroma with hints of skim milk and fresh herbs.  Flavor is sweet and roasty,  more chocolate and a bit of molasses, along with herbal nectar.  Medium body and gently prickly carbonation.  Quite nice!

Bottle:Dark brown with no head.  Roasted smoky aroma with a mild charcoal taste which seems to have a somehwhat thin, chalky feel.  The prolonged aftertaste is pretty good.  I noticed hints of celery.  I would probably rate this higher, but I just had Avery Mephistopheles Stout.  Anyway, overall, this is a great brew.  Thanks BuckeyeBoy!
12oz Bottle Pours out dark brown topped with a tan head. With aroma of coffee and some chocolate. Pretty good.

Great Lakes Edmund Fitzgerald Porter
12 oz bottle
Best by 01/07, sank 10/06
Medium pour in a pint glass.

Poured dark brown with mahogony highlights, with a small creamy somewhat lasting head with small lacing.

Smelt of moderate burnt grain, nuttiness, dark chocolate, with some light coffee.

Taste was upfront moderate coffee and dark chocolate bittersweetness, with some light nuttiness, followed by a strong burnt bitterness and nuttiness, more like nut skins, with some light sweet molasses and light bitter grassy hops accent on a mostly hoppy  long grassy/green veggie finish.  Mouthfeel was light to medium bodied, oily, lively carbonated, with heavy astringency.

Overall, kind of an average porter, with an interesting complexity and boldness, but does little to please the palate.  Nicely light bodied as well, so I could drink in the summer too.
Good. Poured black with a tiny ring of a head. Aroma is sweet chocolate, coffee, and a bit of hops. Flavor is tingly with some bitterness from both the roast and the hops.

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2006 12 oz bottle via OhioDad(thanks!). Pours a pitch black with an average size tan head. Nose is of Mocha, vanilla, toffee. Flavor is the same with a mild bit of roastiness and some plums. Hops are there a bit in the finish.Thin to medium body. Silky mouthfeel. Very drinkable. Wish i had a six pack.
I really liked this porter.  The flavor was amazing and it had a nice strong aroma.
12oz bottle.  Black as pitch.  Spotty tan head.  Cocoa and toffee nose.  Ful and rich with a caramel sugary plummy flavor.  Very well done.
Small head, very dark brown body. Light fishy, vegetal aroma, sour. Taste is huge roasted malts, soy. Light spiciness adds to balance. Some ethanol. Great finishing bitterness.

Bottle:  Deep, dark brown pour with three fingers of tan and foamy head.  Taste is true to a porter with coffee, roasted malt, chocolates, bittersweetness, and hop tones.  Nice rich feel, not at all watery like some of the other ratings.  Very nice porter!

Nice looking, quite dark with no head. Not much going on in the aroma, some toasted malts and thats about it. I though this felt  abit thin for a porter, but it wasnt too bad. The same toasted malts came through in the taste, plus some chocolate flavours. There is a bit of a hop presence, but its barely perceptable. Overall this is pretty good, but overall its not really that great.

Bottle. Pours a very dark, almost opaque ink body. Small, quick tan head that leaves a thin ring and slight lacing. Great aroma of dark chocolate, with some vanilla, coffee and hop scents.
Smooth roasty flavor with a good bitter  finish. Full of chocolate and malt. A bit on the med./thinner side. Cant really say anything bad about this beer. Another solid offering from Great Lakes.

Very big roasty aroma wit some hints of chocolate in here as well.  Nice aroma overall.  A nice motuhfeel, but as others have said it may be a little too thin in the finish.  Wonderful taste going on this beer.  Some bittersweet chocolate taste as the cmmercial description says, followed by some very subtle black coffee bitterness.  Not much is present on the hops front, but still a very good beer.  Overall pretty good, and another quality beer from Geat Lakes...at least ohio has good beer!

What a great porter this is.  Super dark, small head. Smells like coffee and chocolate, just as one would expect from a high quality Porter.  The only downside to this beer is the watery mouthfeel.   Id like to see a little more thickness.  Flavors are complex and mesh together perfectly.  A world class porter.  One of the best I have had yet.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2007 Pours dark chocolate in the glass, with a medium, frothy tan head; some big-bubble formation and pleasant lacing.  A good deal of milk chocolate in the nose; some hints of smoke.  Medium mouthfeel, lacking a bit of concentration; almost watery.  Dominant notes are dark chocolate and coffee, finishing with a smoky robustness.  Hardly the most concentrated porter, but still pretty tasty.
