Pours almost black, ruby red around the edges. Cream colored head left some lacing.  Aroma was kind of creamy, also some roasted nuts and just a hint of coffee.  Some hops in the nose as well.  Roasty, chocolatey flavor and an awesome use of hops!  Well balanced beer.

Sampled at Great Lakes in Cleveland.  I Loooves this beer.  Dark brown with a swirling off white head.  Roasted aroma.  3 distinct hops.  This was a winner even amonst the non-craft beer crowd.  A mst have and Ive packed some for the trip home.

This is the best product that Ive tried from Great Lakes to date. Dark opaque brown pur.  Quickly disipating light tan head. Nice lacing. Full smooth mouthfeel. Roast hops aroma. Flavor is burnt cooking chocolate strong hops.  Aftertaste is semi-bitter that sweetens as it lingers.  Very nice.  Im heading to the store to buy more now.  This is great stuff!
Chocolately, nutty, some vanilla and spice. Super smooth, and very enjoyable. Light smoked malt aftertaste. Really good.
Deep cherry colour.  Medium long-lasting off-white head.  Roasted bittersweet cherry aroma.  Coffee flavour with malt aftertones.

Big thanks to the RBer who sent this to me.  Dark black body with a thin tan head that quickly diminishes.  Nice aroma, caramel and chocolate malts with a nice hop background.  Bitter chocolate taste, smooth body.  Very nice ending, highly enjoyable.
Clear dark mohogany body with a thin off-white head. Sweet roasted malt and chocolate aroma. Sweet chocolate flavor, some roasted malt hints, and a touch of caramel.

Pours a dark brown color with a frothy tan cappucion-esque head that fades quickly.  Nice amount of draped lacing line the glass.  Smells of coffee, milk chocolate, and rich malty goodness.  Taste is roasted coffee, chocolate with a good dollup of hops to bring some spiciness to the table.  This is a very rich and delicious porter.

Bottle from trade with kmweaver. Thanks Ken!  Pours a nice dark brown with a medium tan head. Has a nice medium body beer with an aroma of cocoa and roasted coffee. Has a nice hoppy taste that leaves a pleasently bitter overtone.  This is a very nice porter!
I like this porter a lot. Pours dark brown and the head is a tan color. Tasted a bit of chocolate and coffee and I think I tasted a bit of nut too. Smells much the same. Great beer.

Hands down my favorite porter. Enjoyed at Great Taste of the Midwest beer festival in Madison, WI. Very dark brown or even black in appearance, tan head. Roasted aroma with chocolate thrown in. Flavor is more mocha notes. Very smooth mouthfeel, this cat is drinkable.

Thanks OhioDad.  Dark brown beer, thick light brown head.  Aroma is sweet and chocolatey with herbal chicory notes as well.  Some rye toast, a bit of smoke and even some light leathery notes.  Very rich malty aroma.  Flavour is cocoaish, dry huskiness to the malts.   Rich leathery/smoked malts.  Some toast and light herbal flavour as well.  Full-bodied, lingering hoppy dryness and bitterness.  Charry finish.  Is there anything this brewery makes that isnt world-class?

Pours dark brown/black from the bottle, with a foamy tan head. Aroma is strong coffee and roasted malts, as well as some hops that manage to shine through the roast. Flavor is like dark chocolate and coffee with hoppy notes coming in toward the middle, to give it a slightly bitter finish.

Bottle. Nearly opaque body with a medium foamy head. Nose-raisin bread, cold molasses. Taste-fig, light unsweet coco, light acid. This is an outstanding beer, not because it has assembled within it amazing flavors, although it does, but because it is done so well. This exemplifies what a porter should taste ice, with the light coffee, dust, straw, and roast coming together perfectly, not flavor over compensating for the other. Perfectly made with quality ingredients. You cant beat that.

Expected more from this beer.  Dark brown appearance with a thin tan head.  Rather timid chocolate aroma with a flavor to match.  Not a very complex porter... almost no coffee or roasted malt.  Bitter finish was not very appealing.
I love this beer.  This is the benchmark that I compare all other porters to.  Strong aroma with a chocolate and coffee taste that does not disappoint.

06 State College Brew Expo.  Pours a dark brown with a creamy and bubbly light tan head that sustained and left some lacing.  Aroma of cocoa, toasted malt, coffee and chocolate.  Flavors of the same with maybe some lactose?  Slight hop presense in both aroma and flavor.
Bottle, poured dark with a nice light brown head.  Roasted smell and very hoppy.  Coffee and chocolate taste with a nice, full body.

A very nice porter, that tastes like a stout in disguise. The pour is black with a nice tan head. The aroma is full of coffee and some chocolatey notes as well. The taste starts out with just a hint of coffee and some roasted malt, but moves on to the citrusy hop flavors rather quickly. A nice porter with a good transition in flavors while in your mouth."

Bottle.  Pours as perfect as a porter should.  Dark and a great head.  Very smooth coffee and cream nose with a nice dry bitterness to balance it off.  Very roasty, but smooth, in the mouth.  Somewhat unique in that respect.  Roasted malts and hops play very well with a slight grassy hops.  I let this one sit and breathe for a bit, and really didnt lose anything.  In fact, it became a bit creamier, but without losing too much of the hoppiness.  A very well made porter.
Nose of roasty, smoky malts, and coffee; pours opaque ebony with a few tan bubbles; flavor shows more coffee,with some caramel and light smoky note; body a little thin, but decent porter.

UPDATED: JUL 1, 2006 My favorite Porter! An outstanding brew with equal parts smokey choc, coffee and caramel. Pours dark with a decent tan head. I could drink this all the time (and do). Hop presence does NOT disturb maltiness or finish. THE best Great Lakes Brew, by far!

Poured to a dark, opaque brown with thick tan head and great lacing. malty aroma of nuts, chocolate and toffee. The taste was more of the chocolate and toffee. Body was a tad on the thin side, but finish very smooth. Although I had this on a warm summers eve, it was a most enjoyable beer.

Bottle courtesy of Sammy: Poured a deep black color porter with a medium off-white foamy head with minimal retention. Aroma of light coffee and roasted malt is less dominating then expected. Taste is also dominated by light coffee with some medium bitterness form the roasted malt. Body is about average with some creamy aspect. Not sure why this is rate so high, I can think of quite a few porter that are at least equal or better then this.

Gift from Aurelius on his travels. Dark ruby red fading to black. Aroma of strong black coffee. Flavor is rich and earthy with some black potting soil notes. Some bakers chocolate, hint of licorice with a good roasted back end overriding it all.  Solid, thickish mouthfeel. Enjoyed while at the beach - Cape San Blas, Fl.
Had on draft during a trip to Cincinnati. Excellent beer with a great smooth flavor and lots of taste. Will be looking for more.
UPDATED: SEP 19, 2006 Classic after food sipper. Strong coffee/chocolate notes yet dry and hoppy. Best flavor Ive found in a porter but a little too sweet for some occasions.

via trade with OhioDad - Pours a brown color with a light tan head.  Aroma is coffee and chocolate.  Flavor is more of a roasted chocolate.  No noticeable hop flavor.  A smooth medium body beer.  Very nice.  Thanks Scott.

12 oz. bottle from Dilly Deli.  Drank on 6/7/06.  Very dark, almost black.  Clear though and some nice red when held to the light.  Nice thick 1" deep tan head.  Good layer of foam and decent lacing.  Aroma - nice and strong - coffee / espresso and chocolate.  Wow- serious coffee and chocolate.  Little smokey and roasty.  Flavor - high level of bitterness.    Some nice roasty, smokey, coffee, espresso flavors.  Palate is smooth and medium.  Sparkly carb. provides a slightly dry finish.  Pretty good porter - I like the coffee flavor.  Little bit high on the bitterness which takes away from the flavor a little.

A great example of a Porter. Another great beer form Great Lakes. This is one of the best Drinkable" porters that I have tried. Infsct when Im in Cleveland they are almost allways to Drinkable for me to make my meetings.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2006 draft at the brewery.  Aroma:  toasted bread, vanilla, cocoa.  Very intense aroma.  Appearance:  Black with dark ruby highlights.  creamy, dark tan head that lingered for awhile.  Flavor: A surging wave of intense malt flavor is joined by another wave of hop bitterness.  These two forces roll over my tongue like the waves that sunk its namesake.  Cocoa, coffee, vanilla, and deep roasted malts are the most prevalent flavors.  Palate:  Chewy, creamy, and just the right amount of carbonation to pull it all together.  Overall:  Another beer that Ive had hundreds of times and still look forward to.  IMHO, one of the finest porters in the world.
I really liked this beer. Its tasty and easy to drink. Very well rounded and balanced. Distinct chocolate and coffee flavors with malty hoppiness. Will purchase again.

Dark brown appearance /  espresso head with some lacing.  Definately a smooth porter - didnt give me that winey, acidic taste that some porters do.  Very creamy but not too thick.  A very nice finish and aftertaste.  Rates up there with Yuengling Porter.

The appearance of this brew is exactly what I want to see in a beer.  It pours with a wonderful deep brown color toped with a frothy thick tan head. Flavor starts with a sensation that of sinking your teeth into the sharpest cholate covered coffee been. The sensation then tranforms into the most heavenly roasted toffee blend and finishes with a fabulously strong hoppy kick. Hands down, this is my favorite year round brew from GLBC. Ill admit to being the first and only to play beer pong with this beer. Dont tell me thats rude to the beer because just drinking shit beer like Coors is rude. Im a frat boy what do you expect.

Pours a dark brown color with a thick brown head.  Aroma is of chocolate, coffee, hops, roasted malts, and toffee.  Flavor is strong of the coffee and chocolate at first but gives way to the slightly hoppy finish.  Probably one of my favorite porters.  GLBC is becoming one of my favorite brewers.

Pour looks like Coca Cola.  Medium sized head.  Smells just like a porter should, roasty malts, caramel, toffee, and coffee notes.  A very above average porter.  This is a good well made porter, which stands toe to toe with the best in its style.

Thanks to doulos for this one. Enjoyable, but not all that memorable. A nice porter, greatest quality was its drinkability.... the smooth and relatively light mouthfeel (vs. many a stout or thick porter). Poured a mahoganey brown with a respectable initial head that sustained itself well and laced decently. The aroma was of coffee and some chocolate. The flavor was a nice balance of coffee, chocolate, light smokey-roastedness, some hops, and a somewhat overall sweetness. Nice job by GL, but if you cant get it in your area, no biggee. Re-rate on a fresher bottle: Mouthfeel was dead on, not as acidic and thin as my first tasting (nice and creamy, but not motor oil). Flavor was much richer in the coffee category and very nicely balanced with hops in the finish. Contrary to my first experience, Id recommend getting if you can, more memorable on second tasting (fresher bottle).

Excellently large and perfectly brown head sits atop a dark ruby pool of chestnut wonderousness.

Smells like a fantabulous porter. Dark, roasted malts, all bitter and tasty, against sweeter, more chocolately and rough malts, along with a distinct, almost floral hop.

Tastes very much like it smells. Starts with the rawness of a porter, big bitter roasted malt. Moves then into really smooth mocha coffee middle, ending on a dry, flowery hop.

This tastes so fanastic I cant believe that its only 5.8% ABV! What a great session porter.

Pours a deep, dark, clear brown with a small tan head.  Smells of tasted hops, coffee, and a slight malty sweetness.  Lots of choclate a toasted malts up front with a nice hop flavor balancing the finish.  Nice full body with a dry finish.

Pitch black liquid with a thick tan head. Little retention and no lacing. Sweet chocolate malt and good porter smell. Chocolate porter taste that leaves a dry taste on the palate. Nice big malt chewy feel. A great porter.

Pour is dark dark brown with a nice big tan head...smell is smell is yeasty and roasty with lots of coffee...taste is roasty throughout with some hop presence, but I would not call it bold by any means...sweet cocoa and coffee unti lthe slighttest of bitter finishes...good stuff...

beer pours a deep, ruby-tinted brown with a big-bubbled, light tan head that retains ok and leaves nice lacing.  fairly chocolate-dominated nose is nicely overlayed with some floral/citric hoppiness, with some deeper roast/coffee notes peaking around the side.  nice balanced flavor starts with fairly lush notes of bitter chocolate that are nicely dried out by a not-insubstantial whack of hop bitterness and flavor.  very nice and well-balanced beer is a great example of the style, with great roasty/chocolate maltiness nicely complimented by a solid hop presence, both in flavor and bitterness.

From a 12 oz. long neck brown bottle with a blurb about the porter and best before date on the right side of label.

Made a good appearance, poured a opaque ruby hued dark chocolate brown with a foamy tan head that settled into a thin lacing, moderate carbonation.

Had a chocolate, cocoa powdery and caramelized malty nose.

A crisp, slick and creamy smooth medium bodied mouth feel, very good drinkability.

Big chocolate and caramelized malty taste, a little roasted coffee malt as well, a mild citric hoppiness in the middle, a sweet buttery flavor towards the end and dryish chocolate malty finish.

An excellent porter from Great Lakes, one of my favorite brewers, a must try.

Deep, clear ruby.  Bottles have a cool label.  Creamy sweet stout aroma, chocolate and roast.  Sweetish, superbly balanced, roasty.  Caramels.  Fadeaway roastiness.  Deserving of its high ratings.  Finishes a bit caramel at times.  Everything youre looking for in a porter, though it may be slightly sweet for the traditional pigeonhole.

In a bottle. Pours a dark brown/black color with a tan head with edges of brown. Great coffee, roasted grain aroma. Lots of chocolate flavor along with some coffee notes. Great full body and mouth feel. Excellent porter.
Lots of chocolate.  Just a delicious porter.  Might be my favorite porter yet.  Superb balance.  A winner!

Thanks to Ohio Dad for this one.  Ive been wanting to try this one for a long time, and since I started rating it, I cant get Gordon Lightfoot out of my mind, and Lake Gitchegoomy.  The pour is dark black/brown edged, showing ruby through direct light, and a 2-finger tan head.  The aroma is dark malty, with a big corn flake component, some dark chocolate, coffee, and even Copenhagen smokeless tobacco.  The flavor is roasty malty, oaty, with some chocoff, hazelnut, and tobacco hints.  Medium to dense palate, with a great creamy mouthfeel.  It gets a bit on the tart side of the sugar ledger as it warms, and maintains a great balance and complexity.

Pours out dark brown with a small head.  Smells roasted, full of chocolate, and coffee.  Taste is rich, creamy, and down right delicious.  Havent had many of this brewing co. beer, but the ones I have had are all damn good, very easy to drink, and extremely refreshing.  Possibly the easiest drinking porter I have drank.  Really great.

12 oz. bottle courtesy jerc. Dark brown / burgundy colour with a fully lasting creamy tan head. Dark chocolate fudge, roasty coffee, and sweet caramel aroma. Chocolate, roasty, lightly fruity flavours with a lightly acidic finish. Medium bodied, soft and rich mouthfeel. Good stuff.
Initial smell of chocolate and some smoked coffee malts.  Opaque brown in color with khaki colored head with sparse lacing.  Smoked hop initial flavor with an amazing burnt char finish.

Bottle: Dark, dark brown with a light brown head. Lots of roasted malts, some bitterness, chocolate. Flavor has some chocolate and a really strong roasted malt flavor, some nice hop bitterness on the finish. Ive always really liked this one, just havent gotten around to rating it untill now.

Pours very dark brown with a dark tan head.  Aroma is roasted malts with hints of dark chocolate.  Mouthfeel is smooth and medium bodied with moderate carbonation that is frothy.  The flavor is very sharp roasted, maybe burnt, malts - but the sharpness is offset by the creamy aspect of the carbonation.  The finish is roasty and quite bitter from the hops - the bitterness lingers for quite a while.  A very nice porter to look out for.

Pours a dark brown, about average for porters, with an off-white head.  Sweet malty aromas rise up from the glass, with hints of roasted malts and dried fruits.  Taste is slightly milky on top of the malty flavors expected from the nose with a little bitterness at the end.  For bold hop presence, I would reach for a Black Sun Stout.  This one is certainly not as sweet as some porters, but not exceptionally hoppy, either.

bottle. Dark brown, tan head. The aroma is sweet and roasty with chocolate, minimal soy sauce, and plenty of coffee. The flavor is completely solid ; this is a porter! It has the flavors characteristic of this style: coffee, dark chocolate, a mild, bitter hop presence which all unites in a chewy collision. There is a strong, nutty aspect which is reminiscent of almonds. This is a robust, solid brew.

pours a dark black as it should.  boastful head in size, but kinda uneven and ugly when it settles.  very chocolatey, little hops in the aroma.  a nice change from the surprising anchor porter.  still, not full enough, yielding the 8.  very quick flavor profile but a lasting finish.  kinda disappointed.  its probably one of the best porters ive had, but it just makes me want an imperial stout in terms of flavor.  still, the bitterness is nice, and i think what i just learned is that a porter might be like a session beer version of a stout.  a transition beer in the night perhaps.  but hardly something to enjoy in and of its own merits.
Bottled. Black in colour. Minor beige head. It has a burnt aroma. The flavour concists of burnt malt and some chocolate. It has a dry aftertaste.
Poured black with a ruby hue.  Nice roasted coffee malt aroma.  Malt chocolate, bitter creamy coffee, and a toasted dryness.  Leaves a chalky dryness.  A flavorful lighter porter.

12oz bottle, . . . please enjoy by July 23/06.  Pours a very dark brown with a medium tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, floral hops, roasted malt.  Taste follows the aroma with a bit of coffee added.  Chalky, dry finish.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: 12oz. bottle.  Dark red-brown with a small light tan head.  Peanuts, chalky chocolate, some herbal hop aromatics.  Salty roastiness with deep chocolate tones.  Some residual meaty roast and a metallic hop character in the finish.  Mouthfeel is medium, fairly try.

Pours a dark reddish mahogany with a a creamy tan head, mostly diminishing, with a fine long lasting lacing. The aroma is of coffee, carmel and roasted malt. Very creamy and full bodied; a rich feeling on the palate. Great long lasting finish, leaving a slightly burnt malt taste, but crisp and very mellow. Nicely carbonated. A great accompaniment to any hearty fare, including steak, burgers, brats, or stew.

Bottled. Dark amber/rubyish colour, small brown head. Aroma is chocolate, coffee and mild roast. Flavour is strong roast along with chocolate, coffee and some citrus. The citrus fruits comes at first, then turns dark chocolate and roast. Roast dominates the aftertaste. Pleasantly mixed, and very smooth to drink. Well done brew.

Bottled <r>
Very dark brown, good expresso head. Hoppy and chocolaty nose. Roasted malty, hoppy, cold coffee in the finish. Medium-bodied and heavy enogh despite of being "only" 5.8%. Balanced porter.

12 oz bottle, via OhioDad.  Pours a clear dark brown with a one finger fine bubbled beige head that left nice lacing.  Great roasted and chocolate malt nose, with some slightly drying yeast character, and a little coffee.  Well balanced tripod of flavor of roast, chocolate, and a fairly aggressive hoppy bitterness on the finish.  Medium bodied with moderate fine carbonation, a little dusty on the finish.  A very solid Porter, full of flavor and worth seeking out.

Bottle. Pours a very dark mahogany with tan head. The aroma has a lot of roasted malt, some chocolate, a little bit of espresso, and even a distant hint of smoke. The flavor is roasty but subtle with some chocolate and cold coffee floating around. The bitterness is faint, but its there, especially at the end of the finish and in the aftertaste. Most of the finish is burning wood and baking chocolate. Pretty good... my only complaint is that the palate is just barely on the watery side, but not offensively so, so I can excuse it.
if gordon lightfoot thinks the edmund fitzgerald deserves a song then giving it a beer is also a good call, one of the finest porters around
Big chocolatey aromas over a dark brown body with substantial foamy head.  Flavor is creamy with chocolate dominance.  Very nice... drinks a little better warmer rather than colder.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Very dark brown in colour with red highlights. Medium carbonation. Strong aromas of dark chocolate, cold dark roast coffee, and the slightest suggestion of earthy hops at the tail end. More chocolate and coffee in the mouth, with additional flavors of dried fruit, brown sugar, and a touch of lactic sourness. Good body and a long finish. Thanks to radiomgb for the sample.

Dark brown/red color with a big light brown head. Aroma is roasty and warm, very inviting. Flavor is simple yet enjoyable with chocolate maltiness and roasted grains comming in gently and permiating all the way to the finish. Very plesant beer.
On tap at The Map Room.  Black and relatively thick with an off-white head.  Coffee, bitter chocolate, molasses, and dark roasts lead the way to a nice bitter hop finish.  A solid porter.
(tap - Maproom, Chicago) Deep black with very little head. Roast malt and coffee aromas. Flavor was roast malt, burnt coffee, black chocolate, somewhat earthy. Enough hops for a nice balance.

Bottle.  Poured a nearly opaque dark brown with reddish hues in light.  Head was tan, soda-like, and evaporated quickly leaving a slight layer that would lace.  The scent was strong of roasted malts with a hint of coffee.  Sweet up front with a dry bitter binish that left a lingering bitterness dark-chocolate and coffee are noticeable.  Felt a bit thin in the mouth, went down like watery with a very minute carbonated tingle.  I enjoyed it but was a little disappointed with this one I was hoping for a bit more robust flavor.
Nice porter from Great Lakes.  Roasted malt takes over a bit of burnt coffee taste.  Enough hop presence to balance the malty goodness.  Not overly sweet, just a smooth example of a porter.

12 oz bottle.  Light black body with a small, quickly dissipating brown/white head.  Aroma of bittersweet chocolate with some roasted malts and a bit of spice.  Flavor is a very nice blend of chocolate, roasted malts and a touch of sweetness.  Palate seems a bit thin.
On tap.  perfect opaque pitch appearance with a thick tan head.  Roast malt and charcoal on the nose coffee and some earth introduced in the flavor. Very, very good on tap.

Its funny. I bought a six pack of this a long time ago and have been drinking one every now and then. I am down to my last one and I thought, for sure, that I had already rated it, but it appears I have not. 12oz bottle, bb Jan 29, 2005. Served in an english pint at 57.5°. The color is dark red, bordering on black, with some crimson tint around the edges and a small, khaki head. Aroma is roasty and a little sour. The initial taste roasty and mocha-like with milk chocolate sweetning the bitter malts. The midtaste is roasty with some earthy, woodsy hops dancing in the background. The finsh is mildly bitter and the roasty flavor lingers. The mouthfeel is full, but average for a porter. There seems to be an overly earthy flavor in the beer, not sure if it is due to the choice of hops or the age, but it takes away slightly from an otherwise nice beer. Will try again fresh.

(Bottle (best by 6/30/06) via trade with <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?UserID=2 target=blank>OhioDad, thanks Scott!) This one pours a rich dark brown with a smallish khaki head. Aroma is fairly mild - coffee, some rich maltiness, also some plum. A bit of fine lacing. Mouthfeel very smooth, maybe a touch watery. Taste is rich roasted coffee blended with malt. A bit of chocolate comes through as it warms, also that bit of plum. Finishes with a touch of bitter. Has just the right amount of alcohol. Very good.

Pours a transparent blackish garnet red, with copious amounts of lasting tan head. Nose is sweet and malty with faint bitterness. Flavor wise this beer will fool you. Nice rich malts give it a for-front sweetness that becomes darker and more complex. Even has a subtle hop bitterness in the finish. Do yourself a favor and do whatever it takes to get a hold of this bad boy!

"Good beer. Poured brown with mahoganey edges with a good head that laced well. Aroma was of roasted coffee and chocolate. Flavor was the same with just the right amount of hops in it. Good solid beer. "

Poured a very dark reddish brown that I had to shine straight into light to even notice. Had a very choclately and coffee aroma which was very nice. The flavor was even better and it felt great in the mouth. Overal a very good beer.

Poured from a 12oz btl dark reddish brown that at first I thought was black. The head was a rolling frothy tan that changed rather quickly to a nice foamy ring. A roasty, chocolatity aroma laced with coffee and a not overpowering hops background. Taste almost identical to aroma. With medium bitterness that stays with you. A good smooth texture. Overall a good, good beer. The bottle said to drink it at 45* mine got better and better as the temperature crept up at about 55+ I thought it was at its best. 

Gave my wife a taste and told her to tell me what she tasted first her response was "yuk bitter soap". Go figure?
pours dark with not too much head. great initial coffee flavor and same crispness in finish as other great lakes beers. solid heavy overall body and flavor. not as good as anchor steam porter imo

Has a wonderful coffee aroma.  Good deep dark color with a thin brown head that disappates after a couple minutes.  Has a very pleasing coffee flavor, I liked it quite a lot.  Great body and texture, and good carbonation.  Overall, an excellent beer.
Pours rather dark, excellent aroma of coffee-ish chocolate. Head is small and tan colored. A bit thin, but not a big complaint. This is what a porter should be.

Not as great as I hoped from the label and name.  Poured a cola color, with a small brown head, some lacing.  A A roasty nose, but also some skunk which surprised me.  Not so much in the taste though.  Some malt and roasted coffee, but also a little more hops and citrus than I would have expected.  Also a little light on the palate.  Not my favorite porter, but I would certainly drink it again.

Outstanding porter acquired thru a trade.  What a great porter should be.  Big and tasty.  Large mouthfeel, oily and slick.  For as flavorful as this is, its not at all filling.  Hops and some citrus {?} in the finish.  Sweet coffee and chocolates.  Not at all bitter, perfectly balanced.

One of my very favorite brewpubs is the Great Lakes Brewing Company, of Cleveland, OH. This is one brewpub I have made return trips to ever since that first trip back in 1994. At that time, Great Lakes didnt have a brewery, all their beers were brewed at the brewpub, and they were a very local beer. GLBC has enjoyed some growth, and their market has grown from its small Northern Ohio roots to a few Midwestern states. I love all of Great Lakes products, but one beer has a special place in my beer loving heart, and that is Edmund Fitzgerald Porter. This is a delicious, rich, robust porter just packed with flavors. Some robust porters border on being stouts, they are very roasty, coffeeish, and the flavors quite intense. Edmund Fitzgerald is an outstanding example of robust porter.

This beer pours to a deep brown/black, opaque color with a big, tan, creamy head, and a soft carbonation. The nose on this beer is fantastic. Very malty aromas of dark chocolate malts, roasted barley, and coffee marry with a back drop of citric, piney, hop aromatics. The palate is wonderful. More big chocolate malt flavors, coffee, a touch of vanilla, and more roast. Edmund Fitzgerald has a very muscular malt back bone, this beer isnt hefty, but has a big body for a porter. This beer finishes with more good dark malt up front, then finishes with a long, dry, citric hop bite that lingers. A robust, flavorful, and vibrant beer. Match this with a nice porterhouse steak and baked potato. This is a great desert beer as well, it would go well with a chocolate brownie sundae with vanilla ice cream.

Obtained in a trade with beeryum. Dark ruby reddish brown with a medium tan head. Rich chocolate, mocha and hops in the nose. Wow, very bold and flavorful. Up front, the flavor has big notes of chocolate, coffee, ovaltine, roasted malt, a touch of charcoal, plenty of hops and rich caramel/toffee sweetness. Totally delicious. Perfect body for a porter; full, round and very creamy with lively carbonation (without being as thick as some stouts). Decent head retention, light lacing left on the glass. Overall, an amazing porter - one of the best Ive had so far.
12 oz bottle.  Pours black but light still gets through.  Thinner than other porters.  Slight coffee aroma, more prevalent in the taste.  Not bad at all.
Pours a dark brown/black. Small tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt, coffee and chocolate. Tastes the same. Medium bitterness in the end. A good porter.
Very good porter with good roasted coffee flavor  but surprisingly thin body.

12 oz bottle: Pours a blackish brown with a light-brown head that disappears fast with hardly any lacing. The malty aroma is roasty with hints of coffee and dark chocolate. Taste matches the aroma with a smooth bitter finish. A well balanced beer!
Pours a very dark brown with amber highlights.  Tan head with good retention.  Aromas of roasted malts with chocolate and coffee.  Flavor follows aroma very well.  Medium bodied.  Very good.
This is a delicious porter.  I went through a case of it last season.  Very brown and lots of roasty flavors.  Not so strong on the coffee or choco tastes, but it remains balanced.
Pours deep ruby brown, almost black, thin creamy tan head.  Aroma is roasts and chocolate.  Flavor is robust, roasted coffee and chocolate.  Bitterness is well balanced.  Very good.

In the bottle at Bill B.s birthday party. Brownish-black in color with a nice off-white head. Head has a great fluffy staying power.  Slightly roasted and slightly sour aroma. Lots of chocolate flavor. Smooth and balanced. A very good beer.

(trade by way of 1faststi)this porter was a deep see-through red in appearance,and had a tiny brown head.my nose picked up aromas of chocolate,coffee grounds,raosted malts,and fudge.the flavor was a nice mix of chocolate,coffee,fudge,and hops.the mouthfeel was a bit on the light side,and the palate was complex and long lasting.

Pours black with thick and creamy tan head. Aroma is coffee, chocolate and caramel. The flavor starts rich and roasted -  chocolate and caramel, ends with piney bitterness. Medium body, mouthfeel is light.

Pours a very dark brown with slight ruby edges when held up to a light, with a one finger off-white head the fades to a spotty cap that trails some nice lacing.

Smell; it has a kind of earthy and nutty smell, along with some roasted coffee beans and hints of chocolate.

Taste; really nice roasted coffee flavor to start with, followed by some chocolate malts that is balanced with just enough hop bitterness. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with a nice smooth carbonation. I was sure this wouldnt live up to the hype, but this is definitely one of the best American Porters Ive ever had.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text: Dark brown, white neat tan look. Nice roasty aroma with definitive hop character, clean mocha java around. Medium bodied, light mineral hop character, woody, roasty with strong coffee accents. Drinkable, pleasure if you are coffee drinker.

Poured with a nice, dark, creamy appearance. Nice inviting head. Thick, almost chewable beer. Pleasant, deeply intoxicating aroma. Chocolate, coffee or espresso flavors, a hint of nuttiness.  Pleasant aftertaste, with a hint of bitterness. My Favorite everyday beer.

This beer says hello with a wonderfully pleasing roasted malt aroma.  This beer produces a good thick creamy brown colored head that rests upon a dark chocolate tinted solution.  This beer rolls over the tongue thick and heavy distributing a healthy chocolate taste that smoothly fades to a coffee taste as flows down the throat.

Draught at Coles in Buffalo. Deep brown colou with a moderate tan head. Sweet, roasty aroma of chocolate and coffee. Body is thinnish, but creamy and pleasant. Flavour is really solid, with the promised chocolate and coffee notes along with a bit of smoke. This was served to me nearly ice cold, and didnt do much for me at first, but as it warmed I started to see why its so highly regarded. A very nice porter.

Bottle.  Pours to a huge, reverse cascading creamy tan head atop a clear dark cola brown body.  Excellent lacing.  The aroma is sweet buttery malts and instant coffee.  Some grassy hops.  The flavor is like a hopped coffee and iced tea.  Good flavor.  The palate is smooth and creamy.  Almost watery at times.  Goes well with this beer.  A pretty good porter.

Bottle. Pour black, head was  small ring around the glass.  Medium bodied with mild carbonation. Aroma is of sweet malt and roasted coffee, with similar taste. Creamy in the mouth. Not a bad porter, but I was expecting a little more.
Bottle.  Smoky cocoa-coffee aroma.  Dark cola brown color with only slight film of a head.  Nice dark coffee malt flavor with moderate acidity and mild carbonation.  Very nice and easy to drink.
Pours with almost no head, black. Aroma is sweet chocolate and roast coffee, a little butter. Taste is similar with quite a bit of diacetyl, though still creamy and nice. A pretty average porter.

Pour is a dark black with a small tan head.  Aroma is outstanding!  Lots of coffee and dark chocolates.  Flavor is more of the same coffee and chocolate plus a hint of roasted nuts. Very tasty and rich.

Great chocolate taste with a nice aftertaste that lingers for a few minutes.  Not too strong to keep you away, but not so weak it leaves you wanting.  Impressed that such an accessible, easy to find beer could be so good.

Roasty, grainy chocolate-cocoa aroma is very sweet but enticing.  Clear mahogany brown coloured body is topped by a decent, tan, fine bubbled head that lasts very well.  Sweetness and roastiness are harmonious in their balance leading up to the charred, ashy aftertaste.  Medium body with lively though gentle effervescence.  Sampled at GABF 2005.

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2005 Bottle out of Great Lakes Sampler.  Poured a stunning dark brown with amber accents.  Head is a chestnut color and quite dense.  Aroma is a potent whiff of roasted coffee and nuts.  Flavor follows suit, with nice bitter chocolate.  Faint sweet/ cherry flavor within as well. Cant think of anything wrong with this one.

Dark brown with a thick tan head.  Head looked like Capuccino.  Aroma had roasted coffee, chocolate, citrus and cherry.  Taste wonderful with chocolate, citrus and coffee with a touch of cherry.  There was a bit of chocolate brownie in the mix, but it was a roasty flavor for the most part.  Mouthfeel had a bit of port in it.  This was a very impressive Porter.
Dark brown color with a touch of red.  Aromas of chocolate, maybe some cherries, malt and some smoke. Flavor of dark chocolate malt with small amounts of coffee. /

Poured a very deep garnet with a light toffee head.  Really cool copper sheen on the top as the head dissipated.  Some lacing ensued.  Deep, roasty chocolate malts (milk first, followed by bakers chocolate) in the aroma, with bitter coffee coming through as this warmed.  Coffee became more pronounced in the flavor, giving a great bitterness around the edges and at the finish.  Chocolate also played a large part in the flavor... and there was a nice dose of citric hoppiness at the finish.  Heaven on the palate... smooth chocolate across the middle, and roasty & bitter coffee and hoppage around the edges.  Citrus twist at the finish.  Nice medium-heavy fullness to it.  Great brew!

Draught at Coles, Buffalo NY. Pours a very dark brown with ruby hues and a nice size lasting light-brown head. Looks great. Nice well balanced aroma and flavour of roasted malt, hops, espresso, nuts and chocolate. Full bodied, especially for a Porter. Really good!
pours very dark with little head. smells of chocolate. smooth taste, hops and chocolate and coffee all at the same time. easily the best beer from great lakes.
Pours dark brown almost black with a thin tan head. Has a roasted, malty and coffee aroma. Flavor is very well balance with a crisp finish with notes of malt, chocolate, coffee, and smoke.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2006 Draught.  At Coles, Buffalo NY.  Poured deep black with a good lasting light brown head (4.5).  Aroma of dark roast nutty malt, hops, a touch of coffee and raisins, appealing spiciness emerges as it warms.  Taste is burnt aromatic leaves, dray roast malt, toasted chestnuts, theres some sweetness and spices underlying this - very grassy, quite odd - not unappealing, just odd.  Decent body for a porter, extremely dry, this is a complex and difficult to pin down.  A real sipper.

Very impressive for a easily attainable, reasonably priced porter.  Pours a dark black with a foamy (off) white head.  Lacing sticks to the side of the glass.  Flavor is wonderfully choclately and creamy with a nicely sweet (and somewhat hoppy) aftertaste.  Perhaps a bit of a maple flavor.  Very thick in the mouth; one gets the flavor of hop when one licks the lips.  Just a great porter.

UPDATED: APR 13, 2008 This is a re-rate. I think they must be doing something different now as previously I gave this a 3.4. On tap at Kumas. Deep brown, red around the edges, huge roasty character with coffee and chocolate shining through. Quite hoppy and robust. Just plain awesome.

Bottle from OhioDad.  Pours black with ruby highlights and a small frothy tan head.  Sweet dark chocolate roasted caramel malt aroma with raisin and port notes.  Bitter acidic hoppy start, creamy dark chocolate and dark roasted malt flavor.  Dark and full bodied, lightly creamy, smooth palate.

On tap this nice porter hits full stride with a considerable, persistent off-white head and robust hoppy aroma. The hops in the nose subside slightly for a dry sweetness that is all porter roast malt. This parrellels the flavor of this well-balanced brew that is tad on the light side. Could gain a bit in impact and flavor if a little more alcohol and malt complexity were added. On the other hand, its refreshing when a good beer isnt overdone. A good porter that is a standard bearer for the field.

Had to break open a bottle I had been saving for Nov. 10th to commemerate the tragic accident with  this excellent porter. Pours a dark brown with nice lacing and an off white head.  Excellent mouthfeel, with just a little bitter chocolate, but well balanced with the hops. Nicely done porter.

On tap at Firkins, Libertyville, IL. Brown-black hued with average long lasting head with good lacing.  Fresh flowery hop aroma.  Full bodied with creamy texture that starts with slightly sweet malt with flowery hop and finishes with lingering bitterness.  A very good hoppy bitter porter enjoyed on the 30th anniversary of the sinking of the Edmund Fitzgerald at Lake Superior.

Pours out a dark cola brown, very small off white head.  Nose is of chocolate, slight coffee, even slighter malt, some descent malt backbone.  Flavor is of chalk, cocoa powder takes the place of the milk  chocolate, coffee seemed to be filtered from aroma to flavor also.  But my wife surely noticed it after I kissed her after taking a swig.  Not a favorite, but drinkable.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2006 Review 11/10. The 30th anniversary of the sinking of the Edmund Fitzgerald in the icy waters of Lake Superior. I drink this one in commemoration of the 29 who passed away. A fitting commerative beer it is. A porter that bridges the lines between porter and stout. Further, its not overly sweet like many, but theres a fine hop balance. One of my favorite go to beers, and excellent on tap. Good robust flavors of dark chocolate, fudge, and french roast. Nicely done.
another winner from great lakes.  very roasty well hopped.
Too bitter for me. It didnt really make a name for itself as far as porters go.
black pour with a grey head. aroma is chocolate and marshmallow cream. nice rich chocolate taste with some citrus in there too. very creamy and enjoyable. just a nice porter.

Appears a black with a beige head. Lots of solid lacing.
Smell is oily sweet dark fruit with some sour notes coming through.
Taste is of chocolate and sweet fruit mixed with some roasty coffee.
Mouthfeel is full bodied, creamy, and oily.
Drinkability is good. Pretty darn good porter.

Pours a black color with a medium beige,tan head that fades quickly.  Aroma consists of  dark coffee beans, chocolate, and roasted malts.  Taste is nicely bitter with coffee, chocolate and roasted malts prominant.  Excellent porter.

Roasted malts and coffee for aroma. Black body with good tan head. Flavor  had some texure to it. You could taste coffee, chocolate and some bitter bite to it. Roasty on the palate. Glad I got one on a recent trip to Wisconsin.

Bottle poured black with a nice thick head and lacing that hangs on the glass in a sheet.
Rich, sweet roasty malt aroma.
Flavor is roasty malts,chocolate and coffee.
Good medium bodied porter with a rich roasty chocolate finish.
Thanks Bockyhorsey!!

Aromas of dry dark chocolate and coffee. Taste begins rather dry and subtle, with some light coffee notes. The chocolate malts make their presence towards the finish with a bit of raisin as well. Finshes dry and hoppy, especially the more it warms. A rather loght body for a typical porter. This is a solid brew in every category, but does nothing really special. Flavor seems rather subdued and muted throughout the spectrum. Needs some more oomph. Still wanting the try it on tap. Will rerate.

Brought back from Morgantown WV after visiting my daughterin WVU.  I had just seen them lose to VT with Marcus Vick.  Suprised to get almost no head from this pour.  Very good and sweet.  I really liked this Porter.

Bottle.  Dark deep brown pour.  Huge roasty malt aroma and flavors.  Chocolate more prevalent in flavor to me.  Some coffee and hops, and moderate bitterness (tho that could have been dwarfed by the robust roast flavors).  Good robust porter.

UPDATED: APR 2, 2007 12 oz. bottle. Pours a dark, nearly opaque ruby/brown. Two finger tan head that i slong lasting and leaves excellent lace.  Medium body, smooth mouthfeel  with a nice malty richness.  Roasted malt flavors that are not too sweet and complimented by a subtle hop bitterness. Ive had this many times over the years, and it remains one of my favorite porters.

Had this on tap in southern Michigan.  It was served a little too cold, but it was still a treat to savour.  Thick rich mouth feel compliment the dark taste.  It isnt too watery, some subtle hoppiness to give this more than just a smoky backbone.  Good malt depth.  The beer isnt overwhelmingly good, just good.

Ron brought a couple of these over tonight.  A fine brewer.  This was a nice reddish brown color with a light tan thin head.  Fruity, toasted aroma.  Hoppy palate with a finish of toasted malt and hops.

A nice and roasty porter with slight chocolate undertones.  Smooth and moderate on the palate.  The hops dont really show up in the middle but add some bitterness on the end.  A very drinkable, nice porter.  Clean, with a nice roasty coffee aroma.  A good beer that is not overstated at all.

Strange aroma that had a metallic edge predominating. Dark brown with a nice tan head. Flavor was really good with light coffee, a really good chocolate malt, and hops on the back of the tongue. Smooth and full texture made this a wonderful porter outside of the aroma.

Thanks to OhioDad for this wonderful Ohio brew.

Man Oh Man - what a Beer !!!  If you like the "Porters" here it is !!  Kudoos to the Great Lakes Gang ! As mentioned in many of the other rates: strong hints of chocolate and coffee. Keep us the great work guys !!

Quite hoppy, tasty as served in a bottle. One cant help thinking of the famous song by the same name while drinking. Superior its said never gives up her dead, and I certainly wouldnt give up the opportunity to drink this beer.
Dark roast here.  High in bitter hop bite.  Notes of chocolate, and coffee.  Maybe a tiny bit too carbonated.  Not a typical porter in myu opinion, this almost reminds me of a hopped up stout.

Very nice black color. Aroma of coffee and chocolate. Not a strong overbearing beer that I recommend to people who arent big on dark beers. First had it at Great Lakes while I was planning a move to Cleveland. As soon as I settled in I bought a six pack. Prefer it on tap, but out of the bottle is a close second.

Thanks to OhioDad for this beer.

Poured black with ruby highlites and a creamy light-tan head.  Pleasant aroma of coffee, chocolate-covered cherries, and a touch of hops.  Taste feels rather hop-driven... intense grassiness, weakly supported by coffee grounds and a tiny bit of bittersweet chocolate.  Body is average, but somewhat thin for a porter.  Not really understanding this one... too much grassy hops for my taste, not enough malty sweetness.

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2005 From Bottle:

From the first sip I was in heaven. Taste like dark roasted coffee and chocolate. So smooth, so easy to drink. I was sad when I looked at my empty bottle.
Complex porter, good finish.  Not much to say except YUM!!!  Would recommend.  Ive yet to have something from this brewer that I dislike.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2006 This is a great beer. It tastes and smells more like a stout though.Aromas of coffee and a hint of burnt toast, very roasty. It has a nice thin tan head that stay. Has a slight bitter taste and a dry finish, much like toast, very good! Definitely would recommend this to others. THAT MEANS YOU!

Draft @ Tap Room. Pours a black color with a small tan head. Nose is malt, earthy, slight coffee, and hoppy. Taste is also very hoppy for a porter. Roast and coffee fallinline behind the hopps but the hopps presence just amazes me. Finishes with some hoppy bitterness and leaves your mouth coated.

Poured a near-black with a nice tan head, which faded soon with minimal lace.  Aromas of malt, grain, herbs, anise, carrots, yeast, and earth.  Tastes of roasted malt, not cloyingly sweet, with chocolate, coffee, smoke, and chicory with a big hit of hoppy bitterness.  Less sweet and not as thin and flat as most porters.
Complex flavors of mocha, coffee, rich roasted maltiness, hopped-up bitterness, everything as a porter should be and maybe a touch more.

Clear brown pour, with a tall creamy head of tan. Light raspberry and dusty malt aroma, backed with a hint of oat. A little weak. Flavor is bright and bold, very malty and pretty rich and round for a porter. Good light notes of chocolate and coffee. Sweet, yet still watery with a clear clean finish. Hops add a nice third dimension with oaky efforts on the palate. Delectable.

OhioDad, thanks. This poured a dark brown with red everywhere.Rich, creamy off white head. Nose was an intense fresh ground coffe with dark chocolate malted into it.The initial taste was cold coffee, excellent. As I let this warm, more of a dry bitter end came out. And man, was this really bitter the more it warmed. I liked this, I like it alot!

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2006 What an excellent beer.  Great mix of complex tastes, of hops, malt, roast, sweet, and bitterness.  The color is gorgeously dark, and has a nice head.  Porter is the style of beer I drink least, but this one is the best.
GTM. Wonderful, milk chocolate, lactose aroma. Dark, almost brownish black. Tan head. Lots of flavor. Lively carbonation on the tongue. Rich, roasted malt. Really nice and flavorful. Very good.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2007 Feb 11th 2007 re-rate bottle courtesy of OhioDad.

Aroma is sweet malt, chocolate, mild coffee, cocoa, mocha latee and roasted components. It smells good but it seems held back. Just doesnt open up all the way. The body is dark brown to black with a slowly diminishing thumb thick tan head.

Fore is smooth and creamy with ample chocolate notes, but more coffee and roast than I recall from past samples. Gets slightly watery though the middle, but ends quite robust and roasty with coffee acidity and bitterness and a hint of Anchor Porter-like molasses and brown sugar. Definitely a better beer than I remember. Perhaps Id had old bottles before, but this beer is better than my memories of it.

Original Rating 3.5:

Strong malty aroma with a touch of mocha. Deep black with a thin bubbly head. Sweet and approachable flavor palate, but I hate to say it I am not as impressed as I thought Id be. There is a wateryness to the flavor in the finish that is impossible not to notice. A very decent porter, but I think it is highly overrated. Just doesnt have enough ass to it. Needs a lot more roastiness and less chocolate creaminess.
Beautiful ... dark and deep with a towering tan top.  Nice big mocha aroma.  Well rounded chocolate flavors, lightly bittered, with a tinge of a nice coffee.  Damn, this is a great beer.

Pours a nice deep black with just a glimmer of ruby when held up to the light. Nice layer of silky fine tan head that lasts and lasts, and adds a nice smoothness to your lips on each sip. Probably the most dense and pretty head Ive seen from a bottled beer. (Barring those gimmicky widget bottles.) Lovely dark set of smells--somewhere between flourless chocolate cake and a cup of fresh coffee. Nice full mouthfeel, much more substance than the ABV would lead you to expect. Soft coffee flavors, with just enough roast to balance the sweetness level. Nice hint of burnt toast in the finish to give each sip closure. The hops barely register in the taste. Kind of a surprise at 60 IBUs. Id be tempted to call this a stout rather than a porter--and an unusually well crafted stout at that. Stylistic vagaries aside, this is amazingly fine beer, beautiful to look at, and perfectly balanced. There are lots of much bigger beers with not nearly this much character. Bravo!

Tap. Does this still count as a microbrew? It was a little to thick - I nearly couldnt finish my 20 oz glass. Chocolate, sweet, not bitter. Many, many flavors. Almost sticky, otherwise id have given the palate a 5.
Pours dark brown, with a tan head. Aromas are roasted malt, hops, and chocolate. Flavors are roasted malt, smoke, hops, and chocolate.
Absolutely decent, but I found this one a bit too upfront for me. I wouldnt kick this one out of bed for eating cookies, though.

Pours black with a medium tan head. Aroma is a fresh roast, semisweet chocolate, and cinnamon (I always get cinnamon from hops trying to poke through a strong roast malt). Flavor is a bitter roast cut by a sweet chocolate, a slight ashy smokiness with a  hoppiness on finish that comes from no where.  Medium to full body. Very hardy porter very full and assertive flavor.

Draft, at GLBC. Rats. I didnt take many notes on this because I thought Id already rated this. But anyway: A light hoppy smell, unusual to find in a dark beer. This was toward the end of my sampler tray, there was still a thin head that clung lacily to the glass. Roasts are just moderate, to keep this very smooth. Excellent beer to be trying on draft!

Pours an opaque brown with a 1/2 inch rocky tan head. Lots of thick lacing. Smells of sweet dark malt with an underlying light milky bitterness.

Alternately dry and sweet maltiness up front. Morphs into strong roasted coffee bean flavors. This is like porters greatest hits. Smoky, sweet, creamy and bitter. Coffee and chocolate and damn smooth. It has it all. Really like this creamy mouthfeel. Easy drinker and this one was well worth my trip to Cleveland all by itself.

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2007 Bottle for this review but have had draft-brewery also. Pours dark, yet not cloudy,  with a nice  somewhat dark head. It has a wonderful roasty aroma and flavor. It is malty to start, but not too much with just enough hop presence to balance the flavor, and finished slightly dry. This was their flagship brew at one time, although they now brew a line of bigger, bolder, higher % brews.

Served in a pub glass at Conor ONeils in Ann Arbor, Michigan.  Next to the murphys that my friends had ordered this was a little darker, more transparent, it had a lighter, less gray head, with excellent retention.  Very roasty, I didnt get much chocolate, but a little bit of carmely sweetness.  Good body and depth, hop profile mixed in with the bitterness of the roasted malts to make it more balanced and seamless, rather than a roasty/nutty/hoppy contrasting flavour that the description would have me guess.  I would have preferred one more contrasting and progressive, but this smooth brew was very enjoyable anyway.
A nice roast and chocolate aroma.  Chocolate color and brown head.  A nice balance of the hop and malt flavor. A very nice finish to the beer.

Nice dark black appearance. Fairly full head. Roasty dark and chocolate sweet flavor. Nice smoky nose.  Really smooth with a less bold hop appearance than advertised in the description. Real sweet flavor. I liked it.

Quite pleased with this brew-- not overwhelming, very smooth & has all the qualities which define a great porter.  Will certainly re-visit this beer in the future & also explore the rest of the Great Lakes lineup, Im impressed.
Like all Great Lakes brews, a great examle of the style. Commercial description is accurate. Fresh and chewy, though a bit heavy for my stomach. Their Eliot Ness Vienna is tops.

near black with clear ruby red hints, tight tan head.  aroma of chocolate milk, coffee crisp bars, raisin, and mild molasses.  silky smooth mouthfeel.  flavours of coffee, wood, mild smoke and tart fruit.  cocoa and riasiny finish.  excellent.

Dark red brown with a big tan head disipating into a soapy lacing. Aroma is very roasty and full of chocolate and sweet brown sugar. Lots of coffee and chocolate. Clean cereal malts. Pumpernickle. mr_kimchee suggested coffee crisp chocolate bars, I would tend to agree. Mocha. Very tasty creamy finish.

Dark brown pour, with a small tan head.  Not quite opaque, but approaching it.  Roasty coffee/malt aroma.  Flavor is surprisingly chocolaty, with a very coffee dominate finish.  Some English hops are present in the finish, but arent overpowering, even at the 60 IBUs they claim.  Fairly dry finish.  Good mouthfeel -- creamy and thick compared to most other porters Ive had.

Bottled. From trade with OhioDad, thanks.  Pours a dark brown with small tan head but not dark enough to prevent light from passing through.  Aroma is of roasted barley and coffee with some caramelized sugar and molasses present.  Flavor is of rich chocolate and roasted coffee with a surprising earthy hop flavor to complement the dark flavors.  Bitterness is smooth and adequate for the flavor profile of this beer.  Caramel sweet upfront with a moderately dry finish.  Body is pretty full for a porter with a creamy mouthfeel.  Pretty good porter.
Bottled. Black, small creamy head. Coffeeish, roasty aroma. Dry with soft mouthfeel and notes of licorice and a pleasantly bitter finish. Very elegant. Quality all the way through.

bottle. pours a deep dark brown colour with a medium sized mocha head. great aroma of coffee beans and bittersweet chocolate...but its mostly burnt coffee. full roasty body with a tingling carbonation. this is quite bitter with a lot of chocolate flavour. long bitter chocolate finish. a nice porter, too bad about that wreck though.

Thanks to Scary Aaron for bringing it with him for his east coast trip. Poured a dark brown producing a nice tan head. Strong roasted flavor with the malt with some nice chocolate in there as well. Wish I could of had more than 2.

Poured from bottle jet black with almost zero tan head.  Aroma of roasted mocha.  Flavor is mostly chocolate and coffee.  Full bodied.  Bitterness gets you on the back of the tongue in the swallow and aftertaste.  Better served a little warmer than cold.

(Bottle)  Pours a dark brown body with a lasting medium tan head.  Aroma of raosted malt, chocolate, and coffee.  Flavor of roasted malt, coffee, and chocolate chip cookies.  Semi-bitter chocolate finish.

Pours near black with a thin tan head.  Aroma of chocolate and roasted malt.  Mouthfeel is heavy with a delicious sweet aftertaste.  The additional hops provide a nice contrast to the dark flavours, other porters are missing this.    Perhaps a tad too sweet for my taste buds.  But still an excellent brew from one of my favorite breweries.

deep brown pour with scarlet highlights, chocolate aroma with hints of coffee.  flavor is thick with chocolates and a little bit of nut tastes and small amounts of coffee.  a very smooth medium to full body with a little hops in the finish.

Bottle acquired in trade with TAR (thanks!). Poured a dark reddish brown color with an averaged sized tan head. Aromas of chocolates and roasted malts. Tastes of stronger chocolate, nuts, and some bitter coffee. A nice and tasty porter.
Dark brown with a tan head. Roasted malt aroma with hints of chocolate and coffee. A heavy roasted nutty malt taste with a light bitter coffee flavor. A satisfying  medium-full  body brew.

12oz. bottle:  This beer pours an opaque brown.  There was a bit of a tan head that died off rather quickly.  Nice big whiff of chocolate to the nose.  Also some notes of roastiness and nutiness.  The taste is somewhat chocolate sweet, with a nice bitterness to it also.  Very smooth and drinkable.  Thanks, Jay!

Nice dark brown with amber highlights and a good beige head.  Lots of chocolate and nutty aromas with hints of roast.  Flavor is the same with a bit of a dry finish along with some hop bitterness.  Pretty smooth.

Black-red hue with a large, creamy, tan head that lasts forever.  Heavy dark chocolate, coffee, caramel, nutty malt.  Moderate flower and herb hops.  Aromas of red grapes, plums, and tawny port.  Heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter flavor becomes a moderatley sweet, lighlty acidic, moderately bitter finish.  Medium-full body, creamy texture, soft carbonation.  The bottom line is: excellent blend of chocolate, roast and fruit!

Bottle courtesy of csbosox: Dark brown, opaque, creamy tan head.  Aroma is bitter chocolate, roasted malts, mild coffee, and some vinous malt, fruity yeast, and some light, fruity hops.  Full-bodied, medium dry, medium to lively carbonation.  Taste is bitter chocolate, roasted malts, lightly acidic coffee, yeast, and some citrus and pine hops hiding in the background.  Finishes with notes of spicy hops and roasted malt.

12 fl oz bottle. Poured very deep brown, almost opaque, some red highlights. Creamy looking tan head, smooth and lasting. Aroma of chocolate, roasted malts and notes of coffee. In the mouth roasted malts combine with bitter hops, lasting bitter and coffeeish finish.

A complex beer and a good take on a style that is so often one dimensional.  There are vinous characteristics in the aroma and taste.  Aroma also has coffee and chocolate, as well as a roasted herbal flavor. Flavor is complex with milk, chocolate, coffee, and earth. Heavy on the palate.  Italian spices in the aftertaste.  This bottle was nearly a year past its "best by" date; it appears letting it sit for a while helped it along.

Pours black with a thick tall tan head.  Aroma is walnuts and coffee.  Flavors of coffee and chocolate abound in this excellent porter.  On the palate it is creamy and almost buttery.  It melts in your mouth.  Perfect thickness for a porter.  It is crisp with some malty bitterness and absolutely delicious. A complex brew and one of my new favorites in the style.  It is not quite Fullers but very close and much more local to me.  I cant wait to finish the 6 pack.
Pours dark black with tall tan head.  It looks like a root beer float and is just as smooth.  Chocolate favor with hints of coffee.  This is my new favorite porter

A soda fountain chocolate malt aroma with the slightest tinge of roasted coffee.  A pale brown head that lingers and a color as dark as the watery grave of its namesake.  Chocolate, coffee, and some toffee in the taste along with roasted malt bitterness.  Clean, crisp and refreshing palate.  An excellent porter.

Pours deep deep brown with a light tan head.  Aromas of roasted nuts, malt forward, a little vanilla, the infamous coffee note,  and a hint of soy sauce.  Flavors of the same as the aromas with a hint of bitterness, a light sourness,  and a light sweetness.  Very nice....Probably my new favorite porter...

Chocolate aroma, some coffee hints as well.  Flavor is big and bittersweet, although the sweetness starts to build up as time goes on.  Slight berry and melon in the end, which goes well with the heavy, dark, roasted taste that coats your mouth as you sip.  Mouthfel is thick and chewy, but nothing is dry or chalky, a good consistency all around.

Poured jet black with a large creamy light brown head. Aroma starts bitter and changes to sweet, chocolate, roast, and big coffee. Good lacing and retains a small head the entire way. Body is a little too thin. Oily mouthful. Unsweetened chocolate, coffee, and a great hop finish that leaves a sweet aftertaste. The malts become more prominant as this beer warms making it a whole lot more enjoyable.
A good porter has a stron malty aroma with a unsweetend choclate taste... i didnt catch the coffee taste as described

bottle at Crane Alley in Urbana, IL.  a great looking porter.  deep, dark chocolate brown with a wonderful tan head.  aromas and flavors of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee and some hops.  the flavor that comes through the most though was the bittersweet chocolate.  I really liked this porter, nice job Great Lakes!

Smells roasty and nutty.  Chocolate, coffee and ugli fruit.  Very good aftertaste with a medium bitterness and hops.  Good breakfast beer, if you dont have to work of course.  Strong coffee also at the end.

UPDATED: APR 15, 2005 Slight rerate after a recent tasting.  Still a solid porter, but wasnt impressed with it as much this time.  Flavors seemed more muted and the body seemed less dense.  Nevertheless, the newly tweaked review...

Medium to thin viscosity; deep mahogany-brown colored.  Smells of roasted nuts and coffee.  Tastes of bitter-sweet semi-sweet chocolate chips and crisp pine nuts.  Smooth, yet bitter; complex.  A good, solid porter.

Bottle.  I sure enjoyed this one.  Pours a dark brown with nice red-copper highlights.  Aroma is a nice French roast with chocolatey roasted notes.  The mouthfeel is very smooth, definitely noticeable.  The flavor is more light  chocolate and coffee...quite complex and deliicious!  Thanks Pat for this wonderful porter.

Cellar Temp. Burgundy in an English pint. Gushing head. Aroma of caramel malts and nuts. Very chocolaty initially developing nicely into roasted nuts supported by a light cognac underneath. Soft mouthfeel. Finishes with balanced bitterness. Avoids the common pitfalls of being too watery or too stout like. This is a great porter.
Had this bottled.  An outstanding dark porter.  Very dark brown, somewhat cloudy, thick orange-ish head that dissipated quite slowly, very malty but somewhat muddy.  Excellent.

Ein impression vas burnt into me tasten buddys by zis bier. Rich, robust it vas, mit chust ze right hoppen for ze burnt malten balancink. I svear if Helga only zay zis "taste like bier" I vill be stranklink her till zhe dies from it.Earlier Rating: 2/19/2005 Total Score: 3.9Thanks to my buddy Pat for suggesting this beer (PJK33) Very nice looking porter, aroma of roasted malt, black malt flavor balanced nicely by a substancial hop bite, nice mouthfeel for a porter, Porter lovers should not miss this one.

Pours dark black with a nice creamy light brown head that leaves a sticky lacing in my glass, roasty chocolate and coffee aromas. Roasted burnt chocolate, brown sugar and coffee flavors, good roasted bitterness in the finish. Medium body with soft and creamy mouthfeel, this is one of my all time favorite porters.
Have to enjoy coffee to like this one, as it has a very strong roasty flavor.  Love the beer, song by Gordon Lightfoot, and the factual history of the ship itself.

(bottle) A lightly sweet aroma of roasted malt. Beautiful black cherry color with a large creamy head... light brown, fading quickly (a little oily) leaving a slight lace. Rich, roasty flavor, a little sugary, a little hoppy, with a slightly acidic aftertaste. A very good porter, but not my favorite.
Pours dark brown with not much of a head. Aroma is neutral, not much going on. Taste is slight chocolate, hop kick, water.  An average porter with a little bitterness to it.

Bottle.  I had this one on draught at the Brewery in Cleveland, but never rated it so I have brentfeesh to thank for the trade!  Pours a ruby dark red with a fluffy lasting head that laces extremely well.  The head is a nice amber color which is an indication of the quality of the roast on this malt.  Great nose of roasted malt, cocoa, and burnt toast.  This one is as good as I remember on tap... Nice biting hop that doesnt overpower, but blends beautifully with the strong burnt maltiness.  I really like this beer.  Body is a little lighter than I expected for the nose and the flavor, but it certainly fits it well and it quaffs nicely.  Perfect carbonation as it is solid, but not too much for the style. Reminds me of the line in the song from the cook.. "fellas, its been good to know ya.."   Im glad to have known this one  and will have to visit Cleveland again soon to re-aquaint with the "fellas" that make this one!
Very dark mahogany with a light lasting light brown head. Rich roasted coffee aroma. Dark roasted nutty coffee flavour with a nice bitterness in the finish. Like chewing on coffee beans.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2009 Somewhere Gordon Lightfoot is smiling... (unless hes a recovering alcoholic).  A nice, full brew that breathes chocolate and farts coffee.  Thanks to fellow KISS fan pjk33 for charting a course my way for this brew. Thick and chunky on the tongue.  Nice balance of bitter chocolate and coffee, with a faint sweetness that never strays too far away.  A fitting brew for its namesake.  Just wish the story had a happier ending.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: A rich beer.  A strong roasted malt aroma.  A medium sized tan head.  Taste of coffee, chocolate, with a touch of rain fresh hops.  Finishes with just the right amount of bitterness.  Alot of flavor for a porter, borders on stout like.  A favorite.

UPDATED: NOV 1, 2009 After drinking many more beers I have returned to change my rating to a 5.  This is simply my favorite beer and I cannot rate it any other way.  This beer is unlike any other.  Aroma is very strong, and complex: initially a dark bitter vanilla, then a rich roasted malt.  Extremely bitter.  Very hoppy, very roasted.  It has been one of my favourite beers since I first tried it, definitely my favourite porter, and has my favourite aroma of any beer.  But its not for everyone: this is an extreme beer; it packs a punch and can come across as a bit coarse, unrefined, or too powerful.  However, I want to emphasize that it is precisely this coarse and unrefined quality that I love about this beer.  It tastes raw, uncontrollable, bizarre, overpowering...and yet somehow oddly comforting, wholesome, and heartwarming all at the same time.  This is one beer that tastes twice as good on tap.  In the bottle, the roasted quality overpowers the rest of the beer; on tap, much more complex and balanced,  I would recommend for everyone to try this beer...it certainly is not going to be liked by everyone, but those who like it really seem to love it.
Pours black with a beige head. Aroma is well balanced between coffe and chocolate. Taste leans more towards the chocolate with some extra sweetness, almost sugary. Finishes with a sweet aftertaste.

Body is black, thin tan head.  Aroma is Chocolate, dried fruit, and a light background of coffee.  A very refreshing Porter, Lawnmower Porter by any chance.  Light chocolate, with a smooth body, and and plesant roasted malt body.
UPDATED: APR 8, 2007 Pours pitch black with slight tan head, awesome coffee with very dark chocolate and roasted malts to it with a good amount of hops to it.

Let me start by saying that generally this is a very easy beverage to enjoy.  It was lite for a porter, I think, but another wonderful brew from GLBC!  On to the specifics of my 2004 Edmund.  Pours a lovely dark brown to mahogany with some yellow hints (almost headed to amber but more yellow) at the fringe.  Slightly sweet aroma that reminds me of molasses, roasted malt and perhaps some piney hops deep down.  The flavor was roasted malt, slightly sweet and piney right off the bat.  Moved to a smoother but bitter chocolate.  Toasty at the finish.  The only thing I wish is that this was slightly less carbonated.  Thought it took away from the body a bit.

Lovely inky black edged with glints of ruby, scant lacy head the color of my coffee-with-cream, rich but scintillating mouthfeel, flavors of bittersweet chocolate, after this beer, who needs dessert  (although it would be good with chocolate, wonder if I have some around...)?

Color is very dark brown with deep dark ruby highlights, dark as the waves that split the Fitz. Pencil width high head of tannish tight creamy foam, steady and calm, leaving port steady as she goes, no ship sinks in this stuff. Spotty stringy lace sticking some and some losing hold and sinking into the darkness from which it came. 
Aroma is crispy, roasty, slightly sweet and dark burntness of malts and a faint noteable hop. 
Taste sails along in roastyness, smooth at first, then the waves begin to pick up with sweet tinglyness, darkening up, a surge of bitterness through hops and ends into a light lingering smokey feel, woody, coffeeish finish. Moderately dry port to starboard, through and through. Feel is full and heavy, proudly bittering dry right on into the depths of finishing. Much like the ship, this beer sets sail but sadly never ports again. A bit disappointed in this porter being a fan of the great lake and the story of the Fitz. Was hoping for more weight and robustness. Still a very decent porter and wont turn it down for nothing.

12.29.04  12oz bottle thanks to bkelley68.  Finally, a beer that pours like liquid black amethyst: black on the outside appearance, but held to light glows black and purple and red.  Beautiful, and with ample tan head that lingers thoughout.  Aroma is richly choco-coffee, the usual for a good porter.  But the flavor is anything but usual.  Thinner body is sharply hopped and sharply roasty for a real nice bite from front to back.  Easy going dark choco and coffee malts across the middle lend support and balance.  Some raisin.  Solid porter, thanks Brian!

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2005 The pour is near opaque - with a mahogany tint breaking through on the outside of glass.  Thick white head grasps the interior rim of the glass and stays there as the beer is consumed.  Aroma of chocolate-covered raisens.  Nice malt balance with a slight hoppy kick to the taste buds.  Semi-sweet chocolate finish makes this Porter top notch.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2006  Tried this again on tap at Goodbar in Buffalo.  Took my aroma rating down a bit, as it was pronounced enough for an 8, but still quite nice.  I found the taste even better than in the bottle, the roast really comes out here with tons of chocolate to back it up.  It looks great, and is a very complex tasty brew.  Would be a winter staple if I could get it more often - very nice, and bumped up a bit in taste and overall from my original rating.Original 8/4/8/4/16


Bottle graciously shared by jercraigs.  Black pour, ruby red hues.  White head.  Lots of roasted notes in aroma, with a huge hit of chocolate as well.  And quite hoppy.  Flavour is very chocolaty as well, with more roasted bitterness coming through.  I thought this was pretty thick and robust for a porter, I would have thought it was a stout, but what do I know?  This is a fantastic beer we can all agree!

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2007 June 2007. Draft at the brewpub. Black body, with a decent sized tan head. Sweet mocha roast in the aroma (8+) and again in the flavour where is is moderately bitter. Coffee bean notes are cumulative, increasing as the glass goes on. Pleasant mild mocha roast lingers long into the finish and aftertaste. Creamy smooth average palate is undercarbonated, and might be more full bodied otherwise. (3 to 3+) 8+/4/8/3+/16-17 - 4.0

December 2004. Bottle. Brown/ruby tinged black body with a moderate beige head. Very nice aroma of dark chocolate and a touch of roast. Flavour is dryer than the aroma with a nice roasty bitterness. Fair bit of hop character and bitterness melding with the roast. Nice full bodied. Thanks for the bottle Gunny. 8/4/7/4/17 - 4.0

Deep garnet with a thick off white head.
Roast malt aroma with caramel.
The roasted malt flavor remind me of unbuttered toast.
Medium body with a dry finish. 
Good brew and a nice change of pace.

29 years to the day, the Fitz went down.

An excellent porter.  Coffee and chocolate.

Its boldness reminds me of the stormy seas the day she went down.

Sweet coffee and chocolate nose, some milkiness.  Hops are present but well balanced (and in the back)  Marvelous roast gives way to vanilla, crisp dark malt, cherry.  Sweet milk chocolate/coffee/hop finish.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2006 dark brown pour with a subtle porter aroma...roasted coffee and chocolate smell...great taste...hints of roasted coffee and chocolate also; nothing too special, but a good porter nonetheless
Nice dark color. It pours a nice creamy head. Very tasty with a nice chocolate coffee taste.

Pleasing, not overpowering aroma.  Nice dark color.  Creamy head to go along with the rich creamy brew to follow.  Not overboard on the coffee flavor either which can happen with these types.  Overall very good.

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2004 Tried this at the Boneyard in Cleveland.  Absolutly beautiful beer.  Big thick creamy head that lasted right to the end of the glass.  Mouthfeel was thick and creamy.  There was a very distinct flavor that I couldnt really pin down.  It was a good flavor that I very much enjoyed.  There were also the standard chocolate and coffee flavors.  A very beautiful and delicious porter.
Pours nice and dark. Nose is coffee and hops. Mouthfeel is very thick. Any thicker and I would have to chew it. No real strong flavors, just a watery malty weak coffee.

On tap:  Aroma is a little weak but is roasted coffee and light chocolate.  Dark brown, virtually black.  Outstanding tan head with great retention.  Lasts to the end.   Flavor is a watered down roasted coffee with light bitterness in the finish.  Roasted coffee aftertaste.  Chocolate that commercial description claims to have, really isnt there.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2008 [draft - The Sharp Edge - East Liberty, PA] Dark brown pour with a thin tan head. Strong coffee and chocolate aroma with roasted malts and hops throughout. Smooth taste begins with a slight hoppy bite but then goes quickly to a roasty middle and a slightly bitter coffee finish. Very good porter.

A great Porter, lots of roasted grain, coffee and chocolate flavors.  Well balanced, smooth tasting.  I recently renewed my acquantance with this brew. My memories were not exagerated.  It is still good!  I will make it a point of getting it again.

Pours a dark black with a tan head. Very fragrant aroma, coffee, citrus hops, malt, and molasses/caramel.  Flavor is full of choclate/coffee with a hard hit of hops! Very unique flavor, a decent filling of the palate. Nice porter.

12oz bottle.  this has become a benchmark porter for me. its the color of a cola, about 24*L, dark dark brown, almost black with hints of red around the edges.  the head is two fingers, dense,  tan and follows the beer with pretty lace to the bottom of the glass.  roasted malts, chocolate, and slight caramel flavor.  hops are minimal, enough to carry through, crisp, quick hop finish, with lingering chocolate aftertaste.  very nice.

Appearance: solid brown body, with a lush, flowing head of tannish foam atop, though in a hurry to settle down.
Aroma: mild at first, creamy, with hints of nuts, vanilla, caramel, with slowly the better earmarks of a good porter emerging, and were getting the roasted coffee, getting roastier and bitterer as we go, and as it unfurls we can detect things weightier, headier, more thick and viscous: molasses, syrup, motor oil.
On first sip and gulp, I was magically lifted up and removed from the mundane and the everyday. Mouth-filling, rich, powerful, flavorful, and just plain FULL!
Nothing loose or limpid here! Bitterness is just so, and soon turns to the sweet. I dont know what exactly to liken it to, but it seems to tread a middle ground: no too bitter, not to smooth, juuust right!
One caveat: the carbonation feels a bit too cola-like, and that aint good, in my book.
Finish is fine and long-lasting, settles in to occupy the mouth and endear itself to all the senses. 
However, a certain heft is lacking in overall body and character, that I would expect, nay demand, out of any true Baltic porter. Needs more Oooom-pa-pa-mow,mow!, if you follow.
Still an excellent porter, and one which Id greatly appreciate more, if it were available in my environs.
Dark Brown Coloring.  White Head.  Alot of Roasts on the Nose... Coffee and Chocolate. Malts.  Had Some Spank for a Porter.. Good Beer for the Winter.  Chew Slowly...

Classic rich porter aromas of chocolate and some dark fruit come from this dark brown beer. Smooth flavours of choclate and some coffee - had a creamy texture and a bit of a bitter edge too. Pretty good.
Medium dark brown color, medium tan head as well.  Heavily sweet malt aroma, medium sweet hops with some floral woody qualities.  Medium body, creamy texture with a light coffee creamer flavor.

Brown.

Moderately aromatic, with notes of currants, sweet malts, dark malts, chocolate, bold hops, onions and alcohol.
