The malts provide notes of prunes, coffee and chocolate while other notes of brown sugar and molasses are present. The hops are bold and very prominent but in this porter it just didnt work. Too hoppy for its style in my opinion. 

Not that good.

(12 oz bottle, obtained in trade, thanks Brian!) The nose and initial sip make you think this will be a very mild porter, but that moderately strong dark roasted flavor up front picks up steam in the rather bitter and dark roasted finish; Light, but noticeable sweetness, but somewhat dry on the palate; The beer becomes more coffee-like in both the flavor and nose as it warms to room temperature; Medium to full bodied, about average for the style, and definitely lighter on the palate than the thick, chewy porters; Moderately dark roasted nose; Deep brown color has a ruddy hue when held to the light; Tan head has solid retention and leaves a fairly dense blanket of lacing on the glass at first, but most of that lacing vanishes within a minute or two; Maybe not in the upper echelon of porters, but it's not too far behind

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2005 A nice porter with a burnt chocolate aroma, rich dark brown color, and a nice brown head.  Its not to sweet, like many a porter, and has a chocolate/coffee/burnt malt flavoring.  Great mouth-feel.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.shopcpn.com/webpage/display.cfm?ID Liquors/Armanetti Beveragemart, Chicago, IL<font size=-1>

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a dark brown color, solid lacing. A wonderful aroma of smoke, coffee, roasted, chocolate, and tobacco. Rich and smooth, medium-full body, roasted malt joy. An absolutely wonderful porter, smooth and balanced with plenty of body and roastedness.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2011 Something in me wants to like this beer but each time I come away disappointed. +++ Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a thin black color with a medium sized tan head. The aroma was lightly fruity and hoppy with a hint of chocolate. The texture was thin and a bit watery. The flavor was strong with hops and really lacking in malt. I think if I was trying this blindfolded I would have pegged it as an IPA given how much the hops dominate and the malt disappears. Certainly a drinkable beer but a huge disappointment given the hype. I cant say that I would ever seek this one out again.

Super-dark garnet, initially a HUGE head and lots of lacing; eventually the head disappears and the beer flattens out.  Big aroma, mostly of roastiness.  Flavor is quite roasty with a bit of chocolate.  Initially the mouthfeel is absolutely awesome--creamy, frothy, silky, and not even very sticky; as the beer breathes, though, this becomes just another thick, sticky porter.  Yeah, fine, its another big porter, and yeah its good.  Big whoop...  Truthfully, Im mildly sick of these overly-roasty porters/stouts.  Ill take Anchors rendition of this any day.
duvel tulip glass: a dark semi-dry and hoppy porter. dry, cremey, chocolately, bittersweet, hoppy, roasty. all with a deliciousness to be wow wee wow wee wow'd.

Almost opaque dark brown with ruby highlights. The mocha head is very nice, dense creamy and producing excellent lacing. The aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, and some nice citurs hops. The flavor continues the parade of things to like about this beer, hints of choclate chip cookie dough, along with coffee and a good dose of hops. Mediumn body, roasty finish. Damn fine porter. Thanks to JPDIPSO!

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2004 Bottle Pours a very dark redish brown.  A large frothy offwhite tan head and some spotty, coarse lacing. Aroma is of coffee, smioke, leather and a bit of licorice.  Not particularly full or rich though.  Taste is smokey  mostly, but then after a few seconds comes the bitter coffee flavor.  Ah..60 IBUs....
Feel is very soft and easy.  Good stuff 
Thanks to EddieG for the trade.

There were some things I really liked about this porter.  For one, its about as easy drinking and refreshing as any porter (and many other styles as well) Ive ever tasted.  On the other hand, while refreshing is nice, porters tend to be roastier and fuller than this one.  Good and different, but not a great in my opinion.

yeah.  mmmmmm.  yeah.  a great porter that takes a load off of you without putting the hurt on you.  the commercial description is very apt, though the coffee taste could have been a bit strong for my taste.

Deep brown in colour.  Aroma of very mild chocolate, maybe some cherries, malt and some smoke.  Flavour of dark chocolate malt with a chalky bitterness and small amounts of coffee.  Medium-large body.  Finishes with a long bitterness and slightly dry.

I just realized that I had one more beer from Slikwily I hadnt tried. Saved the best one for last. This is an awesome Porter. Smooth, chocolately, full bodied flavor that justs keeps sailing into the harbor. This Boat didnt die at sea I can tell you that:)!!!  Am definitely in acquisition mode for this Great breweries products.  Kevin, great beers all around thank you for the last trade and this terrific beer.
Pours black with ruby edges under a huge, rocky head.  Strong roasted coffee aroma.  Chocolatey flavor along with the coffee.  Full bodied and wonderful.

Dark ruby with a tan head. Raosty dark malt aroma with a hint of plum. Chocoaltey malt flavor with some light roasty notes. Hoppy bitterness in the finish with some slightly sweet fruit notes. Not bad at all. Thanks secret santa.
(bottle) One of the best porters I can remember having.   Understated notes of coffee and chocolate.  I really look forward to having this in draft form.

This is a coffee lovers dream.  It pours a dark coffee like color.  A strong coffee prescence in the nose with hints of chocolate and malt coming through.  Overall a well balanced beer with a mild carbonation and strong coffee and roasted malt flavors.  Adding to that mix of flavors are hints of chocolate and a mild hoppy finish. This is a very good porter.

damn this is good, smells like coffee, chocolate and sweet malts, looks like a dank stout, obsidian appearance covered with a nice layer of khaki foam, sweet dry chocolate flavor, coffee accents, smooth lightly carbonated mouthfeel, this just made the list of my favorite porters.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2006 a deep brown color w/ a short lasting tan head.
smelled almost sweetly of roasted malts w/ hints of coffee in the scent
had a rich creamy smooth palate w/ a hint of carbonation that was surprising since I didnt notice it in the pour.. has a slightly hoppy aftertaste
The flavor is an excellent malted hoppy taste 

Re-rated.. whomped the palate down upped the flavor dropped the overal.  Palate was much lighter than remembered.  Still a darn good porter though.

Inky black/brown, with off white head thick. Coffee, mocha, roasted flavor, sweet malt with green herbal notes (not offensive). Dry, roasted flavors, burnt toast, with a dry lingering finish. Very refreshing.

Very dark pour with slight hints of amber. A nice almost foamy head that stuck around until the last drink. The aroma was my favorite aspect of this fine porter. Almost overwhelming Chocolate/Espresso aromas with a hint of smoke.

This is an extremely strong porter, with a pleasing roasty, hoppy bitterness. The EF seemed to be heavier to me than most porters, almost stout-like, which complimented the taste very well.

I highly recommend this beer, but due to the intensity, I can hardly drink more than one. Easily my favorite porter!

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2005 Thanks to heemer77 for this one.  Pours a nice, deep black with a brown halo and a khaki head that stays massive and lends great lacing to the glass.  Aroma is very dark chocolate malts, hints of yeast, and a good strong hop nose.  Flavor is absolutely perfect, strong coffee notes, bitter chocolate, a little tangy, dry, with a grassy finish.  Palate is just slightly thin, and carbonation is nearly undetectable in the mouth.  A top notch porter.

A noble and worthy memorial to the ill-fated Edmund Fitzgerald.  Pours almost black with some red tints.  Nice foamy tan head.  Nose was semi-sweet chocolate, roasted dark coffee, and a hint of cherry.  Likewise the taste.  Smooth and creamy in the mouth.  An excellent porter.

Hey, here ya go. this is pretty good. Dark with a medium long lasting tan head. The nose is faint malty with smoke and some bitter chocoalte, The taste is nearly the same but here the bitterness of the chocoalte is mnore present. Check this one out if you can.

Bottled.  Poured a good sized long lasting medium tan head; good lacing.  Beautiful ebony color with garnet highlights.  Aroma dominated by a coffee-ish roasted malt character layered with dark chocolate, hint of vanilla, and a spicy hop nose.  Moderately sweet start-to-finish.  Some esteriness emerged mid-palate along with roasted malt and hop characters, both of which became more distinct towards the finish and nicely balanced the sweetness.  Moderately sharp astringency from the roasted malt was quite evident in the aftertaste along with a hop flavor that lingered.  Palate was medium bodied with a somewhat lively carbonation.  I thought this was a nice example of the style.  A complex roasted malt character complimented by a distinct hop flavor and aroma resulted in a rich and satisfying brew.  Thanks very much Drew!

Big brown head atop a red-black body.  Aroma is medium sweet, roasty chococoffee, light grapefruit, faint cherry.  Taste is mild sweet, roasty, coffee, grapefruit, light chocolate.  Watery medium body.  Ive been looking forward to trying this for a long time, and I wasnt disappointed.

I finally went to the Great Lakes Brewing Co. restaurant/bar.  After drinking their beers for so long, I thought I should check the place out.  I ordered an Edmund Fitzgerald.  It has a nice chocolate-coffee aroma.  It is dark and rich.  A roasty malt taste with a lot of chocolate and coffee presence, balanced out with some nice hop bitterness.  I dont think I could drink many of these in one night, but I really enjoyed this fine porter.

Bottle, best by date 6/9/04.  Semi-sweet chocolate aroma, light touches of sweetness along with notes of espresso, cream, toffee and faint, citric, spicy hop.  Rich dark brown color, clear, with a lasting, fine, creamy head and wispy lacing.  Flavor is roasty and grainy to start, becoming sweeter by midpoint and with a long, creamy, mildly fruity, coffeeish and moderately bitter, hoppy finish.  Medium body, palate is smooth and lightly creamy.  Excellently balanced and very easy to drink.  Gains some mellow complexity as it warms.  A great Porter, if perhaps a bit less robust than anticipated.  Thanks, Chris!
Deep brown-red, a thin mocha head.  Lots of roasts in nose and a bit of chocolate.  Very good flavor, bitter, roasty and mildly sweet.  Very robust and full.
UPDATED: MAY 10, 2005 Great porter. Evenly balanced and pure. One of the best porters ever. I wish it was sold in VA.

My first beer in Cleveland was a draft of this fine porter in the Hyatts hotel bar.   Roasty aroma, coffee black color and a solid medium body made it a great porter.   A few of these porters could definitely "sink" me.

I was drawn  to this beer by the name. Living on Lake Superior the Edmund Fitzgerald is a big thing up here. Im glad they brewed a beer that does it justice. Very smooth and fulfilling taste, tastes a bit fruity also.

Appearance: the closest to black from a brown color you can get with a 1/4 inch baige head that holds a fair covering layer throughout consumption

Smell: oh yea....Dark roasted chocolate covered peanuts....burnt caramel...soothing creme brulee...toffee notes are quite apparent....various diacetyl flavors seep in and out of notation...

Taste: oh boy...this is grand....top notch coffee grounds....majestic chocolate puree...milk from the finest cow...hehe....so smooth and well balanced....rich and robust to say the least....I really like the fact that is not overly bitter and far from cloyingly sweet...

Notes: Such a fine offering and great job to the brewers at GLBC ....get some if you can folks!

Deep ruby red/brown, light tan head.  Aroma is just what a porter should be.  Roasty, slight chocolate.  Flavor is very smooth.  Creamy with cocoa aftertaste.  Excellent porter, one of the best Ive had.
Coffeeness dissipated after a few days in fridge. Burnt grounds more pronounced after that. Fruity taste makes it drinkable. Dark color peaks interest.
The first porter Ive ever tried.No other porter has reached heights as this one .England,Ireland,Oregon,Colorodo eat your hearts out.This porter is tops
Dark brown with hints of ruby around the edges nice tan head lots of lacing. chocolate nad coffee with a little bitter finish. GOOD BEER
You will not find a bigger Porter fan than me, and this was a disappointing effort in my book. Just lacked, well, just about everything but appearence.  Not that it was bad, just boring.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2008 Poured with a very small, light tan head. The aroma was bittersweet with peanuts, apples and coffee. This goes down easy with walnuts and burnt applechips in the flavor. This would be a great session beer. Still continues to impress with its nice coffee finish. Solid and it reminds me of why I love porters.

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2004 Roasty chocolate coffee aroma.  Very powerful coffee nut flavor.  Dry and bitter with a distinct hoppy bite at the end.  Fuzzy tan head and dark body.  Overall, not very thick and sweet compared to other porters, but a very interesting flavor nonetheless.  Very good beer!
Very Dark, nice flavor, not too hoppy, draft has nice head choco and coffee flavors
Deep dark brown in color with a nice tan head.  Roasted and chocolate malts in the aroma with a hint of hops (perhaps fuggle).  Clean crisp flavor, very well balanced in the finish.

Dark brown with a ruby tinge.  Tan, bubbly head.  Aromas of coffee, smoke and roasted malts, accompanied by some hops.  Very roasty and full of chocolate, coffee and malt.  Dries out on the finish with hops tying it all up.  My favorite Great Lakes regular bottling.  Perfect partner for Browns games.

Dark brown w/ some garnet/ruby highlights and lasting tan head.  Coffee roasted grain aromas, more irish stout like than porter; hints of diacetyl add to complexity of aroma and chocolate as it warms along with a light herbal hop.  When it nears room temp, it displays some dark fruit character as well.  Roasty malt coffee flavor, well balanced with dark grain and hop bitterness.  Lightly chocolatey.  finish and aftertaste are bittersweet and semi dry.  Overall smooth m/f, but lightly dry before it warms; medium light body and low carbonation, but slightly prickly.  I've not had this one for a while, but it's as good as I remember it the last time.  Aromas are more complex than flavors, but still a quite good beer.  Goes well w/ veal parmesan.

Dark brown/black color with a thick creamy tan head and lots of lacing. The aroma is smoky with some sweet coffee and light dark malts. The flavor is creamy and hoppy with lots of chocolate and nice subtle roastiness. Very balanced porter with some smoke and creamy, I like this one very well! Thanks BBB!

Dark brown with mahogany edges, a creamy off white head and sheet lacing.  Wet malts of roast, smoke, chocolate and coffee. Quite hoppy indeed. Chocolate and roast malts along with some coffee notes. A touch of smoke followed by caramel. Nice and hoppy. Both floral and citrus in there. Sticky palate, medium body and a touch of alcohol in the bitter finish.

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2004 Pours into the porter glass with the look of dark-stained cherry and smells like roasted coffee and raisins. Light carbonation, probably natural, has a mouth watering head and leaves lacing as if straight from a masters loom. Drinkable beer with a full mouth feel and meaty body. Nice hops finish, with an amazing roasty aftertaste. Great beer available (at least around the great lakes) at most grocery stores for a fair price. Excellent choice for a night with some buddies and a good Dominican.

12 oz bottle-pours a deep deep ruby red hue-almost black with aggressive carbonation.  very small tan head that left in an instant.  awesome smokeyness on the aroma-along side the smoke are its partners, coffee, burnt wood, expresso and chocolate.  The flavors match the aroma very nicely.  This could be my fav porter now.  Even though this porter isn;t one of the thicker or darker types, the flavors are just amazing.  WORLD CLASS!  Big thanks to Jsquire sending this my way as an added bonus!

very nice smoky aroma of chocolate and malt.  the body is very sweet, with a definite malt dominance.  finishes a little dry, with a solid bitterness.  unfortunately the bitterness comes after the malt instead of with the malt....still very good.

Aroma of chocolate, malt, and roast.  Smells sweet.  Decent head, though brown clumping in middle.  Very dark brown to black.  Nice color.  Tastes of malt, chocolate, and toffee.  Quite sweet. Chocolate is the strongest flavor.  Quite tasty.  Dry finish, easy drink.
Overall, a tasty, decent porter. It could be dryer.

Nearly opaque and with a sizable head of mostly loose bubbles. Cookie dough in the aroma with some cocoa notes and roasted malt. Medium bodied and smooth. Great mix of flavors, coffee, roasted malt and a slight hop bitterness. Great Porter and a good session beer at that.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Complex roasted aroma. Pours black with a large tan frothy head. Coffee and chocolate flavor. Long lasting mouthful.
Very nice. Grand tan head and all the elements of roast malt, chocolate and bitterness melding in unison. Exceedingly enjoyable (thanks Rockinout!)
This is a very taste porter with lots of roastiness and tons of flavor.  Defintly would drink this alot if could get them.

Pours with a prodigious light brown head.  A very dark beer that has deep red hints to it when held up to the light.  Aroma is of roast coffee, and lightly sweet, with a strong chocolate malt presence and a bit of astringent roast character, though this is fairly muted.  The light sweetness is here in the taste as well, though the dark malt character tends to mute it out.  Roast malt notes with hints of coffee and a good chocolate presence round out the middle of this beer.  Definitely a great example of a porter, the burnt malt character is fairly muted.  Does not have as much of an acrid burnt malt finish as some, it is fairly smooth and drinkable like a good porter should be.  The medium body helps the drinkability, though it has so much flavor packed in it I would not recommend pounding this one, nor would I want too as this beer is just too enjoyable.  This one is nice and creamy.  It has a bit too much burnt malt flavor, if the burnt character was balanced more towards the chocolate side of the spectrum this porter would be perfect.

Bottle pours black with red highlights with a very large and tightly packed head and lots of lace.  The aroma is sweet and roasted.  The flavor is roasted malt, lactic notes, bitterness, a touch soapy, and chocolate.  The palate is smooth and not very carbonated.  Overall, this one is OK.

Immediate sharp roasted flavor in the nose along with some caramel alchohol. A touch vinous and a tad thin. The flavor is true to the aroma with an even more powerful roasted character, although I still find it to be a bit thin for the ingredients seemingly present. Sour grains cut through the roastiness for a flavor that is rather appealing actually. Not a bad porter.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2004 Dark brown beer with a small tan head. Very roasty aroma. Roasted, slightly smokey flavor, evidence of hops in the taste, moreso than a typical porter. This is a fine example of what porters should be.

Mahogany red out of the bottle when held up to the light with a foamy lasting pillow of a tan head.  Dusty nose of sweet roast grain.  Easy drinking medium body with bitter chocolate, roast coffee grounds and a nice green hop finish.  Great, standard stand-by porter.

Fruity burned coffe aroma.
Jet black, low creamy head.
Fruity and hopped flavors with a 
burned aftertaste.
I did not have the largest sample, but it appeared to be a tad lightbodied and I found 
the exit to be a bit weak as well.

Opaque, sticky beige head. Roasty aroma, toast, coffee, chocolate, the breakfast of champions to which we add a good touch of hops. The flawless velvety, silky medium body melts the flavours together perfectly. Dark molasses and black chocolate/coffee are balanced by more roastiness than most and a solid bitterness. Remarkably well executed, just as I awaited from past experiences with Great Lakes. An equilibrium in the porters world.

UPDATED: APR 29, 2010 Earthy chocolate and coffee plenitude over C-hop quietude...A perfect, balanced etude of sweet roastiness and pink grapefruit hops...Black licorice and resinous hops end the meditation beautifully, even throughout...What a delicate delicacy...

Hand pull - this is a beautiful beer!  Typical porter appearance with a dark brown body, but some ruby notes when the light shines through.  Beige head with minimal lacing.  Appealing roasty, chocolate nose.  Flavor was a surprise - dominated by coffee that I really didn't get in the nose.  Almost pushing the limit of coffee for my taste, but really just right there!  Excellent.

pours an almost opaque dark brown with wonderful red tints and a creamy brown head...aroma of chocolate and coffee with hints of malty sweetness.  wonderfully complex flavor starting with a sweet chocolate, giving way to robust coffee flavors, balanced by a perfect amount of bitterness, smooth medium body...what a wonderful beer.  very happy with my purchase!!!

Bottle pours black with brown highlights.   Nice foamy head adorns this brew.   Lacing seems very sticky.   Aroma of espresso and chocolate... Mmmmmm.   Initial taste is of nicely roasted malts with a hint of sweet cocoa.   Mouthfeel is medium bodied.   Finish is nice and smooth.   This is one smooth, tasty, and easy to drink Porter.   This is damn tasty.   Thanks goes out to TChrome for the trade!

Pours black with a very long lasting head.  Aroma certianly has the roasty toasty malty scent.  Taste... Mmmmmm... taste... Lots of roasted goodness and coffee to boot.  Hints of chocolate, but not so much it tips off the balance.  There is also a bitterness that lingers at the end.  'Tis truly a wonderful beer.

Beer pours dark brown with a BIG dark beige head that is initially over an inch thick and which appears to be fully retained.  Quite attractive in the glass.  Aroma is primarily roasted malt with a little earth and some cream.  Flavor is inially sweet malt, then bittersweet chocolate kick in.  The finish is bitter and pretty dry.  Quite an enjoyable drinking experience.

Dark brown with a red shine and lasting foamy light tan head.  Very nice nose with notes of coffee and light fruit.  Solid roast throughout the aroma - slightly acidic smelling.  Wow!  The body is outstanding.  Huge coffee notes at the front with a smooth chocolate middle.  The coffee kicks in and out throughout to create and maintain a bold, roasty fan-porter-tastic taste.  A nice solid, yet timid, bitterness compliments the beautifully silky smooth body.  Light licorice towards a bitter sweet end.  Gains the lead in my top porters (aside from Baltics of course)list, a thing of beauty.

Appearance: Very dark brown with a medium brown head that lingers.

Smell: mmmm roasted, toasted, and nice

Taste: roasted, smokey, and smooth... yum

Mouthfeel: nice, a bit tingly and bitter, but nice

This is a drinkable beer without a doubt. One of the better beers from the Great Lakes Brewing Company!

Bottle.  Brown hue, white head.  Aroma is very impressive--caramel, chocolate, malty and sweet.  Smells like a beer I want to drink.  Flavor is malty up front with similar taste to aroma.  However, it is a little thin tasting.  The first few sips have an unnatrually strong bitterness in the finish.  After the first few, though, the bitterness is a lot less noticeable.  Overall, very good.
From a bottle, it pours a dark brown with a rich choclatey aroma. I found the taste of this porter VERY good, with many complex undertones!
Smells like a runaway fruit train, a dark mass in my glass.  Tan head; minimal lacing.  Starts roasty; by room temperature it's sticky and chocolately.  Good.

One of the premier porters in my sometimes humble opinion.  Pours with a deep chestnut brown body and a thick, creamy tan head.  Roasted malts, toast, coffee, and a hint of chocolate share the aroma.  Rich flavor dominated by roasted, toasty malts, dry chocolate, coffee, and even a touch of caramel touching the palate.  Finishes with notable earthy hops.  Good bottles remind me in many ways of Victory Storm King.
Pours almost black with nice bubbly tan head. Light caramel aroma. Watery mouthfeel with light roasted barley taste.
Great roasted aroma.  Body is a great balance of chocolate, roasted malt, and a touch of bitterness.  Just enough body in this one.

Aroma is malt, chocolate, and toffee.  Pours dark brown, almost opaque, decent tan head.  Flavor has all the components of the aroma, with a nice roasty bitterness in the finish.  Pretty full bodied, definitely a robust porter.  Very good.

Dark, with a decent head.  The aroma of this beer was weaker than I expected from reading the previous ratings, but still there.  Very coffee-like in taste with hints of chocolate and just enough bitterness.

Pours very deep ruby-brown, with a medium rocky tan head, medium diminishing to leave bunches of lace.  Aroma is strong - roasted malts, big chocolate, and some coffee.  Flavor is very smooth chocolate, with some bitter coffee in the finish.  Medium-full bodied, slightly creamy mouthfeel.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2005 12 oz bottle.  Pours an almost opaque dark brown with ruby highlights.  It has a creamy tan head that retains well and laces the glass.

The aroma is a mellow, slightly metallic, chocolate with notes of coffee and hops.

The flavor is big on chocolate malts intially, some dark fuits, and a decent hop finish.  The mouthfeel is full and creamy.  The aftertaste is sticky and slightly metallic bitterness.

Overall, a fine porter.  Chocolately with a nice hop balance.

Opaque black color and a nice, sticky head allude to something good. And it was. Coffee-like malt tastes throughout the profile. Roasted grain tastes and a lingering bitterness. Maybe a hint of diacytel there? I'm usually sensitive to that, but it didn't matter to me this time. Like it all around.
I love porters and this is no exception.  Nice dark color.  Good head.  Bit of a coffee tast.  I can see why this beer came recomended by my friend.
Fairly thin, and a bit hoppy.  I can't say that I liked it too much.  I'll need to re-rate this one when I'm not eating.
UPDATED: FEB 22, 2005 Hadto really go digging for a faint chocolate aroma, but the mocha taste jumped out at me big time. Wonderful chewy texture,sweet as hersheys toward the end

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2006 Black cherry liquid.  Dwindling large-bubbled ashen head settles to a ring.  Burnt corn husks, roasted barley, and phenolic aroma.  Moderately estery and prunish with a trace of caramel malt beneath the tarry black malts.  Soft body.  Prickly carbonation, leaning toward creamy.  Big black malt flavors lending a fair amount of phenols, balanced with a dose of prunes, dry chocolate, and earthy English hops.  Finishes semi-dry with a continuous burnt malt, caramel, and dark fruit concotion.  The carbonation was overly prickly, making it more airy than fluffy.  Without the black malt acidity, the malt bill is in a league of its own.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: ruby hued dark body.  nice tan, even head.  well roasted, malty and dark chocolate.  lots of dark choco;ate.  sweet malt character, a very powerful chocolate presence.  hop character was subdued, or overtaken.  I'd like a bit more roastiness in a porter

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2003 Man, this stuff smells like old silage, kind of an acidic funk.  Pours with a nice tan head over a very dark brown body.  This beer really shines when it comes to mouthfeel and flavor.  It has a great silky-smooth texture that makes it a joy to sip.  The flavor is very nice, with a roasty coffee taste.  I'm afraid my aroma rating will pull down what otherwise should be a great score for a very nice beer.
Reddish brown, brown head. Familiar burnt toast aroma. Coffee flavors dominate, then give way to slightly tart hops flavor, then a rich, malty finish.
Very black like a good porter. Red in the light. Nice half inch cream head. Smells smokey, toffee, chocolate. Taste coffee and hops. A little chocolate. This is a very nice porter.

Great porter, black in color with a nice bubbly tan head, dark chocolate flavors, roasted flavors, some coffee undertones as well, smooth finish, great balance, lots of spots where you can taste the hoppiness in the beer as well
Deep dark brown, lighter brown head. Chocolaty aroma and flavor. Nice roasted malt. Full body, Somewhat dry. Very good.
I had this beer at the brewery.  This beer is very dark in color.  The taste is of chocolate and malt.  It is a great compliment to a hearty meal.

This is a great porter. It is not a sweet porter, but rather a big, somewhat dry porter. It exhibits coffee and dark chocolate aromas white a nice roasted flavor. It has a wonderful head and a dark, almost black body.

Bottled. Poured a dark brown/black with a tan, long lasting head.  The nose was of coffee and the taste was a chocolate/coffee/mocha confection that was really delicious.  This is a GREAT porter and I would definitely buy this again.
I had a few of these at my cousins wedding rehearsal. Great porter one of my favorites, just the right tones of coffee and chocolate. Wonderful porter.

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2009 This is a perfect session porter. Extremely dark, with roasted malt, chocolate, and nicely hopped. Also a nice finish. Perhaps not the best porter out there, and not even as good as it used to be, but a fine example of the style.

This beer was acquired in trade with jgb9348; an excellent trader that sends excellent brews. Holly mother of Fitzgerald this is a good porter! Light will not permeate this rich and creamy opaque beer, I think it’s like a black hole, it amazingly dense. It even poured a nice thick lush head. **  The aroma and flavor is of plums, coffee, bakers chocolate, figs, and cream, it’s oh so good! Heavily roasted malt is upfront, some noticeable hops; it’s bitter in the beginning but finishes with some sweetness, something reminds me of stovetop chocolate pudding that has been a bit overcooked, I love it!! Porters are fast becoming my new favorite beer style, thanks Jeremy!

Excellent brew.  Dark, almost black, but with some ruby around the edges.  Nice white head, an excellent contrast.  Smell was very pleasing.  The taste was great.  Chochlates, coffee, and all around goodness.  Almost worth the trip to Ohio, almost.

A great porter. Dark ruby brown color with small head. Toasted chocolate flavor with a touch of coffee. Sweet creamy chocolate feel in the mouth. Well balanced from start to finish.Finishes etremely smooth.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2003 Begins wet and very muted. Definitely some great roasted malt and coffee flavors, but they are not able to fully show through the thinness.  Not enough of it there I guess. Has a smooth mouthfeel is pretty well balanced, having a nice bitter hops finish. Good blackberry notes throughout and a medium to light body.  I have heard that this beer was made with better quality in days gone by and it shows.  Just needs more of everything, the potential is there, a wonderful balance and good complex chocolate, dark fruit, and coffee aroma rounded out with hops.  The argument that porters should not be and were not stouts does not really hold in my mind here.  This beer just dosent have enough flavor even for a porter, to put it in the very top tier.  Great balance though I will reiterate. Nice dark complexion, with a bit of brownish beige head.  Good berry smell. Alcohol not detectable.  Wish there was sediment in the bottle.
UPDATED: DEC 20, 2004 Rich brown, lasting head, good lace.  Fresh roasty aromas, coffee and bitter chocolate.  Lots of espresso flavor, a slight fruity, vinuous complexity.  Balanced finish.
A deep rich brown color with a wonderful roasted aroma.  Perfect coffee and chocolate taste, nice bittersweet aftertaste.  This is another great beer from this brewery.

They recently reformulated this beer and it lost some of it's quality. Used to be a 20/20. I remember this beer being roasty, chocolate, and damn good. The head was a deep rich brown and the aroma was satisfying. Very well done beer. Still is a very good beer but the last time I had it it was noticeably toned down.

i bought this as a joke for my father, since he was on radio watch while in the coast guard, stationed at group muskegon, mi, when the edmund fitz went down...  but wow... this porter was wonderful, sweet, rich, and bold. great porter

Dark brown hue, small head and some lacing. Medium to full-bodied. Coffee, nutty, semi-sweet chocolate, vinous aroma. Slighty fruity and roasty taste, smokey dry finish, good balance. Syrupy and soft mouthfeel. Well done brew.

I think I want to try this again under more ideal conditions.  It was the third session of an all-day beer festival.  I, too, could have been in better condition.  Still, my eyes were not shot when I judged it pulling up somewhat short of really deep dark color.  It had a rich malty finish, but seemed slightly weaker up front--I have compensated here for my weakened taste buds.  Slightly watery, but this isn't a stout. (on tap, Pennsylvania Microbrewers Fest 2003)

This brew poured a medium sized head of medium sized light brown bubbles with a semi-opaque brown body.  It has a mild malt aroma with the coffee flavor of a stout.  It was smooth yet had a bit too much coffee for a porter.  This would be better classified as a stout.
Foamy tan head.  Not quite as dry as advertised, but somewhat dry.  Roasty, coffee like flavor.  Enjoyable on tap or bottled.

Beautiful, sparkling clear crimson hue. Medium-sized, fizzy light brown head. Only a thin ring remains around the top of the beer after a few minutes. No lacing.
The aroma is of dark chocolate, coffee, chocolate covered cherries, chickory, floral hops and ash.
The flavor is malty, roasty and sweet up front with notes of maple syrup. Lightly bitter, sweet and grassy with warm alcohol on the backside. The sweet, malty flavor is not cloying or overdone.
Full-bodied with a syrupy mouthfeel and lively carbonation.
Lengthy, bitter-sweet, dry finish with earth and grass at the wee end. Excellent beer! Pulls up just short of World Class!!

Pours with a dark brown body topped by a light brown medium thick head with lots of lace.  Bitter sweet malt aroma with a roasted/smokey coffee background.  Bitter slightly sweet smokey flavor with cofee notes and a smokey finish.  Full bodied, smooth and slightly dry.
Roasty sweet aroma witha bit of floral fruitiness from hops. A moderate chocolate, toast aroma. Perfect flavor, slight dry, with a roasty finish. Great porter.

Very dark almost opaque amber color.foamy tan head,that last's a long time.Aroma was slightly malty but very heavy on the coffee,in fact the coffee is the strongest point to this brew.Its taste is light in feel but strong in coffee again with some malt to it as well as a very,very slight hint of hops you kind of have to hunt them down to detect them.I think this could be a substitute for coffee in the morning because it has the same taste and after taste as a cold cup of coffee.This is not bad but kind of leaves this brew a bit one sided IMO.Over all this is a good beer just not high on my list of got to have again and again.

Black colour with a light brown head. The beer is not completely opaque, as brown arises from the bottom. The aroma is of definate chocolate. A full-bodied beer with a malt flavour and aftertaste of coffee and bitterness! Definately worth a try as all the beers from Great Lakes!

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2005 Dark black color. Small head. Aroma is chocolate and coffee.  Aroma is chocolate and coffee. A full-bodied porter. Malts are roasty, chocolate and coffee. Slightly bitter. Nicely balanced. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.
Beautiful dark brown liquid fluid.  Nice full head.  Very nice coffee/toffee aroma.  Nice full flavor of roasted malt.  Very full mouthfeel nice texture.

Dark brown with a tinge of garnet.  lasting light tan head. Dark malt and hops aroma combine for a near celery like aroma.  Heavy grain and rich nut flavors.  The finish is remarkable with a cocoa chocolate malts wafting of the palate.  This sample may be a bit dated, but I will gladly revisit, as you can tell this is a well put together brew.
An extremely tasty porter.  Would highly recommend for those that have yet to experience the taste of this finer micro.

A beautiful site setting in the glass, this deep ruby red to almost brown elixir of life, the head gargantuan
In size, creamy in texture, the color a light chocolate brown, the residual lace a thick clinging sheet. Toasted grain lots of malt and to me a sweet black walnut aroma noticed, a fine sniffer at any rate. At the front sweet, the top slender in its feel to the palate, finish has a splendid hop spiciness, the carbonation mild, with the aftertaste droughty and lingering, a fine porter.
To me this beer is more of a stout than a porter.  Roasted aroma, with a pleasant chocolate-coffee taste, its a good beer no matter what you call it.
If it looks like a porter an dacts like a porter it must be a .....porter.  Nicely done, a little less coffee and more chocolate would yeild higher rating.
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text: UPDATED: APR 8, 2003 I usually have trouble distinguishing differences. More coffee? Or more chocolate? Anyway, this was more than just a dogfight between those 2 flavors. I tasted some nutmeg in there...perhaps that gave it some of the bitter edge. Was somewhat bready and a raw vanilla note detected
Chocolatey and coffee-like notes.  Very nice, but not my scene.  Not, well, beery enough.
Thanks to Dogbrick for this bottle. A finally a good beer. Very roasty flavor and smell. Now this is what a porter should taste like.
Luscious bittersweet chocolate flavor with a sharp, bitter, dry finish.  Rich, rroasted malt flavor.  Very nice.

Dark brown appearance with a small, tight tan head. The aroma was sweet...cookie dough...chocolate...coffee. The flavor was big and full of bittersweet tones...coffee for sure...chocolate. The finish is crisp...snappy on the tongue...leaves a bitter aftertaste...very dry.

Smooth, chocolatey nose followed by spicy/hoppy finish relative to most porters. An aggressive interpretation of the style. Malt could be maybe a bit more complex ( a lot of nice roasted chocolate flavor but little sweetness). Overall warming and enjoyable.

Dark brown/ruby hue,with a pillow of a tan,head.Good lacework.Bittersweet,roasty aroma.Mouthfeel is oily and thick.Soft carbonation. Rich toffeeish,roasty,coffee bean mouth lead to chocolate,hoppy finish.Some vanilla in there somewhere.Flavors are strong and the finish lingers with good balance,sweet/bitterness.Another good Great lakes product.

Perfection.  A truly excellent Porter.  There was only one place in Cincinnati that had this stuff on draft.  Every once in a while you would see it in bottles.  Now, my fav watering hole has it so make that 2 places.  Life is good

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2003 Bottle.  Nice dark color.  The balance of chocolate and coffee is perfect.  Right amount of hops. Taste is complex and amazing. A distributor told me they are going to stop making this.  I hope not.  I love this Beer!

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2005 Every time I drink this I am amazed that I find something new and different about this beer.  A deep dark chocolate color with a maple colored head.  Smells of godiva chocolate with Blue Mountain coffee.  The taste is an amalgation of chocolate/coffee/malt/ 
hops that hits the tongue from every direction.  The best porter you can buy. You want to move to Cleveland just so you can be closer to the brewery.
Amazing round, medium sweet flavor with great roasted coffe notes, hints of toffee and chocolate. A good dose of bitterness offsets the sweetness and makes for a dangerously drinkable brew.

Dark brown, almost black body with a quickly diminshing tan head. Some lacing.
Slightly malty aroma. A bit anemic in the aroma category for a porter. Not much roastiness can be detected either.
Roastiness was slightly more noticeable in the flavor. Sweetness and coffee are also apparent. The hops appear as a bite on the back of the tongue.
Pretty active carbonation for a porter too.
1/17/03:  bottle.  nice head when poured which diminishes to a typical, small ring of carbonation.  sweet nose.  sweet, bitter, lighter than expected taste with coffee tones.
UPDATED: JUN 2, 2006 Deep ruby red color with thick light tan head. Aroma is chocolately, creamy, with a touch of roastyness. Flavor is roasty, acidic, ashy.
This is without question my favorite Porter to date.  Rich and smooth with outstanding flavor.
UPDATED: JAN 11, 2003 not much here, dark, I guess,little head, no complexity,a true letdown, a few hops, some cheap coffee and nothing more.
Dark (oh really) with not much head. Starts slightly bitter but then come some interesting roasted flavors. I dont often reach for a porter but I found this to be one of the better ones Ive tried.
A good porter with a lot of flavors going on and a beautiful color and aroma.  Nothing groundbreaking in my opinion, though worth trying.
Good aroma and flavor.  Lots of roasted coffee and chocolate with a touch of cinnamon.  Fairly robust and a great representative of its style. A step behind Fullers London Porter, but not by much.

My ultra-religious cousin served me a bottle of this on my way through Cleveland; Jesus hasnt taken away his taste for beer, anyway!  Very good, chocolaty, balanced porter slightly tending to the sweet side; a might too carbonated.
Very sweet and chocolatey.  Almost like a lighter version of their Emmitts Stout.  No alcohol presence at all and very tasty as it warmed!
Very satisfying porater, subtle hints of coffe and good hop flavor. A strong porter.

Dark ruby in color.  Great aroma on this one.  Smokey notes, chocolate, caramel; mouthfeel is a bit thin and slightly more body and perhaps more hops would suit me better.  Overall a very enjoyable porter.

I was very impressed with this beer.  Im just starting to like porters a lot and this porter was tasty.  Very chocolatey aroma.  Slowly diminishing tan head.  Ruby undertone to mostly dark brown color.  Lightly carbonated.  Bitter coffee beans and smokiness transitions in to chocolatey maltiness and bitterness.  I have to thank Dogbrick for trading me for this one.

Black, almost completely opaque. Next to no head. Toasty, chocalately nose. Bitter front with hints of dark chocolate. Creamy mouthfeel, though a bit thin. Mild malts. Short finish with a hint of coffee. Very tasty.
loved it . . .superb balance of hops and malt, reminded me of Siera Nevada Porter.

I really like porters, but a good one is hard to find. This one fits the bill. Great medium mouthfeel, warm and roasty/chocolate aroma and flavor, some hoppiness to balance. Seems like it is almost as good from the bottle as it is on tap.
UPDATED: JAN 19, 2007 Easy drinking porter. Dark, coffee, chocolate with plenty of head. Head is good. Excellent.
This is a good porter.  The bittersweet taste is there, the head is nice and the initial bite is appetizing.
This is a very nice porter, poured a very dark brown, nice and roasty, chocolate, coffee flavor with a nice finish.

Black. Oh so black. Nice dark beige head which lasts.  Nose is really nice, with roasty dark coffee.  Flavour is very nice, with malt galore.  Hard to find the hops, but still OK balance.   Very nice beer, but I probably shouldnt have tried my new Imperial Stouts before this one.  Thanks hopsrus!
Nice caramel/chocolate nose. The palate is very roasty. Very dry. This porter is stout-like, lots of roasted barley flavors. Lots of malt, coffee, and caramel in this porter.
this is pretty good. very roasty and the hops really give it a zing. very solid porter.
Delicate creamy head, great deep coffee color with the nose to match.  Nice even roasted malt with a great creamy finish.

Black color and a lot of head. Coffee and chocolate smell. The chocolate dominates the coffee flavor, but the coffee seeps through enough to make it interesting. The flavor could stand to be a little more intense, but that might be due to the fact that it was old (drink by date in May. Oops.) Even so, this is an excellent beer, and if it was easily available to me, it would certainly become a session beer of mine.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2003 Draft:   dark with just a halo of slightly nutty/slightly hoppy aroma with the added pleasure of some mustiness...the flavor shouted, screamed, yelled..in BROWN SUGAR...its funny how it wasnt sweet yet it was still brown sugar bliss..i guess there might have been some added roasty and coffee notes..but this beer is about tasting like brown sugar..Solid mouthfeel, minimal to no bitterness..just roasted malts and brown sugar..smooth as hell! bottle: Definitely not as good as draft and much more bitter...
Aroma is alcoholic with some hops.  Malt profile is strongly roasty with some subdued chocolate.  Alcohol is evident, but finish is nice.  Good porter. Thanks Dogbrick!
Dark, more roast than chocolate notes.  Almost petrol like without being offensive.  Some coffee flavors and easy drinking.

Best before May 2001, drank November 2002.  This porter held up beautifully--big and rich and bursting with chocolate and roasted flavor with restrained dark fruit providing perfect highlights.  Not much unlike Sierra Nevada, but with less hops.  Amazing and maybe better than Fullers.
Roasted caramel aroma; dark brown color w/ a two finger tan head. Lots of complex flavor, almost like a dry stout.
Large brown head, bitter hops mixed well with roasted nuts, coffee and bunches of chocolate.  Nice.

I enjoyed this beer.  A nice dark brown color with a touch of red.  Topped off, this beer gives a nice chocolate milk colored head.  Aromatic hops, bitter chocolate, burnt toast and coffee.  Very pleasant.
Dark black color.  Strong hops and taste here.  Not as malty and roasted as some porters.  Quite bitter and dry.

Black pour that reveals a ruby heart when held up to the light.Aroma of roasted malt,coffee and dark chocolate. Has a nice hop bite at the end with the front being pure roasted goodness. Thanks hopsrus for this fine brew.

had a bottle of this at my bro Dubbies house. Traded for a bells tumpeters stout.  This was good porter, not as good as bells.  The lable makes me want to know what happened to the edmund fitzgerald.
UPDATED: JAN 11, 2004 On tap GABF '02:  Big chocolate aroma, creamy mouthfeel, brownish black in color, with a mellow but nice malt taste.

Loads of roasted malt in the nose.  Nice chocolate color with an off-white head.  The flavor is defined by caramel characteristics (I thought much more so than chocolate).  Good hop bite to counterbalance the malt ... but still leans towards the malt.  A great brew.
Dark choclate bitterness, medium bodied, not too thick.   Roasty tasting.   Good anytime.

Bittersweet and creamy; nice smooth porter. RERATE 9/02: Had this on tap a couple times in the last week, and I have to bump it up a bit; wonderful hoppiness that reminds me of Storm King, with a sort of tobacco note that works really well. Yum.

Whoa nellie! An outstandingly flavorful beer for any time of the year. Middle of the road in body, perfectly befitting style. Nice lasting head. Roasty and super-duper chocolate malt (my one major complaint is the choc malt takes so much of center stage in the aroma that you cant get alot else). Real good hop bite in the flavor helps straighten you out. Everyday beer, challanging as hell, winter or summer. Mine was a wee bit stale (freshness date in April 02, I believe) yet still quite good.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: This is a good beer - quality ingredients lead to strong and distinct wheat muffin and coffee flavors.  If I liked such fare, and if I liked porters much, this would get really high marks from me.  But the flavours, especially the bitters, get too much and I end up thinking, great beer, just not great for brownalegirl.
The chocolate seemed to much.  I enjoyed this,  but quickly went back to the burning river.

Drinking this toasty brew, I think of the brave sailors aboard the ill-fated Edmund Fitzgerald back in 1975, not knowing that theyd failed to batten down the hatches as their ship slipped lower and lower into the roiling waves of Lake Superior.  Very sad.  Saw a History Channel bit on it.  Come to think of it, all that has NOTHING to do with this beer, but its still a damn good story.  The beer is a bit bitter up front, not all that thick for a porter, and rather roasty/toasty.

Rich aroma of chocolate, coffee, and roasted malt.  Very dark red-brown; not totally opaque.  Good tan head.  Strong rich roasted flavor, and a reminiscience of iced coffee.  Very smooth.  A dry stout?

It poured a nice dark brown, almost black color. Had a descent light tan head. Aroma had elements of coffee and malt. The taste also had malt and coffee with some chocolate. A little lighter then most other porters I have had, but still a good beer.  Had on tap.
a nice porter done how they should be. dark color. with a dark tan head that stays with it. roasty and a bit of a hoppy finish. re-rate had these on tap and it was delicious nice full body and head.
An interesting porter. Quite enjoyable and easily drinkable!
One of the finest American Porters. Extremely malty with hits of toffee, chocolate, and a big hop prescence to boot.
Tap.  A dark roasted chocolate-coffee flavor but well balanced.  A little thin on the palate.

Nice, deep black color. Very dark. Good tan head that leaves good lacing on the glass. The aroma is a little mild, and you pick up citric hops over the rich malt aromas. The taste starts off rich, with a coffee-like (not as much as some others, but still there) and caramel/toffee mix of the malts. This is lightened up a bit by the ample hops. The beer is surprisingly light and drinkable despite the richness of the flavor. An easy drinking example of a porter thats basically a stout light.
suprisingly nice hop presence to this beer. quite a creamy brew.

Glad I still had some of this still sitting around in the fridge to put to formal testing procedures someday.  Im having this right after I had a Smith oatmeal stout, and they pour and look exactly the same, whoda thunk it.  That meaning, black, with a tan head that recedes to near-nothingness pretty quickly.  Got a musty aroma in the bottle (sorry, my sense of smell seems to be limited enough that my best whiffs come from when the nectar is nestled in its glass cage), and little aroma detected after that.  Upon getting it into my mouth, I found it surprisingly bland and stale.  I remember this from previous tastings, so its not an abberation with this bottle, Im afraid.  That makes downing one of these especially hard, considering were already dealing with a Porter here.  I mean, I dont even know if I detect any of the stuff that other drinkers claim to get that is supposed to give it complexity.  Just a predominantly woody flavor and woody feeling sitting in the gut.  Not the only Porter thats done this to me, BTW.  I just remember the woodiness, primarly.  You definitely get a chocolatey bite in Anchor that you dont get in this.  Okay, Ive gone on long enough, the rest isnt notable enough to comment on so Ill leave it there.
Chocolate, coffee smell. Dark brown, with a red edge, big toffee head. Roasted, bitterness of coffee, well balanced. Slight oiliness, great texture. Complex. Fantastic! Thanks Dogbrick.
Nice and chocolaty.  Bit of bitterness, but overall a nice porter, strong head and good lace.
This is a good looking beer, dark and think.  The head was no thin at best.  But the biggest suprise I had was the fruity finish.  I like this beer.

Now that Arcadia London has firmly established itself as my favorite porter, Ive been going back and checking out past raves.  This one is very good - bold with the dark malts and enough hops and toasted edges to keep it honest.  Great stuff!
Great aftertaste.  It is a dark beer that doesnt taste too dark.  An interesting blend of ingredients.  Perhaps the best beer ohio has to offer.
Dark color, tan head that never completely leaves. Roasted aroma. Perfect balance of roasted chocolate, coffee and hops. The carbonization is just right too. Finish is like dark chocolate.

A nice porter.  It has a decent amount of roasted malt and Munich malt character.  A smoothing balance of hops   but, it lacks the omph in body and overall flavor to carry the robust name.  All that said I like it.
My favorite beer.  Smooth, dark, roasty....recommend to anyone who likes this particular style of beer.
Slight maltiness soon overwhelmed by the hops. Somewhat wet cardboard. Spend your money in Britian.

dark as a mink with just a little orange along the edge. head can be excited somewhat by a vigorous swirl of the glass, but then relaxes to the point of near baldness. in a taste test with rogues mocha porter this was the less assertive in aroma, but alone it seems gorgeous and about all id ask from a porter. it has some aromatic semblances to black burley pipe tobacco, some dates, and italian roast coffee.  creamy texture spreads an even caress of  sweetness and hoppy bitterness across the palate, just what id do if i were a robust porter.  then gordon lightfoot would write a song about me too.
These flavers didnt sit right with me.  But Im sure others will like it.  Cant see myself buying any more of these.
Excellent!  A must try - beautifully dark, great taste.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2003 Greater than the sum of its parts. This is my introduction to the Great Lakes line, and I don't know if they can top this. Hints of coffee and somewhat dry, consistently good flavor throughout.

Black with hints of ruby and copper in it. Nice off white head. HUGE roasted aroma with hints of coffee and subtle traces of chocolate. Huge coffee taste with notes of chocolate, its just enough to attempt to balance the bitter roastiness, assertive in everyway. Not the greatest balance but a fun one to drink.
One great Porter!!!

A bottle of this was my introduction to Porters.  This brew has a dark brown body with an average mostly diminishing rocky head the color of brown sugar with fair lacing.  The nose is malty with hints of cookie and coffee, and slightly yeasty.  The initial flavor is light to moderatly bitter with a slightly sour middle and a complex finish that is moderate to heavily bitter with a slight acidity and a roasted coffeelike quality.  The finish duration was long.  The brew has a medium to full body with a thick dry texture and soft carbonation.  Overall a nice brew, especially for the winter months.

Clear mahogany with a thin but tight light tan head. Light carbonation. Hoppy aroma with light roasted malts and some wet cardboard. Nice thick body, light roastedness and a mild burnt caramel sweetness. Fading hop flavor, but it does leave good hop burps. Best before date - 2/20/02. Cardboard flavor is dominant, although the malt base and body of this brew show extreme potential. A fresh brew is a must, as this would be staggeringly good.
Quite possibly the best Robust Porter I have ever tasted.  North American Clone brew book suggests the same and has a great clone recipe.

Great darkish porter, good strong bitter taste, chocolate bubbles. Worth the price unlike many Great Lakes brews. I dont buy this as often as I should. Slightly heavy aftertaste does require a bit of water with drinking xperience, good at room temperature, almost a stout.
medium thickness; rich. the higher than expected hops give it a nice kick at the beginning, especially if served too cold. thins out as it warms and flavors become more subtle. fairly decent porter.
Black color, coffee and chocolate flavor, nice beer.
Black color; deep tan head with great lace; hit of alcohol in the aroma. Very thin on the palate kept this porter from working. Needs some body to carry off the alcohol.
Coffee, creamy feel, smooth and balanced.Some spiciness, acidic, clean and bright.
Not my favorite style but this is a very good example of it. There are other porters I would choose in a perfect world, but when in Cleveland this should not be ignored
This is my favorite porter, bar none.
My favorite beer! Rich foamy head complemented with chocolate & coffee while well hopped.
A lot going on in this complex, satisfying porter. Everything comes together in this big porter.
Pretty good porter.  Ive had better, but this one is solid.

A great porter by the great lakes micro.
 hints of coffee and chocolate. malty and rich without being too sweet.
A pleasant porter - sweet at the start and then dry at the finish.  Overall dry in nature, more than customary for a porter.  Seemed to rely on the dryness too much to provide character.
Another winner from Great Lakes.  Malty, chocolatey taste without being obnoxious.
Dark brown; nice red-copper highlights; french-toasty, chocolate chip cookies in the aroma; chocolate, coffee in the palate; complex.

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2003 This was a great porter and i don't usually like porters. It was very dark and yet remained smooth and tasted good. Great Lakes is by far one of the best breweries in the country.
Great Porter! Easy drinking, great chocolate notes, and great body. My favorite porter thus far.

I have been waiting to try this one for a while and got the chance to do so at a fancy dinner party.  I like my porters on the sweet side and this one fits the bill perfectly.  Nice chocolate aroma and smooth chocolate/roasted malt flavour.  Another great ale from Great Lakes.
My favorite thus far of the Great Lakes beers. Nice deep, dark, thick, tasty.
just classic porter, nothing exceptional anywhere.  good though
Damn good.  Not in the Sammy Smith or Bells range but still right up there.
A truly delicious porter.
UPDATED: NOV 20, 2005 Cornucopia of flavor! Thus far, one of the best Porters Ive ever had.
